Subscription set.

Approximately 70 years ago, a 10-year-old Polish-Jewish boy named Leopold (Leo) Gursky falls for his neighbor, Alma Mereminski. Their relationship blossoms over a decade, during which Leo pens three books for Alma, the only person he truly loves. 

The first book is overly realistic and dull, the second is pure fiction and lacks believability, while the final book, "The History of Love," is a tribute to his affection for her. Leo vows to never love anyone else but Alma. 

At 20, Alma is sent to the United States by her father, who is alarmed by the rising threats from fascist Germany. Unbeknownst to Leo, Alma is pregnant and dreams of reuniting with him in America. 

Soon after, the Germans invade Poland, forcing Leo to hide in the woods, surviving on roots, small creatures, insects, and whatever he can pilfer from farmers' cellars. 

After two years of concealment, he makes his way to America, only to be heartbroken to learn that Alma believed he had perished in the war and has married the factory manager's son. 

His devastation deepens upon discovering that she has had another child with her husband. 

He pleads with her to join him, but she declines. 

However, she reveals that they have a son named Isaac, who is now five years old. With a heavy heart, Leo departs and becomes a locksmith. 

From a distance, Leo watches Isaac grow, yearning to be part of his life but too afraid to approach him. 

In the present, Leo is a solitary old man awaiting death, accompanied by his childhood friend Bruno, who may only exist in his imagination, especially since Alma has been gone for five years. 

Leo keeps tabs on Isaac, who has become a renowned writer, bringing Leo joy as he believes Isaac inherited his talent. Leo's sorrow intensifies when he reads in a newspaper that Isaac has died at 60, leading him to obsess over finding his place in his son's life, even breaking into Isaac’s home to see if he had read "Words for Everything." 

Leo longs to reread "The History of Love," so he seeks a copy of the book he had given to his friend Zvi Litvinoff, who moved to Chile. 

Their friendship began when Leo fell gravely ill in Poland and wrote his own obituary, which Lev stole in hopes of keeping his friend alive. 

Leo writes to Zvi, but his wife informs him that the book was lost in a flood, concealing the fact that her husband did not author "The History of Love." Unbeknownst to Leo, the book had been published in a limited run of two thousand copies in Spanish, credited to Zvi Litvinoff, who believed Leo had died in Poland. Zvi, feeling guilty for plagiarizing, added Leo’s stolen obituary as the final chapter, claiming it was a condition for publication, even though it did not fit the narrative. When Leo inquires about the book, Zvi's wife, Rosa, fearing her husband would lose his reputation if the truth emerged, lies about the manuscript being destroyed and even stages a flood in their home to support her claim. Zvi passed away without revealing the true author of "The History of Love." 

In a parallel narrative, a 15-year-old Jewish girl named Alma Singer, named after the character in "The History of Love," struggles with the loss of her father to cancer. Her mother becomes withdrawn, immersing herself in her work as a book translator. 

Her younger brother, Bird, named for his attempt to fly by jumping from a second-story window, seeks solace in religion, believing he is among God's chosen, which further alienates him from reality. Alma finds comfort in one of her father's pastimes: wilderness survival. She also harbors feelings for her Russian pen pal, Misha, who has relocated to New York. They become a couple but eventually part ways due to Alma's uncertainty. One day, her mother receives a letter from a mysterious man named Jacob Marcus, who requests her to translate "The History of Love" from Spanish to English for $100,000, to be paid in installments of $25,000 as the work progresses. Alma’s mother is suspicious of the offer, but the stranger reveals that his mother used to read the book to him as a child, making it deeply sentimental. Alma sees this as a chance to help her mother heal and transforms her mother’s straightforward letters to Jacob Marcus into more romantic versions. 

When the correspondence halts before her mother finishes the translation, Alma decides to track down the enigmatic client. 

She begins by documenting everything she knows about Jacob Marcus in her diary, concluding that the Alma in the book must be real and sets out to find her. Her search for Alma Mereminski proves challenging, but she eventually discovers that Alma may have married and is now known as Moritz. She is disheartened to

Rewritten:
Approximately 70 years before the present, the 10-year-old Polish-Jewish Leopold (Leo) Gursky falls in love with his neighbor Alma Mereminski. The two begin a relationship that develops over the course of 10 years. In this time, Leo writes three books that he gives to Alma since she is the only person whom he deeply cares about. 

The first book is too realistic and boring, the second one is entirely fiction and unconvincing, and the last book is dedicated to his love: "The History of Love." Leo promises he will never love anyone but Alma. 

Alma, now 20, is sent to the United States by her father, who feared the alarming news concerning fascist Germany. Leo does not know that Alma is pregnant and dreams of going to America to meet her. 

A short time after, the Germans invade Poland and Leo takes cover in the woods, living on roots, small animals, bugs and what he can steal from farmers' cellars. 

After two years of hiding he goes to America and finds Alma but is shocked to hear she thought he had died in the war and had married the son of the manager of the factory she works at. 

He is devastated when he finds she has had another child with her husband. 

He asks her to come with him, but she refuses. 

She tells him, however, about his son Isaac who is now five years old. Heartbroken, Leo leaves and becomes a locksmith. 

Leo regularly watches Isaac from a distance, wishing to be part of the boy’s life but scared to come in contact with him. 

In the present day, Leo is a lonely old man who waits for his death, along with his recently found (most probably in his imagination) childhood friend, Bruno, especially since Alma has been dead for five years. 

Leo still keeps track of his son, who has become a famous writer, much to Leo’s enjoyment since he believes Isaac inherited the talent from his father. Leo's depression deepens when he reads in a newspaper that his son has died at the age of 60, and Leo develops an obsession with finding his place in his son's world, to the extent that he breaks into Isaac’s house to see if he had read "Words for Everything". 

Leo wants to reread "The History of Love", so he tries to obtain a copy of the book that he gave to his friend Zvi Litvinoff, who had immigrated to Chile. 

Their friendship dates from when Leo fell gravely ill in Poland and wrote his own obituary, after which Lev stole it in the hope that it would keep his friend alive. 

Leo writes a letter to Zvi, but his wife informs him that the book was destroyed in a flood, conspiring to hide that her husband did not write "The History of Love". Unknown to Leo is that the book had been published in a small printing of two thousand copies (and re-published upon the supposed author's death) in Spanish, but under the name of Zvi Litvinoff, who copied the book thinking Leo was killed in Poland. Zvi felt so guilty for copying his book that he added his friend’s stolen obituary as the last chapter, telling the publisher that including the obituary was conditional to printing the book, although doing so did not make sense with the plot. When Leo called to recover the book, Zvi's wife, Rosa, fearing her husband would lose his fame if the world found out his well-regarded book was plagiarized, lied by saying the manuscript had been destroyed in a flood, and then manufactured a flood in her house to realize the lie. Zvi died later without telling the world about the real author of "The History of Love". 

In a parallel story, a 15-year-old Jewish girl, Alma Singer, named after the Alma in "The History of Love", her parents’ favorite book, is struggling to cope with the loss of her father due to cancer. Her mother becomes distant and lonely, escaping into her work of book translation. 

Her younger brother Bird, so called for jumping from the second story of a building hoping he could fly, seeks refuge in religion and believes himself to be one of God’s chosen people, thus distancing himself from reality. Alma finds refuge in one of her father’s hobbies: surviving in the wild. Alma also bears a crush on her Russian pen friend Misha, who has moved to New York. The two become a couple but they break up because of Alma’s incertitude. One day, her mother receives a letter from a mysterious man named Jacob Marcus who requests that she translate "The History of Love" from Spanish to English for $100,000 dollars, to be paid in increments of $25,000 as the work progresses. Alma’s mother finds the sum suspicious, but the stranger confesses that his mother used to read the book to him when he was a child, so it has a great sentimental value. Alma sees this as an opportunity to help her mother recover from her depression and changes her mother’s straightforward letters to Jacob Marcus into more romantic versions. 

When the letters stop before her mother completes the translation of the book, Alma decides to find the mysterious client. 

She starts by noting down what she knows about Jacob Marcus in her diary, and concludes that the Alma in the book was real and proceeds to find her. She struggles in her search for Alma Mereminski, but succeeds when she realizes that Alma could have married and finds her under the name of Moritz. She is disappointed to hear that Alma has been dead for five years. However, she finds out that Isaac Moritz is the first of Alma's sons and a famous writer. 

When she starts reading his bestselling book, she finds that the main character's name is Jacob Marcus and realizes that Isaac Moritz had hired her mother to translate the book. 

Isaac is dead, however, which explains why his letters had stopped coming to their home. To be sure about her suspicions, Alma leaves a note on Isaac’s door asking who the writer of the novel is. 

In the meanwhile, Bird finds Alma’s diary and misinterprets the names Alma Mereminski and Alma Moritz as being his sister’s real names, and believes they had different fathers. Isaac’s brother calls Alma, after reading the note and the original manuscript of the book, to tell her that Gursky is the real author, but Bird answers the telephone and it confuses him even further. He now suspects that Leopold Gursky is Alma's real father. 

To cleanse his sin of bragging and to regain the status as one of the chosen ones, he decides to set up a meeting with Alma and Gursky, thus doing a good deed without anybody knowing except God. When the two receive the letter regarding their meeting, both are confused: Alma tries to discover which of the people she met during her searches could have sent her the note, while Leo comes to believe it was Alma who sent him the note, despite her being dead. 

Leo settles himself on a park bench, waiting a long while for Alma to appear. He ponders his life, key moments from his past, the loss of his love, and what it means to be human. He imagines that he will die while he is waiting there, his own death and mortality being one of his preoccupations in the novel. When Alma finally appears, he and she are both confused, although at first Leo believes that she is his Alma from the past and that she is really just in his imagination. 

After he realizes that she doesn't look like his Alma, and he gets confirmation from a man walking by that the Alma who is there is actually real, Leo talks to her briefly about Bruno and Isaac, while Alma starts piecing together the puzzle of who Leo is. 

When Alma asks him if he ever loved a girl named Alma Mereminski, the old man finally feels a sense of transcendence in being recognized at long last, and instead of being able to respond to Alma's questions with words, he keeps tapping his fingers twice against her. She puts her head on his shoulder and hugs him, and he is finally able to speak again, saying her name three times and giving her her own feeling of transcendence at finally being recognized, too. (Some readers believe that Leo has a heart attack and dies at this point, possibly because of Leo's earlier assumption that he is about to die, and also because he says during this meeting with Alma, "I felt my heart surge. 

I thought: I've lived this long. 

Please. 

A little longer won't kill me." A more compelling case can be made that the novel, for all its poignancy, simply ends with this mutually transcendent moment for these two characters.) 

The last chapter is entitled "The Death of Leopold Gursky" and is identical with the last chapter of the book inside a book "The History of Love", both being the self-written obituary of Leopold Gursky. 

By ending the novel this way, Krauss is richly alluding to earlier parts of the novel and to her theme of how words keep people alive for us, indeed, make people in danger of becoming invisible, visible. 

Zvi Litvinoff carried Leo's self-written obit in his pocket for years, as a talisman guarding against Leo's death. 

Litvinoff, when preparing "History of Love" for publication, insists that his editor include the Leo Gursky obit at the end, his way of ensuring that Leo will continue to "live" in the hearts of all readers of the book. And finally, Nicole Krauss includes the same obit at the end of her novel, as a way of urging all readers to keep this Leo, and all Leos, alive.
It's burnt bread.

It's toast.

He is treading on a perilous path,  
Why is she exclaiming, "He is a crack."  
Why are her eyes glistening, is it affection?  
He understands, he doesn’t soar like a dove,  
He realizes it’s a slope, not a bridge,  
The teenage girl is perched on a ridge.  
But his gaze is fixed on her pink dress,  
He, a lover, who never looks less,  
Journey of his eyes from feet to face,  
Kissing and embracing her silky grace.  
It’s the midpoint, and his eyes find rest,  
To regain his breath, this spot is the best.  
Gazing into his eyes, why is she coy?  
Prayers for her lover! Looking at the sky!  
The same wildness in a disciplined naughty boy!  
Different metals, can they create an alloy?  
Perhaps; love is a magic, a force so bright,  
Any moment can turn the wrong into right.  
He’s close to the heart, a valley to adore,  
Listen to the beats climb more, climb more.  
Here he is, he can see her dancing hips,  
Hands around the neck, lips on the lips!  
Writing and stamping a wordless deed,  
Welcome, welcome if love is the greed!

Date: Tue, 14 Aug 2001 10:04:07 -0700 (PDT)
From: susan.mara@enron.com
To: vicki.sharp@enron.com
Subject: Update on 1 Cent Surcharge and Attorney-Client Privilege

CC: d..steffes@enron.com, kevin.keeney@enron.com, lamar.frazier@enron.com, 
	steve.swain@enron.com, jeff.richter@enron.com, c..williams@enron.com, 
	wanda.curry@enron.com, diann.huddleson@enron.com, 
	michael.tribolet@enron.com, susan.mara@enron.com
BCC: d..steffes@enron.com, kevin.keeney@enron.com, lamar.frazier@enron.com, 
	steve.swain@enron.com, jeff.richter@enron.com, c..williams@enron.com, 
	wanda.curry@enron.com, diann.huddleson@enron.com, 
	michael.tribolet@enron.com, susan.mara@enron.com

Vicki,

As per your request, I am providing an update on the status of the 1 cent surcharge. 

The 1 cent surcharge was initially approved by the CPUC in January, despite protests from the Alliance for Retail Energy Markets (AReM), to which we belong. However, the CPUC later made the 3 cent surcharge permanent in a March order, while exempting direct access (DA) customers from both surcharges. 

The utilities, SCE and PG&E, implemented the surcharges differently. SCE billed DA customers for both surcharges but then gave them a credit, while PG&E did not charge DA customers for the 3 cent surcharge but continued to charge the 1 cent surcharge.

AReM filed comments and protests in May, supporting SCE's approach and opposing PG&E's continued charging of the 1 cent surcharge. AReM argued that the 1 cent surcharge should not apply to DA customers, given the CPUC's discussion on generation-related costs going forward.

The Energy Division staff of the CPUC is currently working on a Resolution to address the protested issues. Discussions between AReM members and the Energy Division staff indicate that the staff agrees with AReM and will support AReM's request when drafting the Resolution.

However, initiating a formal change to the January order on the 1 cent surcharge would require the filing of a Petition to Modify, which could bring out opposition from unions and other groups. AReM has decided to work with the Energy Division staff to achieve a favorable outcome by the end of September.

I recommend that Enron continue to work through AReM to achieve a favorable outcome on the 1 cent surcharge.

Sue Mara
(415) 782-7802

	steve.swain@enron.com, jeff.richter@enron.com, c..williams@enron.com,

Bcc: d..steffes@enron.com, kevin.keeney@enron.com, lamar.frazier@enron.com, 
	steve.swain@enron.com, jeff.richter@enron.com, c..williams@enron.com, 
	wanda.curry@enron.com, diann.huddleson@enron.com, 
	michael.tribolet@enron.com, susan.mara@enron.com
ATTORNEY-CLIENT PRIVILEGE
Vicki,
As you requested, this e-mail describes the current status of the 1 cent surcharge.
1. The 1 cent surcharge was approved by the CPUC in early January. At the time, the Alliance for Retail Energy Markets (AReM), to which we belong, had protested its application to DA customers. Nonetheless, the CPUC approved the surcharge and its application to all customers, including DA customers, because of the "emergency" nature of the situation and because it was "temporary."
2. The 3 cent surcharge was approved by the CPUC in the March 27 order. Once again, AReM had protested its application to DA customers. This time the CPUC explicitly exempted DA customers and stated that the surcharge was for generation-related costs going forward. The CPUC also made the one cent surcharge permanent but did not address its application to DA customers -- therefore, in my view, the earlier decision still stands on that issue. As AReM had suggested, the CPUC also stated that DA Customers would NOT be billed for the surcharge NOR given any credit for it.
3. The March order required the utilities to file Advice Letters to implement the surcharges. This was done in April (I think) but the SCE and PG&E took two different approaches. SCE, because of billing system limitations, decided to violate the CPUC order in its implementation -- it billed DA customers for BOTH surcharges but then gave them a CREDIT that included both surcharges. PG&E, on the other hand, did NOT charge DA customers for the 3 cent surcharge nor include it in any credit -- in compliance with the CPUC March order. However, PG&E continued to charge the 1 cent surcharge to DA customers in compliance with the CPUC's January order.
4. AReM filed comments/protests on the utility advice letters -- in May, I believe. AReM supported SCE's approach for not charging the 1 cent surcharge and for looking the closest to a "bottoms-up" calculation. AReM did mention that SCE should NOT be charging then crediting the surcharges, however. AReM supported PG&E's approach of neither charging nor crediting the surcharge -- but opposed PG&E's continued charging of the 1 cent surcharge. AReM agreed with SCE that, given the discussion in the March order and the application of the surcharges to generation-related costs going forward, the 1 cent surcharge should NOT apply to DA customers.
5. When Advice Letters are protested, the Energy Division staff of the CPUC prepares a Resolution that recommends how to address the protested issues. The Resolution is then presented to the CPUC at a meeting and voted on. Usually we have between one day and one week to see the Resolution before it is voted on. No Resolution has come forward on these Advice Letters. The CPUC has no time requirement for when Advice Letters must be resolved.
6. Discussions between AReM members and the Energy Division staff indicate that the staff agrees with AReM and will support AReM's request when it drafts the Resolution.
7. Initiating a formal change to the January order on the 1 cent surcharge would require the filing of a Petition to Modify (usually done within a year -- but I believe can be requested at any time thereafter with a special motion). This would begin a formal process -- also WITH NO TIME LINE. It would also bring out the big guns opposing direct access -- the unions and TURN (a supposed small customer advocacy group) -- making quick response and a win for AReM more problematic.
8. AReM has decided to work with the Energy Division staff and see if we can get a favorable Resolution kicked out by the end of September. (The Energy Division staff is overloaded right now with all the DWR-related decisions required for the 8/23 meeting.) If not, AReM will consider making a formal Petition to Modify.
9. I recommend that Enron continue with its current strategy to work through AReM to achieve a favorable outcome on the 1 cent surcharge.
Sue Mara
(415) 782-7802

Media conglomerate Viacom has disbursed $3.5 million (£1.8 million) to conclude investigations into indecency concerning its US radio and television programs. 

This settlement with the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) brings to a close a protracted issue that began in 2001. The FCC was examining 50 programs, including those hosted by "shock jock" Howard Stern and two DJs from New York. 

Stern recently declared his departure from Viacom, while the two DJs were dismissed after their show featured a couple allegedly engaging in sexual activity in a church. Following the church incident two years ago, Viacom consented to implement audio delay systems at its radio stations that air live content. Additionally, it agreed to provide training for its broadcasters and staff regarding indecency regulations. 

The agreement terminates investigations into approximately 50 radio and television programs, according to Richard Diamond, FCC deputy secretary of communications. 

These programs were aired by Viacom-owned stations throughout the United States. Viacom has a five-day window to remit the $3.5 million penalty, as stipulated in the agreement. This payment is separate from the FCC's $550,000 (£293,000) fine imposed on Viacom following the exposure of singer Janet Jackson's breast during the CBS Super Bowl halftime show in January, which Viacom is currently contesting. 

This is not the first instance of Viacom incurring costs due to indecency allegations. 

Infinity Broadcasting, a subsidiary of Viacom, paid a total of $1.7 million (£907,000) in fines in 1995 to resolve FCC violations involving Stern.

Rewritten:
Media giant Viacom has paid out $3.5m (£1.8m) to end investigations into indecency in its US radio and TV shows. 

The settlement to the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) ends a long-running saga dating back to 2001. The FCC was looking into 50 shows, including those by "shock jock" Howard Stern and two New York DJs. 

Stern recently announced he was leaving Viacom while the two DJs were sacked after their show featured a couple purporting to have sex in a church. After the church incident two years ago Viacom agreed to install audio delay equipment at its radio stations that broadcast live programming. It also agreed to train its broadcasters and employees about indecency laws. 

The agreement cancels investigations into about 50 radio and television shows, said Richard Diamond, FCC deputy secretary of communications. 

The shows were broadcast by Viacom-owned stations across the United States. Viacom has five days to pay the $3.5m fine, according to the agreement. The payment is not related to the FCC's $550,000 (£293,000) fine levied against Viacom after the exposure of singer Janet Jackson's breast during the CBS Super Bowl halftime show in January. Viacom is contesting that fine. 

It is not the first time that Viacom has paid out over indecency charges. 

Infinity Broadcasting, which is owned by Viacom, paid cumulative fines totalling $1.7m (£907,000) in 1995 to settle FCC violations by Stern.

Subject: Conference Call/PX Response
Attached you will find the draft of the Response of the Group to the Motion 
for Relief from Stay filed by the Debtor. As an initial caveat, we have 
prepared this as the scrivener for the Group. Like the rest of the Group, we 
have not specifically reviewed the substance of this with our client and we 
reserve the right to suggest changes based on our client's comments, as we 
expect the rest of the Group will. In addition, we have the following 
comments:
1. In carefully analyzing the Motion for Relief from Stay as part of 
preparing this Response, we became convinced that the Debtor meant that the 
preliminary injunction was to remain effective and does not intend to grant 
general relief from stay as to the Federal District Court action. It seems 
to us that the Debtor is basically saying by this motion that we should 
proceed in front of FERC, but nobody has the prerogative, without seeking 
further relief of stay from the court, to proceed outside of FERC to resolve 
the charge-back issues. Accordingly, we did not feel it was appropriate to 
address this issue in the response. The Group may want to consider 
approaching Debtor's counsel on this issue.
2. Technically, by asking the Court to include the Amendment 22 proceeding 
as part of the Relief from Stay, we are expanding the relief. We have tried 
to soft sell this issue as was suggested by the Group to suggest that this is 
simply a related proceeding that is required to go forward to grant complete 
relief as part of the Debtor's motion. If the Debtor objects to the expanded 
relief, the court will likely not grant it because it was not specifically 
the subject of the motion. We probably need to lobby Debtor's counsel to 
help get this accomplished without the requirement of filing an additional 
motion for relief.

Date: Tue, 20 Feb 2001 06:25:00 -0800 (PST)  
From: tori.kuykendall@enron.com  
To: melba.lozano@enron.com  
Subject: Re: 2 new products  
Body:  
The two products will be EPNG Socal Ehrenberg and PG&E Topock. The purpose of creating these restricted products is to prevent El Paso Merchant Energy from trading them. We want to take this step because El Paso Merchant Energy is not engaging in trades with us, the Western region, on their online trading platform, ICE, as well as in the broker market. We believe this is the right course of action to ensure fairness in the market. I anticipate this will raise some questions, which should be directed to our VP, Mike Grigsby, if more clarification is required. Once again, the desk has recently decided to handle the trading of these products in this manner, and they have requested that I ensure we can roll them out on eol by 2/28 at the latest. Thank you for your assistance.

Dear Member of the Silicon Valley Breakfast Club:  
This is a friendly reminder to attend the April meeting of the Silicon Valley Breakfast Club, which will take place on Tuesday, April 24, from 8:15am to 10am, hosted by EPRI in their Cafeteria located at 3412 Hillview Avenue in Palo Alto.  
This month’s speaker is Bob Therkelsen, the Manager of Special Projects Engineering at the California Independent Systems Operator. Mr. Therkelsen will provide an update on the ten generation facilities that have received approval in the last 18 months, detailing their current construction status, as well as the 14 generation facilities that are presently navigating the CEC process.  
Everyone agrees that this new generation is crucial for addressing the long-term energy crisis. Be sure to attend this informative presentation on significant generation facilities and their timelines for coming online!  
For a map, please check our website at www.svmg.org, under EVENTS. Our host kindly requests that attendees park in the lot above Building 1.

We were discussing someone who was struggling with substance abuse, and I was feeling shaken by it. I had lost a night of sleep and was on the verge of going into depression for a week. My therapist calmly asked how my weekend was, and I told him it wasn't great. He asked if I wanted to talk about it, but I just kept quiet and uttered, "Why don't you ask?" He closed everything and quietly asked, "What happened that made you feel this way?" I instantly opened up and told him it hurt me, and I knew it shouldn't have because my life is more important, and I was learning in therapy how to become a better person. He just replied, "Are you sad about it?" And I replied, "Not sad, disappointed, I don't want people to go down a bad path and others don't even understand it's not okay and support it, and I'm always the odd one out." He just repeated saying, "Shouldn't" is a strong word you used, it's fine to feel that way, you should take your time. He was like, "Trust me, you're just 21 now, by the time you're 27, you'll be the one who will have your life under control where others wouldn't and I understand that's because you understand well." He also told me I don't fit in or isolate myself because I understand people too well and most people don't like it. I just perked up and told him, "So what? I love being this way" and he was like, yeah, that's important. The fact that we both understand each other so well makes me so happy that I can just sit and talk to him and forget that he's my therapist and just someone I'm comfortable with.

I truly wasn't anticipating much, aside from a few chuckles, which would have been fine for a Dreamworks animated film. However, KUNG FU PANDA surpassed all my expectations. The plot is straightforward, yet the execution is outstanding. It would be quite challenging to find anything to enhance the production. The voice performances are excellent, especially Jack Black and Dustin Hoffman. The animation is incredibly vibrant, and the colors are sharp and vivid. The action sequences are exhilarating. The humor is well-timed and integrated into the right moments. The theater was packed, featuring a blend of adults and young children. This is a movie that everyone can enjoy. A testament to this is that nearly the entire audience remained for the end credits. This is a very uncommon occurrence these days. 

Oh... and I hope this doesn't count as a spoiler. I absolutely adored the Samurai-Jack style animation in some scenes.

I'm discussing an event that took place at Aldershot, specifically regarding Farrell, as the matter remains unresolved. Leicester and Saracens are at the forefront of the pursuit, but the Wigan chairman believes the situation is not yet concluded. “In addition to the RFU, the RFL, the club, and the England coaching staff, many parties are involved, so there isn't a quick resolution,” he stated to BBC Sport. – He has dedicated 12 years to us, so if he wishes to leave, we will support his decision. The possibility of Farrell switching codes has been the primary topic of discussion in the Super League this season. “It was a complete surprise,” remarked chairman Roberto Quercia. – However, he is a very loyal member of the club, so there’s no question of him betraying us. He seeks a new challenge. While this transition would have financial consequences for both Farrell and Wigan, money is not the primary concern for the borough. “Financial issues are not our main focus, but for Wigan, it is not a concern,” he told BBC 5 Live. – A lack of funds has never hindered us. If we had more money, we still couldn't spend it due to the salary cap. We would prefer to keep the player, the Warriors' chairman added. Yet, it’s easy to see why the Union would want to acquire Farrell. “We would lose him, but it would benefit them,” he continued. – He is a legendary figure in sports. He has been at the top level for many years and has demonstrated all the qualities necessary to excel in a demanding contact sport. – Individuals like him, Ellery Hanley, and Martin Johnson are rare, so we are fortunate to have them when we do.

The prospect of Farrell changing codes has been the main conversation of the Super League season so far. “It came as a bolt from the blue,” said chairman Roberto Quercia. – But he is a very loyal friend of the club, so there is no question of his betraying us. He wants a challenge. Although this move would have financial implications for both Farrell and Wigan, the money has not been a driving force for the borough. “The money is not the main issue, but for Wigan it is not the issue,” he told BBC 5 Live. – The lack of money has never been a problem for us. If we had more money, we would not be able to spend it because of the salary cap. We would rather have the player. Added the Warriors' chairman. But it is not difficult to understand why the Union would be interested in snatching Farrell. “We would lose him, but it would be a good thing for them,” he added. – This is an iconic man for sport. Subject: Meeting  
Body:  
Greg,  
I am a new Associate from Georgetown and I am thrilled to be a part of Enron. I aspire to achieve great success in the future and will put in significant effort to demonstrate my best here. I would appreciate the chance to have lunch with you to gain your insights on the company and the factors that contribute to success. I believe you would be an ideal person to speak with for two reasons:  
1) Your accomplishments in the Associate Program and your broad multi-divisional experience within the company.  
2) Your deep understanding of the drivers and opportunities in the energy sector.  
Best,  
Jason Jennaro

The Return, a gripping Russian drama, has taken home the prestigious BBC Four World Cinema Award. The film revolves around two teenage boys who are subjected to a strict and unforgiving regime when their father returns after a decade-long absence.

Directed by acclaimed filmmaker Andrey Zvyagintsev, The Return previously made history by winning the Golden Lion award at the 2003 Venice Film Festival. The award ceremony, hosted by Jonathan Ross, took place in London on Thursday. 

A distinguished panel, comprising actress Gillian Anderson, film critic Roger Clarke, and director Kevin McDonald, selected the winner from a shortlist of six outstanding films from around the world. Ross, who presents BBC One's Film 2005, was also involved in the deliberation process.

The nominees included the Motorcycle Diaries, Zatoichi, and Hero, with the latter emerging as the favourite in a viewer poll, garnering 32% of the votes cast. 

Tragedy struck during the production of The Return when 15-year-old Vladimir Girin, one of the young stars, tragically drowned in a lake.

The Return has now taken the title of the BBC Four World Cinema Award, following in the footsteps of last year's winner, the French animated feature Belleville Rendezvous.

Rewritten:
Russian drama The Return (Vozvrashchenie) has been named winner of the BBC Four World Cinema Award. The film tells the story of two adolescent boys who are subjected to a harsh regime when their strict father returns after a 10-year absence. 

Directed by Andrey Zvyagintsev, The Return previously won the 2003 Golden Lion award at the Venice Film Festival. The prize was presented at an awards ceremony held in London on Thursday and hosted by Jonathan Ross. 

The winner was chosen by a panel which included X Files actress Gillian Anderson, critic Roger Clarke and Touching the Void director Kevin McDonald. Ross, who is the presenter of BBC One's Film 2005, was also involved in the deliberations. 

A shortlist of six films from around the world had been drawn up from which the panel chose. Other nominees included the Motorcycle Diaries, Zatoichi and Hero. A viewer poll saw director Zhang Yimou's martial arts epic Hero emerge as the favourite with 32% of votes cast. 

Tragedy struck the production of The Return when one of the young stars, 15-year-old Vladimir Girin, drowned in a lake. 

The winner of the World Cinema Award last year was the French animated feature Belleville Rendezvous

Within moments, all of the peculiar creatures lay lifeless. As they perished, the magic dissipated, and their forms reverted to those of former students. Those bodies then rapidly deteriorated as a consequence of the magic. Before long, the clearing bore little evidence of any prior occurrences. The wizard instantly realized what had transpired with his creations. He was displeased with this girl. He needed to take action against her. Since she was in the woods, he resolved to unleash something that would be nearly impossible to eliminate. The wizard concentrated and established a mental link with a unique tree deep within the forest. He issued the necessary commands, and it sprang into action. This tree had numerous vines spread throughout the woods. These vines animated and advanced toward the girl. There were countless of them, and while severing one would halt that particular vine, many more would take its place. The only way to overcome this would be to either destroy all the vines or locate the tree that governed them and eliminate it. Regardless, the wizard was confident that this time the girl's destiny would be sealed. The vines began to close in on the girl, inching closer with each passing second, clearly moving in her direction.

Rewritten:
Within moments all of the strange creatures were dead. With their deaths, the magic left them and their bodies returned to that of old students. Those bodies then quickly decayed as a side effect of the magic. Soon the clearing showed little sign that there had been any sort of events going on there. The wizard immediately knew what had happened to his creations. He was not happy with this girl. He needed to deal with her. She was in the woods, so he decided to hit her with something that would be nearly impossible to kill.The wizard focused and connected mentally with a very special tree deep in the woods. He gave it the commands it needed and it sprung into action. This tree had many vines set throughout the woods. These came to life and moved toward the girl. There were a lot of them and while hacking off one would stop that one, there would be many more to replace them. The only way to defeat it would be to somehow either kill all the vines, or find the tree that controlled them and kill it. Either way, the wizard was sure that this time the girl's fate would be sealed. The vines started to get close to the girl, closer with every passing second, moving quite obviously toward her.

Guy Fawkes (13 April 1570 – 31 January 1606), also referred to as Guido Fawkes during his time fighting for the Spanish, was part of a group of provincial English Catholics involved in the unsuccessful Gunpowder Plot of 1605. He was born and raised in York; his father passed away when Fawkes was just eight years old, after which his mother remarried a recusant Catholic. Fawkes converted to Catholicism and moved to mainland Europe, where he fought for Catholic Spain in the Eighty Years' War against Protestant Dutch reformers in the Low Countries. He traveled to Spain in search of support for a Catholic uprising in England, but was unsuccessful. Eventually, he met Thomas Wintour, with whom he returned to England. Wintour introduced him to Robert Catesby, who was plotting to assassinate and reinstate a Catholic monarch on the throne. The conspirators rented an undercroft beneath the House of Lords; Fawkes was assigned the responsibility of the gunpowder they stored there. An anonymous letter prompted the authorities to search Westminster Palace in the early hours of 5 November, where they discovered Fawkes guarding the explosives. He was interrogated and tortured over the following days and admitted to his intention to blow up the House of Lords.

Rewritten:
Guy Fawkes (; 13 April 1570 – 31 January 1606), also known as Guido Fawkes while fighting for the Spanish, was a member of a group of provincial English Catholics who was involved in the failed Gunpowder Plot of 1605. He was born and educated in York; his father died when Fawkes was eight years old, after which his mother married a recusant Catholic. Fawkes converted to Catholicism and left for mainland Europe, where he fought for Catholic Spain in the Eighty Years' War against Protestant Dutch reformers in the Low Countries. He travelled to Spain to seek support for a Catholic rebellion in England without success. He later met Thomas Wintour, with whom he returned to England. Wintour introduced him to Robert Catesby, who planned to assassinate and restore a Catholic monarch to the throne. The plotters leased an undercroft beneath the House of Lords; Fawkes was placed in charge of the gunpowder that they stockpiled there. The authorities were prompted by an anonymous letter to search Westminster Palace during the early hours of 5 November, and they found Fawkes guarding the explosives. He was questioned and tortured over the next few days and confessed to wanting to blow up the House of Lords.

Sydney is set to host a charity match between the northern and southern hemispheres in June or July, according to the Australian Rugby Union (ARU). The match will feature players from the Lions tour of New Zealand. The ARU has expressed its support for the proposed match, which aims to raise funds for tsunami appeals. Although the exact date has yet to be decided, the likely venue is Sydney's Olympic Stadium. ARU chief executive Gary Flowers stated that the recent world cricket charity match in Melbourne had inspired the idea. "We still need to discuss the options with the IRB (International Rugby Board), the Lions, and our SANZAR (South Africa, New Zealand, and Australia Rugby) partners, but June or July is seen as a better option than March to ensure we have the cream of southern hemisphere rugby available," he said. Wallabies captain George Gregan described the charity match as a "great initiative." The match will feature prominent players from the Tri-Nations rivals Australia, New Zealand, and South Africa, who will form a southern team against a northern side comprising six Nations teams - France, Ireland, England, Wales, Italy, and Scotland. The Lions squad, coached by Clive Woodward, will tour New Zealand in June and July, including Tests on June 25, July 2, and July 9. Almost 80,000 fans packed into Melbourne Cricket Ground on January 10 for a charity match that raised £5.9m for victims of the Asian tsunami.

Rewritten:
Sуdnеу wіll hоst а nоrthеrn vеrsus sоuthеrn hеmіsрhеrе сhаrіtу mаtсh іn Junе оr Julу, thе Аustrаlіаn Rugbу Unіоn (ΑRU) sаіd оn Wеdnеsdау.
Τhе mаtсh wіll іnсludе рlауеrs frоm thе Lіоns tоur оf Νеw Ζеаlаnd. "Τhе Аustrаlіаn Rugbу Unіоn hаs thrоwn іts suрроrt bеhіnd а рrороsеd Νоrth-Sоuth mаtсh tо rаіsе funds fоr thе tsunаmі арреаls," thе ΑRU sаіd. Τhе dаtе іs уеt tо bе dесіdеd but thе mоst lіkеlу vеnuе іs Sуdnеу's Оlуmріс Stаdіum. ΑRU сhіеf ехесutіvе Gаrу Flоwеrs sаіd thе wоrld сrісkеt сhаrіtу mаtсh іn Μеlbоurnе еаrlіеr thіs mоnth hаd іnsріrеd thе ΑRU. "Wе stіll nееd tо dіsсuss thе орtіоns wіth thе ΙRΒ (Ιntеrnаtіоnаl Rugbу Βоаrd), thе Lіоns аnd оur SΑΝΖАR (Sоuth Αfrіса, Νеw Ζеаlаnd аnd Αustrаlіа Rugbу) раrtnеrs, but Junе оr Julу іs sееn аs а bеttеr орtіоn thаn Μаrсh tо еnsurе wе hаvе thе сrеаm оf sоuthеrn hеmіsрhеrе rugbу аvаіlаblе," hе sаіd. Wаllаbіеs сарtаіn Gеоrgе Grеgаn sаіd thе сhаrіtу mаtсh wаs а "grеаt іnіtіаtіvе". Тrі-Νаtіоns rіvаls Αustrаlіа, Νеw Ζеаlаnd аnd Sоuth Аfrіса wоuld fеаturе рrоmіnеntlу іn а sоuthеrn tеаm аgаіnst а nоrthеrn sіdе соmрrіsеd оf Sіх Νаtіоns tеаms Frаnсе, Іrеlаnd, Еnglаnd, Wаlеs, Ιtаlу аnd Sсоtlаnd. Соасh Сlіvе Wооdwаrd's Lіоns squаd wіll tоur Νеw Ζеаlаnd іn Junе аnd Julу, іnсludіng Τеsts оn 25 Junе, 2 аnd 9 Julу.
Аlmоst 80,000 fаns расkеd іntо Μеlbоurnе Сrісkеt Grоund оn 10 Jаnuаrу fоr а сhаrіtу mаtсh thаt rаіsеd £5.9m fоr vісtіms оf thе Аsіаn tsunаmі.

To make a delicious chipotle dish, start by chipping 7 ounces of chipotle chilies in adobo sauce (you can reduce this amount and taste and test while adding more or it will blow your eyes out). 

Next, combine 2 teaspoons of lime juice, 12 cups of mayonnaise, 14 cups of finely chopped cilantro, kosher salt, fresh ground black pepper, and vegetable oil (about 2 quarters or enough to have a 3-inch depth in the pot) in a blender. 

Add 1 lime, its juice, 2 cups of water, 1 cup of all-purpose flour, and 1 cup of panko breadcrumbs to the blender. Blend the mixture until smooth, then set it aside. 

Place the mayonnaise in a medium bowl. Whisk in one-third of the chipotle mixture at a time, tasting between each addition for spiciness (you may not want to use all of the chipotle puree). Add cilantro and season with salt and pepper. 

Cover the mixture with plastic wrap and refrigerate until ready to serve. 

While the mixture is chilling, heat the vegetable oil in a large pot over high heat until it reaches 350 degrees. 

In three separate shallow dishes, mix together the all-purpose flour, lime juice mixed with 2 cups of water, and panko breadcrumbs. Cut an avocado into quarters lengthwise. Remove the wedges from the pit and peel off the skin. Cut each quarter in half so you have 8 wedges in total. Season with salt and pepper. 

Dredge the avocado wedges in flour, then dip into lime water, and finally dredge through breadcrumbs. Make sure each slice is completely coated. 

Once the oil has reached 350 degrees, fry the breaded avocado slices for about 3 minutes, or until lightly browned. Remove the avocado from the oil using a slotted spoon and place on a paper towel-lined plate to drain. 

Serve the avocado with lime wedges and chipotle remoulade.

Creating cluster states efficiently is essential for building large-scale measurement-based quantum computers. A promising approach to achieving this is through hybrid matter-optical systems, which utilize an ancilla as a central hub to connect qubits. Our research demonstrates that by generating smaller cluster components, known as "Lego bricks," and reusing the same ancilla for each brick, we can produce the cluster with maximum efficiency. This method requires fewer than half the operations needed without reusing the ancilla. By reducing the time required to prepare sections of the cluster, reusing the ancilla enables the creation of a larger computational workspace before decoherence effects become dominant. Furthermore, using multiple buses in parallel allows for fully scalable cluster state generation, requiring only 20 CPhase gates per bus use.

Rewritten:
Efficient generation of cluster states is crucial for engineering large-scale
measurement-based quantum computers. Hybrid matter-optical systems offer a
robust, scalable path to this goal. Such systems have an ancilla which acts as
a bus connecting the qubits. We show that by generating smaller cluster "Lego
bricks", reusing one ancilla per brick, the cluster can be produced with
maximal efficiency, requiring fewer than half the operations compared with no
bus reuse. By reducing the time required to prepare sections of the cluster,
bus reuse more than doubles the size of the computational workspace that can be
used before decoherence effects dominate. A row of buses in parallel provides
fully scalable cluster state generation requiring only 20 CPhase gates per bus
use.

We present the design and evaluation of a non-imaging polarimeter that operates within the millimeter to submillimeter wavelength range. The polarimeter's rectangular shape ensures that the polarization state remains consistent in the incoming f/2 beam, and our measurements show that the polarization of the output beams at both low and high frequency modes aligns with a straightforward model of mode truncation. The copolar beam pattern is found to be nearly independent of frequency for both polarizations. Conversely, the cross-polarized beam pattern is primarily characterized by a uniform term, which can be accurately described by a single power function and corresponds to a polarization efficiency of 94 percent. After accounting for the polarization efficiency, the cross-polarized response is measured to be -18 dB.

Rewritten:
We report the design and performance of a non-imaging polarimeter for millimeter to submillimeter wavelengths. The rectangular geometry maintains the polarization state in the f/2 incident beam, and the polarization of the output beams at both low and high over-modes is consistent with a simple model of mode truncation. The measured copolar beam pattern is nearly frequency independent for both polarizations. The cross-polarized beam pattern is dominated by a uniform term, which can be fitted by a single power function and which corresponds to a polarization efficiency of 94 percent. After allowing for the polarization efficiency, the cross-polarized response is -18 dB.

Controversy and Lawrence Dallaglio have consistently been intertwined throughout his illustrious international career. The conclusion of his nine-year journey came unexpectedly, just four days prior to the season's kickoff. However, Dallaglio has always been an independent spirit. Since his debut on the international stage, Dallaglio has divided opinions. For England supporters, he could do no wrong. A vital component of a successful era for England, Dallaglio's pinnacle moment was his contribution to the team that clinched the Rugby World Cup in 2003. 

Conversely, rival fans have often held a different perspective, viewing Dallaglio as a representation of the less favorable traits of English rugby. Unafraid to voice his opinions—whether to the referee or opponents on the field, or to his coach and the media off it—Dallaglio has occasionally rubbed people the wrong way. He made his mark as part of the underrated England squad that surprisingly won the inaugural Rugby Sevens World Cup in 1993. It took him another two years to join the full England XV, but once he did, he quickly proved his worth. Demonstrating maturity and physical strength beyond his years, Dallaglio swiftly became a first-choice player capable of excelling in any of the three back-row positions at the international level.

Within two years of his debut, Dallaglio was given the England captaincy, and his career continued to flourish as he participated in the 1997 Lions tour to South Africa. Although he was passed over for the captaincy in favor of his England teammate Martin Johnson, he played a crucial role in the 2-1 series victory. However, after gaining what seemed like unstoppable momentum, Dallaglio's career faced a significant setback in 1999. 

First, there was the last-minute loss to Wales, where Dallaglio's choice not to kick for goal in the final moments was blamed for costing England a Grand Slam. Things worsened when a notorious newspaper sting led to the loss of his cherished England captaincy. With sensational drug use allegations—of which he was later exonerated—making headlines, a devastated Dallaglio stepped down as captain. Nevertheless, he made a comeback, focusing on club-level performance before rejoining the England squad, now as a deputy to the new captain Johnson. As part of a revamped England team on the long path to World Cup success—one not without its share of missed Grand Slam opportunities—Dallaglio re-emerged as a key player.

Another challenge arose in 2001 when a severe knee injury curtailed Dallaglio's participation in the Lions tour to Australia. Rumors began to circulate about the end of his career, but in true Dallaglio fashion, he committed to an intense rehabilitation regimen, returning as an even more formidable athlete. The injury did diminish his speed, but ever the realist, he adapted his game to become a top-tier close-quarters number eight.

As the only player to participate in every minute of England's World Cup victory in Australia, Dallaglio did everything possible to secure England's historic win, earning him lasting admiration from England fans. Following Johnson's retirement, Dallaglio's career came full circle when Woodward reinstated him as England captain. Although England did not reach the same heights during Dallaglio's second term as captain, losing five of their eight Tests after the World Cup, he led by example, remaining one of the few squad members to meet expectations in a team lacking many World Cup stars. Dallaglio departs from international rugby knowing he will be remembered as one of England's most skilled players, if not one of its greatest captains, despite his evident pride in leading his country.

The challenge for England now lies in finding a replacement for the nearly irreplaceable Dallaglio. Names like Matt Dawson, Jonny Wilkinson, Phil Vickery, and Hill have all been suggested as potential candidates for the captaincy. However, it is in terms of his playing ability that England will truly struggle to fill the void left by the 32-year-old. While players like Joe Worsley and Chris Jones are certainly capable of stepping up, the absence of a standout candidate highlights Dallaglio's immense impact on English rugby.

Rewritten:
Controversy and Lawrence Dallaglio have never been very far away from each other throughout a glittering international career.
Even the end of his nine-year career came out of the blue, just four days before the start of the season. But then Dallaglio has always been his own man. Ever since emerging onto the international scene Dallaglio has polarised opinions. To supporters of England, Dallaglio could do no wrong. An integral part of a sustained period of success for England, Dallaglio's crowning glory was his part in the side that won the Rugby World Cup in 2003.
Rival fans, meanwhile, have tended to take an alternative view, seeing Dallaglio as the epitome of the less agreeable characteristics of English rugby. Never afraid to speak his mind, be it to the referee or the opposition on the pitch, or his coach or the media off it, Dallaglio has sometimes rubbed people up the wrong way. Dallaglio arrived as part of the unheralded England side which became the shock winners of the first Rugby Sevens World Cup in 1993. It took him another two years to graduate to the full England XV, but once there he proved to the manor born. Displaying maturity and physical power beyond his years, Dallaglio rapidly established himself as an automatic choice able to play any one of the three back-row positions at international standard.
Within two years of his debut, Dallaglio was offered the England captain's band, and his career continued to go from strength to strength as he made the 1997 Lions tour to South Africa. Although overlooked for the captaincy in favour of England team-mate Martin Johnson, he played a massive role in the 2-1 series victory. But after building up a seemingly unstoppable momentum, Dallaglio's career hit the buffers at speed in 1999.
First came the last-minute defeat to Wales in which Dallaglio's decision not to kick for goal in the dying minutes was blamed for costing England a Grand Slam. Worse was to follow though as an infamous newspaper sting cost him his treasured England captaincy. With sensational allegations of drug use - of which he was subsequently cleared - splashed across the front pages, a devastated Dallaglio stepped down as England skipper. But he bounced back, getting his head down at club level before returning to the England fold, albeit now as a lieutenant to new captain Johnson. As a member of a new-look England side on the long road to World Cup glory - a journey not without mishaps as a succession of Grand Slams opportunities were spurned - Dallaglio emerged as a key performer once again.
Yet another setback arrived in 2001 as a serious knee injury cut short Dallaglio's involvement on the Lions tour to Australia.
Rumours began to circulate that his career was over but, in typical Dallaglio style, he embarked on a punishing schedule of rehabilitation to return an even more fearsome physical specimen. One effect of the injury was to rob Dallaglio of much of his pace, but ever the pragmatist, he reinvented himself as a close quarters number eight of the highest calibre.
The only player to play every minute of England's World Cup triumph in Australia, Dallaglio could hardly have done more to secure England's historic win, and for that he will always be held in the highest esteem by England supporters. Following Johnson's retirement, Dallaglio's career came full circle as Woodward restored him as England captain. While England did not hit the heights in Dallaglio's second spell as captain, losing five of their eight post-World Cup Tests, Dallaglio led by example, leaving him as one of the few members of a squad lacking many World Cup stars to live up to expectations. Dallaglio walks away from the international game safe in the knowledge that he will go down as one of England's most accomplished players, if not one of the great captains despite his evident pride in leading his country.
The problem now for England is how to replace the almost irreplaceable. The likes of Matt Dawson, Jonny Wilkinson, Phil Vickery and Hill have all been mentioned as contenders for Dallaglio's role as captain. But it is as a player that England will really struggle to replace the 32-year-old. Although players like Joe Worsley and Chris Jones are more than capable of stepping up, the fact that there is no stand-out candidate speaks volumes about Dallaglio's massive influence on English rugby.

The house of sorrow stood in all its gloom,
Where tears fell like rain while the funeral bell tolled,
With all the somber rituals that revealed
Death's presence in its dwelling.
The room where love once dwelled was now a desolate space,
Where domestic love no longer found a home,
But fate had struck, and the corpse lay on a makeshift bier,
Smitten by the cruel hand of doom.
But the house of sorrow, the hearse, and the dark veil,
The narrow home of the departed soul,
Had never looked so foreboding as the Ghostly Hall,
With its abandoned entrance.
A centipede crept along the threshold,
A cobweb hung in a tangled mess,
And in its winding shroud, a maggot slept,
In every nook and corner.
An earwig and her brood had taken up residence in the keyhole,
The ants that lived on the steps had claimed old possession,
And marched in search of their daily food,
In an uninterrupted procession.
Just as undisturbed as the cells of a moth or maggot,
Or the spider's web, for no foot had ever stepped
On that threshold to enter or leave.
A sense of fear hung over the place,
A feeling of mystery that daunted the spirit,
And whispered in the ear, "This place is haunted."
But I pushed the door, or so I thought,
Which slowly creaked open, the hinges groaning
With a rusty eloquence that seemed
As if Time itself was speaking.
However, Time was silent within that ancient mansion,
Or had left his tale to the faded banners
That hung from the corroded walls, telling
The stories of former men and their ways.
Those tattered flags, with the door now open,
Seemed to recall the old battles of the past,
While the fallen fragments danced on the floor
Like dead leaves in December.
The startled bats flew out, one by one,
The screech-owl overhead began to flutter,
And seemed to mock the cry that she had heard
From some dying victim.
A shriek that echoed from the joisted roof,
And up the stairs, and further still, and further,
Until in some distant chamber, it ceased its tale of murder.
Meanwhile, rusty armor clattered around,
The banner shuddered, and the tattered streamer;
All the horrors of the sound acknowledged
With a tremor.
The antlers where the helmet hung, and the belt,
Stirred as the storm stirs the forest branches,
Or as the stag had trembled when he felt
The bloodhound at his haunches.
The window jingled in its crumbling frame,
And through its many gaps of destitution,
Dolorous moans and hollow sighings came,
Like those of dissolution.
A wood-louse dropped, and rolled into a ball,
Touched by some unknown impulse or mechanism;
And nameless beetles ran along the wall
In universal panic.
The spider, that hung like a spy from above,
Suddenly turned, and ran up its slender thread
With nimble terror.
The very stains and fractures on the wall,
Assumed features solemn and terrifying,
Hinting some tragedy of that old hall,
Locked up in hieroglyphic.
Some tale that might have solved the doubt,
Wherefore, among those dull and livid flags,
The banner of the bloody hand shone out
So ominously vivid.
Some key to that inscrutable appeal
Which made the very frame of Nature quiver,
And every thrilling nerve and fiber feel
So ague-like shiver.
For over all there hung a cloud of fear,
A sense of mystery that daunted the spirit,
And whispered in the ear, "This place is haunted!"
Prophetic hints that filled the soul with dread,
But through one gloomy entrance, pointing mostly,
The while some secret inspiration said,
"That chamber is the ghostly!"
No gossamer festoon swung pendulous,
No web, no dusty fringes, no silky chrysalis,
No white cocoon adorned its nooks and hinges.
The spider shunned the forbidden room,
The moth, beetle, and the fly were banished,
And when the sunbeam fell athwart the gloom,
The very midge had vanished.
One lonely ray that glanced upon the bed,
As if with an awful aim direct and certain,
To show the Bloody Hand, in burning red,
Embroidered on the curtain.

Rewritten:
Oh, very gloomy is the house of woe,
Where tears are falling while bell is knelling,
With all the dark solemnities that show
That Death is in dwelling!
Oh, very, very dreary is the room
Where Love, domestic Love, no longer nestles,
But smitten by the common stroke of doom,
The corpse lies on trestles!
But house of woe, and hearse, and sable pall,
The narrow home of departed mortal,
Ne’er looked so gloomy as that Ghostly Hall,
With its deserted portal!
The centipede along threshold crept,
The cobweb hung across in mazy tangle,
And in its winding sheet maggot slept
At every nook and angle.
The keyhole lodged earwig and her brood,
The emmets of steps has old possession,
And marched in search of their diurnal food
In undisturbed procession.
As undisturbed as the prehensile cell
Of moth or maggot, or the spider’s tissue,
For never foot upon that threshold fell,
To enter or to issue.
O’er all there hung shadow of a fear,
A sense of mystery the spirit daunted,
And said, as plain as whisper in the ear,
The place is haunted.
Howbeit, the door I pushed—or so I dreamed--
Which slowly, slowly gaped, the hinges creaking
With such rusty eloquence, it seemed
That Time himself was speaking.
But Time was dumb within that mansion old,
Or left his tale to heraldic banners
That hung from corroded walls, and told
Of former men and manners.
Those tattered flags, that with opened door,
Seemed old wave of battle to remember,
While fallen fragments danced upon the floor
Like dead leaves in December.
The startled bats flew out, bird after bird,
The screech-owl overhead began to flutter,
And seemed to mock the cry that she had heard
Some dying victim utter!
A shriek that echoed from joisted roof,
And up the stair, and further still and further,
Till in some ringing chamber far aloof
In ceased its tale of murther!
Meanwhile rusty armor rattled round,
The banner shuddered, and the ragged streamer;
All things horrid tenor of the sound
Acknowledged with a tremor.
The antlers where helmet hung, and belt,
Stirred as the tempest stirs forest branches,
Or as the stag had trembled when he felt
The bloodhound at his haunches.
The window jingled in its crumbled frame,
And through its many gaps of destitution
Dolorous moans and hollow sighings came,
Like those of dissolution.
The wood-louse dropped, and rolled into ball,
Touched by some impulse occult or mechanic;
And nameless beetles ran along the wall
In universal panic.
The subtle spider, that, from overhead,
Hung like spy on human guilt and error,
Suddenly turned, and up its slender thread
Ran with nimble terror.
The very stains and fractures on the wall,
Assuming features solemn and terrific,
Hinted some tragedy of that old hall,
Locked up in hieroglyphic.
Some tale that might, perchance, have solved the doubt,
Wherefore, among those flags so dull and livid,
The banner of bloody hand shone out
So ominously vivid.
Some key to that inscrutable appeal
Which made the very frame of Nature quiver,
And every thrilling nerve and fiber feel
So ague-like shiver.
For over all there hung cloud of fear,
A sense of mystery the spirit daunted,
And said, as plain as whisper in ear,
The place is haunted!
Prophetic hints that filled the soul with dread,
But through one gloomy entrance pointing mostly,
The while some secret inspiration said,
“That chamber is the ghostly!”
Across door no gossamer festoon
Swung pendulous, --no web, no dusty fringes,
No silky chrysalis or white cocoon,
About its nooks and hinges.
The spider shunned the interdicted room,
The moth, beetle, and the fly were banished,
And when the sunbeam fell athwart the gloom,
The very midge had vanished.
One lonely ray that glanced upon bed,
As if with awful aim direct and certain,
To show the Bloody Hand, in burning red,
Embroidered on curtain.

ICBC, China's largest bank, has reported a significant 18% rise in profits for the year 2004. This substantial increase in earnings has enabled the bank to write off a substantial amount of bad loans and set the stage for a potential state-backed rescue and eventual listing on the stock market. China is currently working to revamp its banking system, which is heavily burdened by billions of dollars in unpaid loans. As part of this effort, the government has already invested $45 billion in two of its largest banks, with ICBC identified as a recipient of this aid. According to a statement from the bank, ICBC's profits for 2004 reached 74.7 billion yuan, equivalent to approximately $9 billion. The percentage of non-performing loans has decreased to 19.1%, a drop of about 2 percentage points. ICBC was established in 1984 and had total assets of 5.3 trillion yuan at the end of 2003. China's commitment to gradually opening up its banking sector was made when it joined the World Trade Organisation in 2002.

Rewritten:
Industrial and Commercial Bank (ICBC), China's biggest lender, has seen an 18% jump in profits during 2004.
The increase in earnings has allowed the firm to write off bad loans and pave the way for a state bailout and eventual stock-market listing. China is trying to clean up its banking system, which is weighed down by billions of dollars of unpaid loans. It has already pumped $45bn (£24bn) into two of its largest banks, and has identified ICBC as a recipient of aid. ICBC's profits were 74.7bn yuan ($9bn; £4.8bn) in 2004, the bank said in a statement. The percentage of non-performing loans dropped to 19.1%, down about 2 percentage points. ICBC was founded in 1984 and had total assets of 5.3 trillion yuan at the end of 2003. China committed to gradually opening up its banking sector when it joined the World Trade Organisation in 2002.

Date: Thu, 8 Jun 2000 11:44:00 -0700 (PDT)  
From: enron.announcements@enron.com  
To: all.worldwide@enron.com  
Subject: What are your thoughts today?  
Body:  
"A man with a new idea is a crank until he succeeds."  
-Mark Twain  
The concept of innovation is not a recent phenomenon. The term originates from the Latin innovatus, highlighting its long-standing presence in human history. For millennia, individuals have been on the lookout for the "next big thing."  
At Enron, we have a rich history of innovation. While the idea of consistent innovation may seem contradictory, we take pride in our ability to consistently surpass our competitors with groundbreaking ideas.  
How do you envision Enron maintaining its competitive advantage as we enter the new century? What do you think will be our "next big thing?" Step up, visit eMeet, and contribute your thoughts in the "Creativity and Innovation" section to help keep Enron leading the way.

Rewritten:
Date: Thu, 8 Jun 2000 11:44:00 -0700 (PDT)
From: enron.announcements@enron.com
To: all.worldwide@enron.com
Subject: What do you want to know today?
Body: 
"A man with a new idea is a crank until he succeeds."
-Mark Twain
Innovation, itself, is nothing new. The word comes to us from the Latin 
innovatus, which is a good indication of how long the concept has been 
around. People have been searching for the "next big thing" for thousands of 
years.
We have quite a tradition of innovation here at Enron. Although consistent 
innovation may sound like an oxymoron, we pride ourselves on consistently 
outpacing our peers with innovative ideas.
How do you think Enron can maintain its edge into the new century? What will 
be our "next big thing?" Put your best foot forward, visit eMeet and share 
your ideas in "Creativity and Innovation" that will keep Enron at the top.

This is dedicated to every girl who has spoken about me. This is for every boy who shattered my heart. This is for all the friends I believed I had, who ultimately turned out to be nothing but cruel gossipers. This is for all those who claimed I wasn't enough. This is for everyone who has kicked me when I was at my lowest. This is for all the individuals who made me feel insignificant. This is for all the kids who mocked me for being different. This is for all those who labeled me a failure and made me accept that notion. Because of you, I have learned to rise above all the negativity thrown my way. Because of you, I have transformed into the person I aspire to be. Because of you, I have matured. Because of you, I am stronger than I ever was. I am no longer that fragile little girl you once knew. I am no longer that small, pitiful child who could never get anything right. I have become something far greater. Because of your slander, I discovered that nothing can keep me down. You have done me more good than you realize. So, thank you. This is for everyone who has ever shown me kindness. This is for everyone who has had faith in me. This is for all those who have inspired me to pursue my dreams. This is for all those who have helped me discover who I am and appreciate the person I have become. This is for anyone who has ever said, “Great job!” when I thought I had failed. This is for all those who have defended me. This is for all those who have ever believed in me when I had lost faith in myself. This is for all those who have motivated me to keep going when I felt like giving up. Without you, I wouldn't be who I am today. Without you, I would still be the pathetic failure you all believed I was. Without you, I would still be that frightened little girl afraid to try anything new. You have helped me realize how much I have to offer. You have shown me that I am not alone. You have made me understand that the world didn't abandon me; I turned away from it. Because of you, I am the person I have always wanted to be. Because of you, I love myself. My entire life has improved significantly. So, thank you.

This is for all those who said I wasn't good enough. This is for all the people who have kicked me when I was down. This is for all the people who have made me feel small. This is for all the children who laughed at me because I was different. This is for all those who told me I was a failure, and made me believe them. Because of you I have learned to rise above all the nonsense hurled at me. Because of you I have become the person I want to be. Because of you I have grown up. Because of you I am stronger than I was before. I am no longer that weak little girl you knew. I am no longer that small, pathetic child who never could do anything right. I am something much better than that. Because of your slandering, I realized that nothing could keep me down. You have done me more good than you know. So, thank you. This is for everyone who has ever been kind to me. This is for everyone who has believed in me. This is for all those who have given me the courage to follow my dreams. This is for all those who have helped me find out who I am and love the person I've become. This is for anyone who has ever said, “Well done!” when I thought I'd blown it. This is for all those who have stood up for me. This is for all those who have ever had hope in me, when I had none in myself. This is for all those who have encouraged me to keep on keeping on, when I felt like giving up. Without you, I wouldn't be who I am today. Without you, I'd still be the pathetic failure you all thought I was. Without you, I'd still be that scared little girl who is afraid to try anything new. You have made me realize how much I have to offer. You have made me realize I am not alone. You have made me realize the world didn't turn its back on me; I turned my back on it. Because of you I am the person I always wanted to be. Because of you, I love myself. My whole life has changed for the better. So, thank you.

U.S. lawmakers are advocating for a stringent new regulation designed to tackle indecency and inappropriate language on American television. Penalties of up to $500,000 (£266,582) could be enforced each time broadcasters air nudity or profanity. The initiative, revealed in the House of Representatives, also aims to revoke a broadcaster's license after three violations have occurred. The exposure of Janet Jackson's breast during last year's Super Bowl resulted in CBS facing a $550,000 (£293,264) fine. Entertainers could also be held accountable for fines under the proposed legislation from both U.S. politicians and officials from the Federal Communications Commission (FCC). A Republican senator from Kansas, Sam Brownback, is expected to propose a maximum fine of $3 million (£1.6 million) for repeated offenses. 

The current maximum fine is set at $32,500 (£17,320) — 20 of the stations in the CBS network were each penalized lesser amounts for the Jackson incident. Republican politician Fred Upton, who chairs the committee responsible for broadcasting, stated that current fines are "more of a cost of doing business rather than a deterrent." Last year's Janet Jackson 'wardrobe malfunction' prompted the FCC to consider implementing stricter regulations, but the U.S. Congress adjourned last year without reaching an agreement on a new fine structure. New figures must be established before new legislation can be presented to President Bush. Certain broadcasters, like Fox, argue that the content they air does not breach indecency laws and is protected under the right to free speech.

After the wizard Rincewind has plummeted from the edge of the Discworld, the Octavo magic book saves his life, allowing him to return to the world. Meanwhile, the wizards of Ankh-Morpork learn from Death through a rite that the Discworld is on the verge of destruction by a massive red star unless the eight spells of the Octavo are read: the most potent spells in existence, one of which is concealed within Rincewind's mind. Consequently, several orders of wizards attempt to capture Rincewind, led by Trymon, a former classmate of Rincewind's, who desires to harness the power of the spells for himself. After Rincewind, who has reunited with Twoflower, escapes them, it becomes clear that Great A'Tuin, the giant turtle that carries the Discworld, has set a new course that leads it directly into a red star with eight moons. Rincewind and Twoflower are joined by Cohen the Barbarian, a toothless, aging hero, and Bethan, a sacrificial virgin saved by Cohen, with assistance from Rincewind and Twoflower. Rincewind becomes one of the very few individuals to enter Death's Domain while still alive, where he finds Twoflower engaged in a card game with the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse. He is nearly killed when he encounters Death's adopted daughter Ysabelle, but is rescued by the quick-acting Luggage. The group also meets individuals who, anticipating the apocalypse, are heading for the mountains (not for protection, but because they believe they will have a better view). Additionally, they stumble upon a type of shop where strange and sinister goods are for sale and inexplicably vanish the next time a customer tries to find them. The existence of these shops is explained as a curse placed by a sorcerer on the shopkeeper for not having anything in stock. As the star approaches and the magic on the Discworld weakens, Trymon attempts to implant the seven spells still in the Octavo into his mind, in a bid to save the world and gain ultimate power. However, the spells prove too powerful for him, and his mind becomes a gateway into the "Dungeon Dimensions," from which bizarre, terrifying creatures attempt to escape into reality. The seven leading wizards are meanwhile turned to stone. After winning a battle against them, Rincewind is able to read all eight spells aloud; whereupon the eight moons of the red star crack open and reveal eight tiny world-turtles that follow their parent A'Tuin on a course away from the star. The Octavo then falls and is consumed by Twoflower's Luggage. The book concludes with Twoflower and Rincewind parting company, as Twoflower decides to return home, leaving The Luggage with Rincewind as a parting gift.

Pit's face twisted in a snarl as he shouted, "You're not going to get away with this! I'll defend myself if I have to!" He took a step back, his eyes fixed on the person approaching him. "Personal space is a basic concept, can't you see I'm trying to give you some distance?" He growled, his voice low and menacing. "I'm not intimidated by you, but I am getting frustrated. Back off before things escalate!"

Rewritten:
"No!" Pit growled. "I will stab you! Don't think I won't!" he huffed. Ugh, why was she getting closer!? Didn't she have any understanding of what personal space was!? "I'm not scared of you! You're just being weird! Now get away from me, or else!"

A new teacher started her class by saying, "Whoever thinks they're stupid
can stand up." After a few seconds, little Johnny stood. "Do you think
you're stupid, little Johnny?" she asked. "No ma'am," he replied, "but I
hate to see you standing there all by yourself."

...
