Nicola's pet, the Sprog, escapes from the train when she's on her way back to school, and in the process, it catches a sparrow for the first time. Upon returning to the station, Nicola meets a new student, Esther Frewen, who has been sent to boarding school due to her parents' divorce. Esther is more concerned about leaving her puppy, Daks, behind than about her new surroundings. A few weeks into term, Nicola is shocked to discover that she's been left out of the Junior Netball team, a decision orchestrated by Lois Sanger, Nicola's long-time rival and the school's Games Captain. Although Nicola does get to be a soloist in the Christmas Play, she doesn't find it much consolation. During the half-term break, Nicola and her friend Patrick sneak away to visit Wade Minster, where they admire the carved falcon and enjoy a thrilling ride back over the downs. Meanwhile, back at school, Nicola is given the part of Shepherd Boy in the Christmas Play, a role that Lawrie desperately wanted. Lawrie believes that this is a betrayal of the highest order. However, when Lawrie injures her leg and can't participate in a netball match, Nicola comes up with a plan. She agrees to pretend to be Lawrie so that the team can win the match, which they do with ease. Lawrie is now convinced that she'll be the one playing the Shepherd Boy. On the day of the Play, Esther disappears, leaving a note for Nicola. Esther has gone home to prevent her mother from getting rid of Daks. Nicola, Lawrie, and their friends Tim and Miranda come up with a new plan, where Nicola will sing and Lawrie will act. Miranda, who is Jewish, agrees to fill the spare place in the procession. The staff at the Minster are shocked when they discover what's happened, and there's a sense of impending chaos. However, no one can think of a better plan. Everyone, including Grandmother and Patrick, is amazed by Nicola's singing and Lawrie's acting. Ginty and Ann play Gabriel and Mary, respectively, causing Mrs Marlow some embarrassment when she realises how much her family has dominated the production.

Rewritten:
Nicola's merlin, the Sprog, makes off from the train when she is on her way back to school, taking a sparrow for the first time in his life. Returning to the station, she finds a new girl, Esther Frewen. Esther's parents are divorced and have sent her to boarding school because she doesn't quite fit in their new lives. She is not too worried about this, but mainly about leaving her puppy, Daks, behind. A few weeks into term, Nicola, along with most of the school, is shocked to find that she has been left out of the Junior Netball team. In fact, this is the work of Lois Sanger, Nicola's old enemy and now school Games Captain. She is a soloist in the Christmas Play, but does not find this much consolation. Half-term is less fun than expected, mainly because Mrs Marlow's mother is visiting. Nicola and Patrick manage to sneak off for a day to visit Wade Minster and look at the carved falcon and then enjoy a cold, dark ride back over the downs, while Patrick recites the Lyke-Wake Dirge. Back at school, Nicola finds that she has been given the part of Shepherd Boy in the Christmas Play, the part Lawrie desperately wanted. Lawrie thinks this is treachery on a grand scale. However, when she falls and hurts her leg so that she cannot play in a netball match, she finds a possible solution. Nicola agrees to pretend to be Lawrie so that she can play in the match - which they win comfortably. Lawrie is now convinced that somehow she will be the Shepherd Boy. On the day of the Play, Esther (who is now supposed to be singing Nicola's solos) disappears, leaving a note for Nicola. She has gone home to prevent her mother getting rid of Daks. Nicola, Lawrie, and their friends Tim and Miranda agree that Nicola should go back to singing and Lawrie will act. Miranda, despite being Jewish, agrees to fill the spare place in the procession. There is a huge fuss at the Minster when the staff realise what has happened and there will clearly be "blood for breakfast" before too long. However, no-one can think of a better plan. Everyone, including Grandmother and Patrick, is amazed by Nicola's singing and Lawrie's acting. Ginty and Ann play Gabriel and Mary respectively, causing Mrs Marlow a certain embarrassment when she realises how much her family have dominated the production.

I've been struggling with depression and anxiety for a long time. I often self-harm and currently, I'm dealing with suicidal thoughts. A lot of the time, I feel like these mental health issues are my fault. I feel like I should be able to fix them on my own. I blame myself for things that my mental illness causes, like when I have a panic attack or when I can't get out of bed because I have no motivation to do anything and I sleep too much or not take care of my personal hygiene or self-harm. This semester, I'm falling behind in school and my grades aren't as good as they used to be because of how bad my mental health has gotten and I blame myself for that too. On really bad days, I physically can't get out of bed no matter how hard I try. I would just lay in bed all day and not eat, not shower, not do any work, not go to any of my classes, and completely ignore my friends and family and I hate myself so much for it because I know I can be better than this. I had a panic attack in the middle of an exam and I blamed myself for that too because I feel like I should be able to control my anxiety. There's so much I want to do but I just can't bring myself to do any of it. I just feel like everything is my fault and I feel so guilty because I feel like my life isn't that bad and I have no reason to be depressed.

Rewritten:

​b​a​d​ ​a​n​d​ ​t​h​a​t​ ​I​ ​h​a​v​e​ ​n​o​ ​r​e​a​s​o​n​ ​t​o​ ​b​e​ ​d​e​p​r​e​s​s​e​d​.​

6 boneless skinless chicken breast halves (approximately 2 pounds)  
1 1/2 cups prepared Bloody Mary mix  
2 tablespoons prepared horseradish  
2 tablespoons Worcestershire sauce  
3 tablespoons butter or 3 tablespoons margarine  
1 medium onion, chopped  
2 stalks celery, sliced  
1 cup rice  
2 ounces thin spaghetti or 2 ounces vermicelli or 2 ounces angel hair pasta, broken into 1-inch pieces (about 1/2 cup)  
2 1/2 cups hot water  
3 chicken bouillon cubes or 2 teaspoons instant bouillon granules  
1 bay leaf  
2 teaspoons grated lime zest, divided  
1/4 teaspoon black pepper  
celery leaves  
lime wedge  

Making the Chicken: In a large resealable plastic bag or a large covered bowl, mix together chicken, Bloody Mary mix, prepared horseradish, and Worcestershire; refrigerate for at least 2 hours, turning the bag occasionally. Prepare grill for low heat. Remove chicken from marinade. Grill chicken until tender, 10-15 minutes. In a small saucepan, bring marinade to a boil over medium heat; transfer sauce to a serving pitcher and set aside.  

Making the Rice: In a medium skillet, melt butter over medium-high heat. Add onion and celery to the skillet; cook for 5 minutes. Add rice and spaghetti; stir until rice is golden, about 3 minutes. Add hot water, a little at a time, to the skillet; stir in bouillon cubes, bay leaf, 1 teaspoon lime zest, and pepper. Bring rice mixture to a boil, stirring until bouillon cubes are dissolved. Reduce heat to low; cover skillet and simmer rice until tender, about 15 minutes. Remove bay leaf; stir in remaining lime zest.  

Serving the Chicken and Rice: Transfer rice to individual plates; top with chicken. Garnish with celery leaves and lime wedges; serve with reserved sauce.

Fluorescence microscopy images are made up of multiple channels, each representing a specific marker that has been applied to the sample. Given the wide variety of marker combinations used in practice, it has been difficult to apply deep learning-based segmentation models. These models typically require a predefined channel combination for both training and inference. Recent research has attempted to overcome this limitation by using a modality attention approach, which allows for effective segmentation across any possible marker combination. However, this approach still has a major drawback: it is unable to provide any estimate of segmentation quality when encountering a marker combination that does not exist in the labeled training dataset. This lack of quality assurance not only makes it difficult to evaluate the performance of the model but also hinders the allocation of additional resources for imaging and labeling. To address this issue, we propose a novel method that estimates segmentation quality on unlabeled images by (i) quantifying both the aleatoric and epistemic uncertainties of convolutional neural networks for image segmentation, and (ii) training a Random Forest model to interpret uncertainty features via regression to their corresponding segmentation metrics. Furthermore, we demonstrate that incorporating these uncertainty measures into the training process can lead to improved segmentation performance.

Rewritten:
Fluorescence microscopy images contain several channels, each indicating a
marker staining the sample. Since many different marker combinations are
utilized in practice, it has been challenging to apply deep learning based
segmentation models, which expect a predefined channel combination for all
training samples as well as at inference for future application. Recent work
circumvents this problem using a modality attention approach to be effective
across any possible marker combination. However, for combinations that do not
exist in a labeled training dataset, one cannot have any estimation of
potential segmentation quality if that combination is encountered during
inference. Without this, not only one lacks quality assurance but one also does
not know where to put any additional imaging and labeling effort. We herein
propose a method to estimate segmentation quality on unlabeled images by (i)
estimating both aleatoric and epistemic uncertainties of convolutional neural
networks for image segmentation, and (ii) training a Random Forest model for
the interpretation of uncertainty features via regression to their
corresponding segmentation metrics. Additionally, we demonstrate that including
these uncertainty measures during training can provide an improvement on
segmentation performance.

Set in 18th-century France and Louisiana, the story revolves around the heroic Chevalier des Grioux and his beloved Manon Lescaut. Born into a noble and wealthy family, des Grioux forgoes his inheritance and incurs his father's disappointment by running away with Manon. In Paris, the young lovers enjoy a blissful cohabitation, but des Grioux struggles to satisfy Manon's desire for luxury. He resorts to borrowing from his loyal friend Tiberge and cheating gamblers to make ends meet. However, his wealth frequently evaporates, prompting Manon to leave him for a richer man due to her inability to tolerate poverty.

The couple eventually settles in New Orleans, where the absence of social class differences allows them to live in idyllic peace for a while. However, when des Grioux reveals their unmarried status to the Governor and asks to be wed to Manon, the Governor's nephew sets his sights on winning her hand. In desperation, des Grioux challenges the Governor's nephew to a duel and knocks him unconscious. Believing he has killed the man and fearing retribution, the couple flees New Orleans and ventures into the wilderness of Louisiana, hoping to reach a nearby English settlement. Tragically, Manon dies from exposure and exhaustion the following morning; after burying her, des Grioux returns to France to become a cleric.

Sеt іn Frаnсе аnd Lоuіsіаnа іn thе еаrlу 18th сеnturу, thе stоrу fоllоws thе hеrо, thе Сhеvаlіеr dеs Grіеuх, аnd hіs lоvеr, Маnоn Lеsсаut. Dеs Grіеuх соmеs frоm а nоblе аnd lаndеd fаmіlу, but fоrfеіts hіs hеrеdіtаrу wеаlth аnd іnсurs thе dіsарроіntmеnt оf hіs fаthеr bу runnіng аwау wіth Μаnоn. Ιn Ρаrіs, thе уоung lоvеrs еnjоу а blіssful соhаbіtаtіоn, whіlе Dеs Grіеuх strugglеs tо sаtіsfу Маnоn's tаstе fоr luхurу. Не sсrоungеs tоgеthеr mоnеу bу bоrrоwіng frоm hіs unwаvеrіnglу lоуаl frіеnd Тіbеrgе аnd frоm сhеаtіng gаmblеrs. Оn sеvеrаl оссаsіоns, Dеs Grіеuх's wеаlth еvароrаtеs (bу thеft, іn а hоusе fіrе, еtс.), рrоmрtіng Μаnоn tо lеаvе hіm fоr а rісhеr mаn bесаusе shе саnnоt stаnd thе thоught оf lіvіng іn реnurу. Τhе twо lоvеrs fіnаllу sеttlе dоwn іn Νеw Οrlеаns, whеrе thе vіrtuаl аbsеnсе оf сlаss dіffеrеnсеs аllоws thеm fоr а whіlе tо lіvе іn іdуllіс реасе. Βut whеn Dеs Grіеuх rеvеаls thеіr unmаrrіеd stаtе tо thе Gоvеrnоr аnd аsks tо bе wеd wіth Маnоn, thе Gоvеrnоr's nерhеw sеts hіs sіghts оn wіnnіng Μаnоn's hаnd. Іn dеsраіr, Dеs Grіеuх сhаllеngеs thе Gоvеrnоr's nерhеw tо а duеl аnd knосks hіm unсоnsсіоus. Тhіnkіng hе hаd kіllеd thе mаn аnd fеаrіng rеtrіbutіоn, thе соuрlе flее Νеw Оrlеаns аnd vеnturе іntо thе wіldеrnеss оf Lоuіsіаnа, hоріng tо rеасh а nеіghbоurіng Еnglіsh sеttlеmеnt. Μаnоn dіеs оf ехроsurе аnd ехhаustіоn thе fоllоwіng mоrnіng; аftеr burуіng hеr, Dеs Grіеuх rеturns tо Frаnсе tо bесоmе а сlеrіс.

Matagarup Refugee Camp serves as a political demonstration against the Western Australian Government's intention to shut down numerous Aboriginal remote communities and provide a safe space for Noongar homeless individuals. Matagarup is the Noongar term for Heirisson Island, located in the heart of Perth. On March 1, 2015, over 100 Aboriginal protesters and homeless individuals set up a "refugee protest" camp on Heirisson Island in response to the State Government's threat of enforced closures of small remote communities. The City of Perth Shire has denied the protesters the right to camp, protest, and shelter the homeless. Between March and August 2015, the City of Perth conducted nine raids on the island camp, typically accompanied by a significant police presence, confiscating the tents and belongings of the campers and the homeless. During some of these raids, police have been accused of "excessive use of force." Some of the raids resulted in police arresting campers, issuing move-on notices, and court appearances, but the campers and the homeless continue to return. Each time, the camp has re-established itself, led by Nyungah Elder Bella Bropho, who has been camping on the island since March 1, 2015. Bropho stated that the homeless camp had to be defended "because if this fails, I don't know where the people are going to go."

Sarah Moyle (born 14 September 1969) is a British actress, recognized for her performances as Linda Fawcett in various stage adaptations of Jerusalem and Valerie Pitman in the BBC soap opera Doctors. Moyle also took on the recurring character of Caroline Swann in the ITV soap opera Emmerdale. For her portrayal of Valerie in Doctors, Moyle received the Best Comedic Performance award at the 2019 British Soap Awards. Career Moyle received her training at Bodywork Dance Studios, holds a B.A. in Performance Art from Middlesex University, and spent six months studying at the State University of New York. From 1988 to 1991, she was part of the National Youth Theatre. Moyle launched her career in 1992 with theatre roles, her debut being in Lust at Theatre Royal Haymarket, directed by Bob Carlton. In the early stages of her career, Moyle played parts in An Inspector Calls, Oliver!, Les Misérables, and My Fair Lady. Her stage work also features roles in Drowning on Dry Land and Private Fears in Public Places, which were written for her by Sir Alan Ayckbourn. In 2010, Moyle took on the role of Linda Fawcett in Jerusalem at the Royal Court Theatre and the Apollo Theatre, before bringing it to Broadway at the Music Box Theatre.

We are examining a natural variation of a specific part of propositional logic, known as the implicational fragment. The formulas in this variation consist of pairs of conjunctions of positive statements, connected by a special type of implication. The meaning of this implication is determined by a threshold on the probability of the consequence occurring given the premise. This concept is referred to as confidence in partial implications or association rules in the data analysis community.

Previous studies on redundancy among these partial implications have focused on cases where there is entailment from one premise and from two premises, both in isolation and when additional classical implications are present (referred to as "relative entailment").

By leveraging an alternative perspective on entailment, which involves linear programming duality, we have identified the exact cases of entailment from any number of premises, both in isolation and when additional classical implications are present.

As a result, we have developed decision-making algorithms with improved complexity. Furthermore, for each potential case of entailment, we have identified a critical confidence threshold that is inherent to each set of premises and the conclusion's antecedent.

Rewritten:
We study a natural variant of the implicational fragment of propositional
logic. Its formulas are pairs of conjunctions of positive literals, related
together by an implicational-like connective; the semantics of this sort of
implication is defined in terms of a threshold on a conditional probability of
the consequent, given the antecedent: we are dealing with what the data
analysis community calls confidence of partial implications or association
rules. Existing studies of redundancy among these partial implications have
characterized so far only entailment from one premise and entailment from two
premises, both in the stand-alone case and in the case of presence of
additional classical implications (this is what we call "relative entailment"). 

By exploiting a previously noted alternative view of the entailment in terms of
linear programming duality, we characterize exactly the cases of entailment
from arbitrary numbers of premises, again both in the stand-alone case and in
the case of presence of additional classical implications. 

As a result, we
obtain decision algorithms of better complexity; additionally, for each
potential case of entailment, we identify a critical confidence threshold and
show that it is, actually, intrinsic to each set of premises and antecedent of
the conclusion.

The story unfolds in London. Morose, a rich elderly man with an intense aversion to noise, intends to disinherit his nephew Dauphine by getting married. He believes his bride Epicœne to be an exceptionally quiet woman; however, he is unaware that Dauphine has orchestrated the entire arrangement for his own reasons. The marriage takes place despite the well-meaning attempts of Dauphine's friend True-wit to intervene. Soon after the wedding, Morose begins to regret his decision, as his home is overrun by a noisy celebration that includes Dauphine, True-wit, and Clerimont; a bear warden named Otter and his spouse; two foolish knights, La Foole and Daw; along with a group of "collegiates," pretentious women who are vain and scheming. To Morose's dismay, Epicœne quickly shows herself to be a loud and nagging partner. In his desperation for a divorce, Morose seeks advice from two lawyers (who are actually disguised agents of Dauphine), but they find no valid reasons to dissolve the marriage. Ultimately, Dauphine agrees to provide grounds for the divorce (in return for a financial settlement from Morose). Once the deal is struck, Dauphine reveals Epicœne's true identity by removing her female attire, exposing that she is actually a boy. Morose is dismissed with disdain, and the other absurd characters are unsettled by this revelation; for example, Daw and Foole had boasted about having been intimate with Epicœne.

Rewritten:
The play takes place in London. Morose, a wealthy old man with an obsessive hatred of noise, has made plans to disinherit his nephew Dauphine by marrying. His bride Epicœne is, he thinks, an exceptionally quiet woman; he does not know that Dauphine has arranged the whole match for purposes of his own. The couple are married despite the well-meaning interference of Dauphine's friend True-wit. Morose soon regrets his wedding day, as his house is invaded by a charivari that comprises Dauphine, True-wit, and Clerimont; a bear warden named Otter and his wife; two stupid knights, La Foole and Daw; and an assortment of "collegiates," vain and scheming women with intellectual pretensions. Worst for Morose, Epicœne quickly reveals herself as a loud, nagging mate. Desperate for a divorce, Morose consults two lawyers (actually Dauphine's men in disguise), but they can find no grounds for ending the match. Finally, Dauphine promises to reveal grounds to end the marriage (in exchange, Morose must come to financial terms with him). The agreement made, Dauphine strips the female costume from Epicœne, revealing that the wife is, in fact, a boy. Morose is dismissed harshly, and the other ludicrous characters are discomfited by this revelation; Daw and Foole, for instance, had claimed to have slept with Epicœne.

Date: Thu, 27 Sep 2001 19:18:58 -0700 (PDT)  
From: 40enron@enron.com  
Subject: EnTouch Newsletter  
Body:  

BUSINESS HIGHLIGHTS  
Enron Global Markets  
Washington, DC -- The Society of the Plastics Industry Inc. (SPI), which represents one of the largest manufacturing sectors in the United States, has announced a strategic partnership with Enron Global Markets LLC (EGM). This collaboration aims to jointly promote financial products for price risk management that will assist plastics processors in navigating the financial risks linked to resin price fluctuations.  
As a result of this agreement, SPI members will gain direct access to EGM's expertise in the plastics sector and the financial products currently available in the market. Furthermore, SPI and EGM will host specialized seminars tailored to the specific needs of SPI members on effectively managing price risks. As part of Enron's collaboration with SPI, we will organize a series of risk management seminars focused on the industry.  
Plastics companies are currently facing various challenges, including rising raw material and energy costs, as well as economic factors beyond their control, such as sluggish demand. The financial products offered by EGM can, for instance, set or cap a maximum resin price for a specified duration, enabling companies to make more informed business decisions and enhance financial stability.  

EGM Crude and Products Fundamentals  
The EGM Crude and Products Fundamentals team is excited to announce the introduction of its new "Morning Briefing" report. This report is designed to provide traders, mid marketers, and originators with a detailed yet succinct overview of the factors affecting the oil and products markets over the past 24 hours and their potential impact on the market for the upcoming day. In addition to significant news items, the report includes essential market data such as prices, MMBtu curves, refinery outages, open interest analysis, and other market-driving information. The report will be updated daily by 7:30 a.m. and can be accessed on the Crude and Products Fundamentals intranet at <http://egmfundy.corp.enron.com/crude/> under In House Analysis, Morning Briefing.  

EES Business Center  
The Business Center is now prepared to receive and monitor all customer leads and service issues. EES requires a single point of contact for all customer inquiries and issues to guarantee customer satisfaction. Effective immediately, please direct all general inquiry calls to our Business Center to ensure each customer receives consistent and effective support. The Center's contact number is 800-337-7827 (800-EES-SVCS), or calls can be transferred to x59390. You can also reach them via email at EESBusinessCenter@enron.com.  
If an account, partner, utility, or vendor's actions impact EES' interests, an URGENT ISSUE request should be submitted without delay. Such actions may include changes in credit ratings, bankruptcy filings, high-risk shut-off notices, health and safety issues, potential litigation, etc. Please file the relevant information by phone or email and mark it as an URGENT ISSUE to allow the Business Center to respond promptly.  

EWS Business Analysis and Reporting  
Enron Wholesale Services (excluding Net Works) currently has nearly 1350 invoices amounting to almost $12 million awaiting coding and approval in the iPayit system. Over 900 invoices have been in the system for more than 30 days. While a company-wide task force is working to enhance the overall process, each of us must contribute to ensure timely and accurate payments to our vendors.  
Here are the statistics for invoices in the system that have been outstanding for more than 30 days:  
ENA 443 invoices totaling $4.3 million  
EBS 358 invoices totaling $4.6 million  
EGM 87 invoices totaling $262,000  
EIM 33 invoices totaling $123,000  
If you are responsible for purchasing items that generate invoices (including cell phones, pagers, etc.) or for coding and approving invoices, you will receive an email notification when an invoice arrives in your iPayit inbox. You must log in to iPayit and take the necessary action. No one else can process the invoice for payment while it remains in your iPayit inbox.  
We expect EWS to remain current and process invoices within 5 days of notification. We will continue to monitor the status of accounts payable and anticipate significant improvements by the end of September.  
For assistance with outstanding invoices, please reach out to Christa Winfrey at christa.winfrey@enron.com.  

IN THE NEWS  
Judge Postpones California Refund Report Until March 8  
Washington, Sept. 25 (Bloomberg) -- The judge responsible for recommending whether Enron Corp., Duke Energy Corp., and other power sellers owe California up to $8.9 billion in refunds for electricity sales has delayed his recommendations until March 8.  
Federal Energy Regulatory Commission administrative judge Bruce Birchman stated

Date: Thu, 27 Sep 2001 19:18:58 -0700 (PDT)

Subject: EnTouch Newsletter
Body: 
 
BUSINESS HIGHLIGHTS
Enron Global Markets
Washington, DC -- The Society of the Plastics Industry Inc. (SPI), the trade association representing one of the largest manufacturing industries in the United States, announced that it has entered into a strategic alliance with Enron Global Markets LLC (EGM), to jointly promote price risk management financial products that will help plastics processors in managing financial risks associated with resin price volatility.
Through this agreement, SPI members will have direct access to EGM's experience in the plastics industry and to the financial products the company currently offers to the market. In addition, SPI and EGM will offer special seminars uniquely tailored to the needs of the SPI membership on effectively managing price risk. As part of Enron's partnership with SPI, we will conduct a series of industry-specific risk management seminars. 
Companies in the plastics industry today face a number of challenges such as rising costs in raw material and energy, and economic factors beyond their control including slow demand. Financial products being offered by EGM can, for example, fix or establish a maximum resin price for a given period of time, thereby allowing the companies to make better business decisions and improve financial stability.
EGM Crude and Products Fundamentals
The EGM Crude and Products Fundamentals team is proud to announce the launch of its new "Morning Briefing" report. The report is aimed at providing traders, mid marketers and originators with a detailed yet concise overview of factors impacting the oil and products markets in the previous 24 hours and how these factors are likely to affect the market in the coming day. In addition to market moving news items, the report contains key market data such as prices, MMBtu curves, refinery outages, open interest analysis and various other market driving information. The report is updated by 7.30 a.m. each day and can be found on the Crude and Products Fundamentals intranet at <http://egmfundy.corp.enron.com/crude/> under In House Analysis, Morning Briefing.
EES Business Center 
The Business Center is ready to receive and track all customer leads and service issues. EES needs a single point of entry for all customer calls and issues to ensure customer satisfaction. Starting today, please route all general inquiry calls to our Business Center to provide each customer with consistent and effective assistance. The number for the Center is 800-337-7827 (800-EES-SVCS) or calls can be transferred to x59390. You may also contact them through e-mail at EESBusinessCenter@enron.com. 
In the event that an account, partner, utility or vendor's activity affects EES' interests, an URGENT ISSUE request should be filed immediately. Such activity includes change in credit rating, bankruptcy filings, high risk shut-off notices, health and safety concerns, possible litigation, etc. File the relevant information by either phone or e-mail and note it as an URGENT ISSUE to enable the Business Center to act immediately. 
EWS Business Analysis and Reporting
Enron Wholesale Services (excluding Net Works) has nearly 1350 invoices totaling almost $12 million waiting for coding and approval in the iPayit system. Over 900 invoices have been in the system greater than 30 days. Although a company-wide task force is working to improve the entire process, each of us needs to do our part to ensure accurate and timely payment to our vendors. 
Following are the statistics on invoices in the system greater than 30 days:
ENA	443 invoices totaling $4.3 million
EBS	358 invoices totaling $4.6 million
EGM	 87 invoices totaling $262,000
EIM	 33 invoices totaling $123,000 
If you purchase items that generate invoices (including cell phones, pagers, etc.), or if you are responsible for coding and approving invoices, you will receive an e-mail notification that an invoice has arrived in your iPayit inbox. You must log on to iPayit and take the appropriate action. No one else can process the invoice for payment while it is in your iPayit inbox. 
We expect EWS to stay current and process the invoice within 5 days of notification. We will continue to monitor the status of accounts payable and expect to see significant improvement by the end of September.
If you need assistance processing outstanding invoices, please contact Christa Winfrey at christa.winfrey@enron.com. 
IN THE NEWS 
Judge Delays California Refund Report Until March 8
Washington, Sept. 25 (Bloomberg) -- The judge who will recommend whether Enron Corp., Duke Energy Corp. and other power sellers owe California as much as $8.9 billion in refunds for electricity sales has postponed his recommendations until March 8.
Federal Energy Regulatory Commission administrative judge Bruce Birchman said today that California's grid operator needs more time to collect information about power sales during the October-through-January refund period. This is the second time he postponed his report. Birchman originally said he would make his recommendations to the commission by Nov. 5, then delayed it to Dec. 13.
California demanded the refunds, charging that the power sellers inflated electricity prices. Power providers blame the fourfold increase in the average price of power in California from January to June compared with a year earlier on supply not keeping up with demand.
``I'm not surprised the judge is having trouble finding evidence because I don't think that refunds are due from anybody,'' Enron spokesman Mark Palmer said.

CHAIRMAN'S AWARD 2001
Do you have a colleague that deserves to be recognized for their dedication and commitment to Enron's core values - Respect, Integrity, Communication, Excellence? The 2001 Chairman's Award is your chance to put forward someone you know who really captures the spirit, philosophy and the day-to-day business practices of our company in their work, their attitude and in how they regard their colleagues. All Enron employees can nominate fellow employees at any level - from the top down or bottom up.
The nomination process is simple. Submit a completed nomination form, available on <http://home.enron.com> by Wednesday October 10, 2001. The award winner and finalists will be announced at the annual Enron Management Conference in San Antonio, Texas on November 16, 2001.

Enron Wholesale Services Best Practice Tips
United Parcel Service (UPS) After Hours Drop Boxes are Open
The Enron Building drop box is located near the automated teller machine. The last pick up is 8:00 PM. 
The Three Allen Center drop box is located behind the down escalator on the ground floor by the self-service postal center. The last pick up is 7:45 PM.
Drop boxes handle letters and boxes up to 18"x13"x3" and can be shipped via Next-Day Air, Second-Day Air, Third-Day Select, UPS International and UPS World-Wide Express Service. Be sure to include the Enron account number, and your company and cost center number in the reference field on the shipping documentation.
For more information, contact Glenn Lewis (GSS) at 713-646-7512.
United Parcel Service (UPS) is Enron's preferred vendor for express deliveries. 
NEWS FROM THE GLOBAL FLASH
Enron Commences Authorization Process for New Power Plant in Italy
Enron has begun an application procedure to get the necessary consent to develop a natural gas fired combined cycle gas turbine (CCGT) power station of up to 1,200MW on a 10-hectare site 1.5km from Roveleto di Cadeo, in the Comune of Cadeo, in the Province of Piacenza (NorthEast Italy). The following consents must be received before Enron's proposals for a power station can be implemented:
- Decree of Environmental Compatibility from the Ministry of the Environment, 
- Authorization to construct and operate the plant from the Ministry of Industry
- All other necessary local and national permits for construction and operation of the plant, including administrative authorizations and power and gas line connections.
The authorization process is expected to take around two years, such that construction could begin in early 2004, with operation 30-36 months from construction start. However, the decision to proceed with construction of the project will remain contingent on further developments in the liberalization of the Italian power and gas markets.
 "This is the first time one of our Italian asset development projects has moved forward since our jointly-owned Sarlux IGCC (Integrated Gasification Combined Cycle) plant in Sardinia went into full commercial operation in December 2000," says Ross Sankey who is leading Enron's Cadeo project team. "We're pleased to have identified such a suitable site for a new power plant and continue to assess other similar opportunities."
GasMarktFax Stirs "Trouble" in German Incumbent-dominated Gas Market
Following on from a recent GlobalFlash! report on the launch of GasMarktFax by the German origination team we are pleased to provide the following update on the impact the product is beginning to have on the German gas market: 
European Spot Gas Markets reported on Thursday, 13 September, that Ruhrgas will decrease prices for their Stadtwerke and regional gas companies as of 1 October. The article mentions that it is clear that Ruhrgas is taking competition seriously and that last month's release of Enron's GasMarktFax provided Stadtwerke with the opportunity to compare their standard price to Enron offers. "Pricing pressure pushes incumbents to lower their tariffs," said Helge-Jurgen Beil, director with the German origination team, who lead the GasMarktFax initiative. "However, it is important to note that incumbents try to crowd out marginal supplies and abuse their dominant supplier position. Grid access is still cumbersome and only very few customers have a real choice," Helge-Jurgen added.
Enron Signs First Trading Deal in Poland
Enron's Polish team have signed the company's first ever trading deal in the country - which is also the first transaction entered into by a Polish power trading company based on the EFET (European Federation of Energy Traders) Master Trading Agreement.
The 50MW deal is with PKE, currently Poland's largest generator by installed capacity, responsible for around 17% of total energy production in Poland.
The deal with PKE is effectively a series of 51 call options, each one of them being a separate option for 50MW of baseload power for any given calendar month. Enron is the buyer of this series of options. The first month for which Enron will have a call option will be October 2001, and the last will be December 2005. The exercise date for each option is 26 days before the beginning of the delivery month. The strike prices follow a pre-determined schedule.
"This pioneering agreement sets new standards of power trading in Poland," declares Jarek Dybowski, Enron's director of power trading in Poland.
"This deal has set a precedent and created a platform for us to further break into the bilateral wholesale electricity trading market in Poland," adds Jarek Astramowicz, Enron's vice-president and head of the Polish office. A big thank you to Jarek Dybowski, Tomasz Krzyzewski, Sid Cox, Marcus Zwinger, Pat Cini and Jason Clatworthy and all the others who helped make this deal possible."
EBS Celebrates Neos Deal
Congratulations to EBS who secured a deal with Neos, a company that specialises in providing bandwidth within London and other UK cities (known as metro connectivity). The transaction gives Enron instant access to London's metro network, which expands Enron's coverage. The agreement involves a ?3 million take or pay commitment over ten years, with Enron receiving fixed prices and degradation for the capacity.
 
Marcello Romano, Vice President Bandwidth Trading, is delighted: "We needed to close a strategic deal to increase our metro coverage. Not only has this been achieved but the team negotiated well below market prices."
Launch of Nordic precipitation index
In another first for Enron, this week saw the launch by Enron Nordic Energy of a precipitation index based on rainfall levels in a number of locations. The index will serve as a new weather trading instrument bringing more choice to the weather market and thereby promoting market liquidity. Given the close relationship existing between precipitation levels and power prices in the Nordic region, the index will be of interest to both power traders and large hydro producers. The index will serve as a new trading instrument enabling power traders to add to and refine their positions. For the large hydro producers, the index will provide a benchmark for hedging their risk against fluctuations in rainfall. The index will be based on a large number of locations available throughout the Nordic region, with 27 locations in all (19 in Norway and 8 in Sweden).
On the very day of the index launch, we were able to announce the completion of a deal with Norsk Hydro whereby we have constructed a specific index enabling Norsk Hydro to hedge its production volumes throughout the Nordic region. 
Given the amount of hydroproduction in the Nordic region - approximately 99% (116TWh/yr) in Norway and 50% (64TWh/yr) in Sweden - the index is likely to be of significant interest in the Nordic market. In Norway and Sweden, about 70% of the supply side is hydro and the volume of this supply can deviate by around 10% from normal (and by up to 30% during extreme years). The subsequent impact on prices is huge and the variation in produced volumes is of great concern to hydro producers.

Akihime spun around, her voice laced with urgency as she called out, "Wha Ama, what's happening?!" She quickly turned to follow the sound of her friend's voice, but her movement was halted abruptly as a dark, copper-colored blur suddenly materialized before her. Before she could even process what was happening, a soft thud echoed through the air, and when she turned to look, she saw that her own arm had been knocked loose. Her eyes widened in shock, and a trembling gasp escaped her lips as she stared at the gaping wound where her arm once was, her scream building in intensity.

Rewritten:
"Wha Ama, what's going on?!" Akihime called and moved after her, only to stop when a black and copper blur appeared before her. Before she even knew what happened, there was a gentle thud on her left side, and when she looked she saw it was her own arm. Her eyes widened and she let out a shaky gasp before screaming, holding the gushing void where her arm once was.

The widow, Leonora Eyre, is a delightful and sophisticated, yet self-centered woman in her middle age. She forms a friendship with two antique dealers, Humphrey Boyce and his nephew James. Both men find her appealing, but her interest leans more towards James, who is youthful and handsome. However, when James is away on a buying trip, she becomes upset to discover him with Phoebe, a girl his own age. In retaliation, she seeks Humphrey's assistance to embarrass Phoebe and evicts a tenant so that James can occupy a room in her home, seemingly to exert control over him. Meanwhile, during his travels, James has been involved with an American named Ned, who arrives in London to meet Leonora. Ned deceives James into abandoning Leonora, only to spurn him for another. James tries to mend their relationship, but Leonora is hesitant to give him another opportunity to hurt her and instead opts for the affection of the less appealing Humphrey. As is typical in Pym’s novels, there are numerous literary references, particularly to Keats, Milton, and Henry James.

Rewritten:
The widow, Leonora Eyre, is a charming and elegant, but selfish middle-aged woman. She becomes friendly with two antique dealers, Humphrey Boyce and his nephew James. Both are attracted to her, but she is attracted more to James, who is young and good-looking. But while James is away buying, she is angered to find him with Phoebe, a girl of his own age. She enlists the help of Humphrey to humiliate her, and turns out a tenant so that James can take a room in her house, apparently in order to control him. But while abroad, James had been seeing an American, the amoral Ned, who comes to London to see her. Ned tricks James into leaving Leonora, only to reject him again for someone else. James attempts a reconciliation, but Leonora is afraid to allow him another chance to hurt her, and settles for the affections of the less attractive Humphrey. As with all Pym’s books, there are many literary allusions, especially to Keats, Milton and Henry James.

    john.viverito@enron.com, carol.clair@enron.com  
Debra:  
As Debra and I talked about, we are in the process of drafting a GISB contract for GPU Services Company, acting as an agent for ______. I informed Debra that when we deal with a counterparty represented by an agent in transactions, we aim to incorporate the attached agency riders into the master agreement. These riders contain representations and warranties concerning the agent's authority, along with an acknowledgment from the principal regarding the same. I suggest that you all take the attached riders into account when formulating master agreements in an agency context.  
If the counterparty is open to it, I strongly recommend that you propose the principal sign the contract on its own behalf, with the contract simply stating that the agent is authorized to conduct transactions under the agreement for and on behalf of the principal. This is the strategy I plan to pursue with GPU. If an agent represents several principals, attempt to establish a separate master agreement with each principal. However, if the counterparty is completely against this approach, at the very least, I would include the riders and obtain acknowledgments from the principal(s). If there are multiple principals, strive to secure a distinct agreement with the agent for each principal (rather than a single master with an agent representing multiple principals) to prevent any confusion regarding transaction allocation and credit risks.  
Please don’t hesitate to reach out with any questions or feedback.  
I have also attached a memorandum I prepared previously that outlines various considerations when managing an agency relationship.  
Leslie

In this study, we examine the fundamental modal logics $\mathbf{K}$, $\mathbf{T}$, $\mathbf{K4}$, and $\mathbf{S4}$, and investigate their sub-propositional components. Specifically, we analyze the classical Horn fragment, the Krom fragment, and the core fragment, which is the intersection of the Horn and Krom fragments, as well as their sub-fragments that restrict the use of boxes and diamonds in clauses. Our primary focus is on the relative expressiveness of these languages. To achieve this, we develop a suitable measure of expressiveness and establish a complex hierarchy that encompasses all fragments of the considered logics. Following this, we observe the limited expressiveness of the Horn fragments without diamonds and proceed to investigate the computational complexity of their satisfiability problem. We demonstrate that, in general, this problem becomes polynomial.

Rewritten:
In this paper, we consider the well-known modal logics $\mathbf{K}$,
$\mathbf{T}$, $\mathbf{K4}$, and $\mathbf{S4}$, and we study some of their
sub-propositional fragments, namely the classical Horn fragment, the Krom
fragment, the so-called core fragment, defined as the intersection of the Horn
and the Krom fragments, plus their sub-fragments obtained by limiting the use
of boxes and diamonds in clauses. We focus, first, on the relative expressive
power of such languages: we introduce a suitable measure of expressive power,
and we obtain a complex hierarchy that encompasses all fragments of the
considered logics. Then, after observing the low expressive power, in
particular, of the Horn fragments without diamonds, we study the computational
complexity of their satisfiability problem, proving that, in general, it
becomes polynomial.

A murder in 17th-century Oxford is depicted through the conflicting perspectives of four characters, all of whom serve as unreliable narrators. The story unfolds in 1663, shortly after the monarchy's restoration following the English Civil War, during a time when King Charles II's authority is still being established, and conspiracies are rampant. Most of the characters are based on historical figures. Two of the narrators are the mathematician John Wallis and the historian Anthony Wood. Other characters include the philosopher John Locke, the scientists Robert Boyle and Richard Lower, the spy master John Thurloe, and the inventor Samuel Morland. Initially, the plot focuses on the death of Robert Grove but later expands to include the conspiracies of John Mordaunt and William Compton (of Compton Wynyates), as well as the political maneuvers of Henry Bennet and Lord Clarendon. Additionally, the fictional characters are nonetheless inspired by real events. The narrative of Sarah Blundy intertwines with that of Anne Greene, while Jack Prestcott is involved in events drawn from the life of Richard Willis (of the Sealed Knot). The book is an epistolary novel. The accounts are penned many years after the events they recount, following Thomas Ken gaining his bishopric but before the death of Henry Bennet. This places them in 1685, the final year of Charles' reign. A contrasting portrayal in the novel is, on one hand, a philosophy rooted in ancient and medieval learning, and, on the other, the scientific method that was beginning to be applied in physics, chemistry, and medicine.

The following text is a repetitive sequence of the word "Money" with varying levels of indentation. It appears to be a deliberate attempt to convey a sense of abundance or excess, but its meaning is unclear without further context.

The text begins with a single line of "Money" repeated multiple times, followed by lines with increasing indentation. This pattern continues for several lines, with the indentation decreasing and increasing in a seemingly random manner.

The text then repeats this pattern several times, with the same sequence of indentation and repetition of the word "Money". The overall effect is one of monotony and repetition, with the word "Money" becoming increasingly meaningless as it is repeated ad infinitum.

Without further context or explanation, it is difficult to say what the author intended to convey with this text. However, it is possible that the author was attempting to make a point about the excesses of capitalism or the devaluation of money in modern society. Alternatively, the text may simply be a form of experimental writing or a commentary on the nature of language itself.

Sakaida Kakiemon, also known as Sakaida Kizaemon (1596 — 1666), was a Japanese potter who created the style that later became known as Kakiemon. He collaborated with Higashijima Tokué and was responsible for producing the first enameled porcelain in Japan. Biography Sakaida Kakiemon began his porcelain business after the decline of the Ming dynasty in China, which led to the disruption of traditional Chinese porcelain exports to Europe. It is said that Sakaida Kakiemon learned the technique of enameled porcelain from a Chinese artisan in Nagasaki in 1643. He was the first in Japan to practice overglaze enameling (applying enamel on top of the glazing), a technique that originated in China during the Kangxi era of the Qing dynasty. He also improved the method for creating a translucent white glaze, known as nigoshide. In the Arita dialect, nigoshide describes the water used to wash rice, thus referring to the translucent white of nigoshide. In contrast to other Arita ware, which often has a bluish tint, nigoshide exhibits virtually no bluish cast.

Jacob Allen Abel (born November 18, 1987) is an American actor. He has featured in film adaptations of the young adult novels Percy Jackson (2010–2013), I Am Number Four (2011), and The Host (2013), in addition to portraying musician Mike Love in the biographical drama Love & Mercy (2014). Beyond film, he played the recurring role of Adam Milligan on the CW series Supernatural (2009–2010; 2019–2020). Abel was also a series regular in the first season of the Netflix science fiction drama Another Life (2019). 

Life and career  
Abel was born in Canton, Ohio, to Kim and Mike Abel. He has a brother named Shaun. His first credited role was in the Disney Channel Original Movie Go Figure, where he played Spencer. He later had a recurring guest role on CBS's short-lived science fiction series, Threshold. He has made numerous guest appearances in shows including Cold Case and ER. He was honored with a Rising Star award at the 16th Hamptons International Film Festival in October 2008 for his performance in the film Flash of Genius. In 2009, Abel briefly appeared in the Peter Jackson film The Lovely Bones, based on Alice Sebold's novel. He also had a regular role in the web series Angel of Death, which ran for 10 episodes.

... LET’S DISCUSS The 77th Annual Academy Awards will take place on February 27, and actors from around the globe will once again be on edge to find out who will take home the honors this year. But how did this event evolve from its humble origins? The inaugural Academy Awards were held in 1929 at a relatively simple dinner at the Hollywood Roosevelt Hotel, located just a short distance from its current location. At that time, around 250 guests were present, and tickets were priced at just $5. The first best picture award was given to “Wings,” a silent film featuring Clara Bow. For nearly a decade afterward, the names of the winners were disclosed to newspapers at 11 p.m. However, in 1940, the Los Angeles Times published the winners' names at 8:30 p.m., meaning that even those at the ceremony were aware of the results beforehand. This controversy led to the implementation of the sealed envelope system, creating the suspenseful event we know today. The ceremony continued to be held at a dinner until 1942, when it became impractical to host the awards in a hotel. The event was then relocated to a theater, with the famous Chinese Theater being the first to accommodate the larger gathering. The awards were also presented at the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion and the Shrine Auditorium, but they are currently held at the 6,500-seat Kodak Theatre, which opened across the street from the original site in 2002. From 1929 until 1954, the awards ceremony took place on Thursdays, then shifted to Mondays and Wednesdays before finally settling on Sunday nights. The date has varied each year, moving from May to April, then to March, and now to February. The first televised ceremony occurred in 1953, hosted by Bob Hope. The origin of the name “Oscar” is somewhat unclear. A common theory is that academy librarian Margaret Herrick commented that the statuette resembled her Uncle Oscar, and a journalist overheard her remark and used the name in an article. It is believed that the first instance of the word “Oscar” appearing in print was in a column by Sidney Skolsky, reviewing Hepburn’s first win in 1934. The name became widely accepted, and in 1939, the Academy officially adopted it. The statuette was crafted by MGM art director Cedric Gibbons, and since the awards began, 2,550 Oscars have been awarded. During World War II, the statuette was made of zinc instead of gold, but once the war ended, the material was switched back to gold. In 2000, fifty-five golden statuettes were stolen en route to the ceremony, but after nine days, fifty-four were recovered. The originals were destroyed, and new ones were quickly produced. The academy was established in 1927 as a non-profit organization, initially with 36 members from various sectors of the film industry. After the first ceremony in 1929, the membership grew to 1,099, and today it stands at 5,670. New members are invited on an invitation-only basis, with criteria for acceptance including film credits that meet the academy's high standards, having been nominated for an Oscar, receiving special merit, and making significant contributions to the industry. While the Academy has honored many of the most significant films and filmmakers, several classics have emerged without receiving nominations, such as Hobson’s Choice, Dirty Harry, The 39 Steps, King Kong, and Homage to the Wind. Numerous actors have also been overlooked, including Al Jolson in The Jazz Singer in 1927, Humphrey Bogart in Casablanca in 1944, Gene Kelly in Singing in the Rain in 1952, and Henry Fonda in Twelve Angry Men in 1957. Many others, including Alfred Hitchcock, despite five nominations, were never acknowledged for their contributions to the horror genre. However, in 1968, he received an honorary Oscar for his extensive work in that field. The glamorous event has never been interrupted by a single war. There were calls to cancel the 2003 ceremony due to the Iraq war, but since the event had continued during World War II and the Vietnam War, it proceeded. Nevertheless, Michael Moore, nominated for best documentary, used his speech to speak out against the American invasion. The ceremony itself was subdued, with many women opting for dark dresses. During World War II, the ceremony was postponed only three times. In 1938, it was delayed for a week due to a significant flood, and two days were added to the schedule to honor Martin Luther King Jr. The ceremony was also postponed for twenty-four hours in tribute to President Reagan, who had just been shot. Subsequently, George C. Scott declined to accept his Oscar in protest, claiming it was all a farce. In 1935, writer Dudley Nichols rejected his award for writing The Inside Man due to a strike by the Writers Guild of America. In 1973, Marlon Brando refused to accept

LET’S DISCUSS The 77th Annual Academy Award event will be held on February 27, and movie stars all over the world will be on tenterhooks once again to see who will win the awards this year. But how did the show grow from its modest beginnings? The first Academy Awards were presented in 1929 at a relatively low-key dinner at the Hollywood Roosevelt Hotel, just down the street from its present venue. At the time, only about 250 people attended, and tickets cost a mere $5. The first best picture award went to “Wings,” a silent film starring Clara Bow. For about ten years thereafter, the names of the winners were released to the newspapers at 11 p.m. However, in 1940 the Los Angeles Times printed the names of the winners at 8:30 p.m., so even those attending the ceremony knew the outcome in advance. The resulting scandal led to the introduction of the sealed envelope system, resulting in the suspenseful show we have today. The ceremony was held at a dinner until 1942, when it became impractical to hold the awards ceremony in a hotel. The ceremony was moved to a theater, with the iconic Chinese Theater being the first to host the enlarged event. The awards were also held at the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion and the Shrine Auditorium, but today they are presented at the 6,500-seat Kodak Theatre, which opened across the street from the original venue in 2002. From 1929 until 1954, the awards ceremony was held on a Thursday, but then moved to Mondays and Wednesdays until finally settling on Sunday nights. The date, however, was changed each year, from May to April, then to March and now to February. The first televised ceremony was held in 1953, with Bob Hope as host. The origins of the name “Oscar” are unclear. A popular explanation is that the academy librarian Margaret Herrick remarked that the statuette looked like her Uncle Oscar, and a journalist overheard the comment and used the name in an article. It is said that the first time the word “Oscar” was printed in a newspaper was in a column by Sidney Skolsky in a review of Hepburn’s first win in 1934. The name stuck, and in 1939 the Academy formally adopted it. The statuette was designed by MGM art director Cedric Gibbons, and 2,550 Oscars have been handed out since the awards began. It was cast in zinc rather than gold during World War II, but as soon as the war was over, the casts were changed to gold. In 2000, fifty-five of the golden statuettes were stolen on their way to the ceremony, but after nine days, fifty-four were found. The originals were destroyed and new ones hurriedly cast. The academy was founded in 1927 as a non-profit organization, with 36 members representing various fields in film. After the first ceremony in 1929, the number of members was increased to 1,099, and today there are 5,670. There is an invitation-only, by-invitation-only policy for new members, and among the criteria for acceptance are film credits that reflect the high standards of the academy, having been nominated for an Oscar, earning special merit, and making a notable contribution to the industry. While the Academy has recognized a long list of the biggest films and film-makers, there are still a number of movies that have become classics without being nominated for an award, including Hobson’s Choice, Dirty Harry, The 39 Steps, King Kong, and Homage to the Wind. A number of actors have also gone unrecognized, including Al Jolson in The Jazz Singer in 1927, Humphrey Bogart in Casablanca in 1944, Gene Kelly in Singing in the Rain in 1952, and Henry Fonda in Twelve Angry Men in 1957. There have been many others, including Alfred Hitchcock, who despite five nominations was never recognized for his achievements in horror. But in 1968 he was given an honorary Oscar for his many contributions to the horror genre. The glittering event has not been interrupted by a single war. There were calls for the 2003 ceremony to be cancelled because of the war in Iraq, but since the ceremony had not been cancelled during World War II or the Vietnam War, it went on. But Michael Moore, who was nominated for best documentary, did not allow the war to be forgotten when he used his speech to denounce the American invasion. The ceremony itself was muted, and the glitter was turned down. Many of the women wore dark dresses. During World War II, the ceremony was postponed only three times. In 1938 it was postponed for a week because of a great flood, and two days were added to the scheduled date to honor Martin Luther King Jr. In honor of President Reagan, who had just been shot, the ceremony was postponed for twenty-four hours. Subsequently, George C. Scott refused to accept his Oscar in protest because he said it was all a farce. In 1935, writer Dudley Nichols turned down his award for writing The Inside Man because of a strike by the Writers Guild of America. In 1973 Marlon Brando refused to accept his best actor award for The Godfather in protest of the way he felt the industry was discriminating against Native Americans. Rather, he sent in an impersonator named Sacheen Littlefeather, who was a fictitious character, who was actually the actress Maria Cruz. The next year Robert Osborne turned up at the ceremony wearing only a black bathrobe, flashing a peace sign and making a number of gestures. In his acceptance speech he mentioned, among other things, the death of President Nixon. It was on that occasion that Osborne was assassinated. Then in 1934, when Frank Capra was the presenter, he opened up his envelope, said, “The winner is Frank, and the winner is...” and announced, “Frank Lloyd!” Frank Capra immediately jumped up to the stage, only to realize it was not him but Frank Lloyd who had won for Cavalcade. Capra swore he would never attend the ceremony again, but the next year he went to accept his award for It Happened One Night.

This article discusses the demographic characteristics of Niger's population, covering aspects such as population density, ethnic groups, education levels, public health, economic conditions, religious beliefs, and other population-related factors. The predominant ethnic groups in Niger are the Hausa, who are also the largest ethnic group in northern Nigeria, and the Zarma Songhai (alternatively spelled Djerma-Songhai), who inhabit certain regions of Mali as well. Both of these groups are settled farmers residing in the fertile southern region. The Kanouri (which includes Beri Beri and Manga) represent the majority of the settled population in the far southeast of the country. The rest of the Nigerien population consists of nomadic or semi-nomadic herding communities—Tuareg, Fulani, Toubou, and Diffa Arabs. With rapidly increasing populations and the resulting competition for limited natural resources, the lifestyles of these two groups have increasingly clashed in Niger in recent years. A small number of white French individuals reside in the country, a remnant of Niger's history as a former French colony.

Rewritten:
This article is about the demographic features of the population of Niger, including population density, ethnicity, education level, health of the populace, economic status, religious affiliations and other aspects of the population. The largest ethnic groups in Niger are the Hausa, who also constitute the major ethnic group in northern Nigeria, and the Zarma Songhai (also spelled Djerma-Songhai), who also are found in parts of Mali. Both groups are sedentary farmers who live in the arable, southern tier. The Kanouri (including Beri Beri, Manga) make up the majority of sedentary population in the far southeast of the nation. The remainder of the Nigerien people are nomadic or seminomadic livestock-raising peoples—Tuareg, Fulani, Toubou and Diffa Arabs. With rapidly growing populations and the consequent competition for meager natural resources, lifestyles of these two types of peoples have come increasingly into conflict in Niger in recent years. Some white French people live in the country due to Niger being a former colony of France.

The Gun Seller narrates the tale of Thomas Lang, a former Army officer who leads a somewhat precarious life in London, primarily preoccupied with consuming whisky and riding his motorcycle. His earnings come from various roles as a bodyguard, enforcer, and mercenary, leveraging the expertise and connections he acquired during his military service. When approached in Amsterdam by a man requesting him to kill American businessman Alexander Woolf, Lang tries to alert Woolf at his Belgravia residence, only to find Woolf absent and instead confronts (and subdues) a mercenary, later meeting Woolf's daughter, Sarah. Subsequently, Lang finds himself under close observation from both the Ministry of Defence and the Central Intelligence Agency, who assert that Woolf is an international drug trafficker currently being investigated. Curious about the sudden attention from two government entities, Lang sets out to locate the man who contacted him in Amsterdam, unexpectedly discovering him in London, and even more surprisingly, realizing that the man is Alexander Woolf himself. Eventually, Woolf and his daughter agree to dine with Lang to address his inquiries. The elder Woolf reveals that he sought to hire Lang as a hitman to assess his character and acknowledges that he is under investigation, but not for drug trafficking. Instead, Woolf is of interest due to his knowledge of a next-generation light attack helicopter. More alarmingly, Woolf and Sarah assert that a conspiracy is in motion to orchestrate a terrorist attack and subsequently promote the light helicopter by deploying it to eliminate the terrorists. Lang is doubtful, but begins to accept the narrative after he is kidnapped and interrogated about Woolf. He manages to escape, discovering a severely tortured Alexander Woolf in a nearby room. Woolf is killed shortly after as Lang flees, taking out his captors in the process. With Sarah missing and now convinced the conspiracy is genuine, Lang seeks to identify the main conspirators, assisted by a friend of Sarah's named Ronnie. After some investigation, he focuses on a CIA Deputy Director named Barnes, who forcibly brings him to meet the chief conspirator: billionaire Naimh Murdah. Murdah, the owner of the helicopter manufacturing company, openly acknowledges the scheme and bluntly states that Lang will be involved in executing the terrorist attack, reinforcing his statement with a direct threat to Sarah's life. To emphasize his point, Murdah casually kills a CIA agent who accompanied Lang and Barnes to his residence. Lang is integrated into a small terrorist group called the Sword of Justice as a Minnesotan named Ricky, officially to gather intelligence and reduce casualties. A Dutch politician appears to be shot dead by Lang in Switzerland as a preliminary exercise for the Sword of Justice, although it was staged, and the politician was briefed and wearing body armor. During a brief return to London, Lang encounters Sarah and confronts her about photographs, provided by his friend and handler Solomon, showing Sarah and Barnes together. Sarah confesses to being part of the conspiracy but insists her father's death was never part of the plan. Lang and the Sword of Justice arrive in Casablanca and successfully seize control of the American embassy there, taking several hostages. Barnes, Murdah, Sarah, and other conspirators arrive in Casablanca to oversee Lang and ensure the plot's success. Lang discreetly exits the Embassy as instructed, but as Murdah speaks to him, Lang draws a gun, which Sarah had slipped to him as part of a plan they devised in London. Lang forces Murdah into the Embassy at gunpoint and handcuffs him to a fire escape on the roof, then demands he call off the helicopter attack. Murdah refuses, confident that the attack will not proceed since he is in danger, but Lang argues that the greed of the remaining conspirators will guarantee the attack goes ahead. Just as Lang anticipated, the helicopter strikes, killing one of the terrorists, but before it can make another pass, Lang shoots it down with a Javelin missile he had smuggled into the embassy earlier. Footage of the helicopter's assault and destruction is broadcast worldwide by news networks covering the siege, obliterating any chance of military investment in the helicopter. Lang issues a statement (through the terrorists) to CNN detailing the conspiracy, ensuring the plot is foiled. The Ministry of Defence flies a weary Lang and Solomon back to England. Upon landing, Lang is welcomed by Ronnie, who managed to persuade the Ministry to allow her to accompany him from the airport, and she makes it clear that she is delighted to see him.

Rewritten:
The Gun Seller tells the story of retired Army officer Thomas Lang, who lives a somewhat hand-to-mouth existence in London, his attention focused mainly on drinking whisky and driving his motorcycle. His income stems from a variety of bodyguard, strong-arm and mercenary jobs he undertakes, utilizing the skills he learned and contacts he made during his time in the Army. After being approached in Amsterdam by a man asking him to assassinate American businessman Alexander Woolf, Lang attempts to warn the intended victim at his Belgravia flat, finding Woolf gone and instead clashing with (and incapacitating) a mercenary, then encountering Woolf's daughter Sarah. Afterward Lang finds himself under intense scrutiny from both the Ministry of Defence and the Central Intelligence Agency, who claim Woolf is an international drug smuggler currently under investigation. Intrigued by the sudden interest of two government agencies, Lang attempts to track down the man who approached him in Amsterdam, unexpectedly finding him in London, and even more unexpectedly discovering that the man is Alexander Woolf himself. Eventually Woolf and his daughter agree to meet Lang at dinner and answer his questions. The elder Woolf explains that he tried to hire Lang as a hitman to see if he was a "good man", and admits he is under investigation, but not for selling drugs. Rather, Woolf is of interest because of what he knows about a next-generation light attack helicopter. More disturbingly, Woolf and Sarah claim that a conspiracy is under way to stage a terrorist attack and subsequently promote the light helicopter by sending one in to eliminate the terrorists. Lang is skeptical, but begins to believe the story after he is kidnapped and interrogated about Woolf. He frees himself, finding a heavily tortured Alexander Woolf in a nearby room. Woolf is killed shortly thereafter as Lang makes his escape, killing his captors in the process. With Sarah missing and now certain the conspiracy is real, Lang attempts to determine the main conspirators, aided by a friend of Sarah's named Ronnie. After some investigating he centers on a CIA Deputy Director named Barnes, who (forcibly) takes him to meet the head conspirator: billionaire Naimh Murdah. Murdah, owner of the company that manufactures the helicopter, openly admits to the plot and plainly states that Lang will be helping to carry out the terrorist attack, backing up his declaration with an open and explicit threat on Sarah's life. To illustrate his point, Murdah casually kills a CIA agent who accompanied Lang and Barnes to his home. Lang is placed within a small terrorist group called the Sword of Justice as a Minnesotan named Ricky, officially in order to gather intelligence and minimize casualties. A Dutch politician is seemingly shot dead by Lang in Switzerland as a warm up activity by the Sword of Justice, although it was a set-up and the politician was briefed and was wearing body armour. During a brief return to London Lang encounters Sarah and confronts her regarding pictures, provided to him by his friend and handler Solomon, showing Sarah and Barnes together. Sarah admits to being a part of the conspiracy, but swears her father's death was never part of the arrangement. Lang and Sword of Justice arrive in Casablanca and successfully take control of the American embassy there, holding a number of hostages. Barnes, Murdah, Sarah, and a number of other conspirators arrive in Casablanca to direct Lang and ensure the success of the plot. Lang covertly leaves the Embassy as directed, but as Murdah is talking to him Lang pulls a gun, slipped to him by Sarah as part of a plan they made in London. Lang forces Murdah into the Embassy at gunpoint and handcuffs him to a fire escape on the roof, then orders him to call off the helicopter attack. Murdah refuses, certain the attack will not come since he is in the line of fire, but Lang contends the greed of the remaining conspirators will ensure the attack goes as planned. Just as Lang predicted, the helicopter attacks, killing one of the terrorists, but before it can make another pass Lang shoots it down with a Javelin missile he smuggled into the embassy earlier. Footage of the helicopter's attack and destruction is shown worldwide via news networks covering the siege, ruining any chance of any military investing in the helicopter. Lang releases a statement (via the terrorists) to CNN outlining the conspiracy, ensuring that the plot is thwarted. The Ministry of Defence flies a tired Lang and Solomon back to England. After landing Lang is greeted by Ronnie, who managed to force the Ministry to allow her to ride with him from the airport, and makes it quite clear she is happy to see him.

Despite her best efforts, Belle couldn't shake the sensation that someone was observing her. She glanced around, feeling out of place in such an environment. The queen...she had cast a spell on them all. Why did everything seem so ordinary inside the castle? It baffled her completely. Nel eagerly indulged in the refreshments, urging Belle to join him as he consumed a fair amount of wine. She poured herself a glass, mostly to calm her nerves. It provided only slight relief. To please her father and avoid being impolite, she nibbled on a few slices of fruit and a small piece of cheese as well. Her stomach rumbled in response, accepting the food. She felt quite nauseous from the anxiety.

Rewritten:
Try as she might, Belle couldn't shake the feeling that she was being watched. She looked around her, feeling strange in such a place. The queen...she'd cursed them all. Why were things so normal on the inside of the castle? She didn't understand it at all. Nel gladly partook of the refreshments, encouraging Belle to do the same as he drank quite a bit of wine. She poured herself a glass and drank it mostly to settle her nerves. It only helped a little. To appease her father and not appear rude, she had a few slices of fruit and a small piece of cheese as well. Her stomach growled as it accepted them. She was quite queasy from the fear.

It's a chilly winter in Boston, and Peter's second-hand bookstore has a sign that reads, "Come in and browse - it's warm inside." The sign catches the attention of Martin Jones, who is not only cold but also being chased by the police because his former boss, Professor North, has accused him of stealing $50,000 from the Anthropology Society. Inside the bookstore, he meets a former teacher from his days at Meredith Academy; Leonidas Weatherall, "the man who looks like Shakespeare," who had lost all his money in the 1929 stock market crash and has become the bookstore's janitor. The bookstore's new owner is a pretty young redhead who is connected to Jones' acquaintance.

After a book thief and a car accident outside, Professor North's body is discovered in the religion section. Under Weatherall's supervision, the group, which soon includes a wealthy Boston dowager, North's sassy maid, Gertrude, and Gertrude's mobster boyfriend, Freddy, spends the evening tracking down clues to the murderer's identity and trying to stay out of the clutches of Freddy's rival gang. Under Weatherall's supervision, the group solves the murder and forces a confession from the murderer just in time to save Jones from the police.
