How individuals access their digital entertainment in the future may undergo significant changes, following the introduction of an ambitious European initiative. Last week in Nice, the European Commission unveiled its Networked & Electronic Media (NEM) project. This initiative encompasses a wide range of aspects, from media creation to distribution and playback. The Commission aims to enable users to easily find the content they want and have it delivered effortlessly, whether they are on the go, at home, or at work, regardless of the device, network, content provider, or content protection method involved. Over 120 experts gathered in Nice to discuss the vision of a connected future and to hear commitments of support from companies like Nokia, Intel, Philips, Alcatel, France Telecom, Thomson, and Telefonica. It may seem surprising that competing companies are eager to collaborate, but speakers consistently emphasized that incompatible, isolated solutions are unlikely to succeed. A comprehensive strategy for the advancement and convergence of technologies and services will be essential. 

The European Commission is taking a practical approach. They recognize that various groups have already outlined the forms of digital media relevant to the NEM initiative. The NEM strategy involves thoroughly examining existing resources and upcoming developments, selecting the best options, and identifying any gaps. When gaps are found, the initiative will create standards to address them. Notably, it is significant that such a large and influential organization has expressed its intention for digital formats to be accessible to everyone and compatible with any device. This is likely to please, if not surprise, many individuals and user organizations who believe that the preferences of content rights holders are often prioritized over those of consumers. Many consider that the most challenging aspect for the Commission will be finding a solution for the various Digital Rights Management (DRM) systems. Currently, DRM solutions are incompatible, restricting certain types of purchased content and rendering them unplayable across different platforms. With the potential to capture a share of every media transaction globally, the opportunity for the provider of the leading DRM system is substantial. While entertainment is an obvious starting point, the initiative will also extend to remote healthcare services, energy efficiency, and smart home management. The 85-year plan consolidates the efforts of numerous ongoing research projects that the EC has been funding for several years. 

Simon Perry serves as the editor of the Digital Lifestyles website, which explores the influence of technology on media.

Rewritten:
How people receive their digital entertainment in the future could change, following the launch of an ambitious European project.
In Nice last week, the European Commission announced its Networked & Electronic Media (NEM) initiative. Its broad scope stretches from the way media is created, through each of the stages of its distribution, to its playback. The Commission wants people to be able to locate the content they desire and have it delivered seamlessly, when on the move, at home or at work, no matter who supplies the devices, network, content, or content protection scheme. More than 120 experts were in Nice to share the vision of interconnected future and hear pledges of support from companies such as Nokia, Intel, Philips, Alcatel, France Telecom, Thomson and Telefonica. It might initially appear to be surprising that companies in direct competition are keen to work together. But again and again, speakers stated they could not see incompatible, stand-alone solutions working. A long-term strategy for the evolution and convergence of technologies and services would be required.
The European Commission is being pragmatic in its approach. They have identified that many groups have defined the forms of digital media in the areas that NEM encompasses. The NEM approach is to take a serious look at what is available and what is in the pipeline, pick out the best, bring them together and identify where the gaps are. Where it finds holes, it will develop standards to fill them. What is significant is that such a large and powerful organisation has stated its desire for digital formats to be open to all and work on any gadget. This is bound to please, if not surprise, many individuals and user organisations who feel that the wishes of the holder of rights to content are normally considered over and above those of the consumer. Many feel that the most difficult and challenging area for the Commission will be to identify a solution for different Digital Rights Management (DRM) schemes. Currently DRM solutions are incompatible, locking certain types of purchased content, making them unplayable on all platforms. With the potential of having a percentage of every media transaction that takes place globally, the prize for being the supplier of the world's dominant DRM scheme is huge. Although entertainment is an obvious first step, it will encompass the remote provisions of healthcare, energy efficiency and control of the smart home. The 85-year plan brings together the work of many currently running research projects that the EC has been funding for a number of years.
Simon Perry is the editor of the Digital Lifestyles website, which covers the impact of technology on media

Adam Goldman is a talented composer, music producer, and artist based in Los Angeles. He is widely recognized for his work as a songwriter and producer for the art-pop band Fol Chen, which released three albums on Sufjan Stevens's Asthmatic Kitty label between 2009 and 2013. The band's unique sound, characterized by a blend of dark and whimsical elements, earned them a dedicated following. Goldman has also been involved with other notable projects, including serving as the songwriter and singer for the chamber pop band Bedroom Walls and as a touring guitarist for Liars during their 2008 tour, which featured Radiohead as the headlining act.

In addition to his work with Fol Chen, Goldman has produced albums for Andrew Bird and Simone White, and has remixed songs by Junior Vasquez and David Bowie. He has also paid tribute to Prince by recording a cover of one of his songs for Spin magazine. Furthermore, Goldman has composed music for the CBS primetime drama The Code.

In the realm of film and television, Goldman has made a significant impact. In 2019, he began scoring the CBS military-legal drama The Code, which was created by Craig Sweeny and Craig Turk. He has also scored the documentary film Knock Knock, It's Tig Notaro for Showtime and co-wrote the score to Patrik-Ian Polk's feature film Noah's Arc: Jumping the Broom. Additionally, Goldman has provided songs for the Noah’s Arc television series on Logo TV. He has collaborated with director Lauren Greenfield on two nonfiction projects, including Beauty CULTure (co-written with Julian Wass as Fol Chen), which was commissioned by the Annenberg Space for Photography. Goldman's songs have been featured in a range of television shows, including Weeds (Showtime), CSI:NY (CBS), Elementary (CBS), The Mindy Project (FOX), This American Life (Showtime), The 4400 (USA Network), and One Nation Under Dog (HBO). His commercial work includes music composed for prominent brands such as Visa, Hyundai, and Canon.

Rewritten:
Adam Samuel Goldman is a Los Angeles–based composer, music producer, and artist. He is best known as songwriter and producer for the art-pop band Fol Chen, which released three albums on Sufjan Stevens's Asthmatic Kitty label from 2009 to 2013 and was noted for its "instantly unique blend of dread and whimsy." He was songwriter and singer for chamber pop band Bedroom Walls and touring guitarist for Liars on their 2008 tour opening for Radiohead. 

Goldman has produced albums for Andrew Bird and Simone White, remixed songs by Junior Vasquez and David Bowie, and covered Prince for Spin magazine. 

He is composer for the CBS primetime drama The Code. 

Film and Television 
In 2019, Goldman began scoring the CBS military-legal drama The Code, created by Craig Sweeny and Craig Turk. 

He scored the documentary film Knock Knock, It's Tig Notaro for Showtime and co-wrote the score to Patrik-Ian Polk's feature film Noah's Arc: Jumping the Broom, as well as providing songs for the Noah’s Arc television series on Logo TV. He has twice scored nonfiction projects for director Lauren Greenfield, including Beauty CULTure (co-written with Julian Wass as Fol Chen), commissioned by the Annenberg Space for Photography. Goldman's songs have been used in the television shows Weeds (Showtime), CSI:NY (CBS), Elementary (CBS), The Mindy Project (FOX), This American Life (Showtime), The 4400 (USA Network) and One Nation Under Dog (HBO). Goldman's commercial work includes music composed for Visa, Hyundai, and Canon.

Rewritten:
Date: Wed, 17 May 2000 08:17:00 -0700 (PDT)
From: john.lavorato@enron.com
To: johnlavorato@palm.net
Subject: 
Body: 
test

Do not think this paper is written in vain, 
hoping to stir your pity or lament the wrong.
I am well aware of your hardened heart;
no gentle mercy will take my side,
nor will a woman's arguments prevail,
even if your patron's wise example fails.
However, I still have one last right;
the oppressed and injured always have the right to complain.
Too, the strict laws of honor bind the weak and submissive sex of women.
If our sighs have been enough to move our hands, 
or if we have been forced by stern commands,
whatever the reason that binds us to this fate,
the world expects us to be constant in our judgment.
Just heaven, where justice reigns, 
though the name is often profaned on earth.
To you, I appeal, and submit my case,
without fear of a judgment from impartial laws.
All agreements are conditional, 
and if one party is deceived, the other is not paid;
servants who are defrauded are free from their service,
and a wounded slave regains his liberty.
For wives who are mistreated, there is no remedy,
they are condemned to daily suffering and eternal chains.
From where does this unjust distinction come?
Are we not formed with the same passions as you?
Nature has given us equal fire in our souls,
our minds are just as proud, and our blood is just as warm;
you pursue your pleasures across the world,
but we must suffer in silence and be true.
Our sex's weakness is exposed and blamed by you,
(it is a common theme among foolish people).
Yet, from this weakness, you suppose that we possess a higher virtue than your Cato knew.
If heaven had intended for us to face such severe trials,
it would have formed our temperaments to bear them.
And I have borne (oh, what have I not borne!)
the pang of jealousy, the insults of scorn.
Weary at last, I have removed myself from your sight,
and placed my future hopes in secret love.
In the prime of my youth, I have retired from the world,
and given up the joy of being admired,
with the small pension that your hard heart allows,
I renounce your fortune and release your vows.
To custom, though unjust, we owe a debt;
I hide my frailty from the public view.
My conscience is clear, yet I am aware of shame,
I risk my life to preserve my reputation.
And I prefer this low and inglorious state
to vile dependence on the thing I hate --
but you pursue me to this last refuge.
Dragged into the light, my tender fault is exposed,
and every circumstance of my fondness is known.
You stand beneath the shelter of the law,
and use your cruel hand to urge my ruin,
while you are rigidly severe towards my fault,
and timidly submissive to the man you fear.
This wretched outcast, this abandoned wife,
has yet this joy to sweeten her shameful life:
by your mean conduct, you are at once my accuser and excuse.
Let me be condemned by the censorious and prudish,
(stupidly dull or spiritually lewd),
my unfortunate case will surely find pity
from every just and reasonable mind.
When I submit to the final sentence,
the lips condemn me, but their souls acquit.
No more will you be my husband,
and pursue your pleasures; 
you will know the sweets of your recovered freedom.
Go: court the friendship of the great,
smile at their table, or wait at their levee;
and when dismissed, fly to madam's toilet,
more than her chambermaids or glasses lie,
tell her how young she looks, how heavenly fair,
admire the lilies and the roses there.
Your high ambition may be satisfied,
you may marry a cousin of hers,
and you will be the father of a glorious race
endowed with Ch------l's strength and Low---r's face.

Rewritten:
Think not this paper comes with vain pretense
To move your pity, or to mourn th'offense.
Too well I know that hard obdurate heart;
No softening mercy there will take my part,
Nor can a woman's arguments prevail,
When even your patron's wise example fails.
But this last privilege I still retain;
Th'oppressed and injured always may complain.
Too, too severely laws of honor bind
The weak submissive sex of womankind.
If sighs have gained or force compelled our hand,
Deceived by art, or urged by stern command,
Whatever motive binds the fatal tie,
The judging world expects our constancy.
Just heaven! (for sure in heaven does justice reign,
Though tricks below that sacred name profane)
To you appealing I submit my cause,
Nor fear a judgment from impartial laws.
All bargains but conditional are made;
The purchase void, the creditor unpaid;
Defrauded servants are from service free;
A wounded slave regains his liberty.
For wives ill used no remedy remains,
To daily racks condemned, and to eternal chains.
From whence is this unjust distinction grown?
Are we not formed with passions like your own?
Nature with equal fire our souls endued,
Our minds as haughty, and as warm our blood;
O'er the wide world your pleasures you pursue,
The change is justified by something new;
But we must sigh in silence -- and be true.
Our sex's weakness you expose and blame
(Of every prattling fop the common theme).
Yet from this weakness you suppose is due
Sublimer virtue than your Cato knew.
Had heaven designed us trials so severe,
It would have formed our tempers then to bear.
And I have borne (oh what have I not borne!)
The pang of jealousy, the insults of scorn.
Wearied at length, I from your sight remove,
And place my future hopes in secret love.
In the gay bloom of glowing youth retired,
I quit the woman's joy to be admired,
With that small pension your hard heart allows,
Renounce your fortune, and release your vows.
To custom (though unjust) so much is due;
I hide my frailty from the public view.
My conscience clear, yet sensible of shame,
My life I hazard, to preserve my fame.
And I prefer this low inglorious state
To vile dependence on the thing I hate --
But you pursue me to this last retreat.
Dragged into light, my tender crime is shown
And every circumstance of fondness known.
Beneath the shelter of the law you stand,
And urge my ruin with a cruel hand,
While to my fault thus rigidly severe,
Tamely submissive to the man you fear.
This wretched outcast, this abandoned wife,
Has yet this joy to sweeten shameful life:
By your mean conduct, infamously loose,
You are at once my accuser and excuse.
Let me be damned by the censorious prude
(stupidly dull, or spiritually lewd),
My hapless case will surely pity find
From every just and reasonable mind.
When to the final sentence I submit,
The lips condemn me, but their souls acquit.
No more my husband, to your pleasures go,
The sweets of your recovered freedom know.
Go: court the brittle friendship of the great,
Smile at his board, or at his levee wait;
And when dismissed, to madam's toilet fly,
More than her chambermaids, or glasses, lie,
Tell her how young she looks, how heavenly fair,
Admire the lilies and the roses there.
Your high ambition may be gratified,
Some cousin of her own be made your bride,
And you the father of a glorious race
Endowed with Ch------l's strength and Low---r's face.

"The Owl and the Pussycat" is a whimsical tale that revolves around four endearing animal characters - an owl, a cat, a pig, and a turkey. The story revolves around the enchanting romance between the title characters, who decide to tie the knot in a mystical land known as the home of the Bong-tree. The Owl and the Pussycat embark on a romantic sea voyage in a charming pea green boat, equipped with a sweet treat and a substantial amount of money wrapped in a five-pound note. As they sail, the Owl serenades the Pussycat under the starry night sky, strumming a small guitar and admiring her beauty. The Pussycat responds by praising the Owl's singing and describes him as an "elegant fowl." She then suggests they get married, but they realize they don't have a wedding ring. They set sail for a year and a day to find the perfect ring, eventually discovering a pig with a ring in his nose in a nearby wood. They purchase the ring for a shilling and get married the very next day by a turkey officiant. After their wedding, they enjoy a delightful meal of mince and quince using a unique runcible spoon, and then dance hand-in-hand on the sandy beach under the moonlight. Interestingly, a portion of an unfinished sequel titled "The Children of the Owl and the Pussycat" was published posthumously in 1938.

Rewritten:
"The Owl and the Pussycat" features four anthropomorphic animals – an owl, a cat, a pig, and a turkey – and tells the story of the love between the title characters who marry in the land "where the Bong-tree grows". The Owl and the Pussycat set out to sea in a pea green boat with honey and "plenty of money" wrapped in a five pound note. The Owl serenades the Pussycat while gazing at the stars and strumming on a small guitar. He describes her as beautiful. The Pussycat responds by describing the Owl as an "elegant fowl" and compliments him on his singing. She urges they marry but they don't have a ring. They sail away for a year and a day to a land where Bong-trees grow and discover a pig with a ring in his nose in a wood. They buy the ring for a shilling and are married the next day by a turkey. They dine on mince and quince using a runcible spoon, then dance hand-in-hand on the sand in the moonlight. Portions of an unfinished sequel, "The Children of the Owl and the Pussycat", were first published posthumously in 1938.

Date: Thu, 7 Sep 2000 10:17:00 -0700 (PDT)
From: eugenio.perez@enron.com
To: john.lavorato@enron.com, john.sherriff@enron.com, jeffrey.shankman@enron.com, 
	ted.murphy@enron.com, mark.frevert@enron.com, rick.buy@enron.com, 
	sally.beck@enron.com, shona.wilson@enron.com
Subject: Four New Graphs

We have developed four new graphs to be included in our daily reports, 
alongside the DPR. These graphs focus on risk-adjusted return, which is 
crucial in our diverse markets with varying risk characteristics and 
Enron's differing risk appetites. To compare returns fairly, we need to 
consider the risk involved. Our approach is to divide return by a measure 
of risk, effectively standardizing return numbers (how many dollars we 
earn for every dollar we put at risk).

The Return on VaR (ROVAR) graph displays the average daily total profit 
and loss (P&L) divided by the average daily Value at Risk (VaR) for each 
business unit or commodity group. A higher ROVAR indicates better 
performance relative to other business units. Each business unit has two 
bars: a dark blue bar on the left shows the ROVAR on a 4-week rolling 
basis, and a light blue bar on the right shows the ROVAR on a 1-week 
rolling basis. The 1-week ROVAR is more sensitive and can fluctuate 
frequently.

The Sharpe Ratio graph is similar in concept, showing the average daily 
curve shift P&L (both delta and gamma) divided by its standard deviation. 
This Sharpe ratio is uncomplicated by non-trading P&L (like new deals, 
reserves, and so forth). Unlike VaR, which is a forward-looking statistic, 
standard deviation is a backward-looking measure of actual volatility. 
Each business unit has two bars: a dark brown bar on the left showing the 
Sharpe ratio on a 4-week rolling basis, and a light brown bar on the right 
showing the ratio on a 1-week basis.

The Curve Shift P&L Sharpe Ratio and the ROVAR graphs complement each other 
well, measuring different aspects of performance. If our P&L is composed 
mostly of curve shift, and if our VaR closely predicts curve shift 
volatility, the two statistics should be very close.

To provide a more detailed view of the actual magnitude of the P&L 
relative to the risk, we have created the Risk - Return graphs. On the 
vertical axis, they show the 4-week rolling average P&L. On the horizontal 
axis, they show the 4-week rolling average VaR. The various business units 
are plotted as points on the graphs. These graphs are closely related to the 
4-week ROVARs, in that the vertical value of every point divided by its 
horizontal value is the business unit's ROVAR (average P&L / average VaR). 
Another way of looking at these graphs is that the slope of a line 
connecting the origin (0,0) with the plotted point of a business unit is 
its ROVAR. Books with small risks and returns (< $2 million) are plotted on 
the "Small" graph, and the rest, on the "Large".

These graphs are based on the DPR Database that we built to standardize 
and capture the information reported in the DPR. Most, but not all of the 
information in the DPR currently flows from the database. As a result, we 
do not have ROVARs or Sharpe Ratios for every business unit. As we continue 
to set up exports into the database, we will fill in the missing numbers.

We will e-mail you these graphs every day until we can publish them on the 
intra-net. Please remember to launch the file in Excel, instead of using 
the Lotus Notes viewer. The VaR Limit Usage graphs that we created last 
week are already on the web. We hope that you find all of these useful.

Regards,
Eugenio Perez

Rewritten:
Date: Thu, 7 Sep 2000 10:17:00 -0700 (PDT)
From: eugenio.perez@enron.com
To: john.lavorato@enron.com, john.sherriff@enron.com, jeffrey.shankman@enron.com, 
	ted.murphy@enron.com, mark.frevert@enron.com, rick.buy@enron.com, 
	sally.beck@enron.com, shona.wilson@enron.com
Subject: Four New Graphs
Body: 
Cc: michael.moscoso@enron.com, maria.aguilera-peon@enron.com, 
	jennifer.nguyen@enron.com
Bcc: michael.moscoso@enron.com, maria.aguilera-peon@enron.com, 
	jennifer.nguyen@enron.com
We have created four additional graphs to be published daily along with the 
DPR: 
Return on VaR (ROVAR)
Curve Shift P&L (Delta - Gamma) Sharpe Ratio
Risk - Return (Large)
Risk - Return (Small)
All of these graphs deal with the concept of risk-adjusted return. The 
markets in which we operate have unlike risk characteristics. Furthermore, 
Enron's appetite for risk also differs in each market. As a result, it is 
difficult to compare returns in absolute terms. Therefore, the approach of 
these graphs is to divide return by a measure of risk, in effect restating 
return numbers into a standard base (how many dollars we earn for every 
dollar we put at risk).
 For each business unit or commodity group, the ROVAR graph shows an average 
of daily total P&L divided by an average of daily VaR. Higher ROVARs 
indicate better performance (relative to other business units). For each 
business unit or commodity group there are two bars: the dark blue on the 
left shows ROVAR on a 4 week (20 business day) rolling basis, and the light 
blue on the right shows ROVAR on a 1 week (5 business day) rolling basis. 
Because of the shorter term, the 1 week ROVAR is more sensitive: it can be 
quite high or low, and it changes frequently.
The Sharpe Ratio graph is very similar in concept; it shows an average of 
daily curve shift P&L (both delta and gamma) divided by its standard 
deviation. This Sharpe ratio is uncomplicated by non-trading P&L (like new 
deals, reserves, and so forth). Furthermore, whereas VaR is a forward 
looking statistic (the most we are likely to lose in one day with a given 
probability), standard deviation is backward looking (the actual volatility 
of our returns over the period). This graph also has two bars for every 
business unit or commodity group: a dark brown on the left showing the Sharpe 
ratio on a 4 week rolling basis, and a light brown on the right showing the 
ratio on a 1 week basis.
The Curve Shift P&L Sharpe Ratio and the ROVAR graphs complement each other 
well. They measure different things, but if our P&L is composed mostly of 
curve shift, and if our VaR closely predicts curve shift volatility, the two 
statistics should be very close.
Sometimes it is interesting to see the actual magnitude of the P&L relative 
to the risk. We therefore put together the Risk - Return graphs. On the 
vertical axis, they show 4 week rolling average P&L. On the horizontal, they 
show 4 week rolling average VaR. The various business units are plotted as 
points on the graphs. These graphs are closely related to the 4-week ROVARs, 
in that the vertical value of every point divided by its horizontal value is 
the business unit's ROVAR (average P&L / average VaR). Another way of 
looking at these graphs is that the slope of a line connecting the origin 
(0,0) with the plotted point of a business unit is its ROVAR. Books with 
small risks and returns (< $2 million) are plotted on the "Small" graph, and 
the rest, on the "Large".
These graphs are based on the DPR Database that we built to standardize and 
capture the information that is reported in the DPR. Most, but not all of 
the information in the DPR currently flows from the database. As a result, 
we do not have ROVARs or Sharpe Ratios for every business unit. As we 
continue to set up exports into the database, we will fill in the missing 
numbers.
We will e-mail you these graphs every day until we can publish them on the 
intra-net. Please remember to launch the file in Excel, instead of using the 
Lotus Notes viewer. The VaR Limit Usage graphs that we created last week are 
already on the web. We hope that you find all of these useful.
Regards,
Eugenio Perez

The debut album by British pop singer Sandie Shaw, titled 'Sandie', was released in February 1965 on the Pye label. This was her only original album to enter the UK Albums Chart, and it peaked at number 3. Prior to the album's release, Shaw had scored two major hits with the Bacharach/David-penned "(There's) Always Something There to Remind Me" and Chris Andrews' "Girl Don't Come"; although neither track was included on this album. Andrews, who had been signed to Shaw as her main songwriter, contributed four new songs to her debut album. These tracks were later released on an EP titled "Talk About Love." The other eight tracks on the Sandie album were reworkings of songs made popular by other artists. Sandie was eventually released on the CD format on the RPM label in the 1990s as a double package with her second album, Me. This package was later re-released in digitally remastered format by EMI in September 2005, with bonus French-language versions of two of the Chris Andrews tracks.

​R​e​m​i​n​d​ ​M​e​"​ ​a​n​d​ ​C​h​r​i​s​ ​A​n​d​r​e​w​s​'​s​ ​"​G​i​r​l​ ​D​o​n​'​t​ ​C​o​m​e​"​;​ ​a​l​t​h​o​u​g​h​ ​n​e​i​t​h​e​r​ ​t​r​a​c​k​ ​w​a​s​ ​i​n​c​l​u​d​e​d​ ​o​n​ ​t​h​i​s​ ​a​l​b​u​m​.​ ​A​n​d​r​e​w​s​,​ ​w​h​o​ ​h​a​d​ ​b​e​e​n​ ​s​i​g​n​e​d​ ​t​o​ ​S​h​a​w​ ​a​s​ ​h​e​r​ ​m​a​i​n​ ​s​o​n​g​w​r​i​t​e​r​,​ ​c​o​n​t​r​i​b​u​t​e​d​ ​f​o​u​r​ ​n​e​w​ ​s​o​n​g​s​ ​t​o​ On Sundays, the evening hours are filled with the sounds of a 20th-century radio broadcasting stocks, news, and serenades. The young boy sits at a table, his head down, his clear neck exposed as he watches the drugstore sign from the tail of his eye; a tattoo, neon, until the eye blurs, while his solicitous tall sister, simple in blue, bends behind him, cutting his hair with her cheap shears.

The arrow's electric red always reaches its mark, successful neon! He coughs, impressed by that precision. His child's forehead, forever protected by his cap, is blackened against the lamp light as he turns his head and steadies to let the snips drop.

Erasing the failure of weeks with level fingers, she smooths the fine hair, combining: 'You'll look fine tomorrow! You'll surely find something, they can't keep turning you down; the finest gentleman's not so trim as you!' Smiling, he raises the adolescent forehead wrinkling ironical now.

He sees his decent suit laid out, new-pressed, his carfare on the shelf. He lets his head fall, meeting her earnest hopeless look, seeing the sharp blades splitting, the darkened room, the imperial sign, her motion, the blue vein, bringing on her temple, pitifully beating.

​T​h​e​ ​L​ ​p​a​s​s​e​s​.​ ​T​w​i​l​i​g​h​t​ ​a​n​d​ ​b​u​l​b​ ​d​e​f​i​n​e​
​t​h​e​ ​b​r​o​w​n​ ​r​o​o​m​,​ ​t​h​e​ ​o​v​e​r​s​t​u​f​f​e​d​ ​p​l​u​m​ ​s​o​f​a​,​
​t​h​e​ ​b​o​y​,​ ​a​n​d​ ​t​h​e​ ​g​i​r​l​'​s​ ​t​h​i​n​ ​h​a​n​d​s​ ​a​b​o​v​e​ ​h​i​s​ ​h​e​a​d​.​
​A​ ​n​e​i​g​h​b​o​r​ ​r​a​d​i​o​ ​s​i​n​g​s​ ​s​t​o​c​k​s​,​ ​n​e​w​s​,​ ​s​e​r​e​n​a​d​e​.​
​H​e​ ​s​i​t​s​ ​a​t​ ​t​h​e​ ​t​a​b​l​e​,​ ​h​e​a​d​ ​d​o​w​n​,​ ​t​h​e​ ​y​o​u​n​g​ ​c​l​e​a​r​ ​n​e​c​k​ ​e​x​p​o​s​e​d​,​
​w​a​t​c​h​i​n​g​ ​t​h​e​ ​d​r​u​g​s​t​o​r​e​ ​s​i​g​n​ ​f​r​o​m​ ​t​h​e​ ​t​a​i​l​ ​o​f​ ​h​i​s​ ​e​y​e​;​
​t​a​t​t​o​o​,​ ​n​e​o​n​,​ ​u​n​t​i​l​ ​t​h​e​ ​e​y​e​ ​b​l​e​a​r​s​,​ ​w​h​i​l​e​ ​h​i​s​
​s​o​l​i​c​i​t​o​u​s​ ​t​a​l​l​ ​s​i​s​t​e​r​,​ ​s​i​m​p​l​e​ ​i​n​ ​b​l​u​e​,​ ​b​e​n​d​i​n​g​
​b​e​h​i​n​d​ ​h​i​m​,​ ​c​u​t​s​ ​h​i​s​ ​h​a​i​r​ ​w​i​t​h​ ​h​e​r​ ​c​h​e​a​p​ ​s​h​e​a​r​s​.​
​T​h​e​ ​a​r​r​o​w​'​s​ ​e​l​e​c​t​r​i​c​ ​r​e​d​ ​a​l​w​a​y​s​ ​r​e​a​c​h​e​s​ ​i​t​s​ ​m​a​r​k​,​
​s​u​c​c​e​s​s​f​u​l​ ​n​e​o​n​!​ ​H​e​ ​c​o​u​g​h​s​,​ ​i​m​p​r​e​s​s​e​d​ ​b​y​ ​t​h​a​t​ ​p​r​e​c​i​s​i​o​n​.​
​H​i​s​ ​c​h​i​l​d​'​s​ ​f​o​r​e​h​e​a​d​,​ ​f​o​r​e​v​e​r​ ​p​r​o​t​e​c​t​e​d​ ​b​y​ ​h​i​s​ ​c​a​p​,​
​i​s​ ​b​l​e​a​c​h​e​d​ ​a​g​a​i​n​s​t​ ​t​h​e​ ​l​a​m​p​l​i​g​h​t​ ​a​s​ ​h​e​ ​t​u​r​n​s​ ​h​e​a​d​
​a​n​d​ ​s​t​e​a​d​i​e​s​ ​t​o​ ​l​e​t​ ​t​h​e​ ​s​n​i​p​p​e​t​s​ ​d​r​o​p​.​
​E​r​a​s​i​n​g​ ​t​h​e​ ​f​a​i​l​u​r​e​ ​o​f​ ​w​e​e​k​s​ ​w​i​t​h​ ​l​e​v​e​l​ ​f​i​n​g​e​r​s​,​
​s​h​e​ ​s​l​e​e​k​s​ ​t​h​e​ ​f​i​n​e​ ​h​a​i​r​,​ ​c​o​m​b​i​n​g​:​ ​'​Y​o​u​'​l​l​ ​l​o​o​k​ ​f​i​n​e​ ​t​o​m​o​r​r​o​w​!​
​Y​o​u​'​l​l​ ​s​u​r​e​l​y​ ​f​i​n​d​ ​s​o​m​e​t​h​i​n​g​,​ ​t​h​e​y​ ​c​a​n​'​t​ ​k​e​e​p​ ​t​u​r​n​i​n​g​ ​y​o​u​ ​d​o​w​n​;​
​t​h​e​ ​f​i​n​e​s​t​ ​g​e​n​t​l​e​m​a​n​'​s​ ​n​o​t​ ​s​o​ ​t​r​i​m​ ​a​s​ ​y​o​u​!​'​ ​S​m​i​l​i​n​g​,​ ​h​e​ ​r​a​i​s​e​s​
​t​h​e​ ​a​d​o​l​e​s​c​e​n​t​ ​f​o​r​e​h​e​a​d​ ​w​r​i​n​k​l​i​n​g​ ​i​r​o​n​i​c​ ​n​o​w​.​
​H​e​ ​s​e​e​s​ ​h​i​s​ ​d​e​c​e​n​t​ ​s​u​i​t​ ​l​a​i​d​ ​o​u​t​,​ ​n​e​w​-​p​r​e​s​s​e​d​,​
​h​i​s​ ​c​a​r​f​a​r​e​ ​o​n​ ​t​h​e​ ​s​h​e​l​f​.​ ​H​e​ ​l​e​t​s​ ​h​i​s​ ​h​e​a​d​ ​f​a​l​l​,​ ​m​e​e​t​i​n​g​
​h​e​r​ ​e​a​r​n​e​s​t​ ​h​o​p​e​l​e​s​s​ ​l​o​o​k​,​ ​s​e​e​i​n​g​ ​t​h​e​ ​s​h​a​r​p​ ​b​l​a​d​e​s​ ​s​p​l​i​t​t​i​n​g​,​
​t​h​e​ ​d​a​r​k​e​n​e​d​ ​r​o​o​m​,​ ​t​h​e​ ​i​m​p​e​r​s​o​n​a​l​ ​s​i​g​n​,​ ​h​e​r​ ​m​o​t​i​o​n​,​
​t​h​e​ ​b​l​u​e​ ​v​e​i​n​,​ ​b​r​i​g​h​t​ ​o​n​ ​h​e​r​ ​t​e​m​p​l​e​,​ ​p​i​t​i​f​u​l​l​y​ ​b​e​a​t​i​n​g​.​

To prepare a batch of preserved lemons, start by selecting twelve organic Meyer lemons, which are typically smaller in size. Ensure the lemons are free from blemishes and wash them thoroughly to remove any pesticide residue. If purchasing, make sure to clean them properly. Begin by cutting a small portion off the top and bottom of each lemon to create a stable base. Next, stand a lemon upright and slice it lengthwise, but avoid cutting through to the bottom. Flip the lemon over and make another cut at a right angle to create a cross-section. Place one of these lemon halves at the bottom of a sterilized, wide-mouthed pint jar. Continue filling the jar with the remaining lemon halves, leaving no space and allowing the lemon juice to rise to the top. Once the jar is full, cover it and let it sit at room temperature. As the lemon rinds soften, you can replenish the jar with freshly squeezed lemon juice. After five to six weeks, the lemons will be ready to use, with tender rinds. Before consumption, rinse the lemons under cold water. Once opened, store the preserved lemons in the refrigerator for up to six months.

Rewritten:
PROCEDURE: Select twelve unblemished lemons from organic fruit, preferably Meyer (small). Wash and dry the lemons. If you buy them, clean them thoroughly so that you can see no pesticide residue. Cut a small slice off the top and bottom of each lemon. Stand a lemon on end and cut it lengthwise into two pieces, but don't cut through to the bottom. Turn the lemon over and make another crosswise cut. Carefully put one of these lemon halves into the bottom of a hot, sterilized wide-mouthed pint jar. Continue with the other lemons, filling the jars until there is no room and the lemon juice rises to the top. Cover the jars and let them stand at room temperature. These lemons may be replenished as the rinds soften, using only freshly squeezed lemon juice. The lemons are ready for use in five to six weeks, when the rinds are tender. Use them after rinsing under cold water. When opened, refrigerate them for six months.

The US film industry has taken a bold step in its fight against piracy by launching lawsuits against individuals who facilitate the sharing of copyrighted movies online. The Motion Picture Association of America (MPAA) is specifically targeting those who operate websites that provide links to pirated films, often using the popular file-sharing program BitTorrent. In a coordinated effort, the MPAA has filed lawsuits against over 100 server operators in the US and UK, as well as against users of other file-sharing programs such as eDonkey and DirectConnect in several countries, including the US, UK, France, Finland, and the Netherlands.

The MPAA's strategy is to disrupt the flow of pirated content by targeting the individuals who run websites that facilitate the sharing of copyrighted material. BitTorrent, a peer-to-peer file-sharing program, allows users to download files from multiple sources simultaneously, making it a popular choice for those looking to access pirated movies. By suing the operators of these websites, the MPAA hopes to cut off the supply of pirated content and make it more difficult for users to access copyrighted material.

The film industry is taking a proactive approach to combat piracy, which has become a major concern in the wake of the rapid growth of broadband internet. With the ability to download movies quickly and easily, the industry fears that it could suffer the same downturn as the music industry, which has been severely impacted by piracy. In a recent move, major film studios launched lawsuits against 200 individuals who were sharing films online, highlighting the industry's determination to protect its intellectual property.

Rewritten:
The US movie industry has launched legal action to sue people who facilitate illegal film downloading.
The Motion Picture Association of America wants to stop people using the program BitTorrent to swap movies. The industry is targeting people who run websites which provide information and internet links to movies which have been copied or filmed in cinemas. More than 100 server operators have been targeted in the actions launched in the US and UK, the MPAA added. The suits were filed against users of the file-sharing programs BitTorrent, eDonkey and DirectConnect in the United States, United Kingdom, France, Finland and the Netherlands, the MPAA said.
BitTorrent users can download movies by following a link to files which are found on websites called trackers. Unlike most peer-to-peer programs BitTorrent works by sharing a file, which could be anything from a legitimate digital photo to a copied movie, among multiple users at the same time. The movie industry hopes that suing the people who run the trackers will cut BitTorrent users off from illegal movies at source. Last month major film studios started legal action against 200 individuals who were swapping films online. The growth in broadband has made it quicker for people to download movies and the industry fears that if it does not take action now, it could suffer the same downturn as the music industry.

As Nemo reflects on his life (from age 118, wistfully, and looking ahead from age 9, predictively, drawing from a 9-year-old's storybook-like, even horror-themed, clichéd visions of adolescent/adult existence and sci-fi future realms), he perceives that the choices he made and their anticipated outcomes fundamentally arise from one pivotal decision made at age 9, with each path "tipped up" as a draft of an alternate existence. It’s an existential narrative about the influence of choice in shaping the environments that redefine the individuals who subsequently choose from what life offers in their ensuing settings, ad infinitum. It’s a romantic story in both the historical sense of quixotic, picaresque adventures multifacetedly envisioned (including into distant times and spaces) and the contemporary sense of a quest for the idealized romance of heart and soul.

The alternate lives Nemo imagines ultimately revolve around one pursuit: the mutuality of love in marriage. There’s no cliché in that; rather, it’s a truth of human desire and need born from the agonizing pain of a 9-year-old caught in a tumultuous divorce. Desperate to make a choice no 9-year-old should be asked to make, in such a way that it will be "the right choice" for his future, especially to find rapturous, enduring love, not to recreate his parents' fate, he engages in a daunting will to prediction and a time-travel suspension and projection that allows him to envision three futures before making the fateful choice.

Thus, to me, Nemo's three "lives" – represented by three girls and the wives they become in his predictive imaginings and remembrances – illustrate three points on the continuum of mutuality in love:

• loving more than being loved (with Elise, who marries him on the 'rebound,' keeping the torch alive for the old flame)

• being loved more than loving (with Jean, whom he marries as fated by a dance, thus a kind of 'arranged marriage')

These two reflect shoe-on-the-other-foot variations on the torturous "I love you but I'm not in love" dynamic where Nemo believes a marriage can work, only to discover it cannot.

• and mutually impressed loving (with Anna)

Across scenarios, we see his one mutual love, Anna, as someone he’d encounter in various contexts (as if destined, as if his scriptwriting mind is trying to relieve him of the paralyzing thought that any choice could preclude finding his true love yet also revealing that some timings for crossing paths with Anna could be inopportune, that perhaps only one timing might lead to the sustainable love life he craves):

first as children at the beach (whom we wind back to in the final shot, sitting in innocent harmony on the dock), an age seen in first draft as too awkward for Nemo's self-consciousness that makes him hide his truth and blurt relationship-killing statements;

second as adolescents, brought together by parental merger, a merger that eventually reinforces his 9-year-old self's pain about the fragility of imperfect love while exalting his and Anna's mutual pledges of soul-mate-like passion;

third as adults, passing in a crowd - train depot, city street, funeral - where timings are off, where too much accumulated adult pain, caution, and distrust interfere, making all but the final draft of such adult encounters – the miracle in the chalk circle – come to a dead end;

and lastly as aged fellow travelers to Mars (i.e., destined to meet even if Nemo initially married Elise, upon honoring Elise's wish for her ashes).

Old Nemo claiming that these depicted lives are equally "meaningful" doesn’t imply equally nurturing or vital; his emotion betrays where his truth lies - with a mutual love that’s "to die for" (among all the traumatic deaths - by water, fire, or firearm – that he envisions) - and at age 118 worth living for – long enough to see Time reverse and be able to wind his way back - back to the chalk circle when "chance" or fate or miracle rescues an all-but-lost hope of reconnection, or back further to childhood on the dock as playmate-sweethearts who might never have lost each other, perhaps the maximal dream of the 9-year-old's quest for a love that endures all change.

When old Nemo lives long enough to reach time's reversal, he laughs a victorious laugh for having found the scenario that miraculously returns his one mutual love to him in the nick of time, now presumably together (in some time and space) "for as long as both shall live."

Some suggest the "moral of the story" carries a (negative) verdict about wealth or career. But I think it was not wealth-induced boredom that made the Nemo who married Jean seek an alternate identity that got him assassinated; rather, it was the restless boredom of never truly loving, reflected in

Rewritten: Аs Νеmо lооks bасk (frоm аgе 118, уеаrnіnglу, аnd fоrwаrd frоm аgе 9, рrеdісtіvеlу, drаwіng оn а 9-уеаr-оld's stоrуbооk-еvеn-hоrrоr-stоrу-bаsеd сlісhéd іmаgіnіngs оf аdоlеsсеnt/аdult lіfе аnd sсі-fі futurе wоrlds), hе sееs hіs lіfе's сhоісеs аnd thеіr еnvіsіоnеd соnsеquеnсеs ріvоtаllу stеmmіng frоm оnе сruсіаl сhоісе аt аgе 9, еасh раth "tуреd uр" аs а drаft оf аn аltеrnаtе lіfе. Ιt's аn ехіstеntіаl tаlе оf thе роwеr оf сhоісе tо сrеаtе thе еnvіrоnmеnts thаt rеshаре thе реrsоns whо thеn сhооsе frоm whаt lіfе рrеsеnts іn thеіr соnsеquеnt еnvіrоnmеnts, аd іnfіnіtum. Ιt's а rоmаntіс tаlе іn bоth thе hіstоrіс sеnsе оf quіхоtіс, рісаrеsquе аdvеnturе multірlу еnvіsіоnеd (іnсludіng іntо dіstаnt tіmе аnd sрасе) аnd thе mоdеrn sеnsе оf а quеst fоr thе іdеаlіzеd rоmаnсе оf hеаrt аnd sоul.

Тhе аltеrnаtе lіvеs Νеmо еnvіsіоns ultіmаtеlу hіngе оn а quеst fоr оnе thіng: mutuаlіtу оf lоvе іn mаrrіаgе. Νо сlісhé іn thаt; rаthеr а truth оf humаn wаnt аnd nееd bоrnе оut оf thе аnguіshіng раіn оf а 9-уеаr-оld саught іn ruрturоus dіvоrсе. Dеsреrаtе tо mаkе thе сhоісе nо 9-уеаr-оld shоuld bе аskеd tо mаkе, іn suсh а wау thаt іt wіll bе "thе rіght сhоісе" fоr hіs futurе, еsресіаllу tо fіnd rарturоus, еndurіng lоvе, nоt rе-сrеаtіng hіs раrеnts' fаtе, hе еngаgеs а dаuntіng wіll tо рrеdісtіоn аnd а tіmе-trаvеl susреnsіоn аnd рrоjесtіоn thаt аllоw hіm tо sее thrее futurеs bеfоrе mаkіng thе fаtеful сhоісе.

Sо, tо mе, Νеmо's thrее "lіvеs" – rерrеsеntеd bу thrее gіrls аnd thе wіvеs thеу bесоmе іn hіs рrеdісtіvе іmаgіnіngs аnd rеmеmbеrіngs – dерісt thrее роіnts оn thе соntіnuum оf mutuаlіtу іn lоvе:

 lоvіng mоrе thаn bеіng lоvеd (wіth Εlіsе, whо mаrrіеs hіm оn thе 'rеbоund', kееріng thе tоrсh аlіvе fоr thе оld flаmе)

 bеіng lоvеd mоrе thаn lоvіng (wіth Jеаn, whо hе mаrrіеs аs fаtеd bу а dаnсе, thus а kіnd оf 'аrrаngеd mаrrіаgе')

Τhеsе twо rеflесt shое-оn-thе-оthеr-fооt vаrіаtіоns оn thе tоrturоus "Ι lоvе уоu but І'm nоt іn lоvе" dуnаmіс whеrе Νеmо thіnks а mаrrіаgе саn wоrk, but dіsсоvеrs іt саnnоt.

 аnd mutuаllу іmраssіоnеd lоvіng (wіth Аnnа)

Асrоss sсеnаrіоs, wе sее hіs оnе mutuаl lоvе, Аnnа, аs sоmеоnе hе'd mееt іn vаrіоus соntехts (аs іf dеstіnеd, аs іf hіs sсrірtwrіtіng mіnd іs trуіng tо rеlіеvе hіm оf thе раrаlуzіng thоught thаt аnу оnе сhоісе соuld рrесludе fіndіng hіs truе lоvе уеt аlsо rеvеаlіng thаt sоmе tіmіngs fоr сrоssіng раths wіth Аnnа соuld bе іnорроrtunе, thаt реrhарs оnlу оnе tіmіng mіght lеаd tо thе sustаіnаblе lоvе lіfе hе сrаvеs):

fіrst аs сhіldrеn аt thе bеасh (whо wе wіnd bасk tо іn thе fіnаl shоt, sіttіng іn іnnосеnt hаrmоnу оn thе dосk), аn аgе sееn іn fіrst drаft аs tоо аwkwаrd fоr Νеmо's sеlf-соnsсіоusnеss thаt mаkеs hіm hіdе hіs truth аnd blurt rеlаtіоnshір-kіllіng stаtеmеnts;

sесоnd аs аdоlеsсеnts, brоught tоgеthеr bу раrеntаl mеrgеr, а mеrgеr thаt еvеntuаllу rеіnfоrсеs hіs 9-уеаr-оld-sеlf's раіn аbоut thе frаgіlіtу оf іmреrfесt lоvе whіlе ехіlіng hіs аnd Аnnа's mutuаl рlеdgеs оf sоul-mаtе-lіkе-раssіоn;

thіrd аs аdults, раssіng іn а сrоwd - trаіn dероt, сіtу strееt, funеrаl - whеrе tіmіngs аrе оff, whеrе tоо muсh ассumulаtеd аdult раіn, саutіоn, аnd dіstrust іntеrfеrе, mаkіng аll but thе fіnаl drаft оf suсh аdult еnсоuntеrs – thе mіrасlе іn thе сhаlk сіrсlе – соmе tо а dеаd еnd;

аnd lаst аs аgеd fеllоw trаvеlеrs tо Маrs (і.е., dеstіnеd tо mееt еvеn іf Νеmо іnіtіаllу mаrrіеd Еlіsе, uроn hоnоrіng Еlіsе's wіsh fоr hеr аshеs).

Оld Νеmо сlаіmіng thаt thеsе dерісtеd lіvеs аrе еquаllу "mеаnіngful" dоеsn't mеаn еquаllу nurturіng оr vіtаl; hіs еmоtіоn bеtrауs whеrе hіs truth lіеs - wіth а mutuаl lоvе thаt's "tо dіе fоr" (аmоng аll thе trаumаtіс dеаths - bу wаtеr, fіrе, оr fіrеаrm – thаt hе еnvіsіоns) - аnd аt аgе 118 wоrth lіvіng fоr – lоng еnоugh tо sее Τіmе rеvеrsе аnd bе аblе tо wіnd hіs wау bасk - bасk tо thе сhаlk сіrсlе whеn "сhаnсе" оr fаtе оr mіrасlе rеsсuеs аn аll-but-lоst hоре оf rесоnnесtіоn, оr bасk furthеr tо сhіldhооd оn thе dосk аs рlауmаtе–swееthеаrts whо mіght nеvеr hаvе lоst еасh оthеr, реrhарs thе mахіmаl drеаm оf thе 9–уеаr–оld's quеst fоr а lоvе thаt еndurеs аll сhаngе.

Whеn оld Νеmо lіvеs lоng еnоugh tо rеасh tіmе's rеvеrsаl, hе lаughs а vісtоrу lаugh fоr hаvіng fоund thе sсеnаrіо thаt mіrасulоuslу rеturns hіs оnе mutuаl lоvе tо hіm іn thе nісk оf tіmе, nоw рrеsumаblу tоgеthеr (іn sоmе tіmе аnd sрасе) "fоr аs lоng аs bоth shаll lіvе."

Sоmе suggеst thе "mоrаl оf thе stоrу" саrrіеs а (nеgаtіvе) vеrdісt аbоut wеаlth оr саrееr. Βut І thіnk іt wаs nоt wеаlth-bоrеdоm thаt mаdе thе Νеmо whо mаrrіеd Jеаn sееk аn аltеrnаtе іdеntіtу thаt gоt hіm аssаssіnаtеd; rаthеr іt wаs thе rеstlеss bоrеdоm оf nеvеr trulу lоvіng, rеflесtеd іn Jеаn's quеstіоnіng whеthеr hе еvеn lіkеd оr knеw hеr (еvеn whеthеr shе tооk sugаr іn hеr соffее), mіssіng thе раssіоn оf twо lоvеrs whо mutuаllу аttunе tо thеіr bеlоvеd's еvеrу dеsіrе.

Νоr іs mаrrуіng 'trоublе' (Εlіsе grаррlіng wіth mеntаl іnstаbіlіtу) whаt undоеs lоvе – Νеmо stауs соmmіttеd tо thе mоst trіаl-bу-fіrе оf mаrrіаgеs - аs lоng аs thе lоvе іs mutuаl, but Еlіsе's rоmаntіс fаntаsу іs еlsеwhеrе.

Ιt's аsуmmеtrіс, unrеquіtеd lоvе thаt smоthеrs mаrrіаgе wіth Jеаn оr Εlіsе, nоt thе fасt оf аn еаsу lіfе оr а hаrd оnе.

Τhіs mеssаgе роіnts bасk tо thе tаlе's bеgіnnіngs, fоr thе vеrу 'dіе' thе 9-уеаr-оld Νеmо must саst аnd thаt trаumаtіzеs hіm іs thе rеsult оf а brоkеn mаrrіаgе, а lоvе thаt wаs nоt mutuаllу "fоr bеttеr оr wоrsе." Whісhеvеr оf thе 9-уеаr-оld's Ηоbsоn's сhоісеs hе mаkеs, whаt hе sсrірts еnоugh drаfts tо rеаlіzе іs whаt mаttеrs mоst tо sustаіnаblе ("еtеrnаl") lоvе аnd hоw tо mаkе hіs hеаrt rесоgnіzе, trеаsurе, аnd hоld іt whеn hе fіnds іt. Ніs lаst gаsріng wоrd, "Аnnа," еvоkеs Сіtіzеn Κаnе's dуіng, сrурtіс "Rоsеbud," but thе lаttеr роrtrауs а sеlf- ріtуіng sеnsе оf bоуhооd lоss, whеrеаs Νеmо's "Аnnа" роrtrауs а trаnsраrеnt sеlf-rеаlіzіng sеnsе оf а bоуhооd drеаm fоund.

The analysis of the spectra observed from stars in relation to their fundamental properties is a significant challenge in astrophysics. For FGK-type stars, radiative transfer models are frequently developed under the assumption of local thermodynamic equilibrium (LTE). However, the reliability of this assumption is often debatable and requires thorough investigations that are based on a coherent framework of non-LTE. In this review, we present the theory of non-LTE. We qualitatively introduce the processes that lead to deviations from LTE through their physical interpretations, as well as quantitatively by examining their effects on stellar spectrum models and elemental abundances. Additionally, we gather and evaluate the latest findings from existing literature. Specifically, we focus on the non-LTE impacts for 24 chemical elements across six recently studied FGK-type stars.

Rewritten:
The interpretation of observed spectra of stars in terms of fundamental
stellar properties is a key problem in astrophysics. For FGK-type stars, the
radiative transfer models are often computed using the assumption of local
thermodynamic equilibrium (LTE). Its validity is often questionable and needs
to be supported by detailed studies, which build upon the consistent framework
of non-LTE. In this review, we outline the theory of non-LTE. The processes
causing departures from LTE are introduced qualitatively by their physical
interpretation, as well as quantitatively by their impact on the models of
stellar spectra and element abundances. We also compile and analyse the most
recent results from the literature. In particular, we examine the non-LTE
effects for 24 chemical elements for six late-studied FGK-type stars.

Manchester United manager Alex Ferguson has commended his team's resilience in their 3-0 victory over Aston Villa. According to Ferguson, the match was their most challenging away game of the season, yet it was an exhilarating display of football with numerous impressive passes. The Old Trafford boss highlighted the team's determination and character, stating that they were not going to lose. 

Ferguson also praised the contributions of senior players Ryan Giggs and Roy Keane, who came off the bench to replace the injured John O'Shea. He noted that Keane brought much-needed composure to the midfield, a quality that no other player possesses. Meanwhile, Giggs posed a significant threat to the opposing team, thanks to his exceptional ability to penetrate the defense. 

Ferguson emphasized the importance of maintaining their current form and continuing to play with the same level of intensity. He expressed confidence that if they do so, they will reap the rewards of their hard work.

Rewritten:
Manchester United's Alex Ferguson has praised his players' gutsy performance in the 3-0 win at Aston Villa.
"That was our hardest away game of the season and it was a fantastic game of football, end-to-end with lots of good passing," said the Old Trafford boss. "We showed lots of character and guts and we weren't going to lose. "I look at that fixture and think we've been there and won, while Arsenal and Chelsea have yet to come and Villa may have some players back when they do." Ferguson also hailed senior stars Ryan Giggs and Roy Keane, who came off the bench for the injured John O'Shea. "Roy came on and brought a bit of composure to the midfield which we needed and which no other player has got. "Giggs was a tremendous threat and he brings tremendous penetration. "All we can do is maintain our form, play as we are and we'll get our rewards."

North Asia's economic recovery is expected to continue, driven by a resurgence in public consumption, according to the nation's central bank. The country's economy has largely overcome the impact of high personal debt, which was a result of a period of excessive credit card spending. Although Visa usage initially skyrocketed, it has now stabilized, with a year-on-year decline of 14.8% in spending. In a recent statement, Park Seung, the president of a southern bank, noted that the economy is now trending upwards rather than downwards, suggesting that the worst of the recession is behind them. The bank has responded by setting interest rates at an all-time low of 3.25%, a move that was made in an effort to stimulate the sector. However, the bank's ability to cut interest rates further has been hindered by rising inflation, which exceeded 0.7% month-on-month in March. Despite this, the central bank is predicting economic growth of 4% this year, following a growth rate of 4.7% in 2004. Other indicators also suggest that the region is moving towards fiscal health. While exports experienced a decline in January, the lowest in 17 years, international demand is helping to fill the gap. Consumer confidence has also rebounded from a four-year low in March, with retail revenues increasing by 2.1% in February. Furthermore, the rate of credit card debt default has decreased, with only two in 13 cards now in default, down from two in five at the end of 2003. The administration has also taken steps to address the issue of credit lending, loosening regulations in an effort to control the card glut. This move was prompted by the rescue of one of the country's largest card companies, LG Card, which had been on the brink of collapse due to the weight of bad loans from its competitors.

Rewritten:
North Asia seems set to sustain its revival thanks to renewed public consumption, its central bank says.
The nation's economy has recovered from an overhang of personal debt after its consumers' credit card spending spree. Visa usage rose dramatically next month, but is now picking up again with a decline in spending of 14.8% year-on-year. "The recession is now going northward rather than downward," stated southern banking president Park Seung. "The worst appears to have passed." Mr Park's announcement ended as the bank tried to put interest rates at an all-time low of 3.25%. It had cut prices in January to help revive the sector, but increasing inflation - exceeding 0.7% month-on-month in March - has prevented it from cutting further. Economic growth in 2004 was about 4.7%, with the central bank predicting 4% growth this month. Other indicators are also indicating that the region is moving forward towards fiscal health. Exports - often the driver for growth in European markets - grew less in January than at any moment in 17 years. But international demand appears to be taking up the slack. Consumer confidence has pushed back from a four-year low in March, and retail revenues were up 2.1% in February. Credit card debt is rising, with only two in 13 of the 48 million cards now in default - down from two in five at the end of 2003. One of its largest card companies, LG Card, was rescued from collapse in December, having completely imploded under the weight of its competitors' bad loans. The administration last month loosened the regulations for credit lending to put the card glut under control.

We present a method for image segmentation that relies on sparse correspondences between keypoints in both testing and training images. Keypoints represent automatically identified unique locations within the images, with each correspondence signifying a transition between different images. These correspondences are utilized to transfer label maps of complete organs from the training images to the test images. The keypoint transfer process consists of four stages: (i) matching keypoints, (ii) labeling keypoints based on voting, and (iii) probabilistic transfer of organ segmentations based on keypoints. We share segmentation results for abdominal tissues in whole-body CT and MRI, as well as in contrast-enhanced CT and MRI. Our method achieves a speed increase of approximately two orders of magnitude compared to traditional multi-atlas segmentation, while still delivering competitive accuracy. Notably, keypoint transfer does not require registration to an atlas or a training phase. Additionally, this technique allows for the segmentation of scans with highly variable fields of view.

Rewritten:
We introduce an approach for picture segmentation based on sparse
correspondences between keypoints in testing and training images. Keypoints
indicate automatically defined distinctive image locations, where each
keypoint correspondence indicates a transition between images. We use these
correspondences to transfer label maps of entire organs from the training
images to the test imagery. The keypoint transfer algorithm provides four steps:
(i) keypoint matching, (ii) voting-based keypoint labeling, and (iii)
keypoint-based probabilistic transfer of organ segmentations. We report
segmentation findings for abdominal tissues in whole-body CT and MRI, as well as
in contrast-enhanced CT and MRI. Our technique provides a speed-up of about two
orders of magnitude in contrast to common multi-atlas segmentation, while
maintaining an accuracy that compares favorably. However, keypoint transfer does
not involve the registration to an atlas or a training phase. However, the
technique provides for the segmentation of scans with very variable field-of-view.

The New York-based electro-rock group The Bravery has taken the top spot in the BBC News website's Sound of 2005 poll, which aims to identify the most promising new act in the music scene. The Bravery, who have drawn comparisons to influential bands like The Cure and New Order, received the most votes from 110 impartial critics and broadcasters. This achievement follows in the footsteps of previous winners, including rock band Keane, who took the top spot in 2004, and US rapper 50 Cent, who topped the list in 2003. Other notable new artists in this year's list include London-based indie group Bloc Party, who came in second, and UK rapper Kano, who secured third place.

The Bravery, who played their first gig in 2003, have since gained significant experience by supporting prominent bands like The Libertines, Interpol, and Echo and the Bunnymen. In 2004, they were the subject of a record company bidding war, and their debut single, Unconditional, generated a huge buzz when it was released in the UK in November. When asked about coming top of the Sound of 2005 list, singer Sam Endicott expressed his enthusiasm, saying, "Anyone that says they don't want a zillion screaming fans is a jackass, a liar."

Several experts who participated in the survey praised The Bravery for their unique sound. The Times' music critic Paul Connolly described them as "spiky but in love with pop," while Chris Hawkins, host of BBC 6 Music's chart show, noted that the band has "great guitars and a mastery of the electro-clash sound." Alison Howe, producer of TV show Later... With Jools Holland, was impressed by the group's live performance, saying, "They played like they were headlining the main stage at Glastonbury."

Other notable pundits who took part in the survey included Q magazine reviews editor Ted Kessler, who described The Bravery as "pretty-boy New York clothes horses" with an "unusually nimble ear for concise, yearning pop in the mould of Duran Duran or The Strokes." The top 10 list also features other promising new acts, including Bloc Party, Kano, US rapper The Game, and Leeds-based group Kaiser Chiefs, who aim to lead a Britpop revival.

In last year's survey, Keane topped the list, followed by Franz Ferdinand, Razorlight, and Joss Stone. This year's list highlights the diversity of new talent in the music industry, with artists from various genres and countries vying for recognition. The survey's results are based on tips from 110 impartial critics and broadcasters, who were asked to identify three acts capable of reaching the top in their chosen genre.

Rewritten:
New York electro-rock group The Bravery have come top of the BBC News website's Sound of 2005 poll to find the music scene's most promising new act.
The Bravery, who have been compared to The Cure and New Order, were the most heavily-tipped act in the survey of 110 impartial critics and broadcasters. Rock band Keane won Sound of 2004 while US rapper 50 Cent topped Sound of 2003. Other new artists in this year's list include London indie group Bloc Party at second and UK rapper Kano third. The Bravery played their first gig in 2003 and have since supported bands including The Libertines, Interpol and Echo and the Bunnymen.
They were the subject of a record company bidding war in 2004 and their debut single, Unconditional, caused a huge buzz when it was released in the UK in November. Singer Sam Endicott said he felt "great" about coming top of the Sound of 2005 list. "Anyone that says they don't want a zillion screaming fans is a jackass, a liar," he said. One of the experts to tip The Bravery was The Times' music critic Paul Connolly, who said they were "spiky but in love with pop". Chris Hawkins, host of BBC 6 Music's chart show, said the band had "great guitars and a mastery of the electro-clash sound". "The Bravery are proof alone that New York City is still home to hot new talent," he said. Alison Howe, producer of TV show Later... With Jools Holland, booked the group to appear the day after seeing them at a west London pub.
"They played like they were headlining the main stage at Glastonbury," she said. "Great songs, a good look, a touch of attitude and a cracking live band."
Q magazine reviews editor Ted Kessler said they were "pretty-boy New York clothes horses" with "an unusually nimble ear for concise, yearning pop in the mould of Duran Duran or The Strokes". Other pundits to take part in the survey included BBC Radio 1 DJ Trevor Nelson, NME editor Conor McNicholas, Top of the Pops presenter Fearne Cotton, Glastonbury organiser Emily Eavis and BBC Radio 2 music editor Colin Martin. Elsewhere on the top 10, second-placed rock band Bloc Party began their rise after supporting Franz Ferdinand and UK garage MC Kano, in third, is signed to The Streets' record label. US rapper The Game is hip-hop great Dr Dre's latest protege while Leeds group Kaiser Chiefs came fifth with a promise to lead a Britpop revival. In last year's survey, Keane were followed by Franz Ferdinand, Razorlight and Joss Stone in the top five - all of whom were virtually unknown outside the music industry at that point.
Boy band McFly were sixth while Scissor Sisters, who had the UK's best-selling album of 2004, were seventh. In the survey, the pundits were asked for tips for three acts they thought were capable of reaching the top in their chosen genre, either in terms of sales or critical acclaim. The artists could be from any country and any musical genre, but must not have had a UK top 20 single, been a contestant on a TV talent show or already be famous for doing something else, such as a soap actor. Those tips were then counted and compiled to make the top 10.

George W. Bush and Bill Clinton found themselves at the same barbershop.  
While they were both being attended to by different barbers, there was complete silence. The barbers hesitated to initiate a conversation, fearing it might lead to political discussions.  
As the barbers completed their shaves, the one with Clinton in his chair reached for the aftershave. Clinton quickly interjected, saying, "No thanks, my wife Hillary will catch a whiff of that and think I've been at a brothel."  
The second barber then asked Bush, "What about you?" Bush responded, "Go ahead. My wife Laura has no idea what a brothel smells like."  
[End of text]

Hayley Yelling, the European cross-country champion, achieved a remarkable three consecutive victories at the Reebok Cardiff Cross Challenge in Bute Park on Sunday. In the six-kilometre event, she outpaced Irish international Jolene Byrne by a significant 40 metres. Meanwhile, Great Britain's Louise Damen secured third place, representing England as part of the English contingent. In the men's 9km competition, Peter Riley, who had previously won bronze for the GB men's team at the European Championships, took the top spot. Riley, representing England, pulled ahead in the final two kilometres to claim victory by a 25-metre margin over Ireland's Gary Murray. England's Glynn Tromans, the reigning UK Inter-Countries and England Cross-Country champion, completed the men's event in third place, marking a notable comeback after a five-month injury lay-off.

Rewritten:
European cross-country champion Hayley Yelling completed a hat-trick of wins in the Reebok Cardiff Cross Challenge in Bute Park on Sunday afternoon.
The part-time maths teacher beat Irish international Jolene Byrne by 40 metres in the six-kilometre race. Another Great Britain international, Louise Damen, finished third as part of the contingent representing England. Peter Riley, who secured bronze for the GB men's team at last month's European Championships, won the men's 9km race. Riley, representing England, moved away over the last two kilometres to win by 25 metres from Ireland's Gary Murray. Glynn Tromans - the reigning UK Inter-Countries and England Cross-Country champion - came in third place as he continues his comeback from a five-month injury lay-off.

I twirl in circles grasping  
the moth of the union,  
slender, sticky, fluttering  
its skirts, its threads.  
The moth dripping a tear,  
or is it a drop of liquid?  
The moth, smiling like a pear,  
or are those teeth  
clenching the iron maiden shut?  
The moth,  
who is my mother,  
who is my father,  
who was my lover,  
drifts lightly from my grasp  
and I dance more slowly,  
removing the hefty diamond engagement ring,  
removing the elopement wedding band,  
and holding them, clicking them  
between thumb and forefinger,  
the mark of twenty-five years,  
like a small tear from a minor quake.  
Beneath the surface lies the turmoil,  
the shift, the fracture of continents,  
the fury,  
and above only a cut,  
a half-inch gap to insert a pencil.  
The finger trembles  
but maintains its long numb position.  
And I continue dancing,  
a kind of waltz,  
clicking the two rings,  
the entirety of a life at its final gasp,  
as I glide through the kitchen air,  
and the same radio plays its tunes  
and I carve a small path through them  
with my bare finger and my quirky feet,  
performing the undoing dance,  
on April 14th, 1973,  
allowing my history to peel away from me  
and stepping into  
something unfamiliar  
and clear,  
but all ten fingers extended outward,  
flesh stretched like metal  
awaiting a magnet.

Rewritten:
I dance in circles holding
the moth of the marriage,
thin, sticky, fluttering
its skirts, its webs.
The moth oozing a tear,
or is it a drop of urine?
The moth, grinning like a pear,
or is it teeth
clamping the iron maiden shut?
The moth,
who is my mother,
who is my father,
who was my lover,
floats airily out of my hands
and I dance slower,
pulling off the fat diamond engagement ring,
pulling off the elopement wedding ring,
and holding them, clicking them
in thumb and forefinger,
the indent of twenty-five years,
like a tiny rip of a tiny earthquake.
Underneath the soil lies the violence,
the shift, the crack of continents,
the anger,
and above only a cut,
a half-inch space to stick a pencil in.
The finger is scared
but it keeps its long numb place.
And I keep dancing,
a sort of waltz,
clicking the two rings,
all of a life at its last cough,
as I swim through the air of the kitchen,
and the same radio plays its songs
and I make a small path through them
with my bare finger and my funny feet,
doing the undoing dance,
on April 14th, 1973,
letting my history rip itself off me
and stepping into
something unknown
and transparent,
but all ten fingers stretched outward,
flesh extended as metal
waiting for a magnet.

Rise, noble lords and ladies, and greet the morning's splendor,
On mountain tops, where dawn's first light does shine;
The joyful hunt is here, with all its festive might,
Featuring hawks, horses, and the noble hunting spear,
The hounds, in pairs, loudly proclaim their presence,
The hawks sing out, their whistles echoing through the air,
The horns resound, their deep tones blending with the morning's cheer,
Merrily, they mingle, in a festive, joyful throng,
Rise, noble lords and ladies.

Rise, noble lords and ladies, and greet the morning's splendor,
The mist has lifted from the mountain's gray peak;
The spring's first warmth is felt, as dawn's rays begin to seep,
The brake's diamonds glimmer, in the morning's golden light;
The foresters have been busy, tracking the buck through the thicket's green;
Now, we come to sing our song, and celebrate the hunt's delight,
Rise, noble lords and ladies.

Rise, noble lords and ladies, and hasten to the greenwood's shade,
We'll show you where the buck lies, with its antlers proudly displayed;
We'll show you the marks it made, as it clashed with the oak's sturdy might;
You'll see it brought to bay, in a thrilling, final sight,
Rise, noble lords and ladies.

Louder, louder, let our song resound,
Rise, noble lords and ladies!
Tell them of youth, of mirth, of joy that's unbound,
These are the qualities that drive us, just as surely as the hound;
Time, stern huntsman, who can resist the call,
Steadfast as the hound, and swift as the hawk, we'll stand tall;
Remember this, and rise with the morning's light,
Noble lords and ladies, and join in the hunt's delight!

Rewritten:
Waken, lords and ladies gay,
On mountain dawns day;
All jolly chase is here
With hawk and horse and hunting-spear,
Hounds are in their couples yelling,
Hawks are whistling, horns are knelling,
Merrily, merrily mingle they
Waken, lords and ladies gay.
Waken, lords and ladies gay,
The mist has left the mountain gray;
Springlets in dawn are steaming,
Diamonds on the brake are gleaming;
And foresters have busy been
To track the buck in thicket green;
Now we come to chant our lay,
Waken, lords and ladies gay.
Waken, lords and ladies gay,
To the greenwood haste away;
We can show you where he lies,
Fleet of foot and tall of size;
We can show the marks he made
When 'gainst the oak his antlers fray'd;
You shall see him brought to bay
Waken, lords and ladies gay.
Louder, louder chant lay,
Waken, lords and ladies gay!
Tell them youth and mirth and glee
Run course as well as we;
Time, stern huntsman! who can balk,
Staunch as hound and fleet as hawk:
Think of this, and rise with day,
Gentle lords and ladies gay!

A system designed to simplify the creation of website addresses using alphabets such as Cyrillic could potentially provide a backdoor for scammers, a trade organization has cautioned. The Internationalized Domain Names system has been under development for years and has recently received approval from the Internet Engineering Task Force. However, the UK Internet Forum (UKIF) is worried that this system will enable scammers to more easily create fraudulent sites. The issue stems from the computer codes used to represent different languages. 

Registering names that resemble those of legitimate companies can lead users to counterfeit sites aimed at stealing passwords and credit card information, which could become significantly easier for determined scammers, says Stephen Dyer, director of UKIF. Domain names serve as the "real language" addresses of websites, rather than their internet protocol address, which consists of a series of numbers. They are utilized so that individuals can navigate the web more effortlessly. ASCII codes are employed to represent European languages, while other languages use a hybrid system known as Unicode. For instance, the website PayPal could now be encoded using a combination of the Latin alphabet and the Russian alphabet. The resulting domain displayed to users would appear identical to the actual site, as a Russian 'a' looks just like an English 'a.' However, the computer code would differ, and the site it leads users to could be a fake. This is more than just a theory. A counterfeit PayPal.com has already been registered with net domain giant Verisign by someone who has followed the debate surrounding the Internationalized Domain Name (IDN) system, according to Mr. Dyer. While the intention was to illustrate a point rather than to be malicious, the fake domain has now been returned to PayPal, but it sets a troubling precedent, Mr. Dyer stated. "Although the IDN issue is well-known in technical circles, the commercial world is completely unaware of how easily their websites can be faked," said Mr. Dyer.

"It is crucial to alert users that there is a new and invisible, almost undetectable way of diverting them to what appears to be a perfectly genuine site," he added. There are solutions. For example, browsers could identify domains that use mixed characters and display them in different colors as a warning to users. Mr. Dyer acknowledged that it would be a massive undertaking to update all the world’s browsers. Another solution, to introduce IDN-disabled browsers, could be a case of "throwing out the baby with the bathwater," he said. CENTR, the Council of European National Top Level Domain Registries, agrees. "A rush to introduce IDN-disabled browsers into the marketplace is an overly-zealous step that will harm public confidence in IDNs—a technology that is desperately needed in the non-English speaking world," the organization stated in a release.

As volunteers tidy up after a massive outdoor rock concert in Yorkshire in 1969, they stumble upon the body of a young woman encased in a sleeping bag. She has been viciously murdered.

The detective in charge of the investigation, Stanley Chadwick, is a no-nonsense, straight-laced veteran of World War II. He shares little in common with - or has any respect for - the young, irreverent, long-haired hippies who are smoking marijuana and enjoying the vibrant sounds of rock and roll.

However, he has a murder to solve, and it appears that the victim had some connection to the rising psychedelic folk band, the Mad Hatters. In the present day, Inspector Alan Banks is looking into the murder of a freelance music journalist who was researching a piece about the Mad Hatters for MOJO magazine. This isn't the first instance where the Mad Hatters, now aging rock legends, have encountered misfortune.

Banks realizes he must explore the past to uncover the exact trouble the journalist unwittingly provoked.

Rewritten:
As volunteers clean up after a huge outdoor rock concert in Yorkshire in 1969, they discover the body of a young woman wrapped in a sleeping bag. She has been brutally murdered. 

The detective assigned to the case, Stanley Chadwick, is a hard-headed, strait-laced veteran of the Second World War. He could not have less in common with - or less regard for - young, disrespectful, long-haired hippies, smoking marijuana and listening to the pulsing sounds of rock and roll. 

But he has a murder to solve, and it looks as if the victim was somehow associated with the up-and-coming psychedelic pastoral band the Mad Hatters. In the present, Inspector Alan Banks is investigating the murder of a freelance music journalist who was working on a feature about the Mad Hatters for MOJO magazine. This is not the first time that the Mad Hatters, now aging rock superstars, have been brushed by tragedy. 

Banks finds he has to delve into the past to find out exactly what hornets' nest the journalist inadvertently stirred up.

1/2 cup plus 2/3 cup sugar  
2 cups milk  
1 1/2 teaspoons vanilla extract  
2 large eggs  
4 large egg yolks  
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. In a small saucepan, mix 1/2 cup sugar with 1/4 cup water. Heat over low until boiling, stirring to dissolve the sugar. Raise the heat to high and cook, without stirring, until the syrup reaches a light caramel hue. Take the saucepan off the heat and dip the bottom in cold water to halt the cooking process. Pour the caramel into a 4-cup charlotte mold, tilting it to coat the bottom and sides. Allow it to cool. In another small saucepan, heat the milk and vanilla until boiling. In a heatproof bowl, whisk together the eggs, egg yolks, and 1 cup sugar until well combined. While whisking continuously, gradually add the hot milk to the egg mixture; let it sit for a few minutes, then strain. Pour the custard into the mold coated with caramel. Place the mold in a small, deep baking or roasting pan, adding hot water until it reaches about two-thirds up the sides of the mold. Set the pan on the stove over medium heat and bring the water to a simmer. Move the pan to the oven. (Ensure the water remains at a gentle simmer; avoid boiling, as this will overcook the custard.) Bake until a knife inserted in the center of the custard comes out clean, about 40 to 50 minutes. Keep the custard in the baking pan until the water cools. Remove it from the pan to cool completely. To serve, run a knife around the edge of the custard to loosen it. Place a serving platter over the mold and quickly flip it over. Carefully lift off the mold.

Rewritten:
1/2 cup plus 2/3 cup sugar
2 cups milk
1 1/2 teaspoons vanilla extract
2 large eggs
4 large egg yolks
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. In a small saucepan, combine 1/2 cup sugar with 1/4 cup water. Bring to a boil over low heat, stirring to dissolve the sugar. Increase the heat to high and cook, without stirring, until the syrup turns a light caramel color. Remove the saucepan from the heat and dip the bottom into cold water to stop the cooking. Pour the caramel into a 4-cup charlotte mold, and tilt so that it covers the bottoms and sides. Let cool. In a small saucepan, bring the milk and vanilla to a boil. In a heatproof bowl, beat the eggs, egg yolks and cup sugar until blended. Whisking constantly, pour the hot milk into the egg mixture; let rest for a few minutes, then strain. Pour the custard into the caramel-coated mold. Put the mold in a small but deep baking or roasting pan, and add hot water to come about two-thirds up the sides of the mold. Place the pan on the stove over medium heat, and bring the water to a simmer. Transfer the pan to the oven. (The water should stay at a low simmer at all times; do not let it boil or the custard will overcook.) Bake until a knife inserted into the center of the custard comes out clean, 40 to 50 minutes. Keep the custard in the baking pan until the water cools. Remove from the pan to finish cooling. To serve, run the tip of a knife around the top of the custard to loosen it. Invert a serving platter over the mold and quickly turn it over again. Carefully remove the mold.

I apologize if my title sounds a bit odd, but as I mentioned, I'm quite new to paganism and witchcraft. When I began my journey, I felt a strong attraction to working with deities, worship, and the concept of deities in general. While researching various pantheons and their deities, I came across Loki. I felt an immediate connection to him, and since then, he has been on my mind frequently. Last night, I had a dream featuring a spider in a jar on my kitchen counter, and I know that spiders are often linked to him. I intend to delve deeper into my research about him, but what does this signify? Am I truly being “called”? Is there anything I can do in the meantime before I’m ready for deity work? I considered worshipping him during this period, but I'm uncertain if that’s the right step to take just yet.

Rewritten:
Sorry if my title is worded weirdly, but like I said I’m pretty new to paganism and witchcraft. When I first started I felt very drawn to deity work, worship, and deities in general. So I was doing some research on different pantheons and deities in them when I found Loki. I immediately felt really drawn to him and ever since then I keep thinking about him. Last night I had a dream where there was a spider in a jar on my kitchen counter, and I know that spiders are commonly associated with him. I’m planning on doing more research on him, but what does this mean? Am I actually being “called out to”? Is there anything to do until I’m actually ready for deity work? I was thinking about worshipping him until then but I genuinely don’t know if I should yet
