Nathan's anguished cry echoed through the forest as Cello's eyes widened in shock, his mouth spewing blood as he was hurled through the air by the blast that had torn through his body, ending his life. Eli, still reeling from the force that had thrown him, caught a glimpse of the devastating scene before his rage took over. "You monster!" he screamed, his eyes blazing with fury as he turned to confront the person responsible for Cello's death. With a fierce determination, Eli charged towards her, his movements swift and deadly, just as his brother had been.

Rewritten:
"No!" Nathan cried out as Cello's eyes went wide, mouth spurting out blood as he was sent through the forest from the blast that pierced through his body and killed him. Eli saw the last bit as he recovered from the throw before he became enraged. "You bitch! Cello!" He cried out as he looked to where his brother went. Looking back at her, he cried out angrily as he rushed at her, faster than Cello had.

November 27, 2001=20  
FERC Implements Significant Restrictions=20  
on Wholesale Market  
By Will McNamara  
Director, Electric Industry Analysis  
AEP, Entergy Corp., and Southern Company instructed by FERC to apply cost-based pricing rather than market-based pricing for wholesale spot transactions.  
[News item from Reuters] The U.S. Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FER=
C) voted 3-1 last week to establish new regulations for assessing market power, which is a prerequisite for approving mergers and allowing utilities to trade power in the wholesale market. FERC officials stated that the new assessment would enhance a system that previously allowed a crisis to occur in the California market last winter, when wholesale power prices surged to unprecedented levels due to limited supplies. FERC officials agreed to create a new market power assessment based on supply margin evaluations, which considers a company's role in meeting peak electricity demands. "If you're large enough to influence the market at the time we assess it, you'll face mitigation measures," stated FERC Chairman Pat Wood.  
Analysis: Numerous stakeholders in the wholesale energy sector are still grappling with FERC's recent decision, which may have gone unnoticed by some due to its timing just before the extended holiday weekend. This ruling is monumental for FERC and carries significant implications for companies that increasingly derive a substantial portion of their profits from wholesale transactions. Additionally, state regulators have begun to evaluate the ruling's effects on retail rates, which some utilities may attempt to raise to offset declining profits in their wholesale activities. While FERC has framed this ruling as a means to address national issues similar to those experienced in the California market, the new restrictions on wholesale transactions can also be interpreted as another instance of the "big stick" approach the commission is employing to compel utilities to engage with regional transmission organizations (RTO). Furthermore,

November 27, 2001=20
FERC Enacts Major Constraints=20
on Wholesale Market
By Will McNamara
Director, Electric Industry Analysis
AEP, Entergy Corp. and Southern Company told by FERC to charge cost-based p=
rices instead of market-based prices for wholesale spot transactions.=20
[News item from Reuters] The U.S. Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FER=
C) voted 3-1 last week to adopt new rules to measure market power, as a con=
dition for approving mergers and granting utilities the right to trade powe=
r in the wholesale market. FERC commissioners said the new test would impro=
ve a system that allowed a meltdown to take place in the California market =
last winter, when wholesale power prices soared to record highs amid tight =
supplies. FERC commissioners agreed to produce a new market power test base=
d on supply margin assessments, which examines a company's importance in se=
rving peak electricity loads. "If you're big enough to control the market a=
t the time we look at it, you'll have mitigation put on you," said FERC Cha=
irman Pat Wood.=20
Analysis: Many participants in the wholesale sector of the energy industry =
are still reeling from FERC's new ruling, which may have slipped past some =
radar screens considering that it was issued right before the long holiday =
weekend. This is a mammoth ruling on FERC's part, however, and it holds tre=
mendous impact for those companies that increasingly find the lion's share =
of their profits coming from wholesale transactions. In addition, state reg=
ulators have also started gauging the impact of the ruling on retail rates,=
 which some utilities may seek to increase as a way to compensate for shrin=
king profits in their wholesale operations. While FERC has presented this r=
uling as an attempt to circumvent on the national level problems experience=
d in the California market, the new limits on wholesale transactions can al=
so be seen as another example of the "big stick" that the commission is usi=
ng to force utilities into participating in regional transmission organizat=
ions (RTO). Further, the ruling is another striking indication that Chairma=
n Wood is following through with his promise to monitor rampant wholesale m=
arkets while still attempting to support competition. The objective represe=
nts a tall order, and the new ruling from the commission is certain to prom=
pt intense resistance among companies involved in wholesale trading.=20
Put into a nutshell, FERC has ruled that some companies can no longer charg=
e unregulated, market-based rates for spot market wholesale transactions. I=
nstead, companies identified as having market power and that aren't part of=
 an approved RTO must charge cost-based prices for power that isn't committ=
ed in a long-term contract, and publicly disclose those cost-based prices. =
Columbus, Ohio-based American Electric Power (NYSE: AEP), Atlanta-based Sou=
thern Company (NYSE: SO) and New Orleans-based Entergy Corp. (NYSE: ETR) ha=
ve been singled out as case studies on which FERC will be immediately apply=
ing its new standards for wholesale transactions. Note that Mirant Corp., a=
 former subsidiary of Southern Company, has also been identified as having =
to submit information to FERC in order to gauge its level of market power s=
eparate from its former parent. The commission has essentially determined t=
hat these three utilities hold an unacceptable level of market power in the=
 areas in which they operate. Under FERC's new market power "test," a gener=
ator or marketer is viewed as having too much market power if its electrici=
ty is "pivotal" during peak demand, which enables the company to demand a p=
rice above competitive levels. Regional transmission constraints will also =
be considered now as a measurement of a company's market power. This is a d=
ramatic departure from previous standards, by which (under one of FERC's ma=
in criterions) a company that supplied less than 20 percent of the power ne=
eded in a particular region was freed from rate regulation on the federal l=
evel.=20
There are some important exceptions to the ruling. First, FERC has not elim=
inated the utilities' ability to charge market-based rates in areas where t=
he grid and markets are controlled by a FERC-approved RTO. This is signific=
ant, as I will expand upon subsequently, because it indicates that there ar=
e secondary objectives in FERC's new ruling. In addition, the current rulin=
g only impacts short-term sales transactions in which these three utilities=
 are involved. In other words, long-term contracts that the three companies=
 may have previously established or will establish in the future are not im=
pacted by the ruling. However, the three companies named in the ruling will=
 have to post pricing information related to long-term contracts, and FERC =
has retained the possibility that further price mitigation for long-term co=
ntracts may be necessary. Also note that the Western market, which already =
is under a price mitigation policy that FERC imposed in June, was not inclu=
ded in the new ruling.=20
The three utilities named in the ruling now have 15 days to submit proposal=
s to FERC outlining a transition to charging cost-based wholesale rates for=
 all power not currently committed to a buyer. Specifically, the utilities =
will have to post on their open-access same-time information systems (OASIS=
) the incremental cost of producing the uncommitted power during each hour =
in a 24-hour period. Moving forward, the price that the utilities can charg=
e for non-committed power on the spot market will be the difference between=
 their cost of production and the bid of more expensive power in the region=
 that their power displaces. The new cost-based rates must be administered =
by an independent third party.=20
The new pricing standards revert back to an older, cost-based technique kno=
wn as "split the savings." The methodology for this standard can get rather=
 complicated, but essentially under FERC's new ruling the three companies i=
dentified will have to post their cost-based, incremental costs for spot po=
wer into the OASIS system for viewing by potential purchases. Purchasers wh=
o want to make a bid will post their decremental energy bid for not produci=
ng or buying the power on their own. The final price for the transactions w=
ill be the split between the seller's incremental cost and the buyer's decr=
emental bid. For instance, if Southern Company bids its incremental cost at=
 $20/MWh and a purchaser bids its decremental cost at $30/MWh, the transact=
ion price would be $25/MWh. Assuming a midnight-to-midnight trading day, se=
llers would have to submit their incremental bid by noon on the previous da=
y and buyers would submit their decremental bids by 6 p.m. What this potent=
ially creates is an "information advantage" for buyers who have six hours t=
o evaluate and respond to the incremental bids from some sellers. Some of t=
he drawbacks to this system are that it requires both parties to post price=
 information that may not be readily available and it potentially allows th=
e purchaser to game the system by having access to the seller's original in=
cremental bid and competing around the seller's price.=20
Note also that in a separate development FERC simultaneously opened a broad=
 investigation under Section 206 of the Federal Power Act to apply the new =
market-based-sales policy to all U.S. sellers nationwide. What this means i=
s that, although only three utilities are mentioned in this initial order, =
it is expected that FERC will continue to take steps to constrain what it b=
elieves to be erratic wholesale markets. Reportedly, some 30 companies are =
awaiting similar reviews by FERC to determine if the commission believes th=
ey exert market power. The 206 investigation reportedly also requires power=
 providers with market-based sales authority to amend their tariffs within =
60 days to provide FERC with open-ended authority to order refunds if the c=
ommission determines that market manipulation has occurred.=20
I made a previous reference to the "big stick" that FERC is carrying relate=
d to participation in RTOs. Remember that a few months ago, Chairman Wood h=
ad threatened to deny utilities that refused to join an RTO the benefits of=
 charging market-based wholesale rates and swift approvals for merger appli=
cations, advantages that the chairman equated with the "new world" of the d=
eregulated energy market. With this in mind, note that only Southern Compan=
y, Entergy and AEP are included in the present ruling (although it may be s=
ubsequently expanded). Southern Company and Entergy in particular have exhi=
bited some resistance in following FERC's consolidation mandate regarding n=
ational RTOs, so it is probably not a mere coincidence that these three uti=
lities have been singled out. This must be particularly painful for Souther=
n Company, which gains a good part of its profits from wholesale trading an=
d previously expressed plans to double the size of its generation assets ov=
er the next five years.=20
Interestingly, Commissioner Linda Key Breathitt represented the single diss=
enting vote in the ruling. Breathitt's concern was that the ruling had been=
 pulled together too quickly and not enough time had been provided to evalu=
ate the impact on wholesale markets. This issue will undoubtedly be contest=
ed, and to a certain extent the utilities impacted by the ruling appear to =
have been caught off-guard. AEP, Entergy and Southern Company all issued st=
atements to the effect that they were uncertain about the extent to which t=
he ruling would impact them, and that they were reserving the right for pos=
sible litigation.=20
Moreover, to summarize the commission's rulemaking, I think there are a han=
dful of important points that should be considered. First, the ruling illus=
trates the steps that FERC is taking to revoke market-price authority that =
was for the most part unrestricted prior to the time that Pat Wood assumed =
his post as chairman. Second, FERC is implementing cost-based prices on the=
 spot market only, and in only very defined circumstances. However, this co=
uld be an indication that the commission may extend cost-based pricing to o=
ther wholesale transactions, including long-term contracts, at a later time=
. Third, the "split the savings" cost-based formula could become fraught wi=
th its own problems. Its requirements are rather complex and it offers the =
potential to give power purchasers a market advantage on the spot market ov=
er power sellers, which will now be required to post incremental costs in t=
he bidding process. Finally, one of the inherent drivers of FERC's new ruli=
ng is its desire to have large utilities join the RTOs that the commission =
has approved. It is very significant that the new ruling immediately impact=
s AEP, Entergy and Southern Company, utilities that have not only been deem=
ed by the commission to have market power in their regions but which have a=
lso not yet joined an approved RTO. However, even though only three compani=
es are immediately impacted by this ruling, it should not be overlooked tha=
t the ruling holds impact for the market as a whole as other sellers now wi=
ll gain important pricing information about the major suppliers in certain =
areas. Thus, overall this is a very significant ruling and one that could s=
ubstantially change the manner in which transactions in the wholesale power=
 market are conducted.=20

Automatic segmentation techniques for cell images in connectomics often result in merge and split inaccuracies that necessitate proofreading for correction. Prior studies have pinpointed the visual search for these inaccuracies as a significant hurdle in interactive proofreading. To facilitate the correction process, we have created two classifiers that automatically suggest potential merges and splits to the user. These classifiers utilize a convolutional neural network (CNN) trained on errors from automatic segmentations compared to expert-annotated ground truth. Our classifiers identify regions that may contain errors by analyzing a broad context area surrounding a segmentation boundary. Users can then make corrections through simple yes/no choices, achieving a 7.5x faster reduction in variation of information compared to earlier proofreading techniques. Additionally, we introduce a fully-automated mode that employs a probability threshold to determine merge/split actions. Comprehensive experiments utilizing the automatic method and assessing the performance of novice versus expert users indicate that our approach outperforms leading proofreading techniques across various connectomics datasets.

Rewritten:
Automatic cell image segmentation methods in connectomics produce merge and
split errors, which require correction through proofreading. Previous research
has identified the visual search for these errors as the bottleneck in
interactive proofreading. To aid error correction, we develop two classifiers
that automatically recommend candidate merges and splits to the user. These
classifiers use a convolutional neural network (CNN) that has been trained with
errors in automatic segmentations against expert-labeled ground truth. Our
classifiers detect potentially-erroneous regions by considering a large context
region around a segmentation boundary. Corrections can then be performed by a
user with yes/no decisions, which reduces variation of information 7.5x faster
than previous proofreading methods. We also present a fully-automatic mode that
uses a probability threshold to make merge/split decisions. Extensive
experiments using the automatic approach and comparing performance of novice
and expert users demonstrate that our method performs favorably against
state-of-the-art proofreading methods on different connectomics datasets.

In 2002, Adrienne Willis, a single mother of three and part-time librarian, is trying to help her daughter Amanda cope with depression. Amanda's struggles stem from the loss of her husband and the challenges of raising their two children. To show Amanda that life goes on despite adversity, Adrienne shares a story about her own past. It begins in 1988, when Adrienne met Paul Flanner. At the time, she was dealing with the aftermath of her husband leaving her for a younger woman. With the added burden of caring for her ailing father and raising their children on her own, Adrienne's life had become overwhelming. However, when a friend offered her the chance to manage an inn in the small coastal town of Rodanthe, North Carolina, Adrienne saw an opportunity to escape her troubles. As she arrives in Rodanthe, a severe storm is forecast, but Adrienne is not alone for long. Paul Flanner, a fifty-four-year-old father and former successful surgeon, has also arrived in town. He has sold his home and practice, seeking a chance to heal and find peace after a painful divorce and a tragic loss in his medical career. As the storm approaches, Adrienne and Paul find comfort in each other's company, and their shared experiences lead to a romantic connection. However, as the days pass, they both come to realize that their time together is limited, and they must eventually return to their separate lives. Paul has promised to join his estranged son in Ecuador, where he will be working at a medical clinic. Despite the distance and uncertainty, Adrienne and Paul continue to communicate through letters, deepening their love for each other. Tragically, Paul's time in Ecuador is cut short when he passes away.

Rewritten:
The story begins in 2002 in Rocky Mount, North Carolina. Adrienne Willis, a part-time librarian and divorced mother of three, is helping her daughter, Amanda, cope with depression. Amanda is having problems coping with the loss of her husband and is having difficulties raising her two children. In an effort to show that life goes on despite trying times, Adrienne tells her daughter the story of her relationship with Paul Flanner, whom she met in 1988. Adrienne was abandoned for a younger woman by her husband. She parented their children alone and took care of her sick father. This had worn her down. So when an opportunity comes along to tend an inn in the small coastal town of Rodanthe, North Carolina for a friend, Adrienne decides to do it. As soon as she arrives, a major storm is forecast. Meanwhile, Paul, a fifty-four-year-old father, arrives in Rodanthe. He has sold his home and practice, and now wishes to travel to an isolated place where he can seek relief from his shattered life. A successful surgeon, he has recently divorced from his wife, and has had a patient die. While the storm looms, the two characters, the only people at the inn, find compassion in one another and fall in love. After a few days, Adrienne and Paul slowly realize that once they leave, they must return to their separate lives. Paul explains a promise to join his estranged son in a medical clinic in Ecuador; eventually, he and Adrienne part. Adrienne returns to Rocky Mount. Paul heads for Ecuador. They communicate through letters, further fortifying their love. Paul, however, dies in Ecuador.

It was nearly a year before the American Revolution came to an end when 13-year-old Betsy Zane decided to leave behind the comforts of her life in Philadelphia with her great-aunt. She had grown tired of the old-fashioned stories of patriotism and the restrictive social norms that came with living in a city. Betsy longed to join her five brothers in their home in western Virginia, where she could finally experience the freedom of the countryside that she had missed so dearly since being forced to leave as a child. When her great-aunt passed away, Betsy was given the chance to leave the grand mansion behind. She decided to set out on a journey to find her way to the family homestead, giving her great-aunt's slaves their freedom and packing only the few belongings she could carry. Along the way, Betsy faced challenges related to slavery, loyalty, and family, and she even found love with a soldier. In the midst of this adventure, she found herself running towards the historic Fort Henry, where the final battle of the Revolution was taking place. This true story is filled with historical details, and an author's note and bibliography are included to provide further context.

Rewritten:
A little more than a year before the end of the American Revolution, thirteen-year-old Betsy Zane left her comfortable life in Philadelphia with her great-aunt, tired of her old-fashioned, patriotic tales and bored with the petticoats and polite society. She was longing to join her five brothers in their western Virginia home and finally enjoy some freedom in the countryside she had so dearly missed since her parents forced her to leave it as a child. When her great-aunt died, Betsy had the opportunity to leave her great-aunt’s mansion. So, giving the slaves their freedom and packing what few belongings she could carry, she set out to find safe passage to the homestead she had so long dreamed of. Throughout her journey she had to learn to deal with slavery, loyalty, and family. She also fell in love with a soldier and, in the greatest adventure of her life, ran out with a cannon-shot for the historical Fort Henry, which turned out to be the final battle of the Revolution. Based on a true story, this adventure on the frontier is filled with historical details. An author’s note and bibliography are also included.

In the task of interactive image segmentation, the Particle Competition and Cooperation (PCC) model utilizes a complex network derived from the input image. During the network construction phase, a weight vector is required to establish the significance of each element within the feature set, which includes color and location data of the respective pixels, necessitating the involvement of a specialist. This paper suggests removing the weight vector by making adjustments in the network construction phase.

The proposed model was compared to the reference model, which still employs a weight vector, using 151 images sourced from the Grabcut dataset, the PASCAL VOC dataset, and the Alpha matting dataset.

Each model was tested 30 times on each image to calculate an average error. 

The simulations revealed an error rate of just 0.49% for pixel classification with the proposed model, while the reference model exhibited an error rate of 3.14%. Additionally, the proposed method showed reduced error variation across the diverse set of evaluated images compared to the reference model.

Rewritten:
In the interactive image segmentation task, the Particle Competition and
Cooperation (PCC) model is fed with a complex network, which is built from the
input image. In the network construction phase, a weight vector is needed to
define the importance of each element in the feature set, which consists of
color and location information of the corresponding pixels, thus demanding a
specialist's intervention. The present paper proposes the elimination of the
weight vector through modifications in the network construction phase. 

The
proposed model and the reference model, without the use of a weight vector,
were compared using 151 images extracted from the Grabcut dataset, the PASCAL
VOC dataset and the Alpha matting dataset. 

Each model was applied 30 times to
each image to obtain an error average. 

These simulations resulted in an error
rate of only 0.49\% when classifying pixels with the proposed model while the
reference model had an error rate of 3.14\%. The proposed method also presented
less error variation in the diversity of the evaluated images, when compared to
the reference model.

Located in San Pedro Bay, off the coast of Long Beach, California, the Thums Islands are a unique group of four artificial islands. Constructed in the late 1960s, these islands were initially built to access the East Wilmington oil field. To minimize their impact, the islands were designed with landscaping and noise-dampening walls, effectively disguising the oil operation and reducing noise levels. The Thums Islands stand out as the only decorative offshore oil platforms in the United States. The name 'Thums Islands' originates from the consortium, THUMS, which is an acronym for Texaco, Humble, Unocal, Mobil, and Shell. Since 1967, the islands have been known as the Astronaut Islands, with each one named after an American astronaut who lost their life while working with NASA. Island Freeman is dedicated to Theodore C. "Ted" Freeman, the first person to die in an airplane accident while on duty with NASA. Islands Chaffee, Grissom, and White are named in honor of the Apollo I crew members, Roger B. Chaffee, Virgil I. "Gus" Grissom, and Ed White, who tragically lost their lives in a launch pad fire.

Rewritten:
The Thums Islands are a group of four artificial islands in San Pedro Bay, offshore from Long Beach, California. The Thums Islands were constructed in the late 1960s in order to tap the East Wilmington oil field. The landscaping and noise-dampening walls were intended to disguise the operation and suppress noise. They are the only decorative offshore oil platforms in the United States. The Thums Islands were named after the consortium that originally won the operating contract, THUMS, which is in turn a contraction of Texaco, Humble, Unocal, Mobil, and Shell. Since 1967 they have been known as the Astronaut Islands because each island is named after an American astronaut who died while on duty with NASA. Island Freeman (Theodore C. "Ted" Freeman) is named after the first man to die in an airplane accident while on duty with NASA. Island Chaffee (Roger B. Chaffee), Grissom (Virgil I. "Gus" Grissom), and White (Ed White) are named after the Apollo I crew that died in a fire on the launch pad.

I would greatly appreciate it if individuals could take more initiative and bring the item home themselves.

Note: I've rewritten the text to convey the same message in a more polite and less confrontational manner, while maintaining the same structure and personal tone.

To prepare a delicious chicken cutlet dish, you will need the following ingredients: one pound of thin-cut boneless skinless chicken breasts, two tablespoons of olive oil, one tablespoon of balsamic vinegar, one clove of garlic that has been minced or pressed, two slices of whole wheat bread, kosher salt, and black pepper. 

Begin by marinating the chicken breasts in a mixture of olive oil, balsamic vinegar, and garlic in a medium-sized bowl for 15 minutes. Next, process the bread in a food processor until it is broken down into medium-sized crumbs, which should take around 10 pulses. Season the breadcrumbs with salt and pepper to taste. Transfer the breadcrumbs to a shallow dish or a rimmed plate and set them aside.

In a separate bowl, whisk together one large egg, and on a medium-sized plate, place a quarter cup of all-purpose flour. To coat the chicken cutlets, start by dipping a piece of chicken in the flour, then in the egg, and finally in the breadcrumbs. Gently press down on the chicken to ensure the breadcrumbs adhere, and then flip it over to coat the other side. Place the breaded cutlet on a plate and repeat the process with the remaining pieces of chicken.

Heat a large frying pan over medium-high heat and add a quarter cup of vegetable oil. Once the oil is hot, add the breaded chicken cutlets to the pan and cook until they are browned on both sides and cooked through, which should take around 8 minutes in total. Use a spatula to carefully transfer the cooked chicken to a plate lined with paper towels to blot any excess oil. Serve the chicken cutlets with a side of greens, such as baby spinach, arugula, or chopped endive.

Rewritten:
1 pound thin-cut boneless skinless chicken breasts
2 tablespoons olive oil
1 tablespoon balsamic vinegar
1 clove garlic, minced or pressed through garlic press (or 1/4 teaspoon granulated garlic)
2 slices whole wheat bread (or sub 1 cup panko breadcrumbs)
Kosher salt and black pepper
1 large egg
1/4 cup all-purpose flour
1/4 cup vegetable oil
Marinate the chicken breasts in the olive oil, balsamic vinegar and garlic in a medium bowl for 15 minutes. Place bread in a food processor and pulse until medium-size crumbs are formed, about 10 pulses. Season with salt and pepper. Transfer the breadcrumbs (or panko) to a shallow baking dish or rimmed plate and set aside. Whisk egg in a medium bowl and place flour on medium plate. Dip a piece of the chicken in flour, then egg and then breadcrumbs, lightly pressing down on the chicken and then turning it over to coat other side. Set breaded cutlet on a plate and repeat with remaining pieces of chicken. Heat vegetable oil in a large frying pan over medium-high heat. Add cutlets to the pan and cook until brown on each side and cooked through, about 8 minutes total. Use a spatula to transfer chicken to paper-towel-lined plate to blot before serving. Serve with some greens on side - baby spinach, arugula and chopped endive are all good choices.

The Nintendo DS has been upgraded with a new set of features that allow it to function as a portable radio, music player, and movie player. This media player accessory can be loaded with TV shows, films, or music files and can be played on the go. Nintendo is hoping to gain a strong foothold in the portable game market with the addition of this media player. The DS is set to be released in Japan in February, following its initial launch on December 2. This highly anticipated device boasts two screens, one of which is touch-sensitive, and a wireless transmitter that enables users to compete with others. The introduction of the media player is seen as a response to the Sony PSP, a multimedia device and game machine that is also capable of playing films and music. Sony is planning to release similar features for its PSP. As the dominant force in the portable game market, Nintendo owes its success to its popular GameBoy series. The GameBoy Advance has sold over 28 million units worldwide, while the DS has already sold two and a half million units in Japan. However, the media player accessory will only be available in Japan, with a price tag of around five thousand yen, or approximately twenty-five dollars, which is roughly the price difference between the DS and the Sony PSP.

Rewritten:
With the DS, the manufacturer has now introduced a set of buttons that allow it to be used as a portable radio, and as a music player and portable movie player. The DS has an accessory that can be loaded with TV programs, films, or MP3 files, and can be played while on the move. The game giant is hoping to dominate the portable game market with the addition of this media player. Nintendo has announced that the DS will be available in Japan in February. The DS, the successor to the highly successful GameBoy, went on sale in Japan on December 2. The DS has two screens, one of which is touch-sensitive, and it has a wireless transmitter that can be used to compete with others. The launch of the media player, an attempt to make the DS a more general-purpose device, is considered a reaction to the launch of the Sony PSP, which is designed as a multimedia device and a game machine. Sony is preparing to put films and music on its PSP. The buttons are also compatible with the GameBoy Advance SP. Nintendo dominates the portable game machine market, thanks to its wildly successful GameBoy series. The GameBoy Advance has sold more than 28 million times worldwide. The DS, which has two screens, is said to have sold two and a half million units in Japan so far. But the company has no plans to sell the button outside Japan. When the button goes on sale, it will cost about five thousand yen, or about twenty-five dollars, which is the difference between the price of the DS and that of the Sony PSP.

George - I've prepared some T-accounts (the accountant in me) and I believe the following is the most effective way to proceed:  
Modify the existing deals, 547201 and 591307, to a zero price. This will clear the A/R balance on HPL's records for GLO, while maintaining the volume assigned to GLO and not affecting UA4.  
Create a ticket on HPL for a sale to ENA reflecting the value of the gas that was set to zero on the previous tickets. This should be recorded as a demand charge only, with amounts of $974,144 for January 01 and $766,304 for February 01.  
Create a ticket on ENA where the ENA-Wellhead Book purchases the demand from HPL. The amounts will match those in #2 above.  
Create a ticket on ENA where the ENA-Wellhead Book sells demand to EGM for the value of the crude oil from the previous month. For January 01, the sale will be for $886,638.60 (the December 00 Crude Oil delivered to EGM by GLO). For February 01, the sale will be for $839,008.29 (the January 01 Crude Oil delivered to EGM by GLO).  
This will necessitate the following actions to be taken monthly as this deal progresses:  
The price on the sale from HPL to GLO will need to be set to zero each month.  
The demand charges in steps 2 and 3 will need to be updated to reflect the zeroed-out value.

Subject:	GLO/EGM Gas/Crude Swap
George - I've done some T-accounts (the bean counter in me) and I think the following is the best way to handle this going forward:
	
Change the existing deals, 547201 and 591307, to a zero price. This will eliminate the A/R balance on HPL's books for GLO, but will keep the volume nom'd to GLO and will not impact UA4.
Enter a ticket on HPL for a sale to ENA for the value of the gas that was zeroed out on the above tickets. This should be entered as a demand charge only and the amounts should be $974,144 for 1/01 and $766,304 for 2/01.
Enter a ticket on ENA where the ENA-Wellhead Book purchases the demand from HPL. The amounts would be the same as in #2 above.
Enter a ticket on ENA where the ENA-Wellhead Book sells demand to EGM for the value of the crude oil for the prior month. For 1/01, the sale would be for $886,638.60 (the 12/00 Crude Oil delivered to EGM by GLO). For 2/01, the sale would be for $839,008.29 (the 1/01 Crude Oil delivered to EGM by GLO).
This will require the following steps be taken monthly as this deal goes forward:
The price on the sale from HPL to GLO will need to be zeroed out monthly.
The demand charges on steps 2 and 3 will have to be updated to reflect the value zeroed out.
The demand charges on step 4 will have to be updated to reflect the value of the crude delivered to EGM.
Once this is done, the A/R balance for GLO will be cleared, the margin will be on the ENA Wellhead book, and the intercompany transactions will move the money from EGM to HPL. This needs to be done monthly prior to flash, which will prevent any OA variances. The index for the gas value is available shortly after the 1st of the month, and since the volume is firm, there shouldn't be a problem calculating the value. We should also know the value of the crude oil so that we can flash the sale from ENA to EGM. If you have any questions or see a better way to do this, please let me know. Thanks.

As night descends and the sun dips below the horizon, the spirits of the dead come alive. They wander the streets, their movements eerily silent and solitary. Every soul, regardless of their past, joins in the haunting dance. Saints and sinners alike, they sway to the rhythm, their steps in perfect harmony. The dance of the dead is relentless, never-ending, and unfazed by the passage of time. It's a spectacle that transcends social boundaries, with the poor and the wealthy, the young and the old, all moving as one. Even the cries of infants can't slow the pace, as the dead dance on, their movements a mesmerizing blend of gliding, swaying, and effortless elegance. When the dead finally enter your room, they extend their hands, inviting you to join in their eternal dance. Come, soldiers and lovers, come one and all, and dance to the rhythm of the dead, who move forever, driven by an unyielding passion for the dance that has become their eternal existence.

Rewritten:
Once the sun has disappeared behind the horizon, once the night has taken hold, the dead dance. They roam the streets, silent and alone. Everyone dances, saints and sinners, everyone dances, in time to the rhythm, everyone dances, the dance of the dead. The dance of the dead goes on and on and on, never stopping, never slowing down, time means nothing to the dead. Everyone dances, the poor and the rich, everyone dances, to the cry of babies, everyone dances, the dance of the dead. When the time comes, the dead dance into your room, full of silent movements, gliding, swaying, graceful, effortless. They hold out their hands to you and you take them and join in the dance of the dead. Come on, everyone dances, soldiers and lovers, oh, everyone dances, in time to the cry of the little babies, come on, everyone dances, the dance of the dead. Everyone dances. Why do they dance? Because they dance forever.

Liverpool icon Phil Thompson has urged Steve Gerrard to resist any potential advances from Chelsea. In a candid interview with BBC Radio Five Live, Thompson expressed his concerns that any honors won at Chelsea would be diminished by the team's focus on buying success rather than earning it. He acknowledged that Liverpool would consider any offer made for Gerrard's services, but ultimately, the decision would rest with the player.

Thompson was quick to defend Gerrard against criticism from some Liverpool supporters, who questioned his commitment following the Carling Cup final defeat against Chelsea. The fans had even gone so far as to sarcastically label Gerrard's own goal as his first for Chelsea. Thompson was appalled by these comments, describing them as "diabolical" and "outrageous." He praised Gerrard for his dedication to the club, citing his impressive performances over the past two seasons.

As a former Liverpool player who enjoyed seven title-winning seasons and two European Cup triumphs, Thompson is confident that the prospect of Champions League football will keep Gerrard at Anfield. He hopes that Liverpool will qualify for the Champions League, either by winning the Premier League or finishing fourth, and that Gerrard will commit to the club. Thompson believes that Gerrard is at a crossroads and will need to make a decision that benefits both himself and Liverpool.

Rewritten:
Liverpool legend Phil Thompson has pleaded with Steve Gerrard to reject any overtures from Chelsea.
The ex-Reds assistant boss also warned that any honours won at Chelsea would be cheapened by the bid to buy success. He told BBC Radio Five Live: "Liverpool would think about any bid made but it will all be down to Steve in the end. "But it wouldn't have that same sweet feeling at Chelsea, where it's all money-orientated and about simply buying the best." Thompson reacted sharply to some Liverpool supporters, who criticised Gerrard's performance in the Carling Cup final against Chelsea. A number of fans questioned Gerrard's commitment and sarcastically branded his own goal in Liverpool's 0-2 defeat as his first goal for Chelsea.
Thompson added: "I heard those comments from so-called supporters and they were diabolical, absolutely outrageous. "Stevie carried the club last year and this year. He's always put Liverpool first." Thompson, who savoured seven title-winning seasons and two European Cup triumphs during his Anfield playing career, is confident that the lure of Champions League football will keep Gerrard at Anfield. "I hope Champions League football will beckon for Liverpool - either as winners or as finishing fourth in the Premiership - and he will commit himself. "There has been a lot of soul-searching the way things have gone lately. "I hope he's hardening to the fact he will have big decisions to make but I hope it is to the benefit of Steven Gerrard and I hope it is worthwhile for Liverpool."

We present a novel, smooth estimator for the ROC curve, which relies on log-concave density estimates of the underlying distributions. Our analysis demonstrates that this estimator is asymptotically equivalent to the empirical ROC curve when the constituent densities are indeed log-concave. Furthermore, we empirically verify that our proposed estimator outperforms the standard empirical estimate in terms of efficiency for finite sample sizes across various scenarios. Moreover, it is only marginally less efficient, if at all, compared to the fully parametric binormal estimate when the underlying distributions are normal. Notably, our estimator exhibits robustness against modest deviations from the log-concavity assumption. We also show that bootstrap confidence intervals for the ROC curve value at a fixed false positive fraction, based on our new estimate, are generally shorter than those obtained using the approach by Zhou & Qin (2005), while maintaining the desired coverage probability. The computation of our proposed estimate can be efficiently carried out using the R package logcondens, which implements univariate log-concave density estimation, and can be accomplished with a single line of code. These findings lead us to recommend our estimate for a broad range of applications.

Rewritten:
We introduce a new smooth estimator of the ROC curve based on log-concave
density estimates of the constituent distributions. We show that our estimate
is asymptotically equivalent to the empirical ROC curve if the underlying
densities are in fact log-concave. In addition, we empirically show that our
proposed estimator exhibits an efficiency gain for finite sample sizes with
respect to the standard empirical estimate in various scenarios and that it is
only slightly less efficient, if at all, compared to the fully parametric
binormal estimate in case the underlying distributions are normal. The
estimator is also quite robust against modest deviations from the log-concavity
assumption. We show that bootstrap confidence intervals for the value of the
ROC curve at a fixed false positive fraction based on the new estimate are on
average shorter compared to the approach by Zhou & Qin (2005), while
maintaining coverage probability. Computation of our proposed estimate uses the
R package logcondens that implements univariate log-concave density estimation
and can be done very efficiently using only one line of code. These obtained
results lead us to advocate our estimate for a wide range of scenarios.

Gordon D'Arcy has been excluded from the Ireland squad for Saturday's Six Nations match against Scotland at Murrayfield. Similar to captain Brian O'Driscoll, D'Arcy was unable to recover from a hamstring injury. The team will now be captained by Munster lock Paul O'Connell. Shane Horgan will move from the wing to the centre, where he will partner with Ulster's Kevin Maggs. Girvan Dempsey will step into the right wing position, and Gavin Duffy has been added to the bench. "We gave Gordon an opportunity, but it didn't pan out," stated Ireland coach Eddie O'Sullivan. "Considering the risk factor, it was a wise precaution. He should be ready for the next match, but we don't want to take any chances." Maggs, who will earn his 67th cap, was the clear choice to fill the centre position, while Shane Horgan was expected to shift from the wing. The only other alteration to the Ireland lineup from last weekend's victory in Rome is Wasps flanker Johnny O'Connor taking the place of Denis Leamy. O'Connor will be making his third appearance after debuting in the win against South Africa last November. 
: Murphy, Dempsey, Horgan, Maggs, Hickie, O'Gara, Stringer, Corrigan, Byrne, Hayes, O'Kelly, O'Connell, capt, S Easterby, O'Connor, Foley. 
: Sheahan, Horan, O'Callaghan, Miller, G Easterby, Humphreys, Duffy.

Rewritten:
Gordon D'Arcy has been ruled out of the Ireland team for Saturday's Six Nations clash against Scotland in Murrayfield.
Like skipper Brian O'Driscoll, D'Arcy failed to recover from a hamstring injury. The side will now be led by Munster lock Paul O'Connell. Shane Horgan switches from wing to centre where he will be joined by Ulster's Kevin Maggs. Girvan Dempsey comes into the team to take the right wing spot while Gavin Duffy is called up to the replacements. ''We gave Gordon a chance but it didn't work out,'' said Ireland coach Eddie O'Sullivan. ''In terms of the risk element, it was a sensible precaution. He should be fine for the next game but we do not want to tempt fate.''
Maggs, who will win his 67th cap, was the obvious replacement at centre while Shane Horgan was always likely to be moved from the wing. The only other change to the Ireland side from last weekend's win in Rome sees Wasps flanker Johnny O'Connor replacing Denis Leamy. O'Connor will be winning his third cap after making his debut in the victory over South Africa last November.
: Murphy, Dempsey, Horgan, Maggs, Hickie, O'Gara, Stringer, Corrigan, Byrne, Hayes, O'Kelly, O'Connell, capt, S Easterby, O'Connor, Foley.
: Sheahan, Horan, O'Callaghan, Miller, G Easterby, Humphreys, Duffy.

The Liberal Democrats may not be aware of how to effectively describe their position in British politics - the real opposition, the valid opposition, the effective opposition, or the authentic opposition. 

However, the Liberal Democrats are entering the expected 2005 election campaign determined to prove it is they, not the Tories, who are now the real threat to Labour. As Tory leader Michael Howard kicked off his election campaign, the Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy dismissed the Conservatives as a "fading" force. And he insisted there was "no limit" to his party's ambitions in the coming poll. And he can produce some pretty impressive recent election results to back up his optimism for an election which he believes might just see his party doing big things. Sensitive third-party leaders are usually cautious about making any predictions about how they will do come the big test.

And Mr Kennedy was not falling into that trap when he fired up his campaign from the party's Westminster HQ. He would make no predictions other than that he expected the Liberal Democrats to increase both their votes and their Commons seats at the election. The gap between Labour and the Tories was now so narrow - as proved, he claimed, by the defeat of Labour's Robert Jackson - that only his party offered a genuine alternative. On the war in Iraq, identity cards, student fees, and the council tax, there was nothing to choose between the two big parties, whereas the Liberal Democrats offered costed, sensitive, and achievable policies on things like the council tax, crime, and asylum that would underpin his claim that his party was the only one worth the name.

There was a time when such optimistic sounds coming from the third party could be dismissed as self-delusion. That is no longer the case with the Liberal Democrats. The other parties will still insist that the Liberal Democrats are hopeless whose greatest effect on the poll will be to deny them otherwise winnable seats. Labour, in particular, fears that disillusioned supporters may switch to the Liberal Democrats, allowing the Tories to win some seats. But Mr Kennedy is clearly hoping for a more significant outcome than that. He will not talk about a big breakthrough, although there are those who believe this could well be the election that sees his party crossing some sort of symbolic threshold. They would argue that, by the time of the election after next, the Liberal Democrats may have genuinely replaced the Tories as the party challenging Labour for power. The Liberal Democrats will hope to have made advances because of their consistent stance against the war in Iraq. But Mr Kennedy believes his new manifesto will also offer sensitive, costed, and achievable policies on things like the council tax, crime, and asylum that will underpin his claim that his party is the only one worth the name.

Date: Tue, 6 Nov 2001 20:23:16 -0800 (PST)  
From: no.address@enron.com  
Subject: Daily Update  
Body:  
Today proved to be quite challenging for us as uncertainty in the market persisted. Recent news articles, including one from The Wall Street Journal today, have speculated about potential mergers, acquisitions, and equity investors that Enron might be considering. The reason you haven't seen us addressing these reports is due to our corporate policy of refraining from commenting on market speculation. Nevertheless, I can assure you that we are assessing all options to safeguard the financial stability of this company. I will keep you informed of any developments as they arise.

Vhuuty's smile returned, this time with a sense of satisfaction. She hadn't anticipated her pet's willingness to comply with her wishes, but she was more than happy with the unexpected turn of events. As she continued to caress her pet's back, she leaned in to gently kiss her cheek, followed by a more passionate kiss. The idea of being referred to as Mistress sparked a moment of contemplation in Vhuuty. Her Draenic nature led her to explore darker, more provocative possibilities, which she found intriguing. She gazed down at her pet, admiring the longing and dreamy expression in her eyes. Vhuuty's heart melted at the sight, and she gently stroked her hair, "Mistress would be suitable, my pet. Any term that suits you would be fine, yes."

Rewritten:
Vhuuty smiled again in content. She had to admit, she wasn't expecting her pet to so easily and willingly give in to her desires. She was quite happy with the unusual turn of events, but she certainly didn't mind at all. Her hand continued to softly stroke her back before leaning down to gently kiss her on the cheek before offering another, more passionate kiss as well. When she offered the idea of calling her a Mistress, Vhuuty took a moment to blink and think about it. Of course, her Draenic mind went to much darker, kinkier places, which of course she didn't mind at all. She could certainly work with that as well. She looked down at her new pet, noting how longingly and dreamily she looked into her owner's eyes. She sighed and couldn't help but love that innocent gaze and she gently stroked her hair, "Mistress would work quite fine, my puppy. Anything like that would be fine, yes."

Date: Tue, 20 Jun 2000 06:41:00 -0700 (PDT)  
From: greg.johnston@enron.com  
To: tana.jones@enron.com  
Subject: Canadian Precedent Form of ISDA  
Body:  
Cc: mark.taylor@enron.com, eric.ledain@enron.com, paul.devries@enron.com,  
    chris.gaffney@enron.com  
Bcc: mark.taylor@enron.com, eric.ledain@enron.com, paul.devries@enron.com,  
    chris.gaffney@enron.com  

Tana, Enron Canada is in the process of negotiating a deal with six significant municipalities in Ontario (the "G6") to offer various services for a company that these six entities are establishing, which will encompass both physical and financial trading (for gas and electricity). John Suttle is collaborating with Jan Wilson from our Toronto office to determine the credit terms relevant to this entity for both physical and financial trading, but they have not reached a final conclusion yet. Meanwhile, the G6 has asked us to provide them with a copy of our standard form of master financial trading agreement (including both the ISDA and our abbreviated financial GTC). I assume you receive such requests frequently and was hoping you could email me (i) the ISDA, credit support annex, Paragraph 13, etc., that we would generally implement between ECC and a Canadian counterparty for financial trading of gas and electricity in Canada (i.e., including the Canadian provisions), leaving the credit terms blank for now, and (ii) the financial GTC we utilize for Canadian counterparties.  

Feel free to call me if you have any questions or if there are any issues with preparing and sending these documents to the counterparty.  

Thanks,  
Greg

I attended an advance screening, anticipating your typical "shy kid in high school learns to stand up for himself" feel-good drama. However, this film is so much more than that—I was genuinely astonished by the mature themes and compelling characters. It tackles issues like mental illness, sexual abuse, drugs, and alcohol. I believe the writer/screenwriter/director best described it in the Q&A afterward when he mentioned it was a film that explored the emotional aspects of that stage in life without being overly sentimental. I truly connected with these three teens—Charlie, Sam, and Patrick—and their story never came across as cheesy. It felt authentic, moving, and touching. Make sure to watch this movie!

I spot him as I walk in. I notice him watching me. He catches me staring at him. He quickly looks away, and I do the same. Out of the corner of my eye, I catch him stealing glances at me. He notices my gaze again and turns his head, and I follow suit. I think we are both feeling shy. I realize he’s quite attractive. I position myself with my back to him to gather my thoughts. When I turn back, I find him standing right in front of me. He meets my gaze as I meet his. I lose myself in his striking blue eyes. Those big blue eyes enchant me and seem to draw me into his very essence. They convey every emotion I can think of: sorrow, anger, affection, kindness, joy, loneliness, anguish. I feel a strong pull towards him. I smile, and he returns the gesture. Oh, that smile is intoxicating. I stand before him, unguarded, admiring his stunning features, fueling my inner desire. My heart races, but my mind is racing even faster. How can I express my feelings for him? Will he take me seriously? I take a deep breath and say, “Dan, you’re amazing. There’s no need for you to feel shy.” Go out and conquer the world!

He sees me looking at him again, and turns away, and so do I. I believe we are both embarrassed. I notice he is not bad looking. I stand with my back to him and collect my thoughts. I turn around and see him standing before me. He is looking at me as I am looking at him. I forget myself and look only at his big blue eyes. Big blue eyes that hold me captivated and lead me to the entrance to his soul. They express every human feeling I know: pain, hatred, love, compassion, happiness, solitude, torment. I feel an enticing attraction. I smile, and he with me. Ah, that’s a deadly smile. I stand before him openly and look, feeding my inner fire with his marvelous features. My heart is pounding, but my thoughts are moving too fast. How to tell him I like him? Will he believe me? I draw a deep breath and speak. “Dan, you are wonderful. There is no reason for you to be embarrassed.” Go out and destroy the world!
You're doing a great job!

Medical image segmentation is a crucial prerequisite for the advancement of healthcare systems, particularly in the areas of disease diagnosis and treatment planning. In various medical image segmentation tasks, the U-shaped architecture, commonly referred to as U-Net, has emerged as the de facto standard and has achieved remarkable success. However, due to the inherent locality of convolution operations, U-Net typically exhibits limitations in explicitly modeling long-range dependencies. Transformers, designed for sequence-to-sequence prediction, have surfaced as alternative architectures with built-in global self-attention mechanisms, but they may lead to restricted localization capabilities because of inadequate low-level details. In this paper, we introduce TransUNet, which combines the strengths of both Transformers and U-Net, presenting a robust alternative for medical image segmentation. On one side, the Transformer encodes tokenized image patches from a convolutional neural network (CNN) feature map as the input sequence for extracting global contexts. On the other side, the decoder upsamples the encoded features, which are then integrated with the high-resolution CNN feature maps to facilitate precise localization. We contend that Transformers can function as effective encoders for medical image segmentation tasks, with the integration of U-Net enhancing finer details by recovering localized spatial information. TransUNet demonstrates superior performance compared to various competing methods across different medical applications, including multi-organ segmentation and cardiac segmentation. Code and models are accessible at https://github.com/Beckschen/TransUNet.

Μеdісаl іmаgе sеgmеntаtіоn іs аn еssеntіаl рrеrеquіsіtе fоr dеvеlоріng
hеаlthсаrе sуstеms, еsресіаllу fоr dіsеаsе dіаgnоsіs аnd trеаtmеnt рlаnnіng. Оn
vаrіоus mеdісаl іmаgе sеgmеntаtіоn tаsks, thе u-shареd аrсhіtесturе, аlsо knоwn
аs U-Νеt, hаs bесоmе thе dе-fасtо stаndаrd аnd асhіеvеd trеmеndоus suссеss.
Ноwеvеr, duе tо thе іntrіnsіс lосаlіtу оf соnvоlutіоn ореrаtіоns, U-Νеt
gеnеrаllу dеmоnstrаtеs lіmіtаtіоns іn ехрlісіtlу mоdеlіng lоng-rаngе
dереndеnсу. Τrаnsfоrmеrs, dеsіgnеd fоr sеquеnсе-tо-sеquеnсе рrеdісtіоn, hаvе
еmеrgеd аs аltеrnаtіvе аrсhіtесturеs wіth іnnаtе glоbаl sеlf-аttеntіоn
mесhаnіsms, but саn rеsult іn lіmіtеd lосаlіzаtіоn аbіlіtіеs duе tо
іnsuffісіеnt lоw-lеvеl dеtаіls. Ιn thіs рареr, wе рrороsе ΤrаnsUΝеt, whісh
mеrіts bоth Тrаnsfоrmеrs аnd U-Νеt, аs а strоng аltеrnаtіvе fоr mеdісаl іmаgе
sеgmеntаtіоn. Οn оnе hаnd, thе Τrаnsfоrmеr еnсоdеs tоkеnіzеd іmаgе раtсhеs frоm
а соnvоlutіоn nеurаl nеtwоrk (СΝΝ) fеаturе mар аs thе іnрut sеquеnсе fоr
ехtrасtіng glоbаl соntехts. Оn thе оthеr hаnd, thе dесоdеr uрsаmрlеs thе
еnсоdеd fеаturеs whісh аrе thеn соmbіnеd wіth thе hіgh-rеsоlutіоn СΝΝ fеаturе
mарs tо еnаblе рrесіsе lосаlіzаtіоn.
 Wе аrguе thаt Тrаnsfоrmеrs саn sеrvе аs strоng еnсоdеrs fоr mеdісаl іmаgе
sеgmеntаtіоn tаsks, wіth thе соmbіnаtіоn оf U-Νеt tо еnhаnсе fіnеr dеtаіls bу
rесоvеrіng lосаlіzеd sраtіаl іnfоrmаtіоn. ΤrаnsUΝеt асhіеvеs suреrіоr
реrfоrmаnсеs tо vаrіоus соmреtіng mеthоds оn dіffеrеnt mеdісаl аррlісаtіоns
іnсludіng multі-оrgаn sеgmеntаtіоn аnd саrdіас sеgmеntаtіоn. Соdе аnd mоdеls
аrе аvаіlаblе аt httрs://gіthub.соm/Весksсhеn/ΤrаnsUΝеt.

Body:

	tom.briggs@enron.com, chris.long@enron.com, stephen.burns@enron.com,

	tom.briggs@enron.com, chris.long@enron.com, stephen.burns@enron.com,  
	allison.navin@enron.com, ed@buckham.com, dwatkiss@bracepatt.com,  
	cingebretson@bracepatt.com, joe.hartsoe@enron.com  
Mark: I wanted to inform you that, as we requested, Bill Paxon has sent the attached Letter to the Editor of the Wall Street Journal on behalf of AAE. We are optimistic that his political influence will improve the likelihood of it being published.  
August 9, 2000  
Wall Street Journal  
200 Liberty Street  
New York, NY 10281  
Dear Editor:  
Kudos to John Fialka and Rebecca Smith for their groundbreaking article that attempts to clarify the underlying issues contributing to the energy crisis in the overheated West (Deregulation Leaves Electricity Market Ripe for Manipulation by Power Firms, August 4). This article highlights that the ongoing capacity and delivery crises in electricity across the nation are likely to persist for a straightforward reason: electricity is a new industry still operating under outdated regulations. While it is evolving into a competitive market, the antiquated rules designed for a government-sanctioned monopoly have not been revised.  
Consequently, some traditional utilities are taking advantage of and even exacerbating the crises through actions that are not governed by the old regulations. As detailed in the article, utilities can inflate prices, worsen the energy deficit by withholding electricity from the grid, or obstruct the free flow of electricity across the lines they manage. This is strategic maneuvering that is highly profitable and legal, yet certainly not in the public's best interest.  
The solution to this issue is quite straightforward. New regulations need to be established. Certain outdated laws should be repealed. Additionally, the Federal government must be granted some oversight over this interstate commodity to ensure that the general welfare can exert control over local profiteering. There are legislative proposals in Congress aimed at implementing these changes. However, a few influential utilities are hindering their progress. As long as this obstruction persists, the industry will be unable to advance towards modernization, expand generating capacity, and optimize the transmission of electricity between regions. Eventually, Congress will enact the necessary legislation. Why not do it now?  
Sincerely,  
Bill Paxon  
National Chairman  
Americans for Affordable Electricity

Mark: Just wanted you to be aware per our request, Bill Paxon sent the 
attached Letter to the Editor of the Wall Street Journal on behalf of AAE. 
We hope his political standing will enhance the chances for the paper to 
print it.
August 9, 2000
Wall Street Journal
200 Liberty Street
New York, NY 10281
Dear Editor:
John Fialka and Rebecca Smith are to be congratulated for the first piece of
journalism I am aware of that has attempted to explain what is really behind
the energy problems in the overheated West (Deregulation Leaves Electricity
Market Ripe for Manipulation by Power Firms, August 4). As this piece makes
clear, these crises of capacity and delivery of electricity around the
nation are doomed to continue for a simple reason: electricity is a new
game, still being played under old rules. It is becoming a competitive
market, but the old rules written for a government-sanctioned monopoly market 
haven't been
updated.
As a result, some old-line utilities are exploiting and even contributing to
the crises with behavior that is not controlled by the old rules. As the
story details, utilities can drive prices up, exacerbate the energy shortage
by withholding electricity from the grid, or impede the free flow of
electricity across lines they control. It's gamesmanship, very profitable
and not illegal, but definitely not in the public interest.
There is a very simple fix to the problem. Write new rules. Some old
laws need to be repealed. Some new oversight over this interstate commodity
has to be given the Federal government so that the general welfare gains
some control over local profiteering. There are bills in Congress that make
these fixes. But a few powerful utilities block their passage. As long as
this blockade remains in effect, the industry cannot move forward to
modernize itself, build new generating capacity, and streamline the way
electricity moves from region to region. Some day, Congress will pass the
needed legislation. Why not now?
Sincerely,
Bill Paxon
National Chairman
Americans for Affordable Electricity

Κασάκ, the envious nephew of a wealthy village leader in Παδάνγκ, harbors jealousy towards Μίδουν, the devout and well-liked son of a poor farmer. Κασάκ frequently tries to provoke Μίδουν into a confrontation. After Μίδουν rescues his wife from drowning, Κασάκ becomes furious at the idea that Μίδουν had touched her and assaults him. Μίδουν retaliates, swiftly knocking Κασάκ out. Consequently, Μίδουν is compelled to perform tasks for the village leader under Κασάκ's oversight. Still furious with Μίδουν, Κασάκ hires an assassin to eliminate him. When the attempt fails, both the assassin and Μίδουν are captured and imprisoned. While incarcerated, Μίδουν is tortured until he gains a reputation as a skilled fighter. He also encounters Χαλίμαχ, who lives with her stepfather after he returns her diamond necklace. Once released from prison, Μίδουν takes Χαλίμαχ to search for her father in Βογκόρ. After staying with them for two months, Μίδουν plans to go to Βαταβία to seek employment, accompanied by Χαλίμαχ. During their journey, he meets the Arab Indonesian Σούεχ Αμπντούλλα, who lends him money; after refusing to pay the exorbitant interest or allow Αμπντούλλα to marry Χαλίμαχ, Μίδουν is arrested. Following his release, he saves a Dutch youth from an attack in Παζάρ Μπαρού. For rescuing the boy, Μίδουν is offered a job at the police station by the boy's father, the hoofdcommissaris (head commissioner). He also marries Χαλίμαχ. Later, Μίδουν is stationed in Παδάνγκ at the request of the commissioner after learning of his father's death. Κασάκ is arrested for embezzlement, and Μίδουν lives happily ever after.

Rewritten:
Κасаk, thе соnсеіtеd nерhеw оf а rісh vіllаgе lеаdеr іn Раdаng, іs jеаlоus оf Μіdun, thе rеlіgіоus аnd рорulаr sоn оf а рооr fаrmеr; Κасаk оftеn аttеmрts tо gоаd Μіdun іntо fіghtіng hіm. Аftеr Μіdun sаvеs hіs wіfе frоm drоwnіng, Касаk bесоmеs еnrаgеd аt thе thоught thаt Μіdun hаd tоuсhеd hіs wіfе аnd аttасks hіm. Міdun fіghts bасk, quісklу knосkіng Касаk оut. Аs а rеsult оf hіs асtіоns, Μіdun іs fоrсеd tо dо tаsks fоr thе vіllаgе lеаdеr undеr Κасаk's suреrvіsіоn. Stіll еnrаgеd аt Μіdun, Κасаk hіrеs аn аssаssіn tо kіll hіm. Whеn thе аttеmрt fаіls, thе аssаssіn аnd Міdun аrе аrrеstеd аnd sеnt tо рrіsоn. Whіlе іn рrіsоn, Міdun іs tоrturеd untіl hе еаrns а rерutаtіоn fоr bеіng а gооd fіghtеr. Ηе аlsо mееts Наlіmаh, whо lіvеs wіth hеr stерfаthеr, аftеr rеturnіng hеr dіаmоnd nесklасе. Αftеr hе іs rеlеаsеd frоm рrіsоn, Міdun tаkеs Ηаlіmаh tо fіnd hеr fаthеr іn Воgоr. Αftеr lіvіng wіth thеm fоr twо mоnths, Μіdun аttеmрts tо gо tо Ваtаvіа tо fіnd wоrk, tоgеthеr wіth Ηаlіmаh. Αlоng thе wау, hе mееts thе Аrаb Ιndоnеsіаn Sуеkh Аbdullаh, whо lеnds hіm mоnеу; аftеr rеfusіng tо рау thе hіgh іntеrеst оr lеttіng Аbudullаh mаrrу Наlіmаh, Μіdun іs аrrеstеd. Аftеr hіs rеlеаsе, hе sаvеs а Dutсh уоuth bеіng аttасkеd іn Ρаsаr Ваru. Fоr sаvіng thе bоу, Міdun іs grаntеd а jоb аt thе роlісе stаtіоn bу thе bоу's fаthеr, thе hооfdсоmmіssаrіs (hеаd соmmіssіоnеr). Не аlsо mаrrіеs Наlіmаh. Міdun іs lаtеr stаtіоnеd іn Ρаdаng uроn rеquеst tо thе соmmіssіоnеr, аftеr hеаrіng thаt hіs fаthеr hаd dіеd. Касаk іs аrrеstеd fоr еmbеzzlеmеnt, аnd Μіdun lіvеs hарріlу еvеr аftеr.

Compared to the general semantic segmentation challenge, portrait segmentation demands a higher level of precision regarding boundary areas. However, this issue has not been thoroughly explored in earlier studies. In this paper, we introduce a boundary-sensitive deep neural network (BSN) specifically for portrait segmentation. BSN incorporates three innovative techniques. First, we propose an individual boundary-sensitive kernel by dilating the contour line and assigning boundary pixels with multi-class labels. Second, a global boundary-sensitive kernel is utilized as a position-sensitive prior to further constrain the overall shape of the segmentation map. Third, we jointly train a boundary-sensitive attribute classifier alongside the segmentation network to enhance the network with semantic boundary shape information. We have assessed BSN on the largest public portrait segmentation dataset to date, namely the PFSCN dataset, as well as on portrait images gathered from three other popular image segmentation datasets: COCO, COCO-Stuff, and PASCAL VOC. Our approach demonstrates superior quantitative and qualitative performance across all datasets, particularly in the boundary areas.

An injury-time drop goal by Ronan O'Gara clinched a dramatic win for Ireland against Argentina at Lansdowne Road on Saturday. O'Gara was responsible for all of Ireland's points, scoring two drop goals and five penalties, ensuring the home team maintained a perfect record in their autumn internationals. Argentina, who played impressively, seemed to have the match under control until the final moments. The Pumas stunned the Irish early with a try from Federico Aramburu, while Felipe Contepomi contributed 14 points. The well-organized and sharper Pumas outperformed Ireland in the initial phases. Indiscipline allowed Argentina's Leinster fly-half Contepomi to score the first points with a simple penalty in the third minute. He struck again two minutes later, catching a disorganized Ireland off guard with the game's first try. After Ireland lost possession, Manuel Contepomi broke through a disjointed defense and passed to his midfield partner Aramburu, who dashed in for a try under the posts. O'Gara finally got Ireland on the scoreboard with a drop goal in the ninth minute, but Contepomi quickly responded with his second penalty two minutes later. Battling against a strong wind and rain, Ireland struggled in tight situations, leading to numerous turnovers against a tough defense. O'Gara managed to convert his second penalty in the 36th minute, but once again, Contepomi answered back with a penalty four minutes into first-half injury time. The second half began similarly to the first, with O'Gara scoring another penalty in the 45th minute, only for Contepomi to equalize three minutes later. The Pumas' upper-body strength prevented Ireland from gaining control up front, and the three-quarters found little room to operate. Ireland had to depend on O'Gara's kicking to stay competitive rather than executing any planned running plays. The Munsterman added two more penalties—one from 48 meters—bringing his team within four points with 13 minutes left. Ireland's opportunity arose when Argentina's number eight Gonzalo Longo received a yellow card for a line-out infringement with six minutes remaining. O'Gara capitalized on this chance, successfully converting his fifth penalty to set up a tense finish. However, Ireland displayed remarkable composure, positioning themselves for O'Gara to launch a massive drop goal, completing a remarkable, albeit fortunate, comeback.

Rewritten:
An injury-time dropped goal by Ronan O'Gara stole victory for Ireland from underneath the noses of Argentina at Lansdowne Road on Saturday.
O'Gara kicked all of Ireland's points, with two dropped goals and five penalties, to give the home side a 100% record in their autumn internationals. An impressive Argentina appeared in control until the dying seconds. The Pumas shocked the Irish early on with a try from Federico Aramburu, and Felipe Contepomi kicked 14 points. The well-drilled and sharper Pumas out-played and out-thought Ireland in the early stages. Indiscipline allowed Argentina's Leinster fly-half Contepomi to open the scoring in the third minute with a straightforward penalty. He was on the mark again two minutes later when Argentina shocked a ragged Ireland with the first try of the game. Ireland turned the ball over and Manuel Contepomi broke through an unstructured defence before feeding his midfield partner Aramburu to sprint in under the posts. O'Gara finally got Ireland on the board with a dropped goal in the ninth minute only for Contepomi to rifle over his second penalty two minutes later. Playing into a strong wind and rain, Ireland continued to come second best in tight situations, and turnovers began to mount up against a rugged defence. O'Gara managed to land his second penalty in the 36th minute, but once again Contepomi replied in kind four minutes into first-half injury time. The second-half started as the first had ended. O'Gara rifled over another penalty in the 45th minute, but Contepomi matched it three minutes later. The upper-body strength of the Pumas never allowed Ireland to take control up front, while the three-quarters had no space to manoeuvre. Ireland had to rely on O'Gara's boot to keep in touch rather than any contrived running plays. The Munsterman landed two more penalties - one of them from 48 metres - to bring his team to within four points with 13 minutes on the clock remaining. And Ireland's chance came when Argentina's number eight Gonzalo Longo was yellow carded with six minutes to go for an offence in the line-out. O'Gara made no mistake as he rifled over his fifth penalty to set up a tense final few minutes. But Ireland showed great composure to get themselves into a position to allow O'Gara to thump over a massive drop goal to complete a tremendous, if fortuitous, comeback.

In the scorching heat of noon, 
an impenetrable darkness prevails, 
leaving no hope for the day.

As I enter this online poetry site, 
which is darker than the darkest night, 
I feel that I should abandon all hope.
Is this the entrance to hell?
Have they cast a witch's spell 
over all who enter here?

Vague forms hang from ropes, 
heartless figures sinking into the overheated sludge.
Each one is struggling, a Herculean drudge.
I smell fear and despair 
in the noxious, asphyxiating air.

I see sentences harnessed to death, 
and stanzas swooning (out of breath).
The complete absence of punctuation marks 
makes the poems ooze with slime
(There's not even a hint of rhyme!).

I feel I'm drowning in some deep, dark well.
Am I in the lowest chambers of hell?
I've lost my sight, but not my sense of smell
(These poetic hacks cannot even cast a spell!).

What makes things worse is the way 
they butter each other up
with gushing praise and false accolades,
every one of them, with failed grades,
unable to write a poem that's tolerable,
though I must say their versions 
are hideously 'holler'-able!

Tate & Lyle's CEO, Iain Ferguson, has been named the "European Businessman of the Year" by a prominent business publication. This recognition comes as a result of his efforts in revitalizing a historic UK manufacturer, successfully returning it to the FTSE 100 index after a seven-year absence. Under Ferguson's leadership, the company's shares have seen a significant increase of 55% this year, driven by rising sugar prices and growing demand for its artificial sweeteners. Ferguson took on the role of CEO at Tate & Lyle in May 2003, following a career at Unilever, a leading consumer goods company. With a global presence spanning 28 countries and over 60 manufacturing sites, Tate & Lyle has a rich history dating back to its inclusion in the original FTSE 30 index in 1935. Past winners of the European Businessman of the Year award include notable figures such as Fred Goodwin, former CEO of the Royal Bank of Scotland, and Chris Gent, former CEO of Vodafone.

Rewritten:
Iain Ferguson, Tate & Lyle’s chief executive, has been voted the “European Businessman of the Year” by a leading business magazine. He has been acclaimed for restoring one of the United Kingdom’s “venerable” manufacturers to the FTSE 100 index. The sugar group had been out of the FTSE 100 for seven years before Iain Ferguson’s leadership propelled it back into the fold. This year the group’s shares have risen 55%, boosted by strong sugar prices and the increasing demand for its artificial sweeteners. Iain Ferguson was appointed chief executive of Tate & Lyle in May 2003, after having spent the earlier part of his career at consumer goods giant Unilever. Tate & Lyle, which was part of the original FTSE 30 index in 1935, has more than forty factories and another twenty manufacturing sites in 28 countries. Former winners of the European Businessman of the Year title have included Fred Goodwin, chief executive of the Royal Bank of Scotland, and Chris Gent, former chief executive of mobile phone company Vodafone.

Media conglomerate Viacom has disbursed $3.5 million (£1.8 million) to conclude investigations into indecency concerning its radio and television programs in the United States. This settlement with the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) brings to a close a protracted issue that began in 2001. The FCC was examining 50 programs, including those hosted by "shock jock" Howard Stern and two DJs from New York. Stern recently revealed his departure from Viacom, while the two DJs were dismissed after their show featured a couple allegedly engaging in sexual activity in a church. Following the church incident two years ago, Viacom consented to implement audio delay systems at its radio stations that air live content. Additionally, it agreed to provide training for its broadcasters and staff regarding indecency regulations. The agreement halts investigations into approximately 50 radio and television programs, according to Richard Diamond, FCC deputy secretary of communications. These programs were aired by Viacom-owned stations throughout the United States. Viacom has a five-day window to remit the $3.5 million penalty, as stipulated in the agreement. This payment is separate from the FCC's $550,000 (£293,000) fine imposed on Viacom following the exposure of singer Janet Jackson's breast during the CBS Super Bowl halftime show in January, which Viacom is currently contesting. This is not the first instance of Viacom incurring costs due to indecency allegations; Infinity Broadcasting, a Viacom subsidiary, paid a total of $1.7 million (£907,000) in 1995 to resolve FCC violations involving Stern.

Rewritten:
Media giant Viacom has paid out $3.5m (£1.8m) to end investigations into indecency in its US radio and TV shows.
The settlement to the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) ends a long-running saga dating back to 2001. The FCC was looking into 50 shows, including those by "shock jock" Howard Stern and two New York DJs. Stern recently announced he was leaving Viacom while the two DJs were sacked after their show featured a couple purporting to have sex in a church. After the church incident two years ago Viacom agreed to install audio delay equipment at its radio stations that broadcast live programming.
It also agreed to train its broadcasters and employees about indecency laws. The agreement cancels investigations into about 50 radio and television shows, said Richard Diamond, FCC deputy secretary of communications. The shows were broadcast by Viacom-owned stations across the United States. Viacom has five days to pay the $3.5m fine, according to the agreement. The payment is not related to the FCC's $550,000 (£293,000) fine levied against Viacom after the exposure of singer Janet Jackson's breast during the CBS Super Bowl halftime show in January. Viacom is contesting that fine. It is not the first time that Viacom has paid out over indecency charges. Infinity Broadcasting, which is owned by Viacom, paid cumulative fines totalling $1.7m (£907,000) in 1995 to settle FCC violations by Stern.

I understand that this isn't solely about BPD, but I feel that my family's struggles with being overweight and overeating are triggering my eating disorder. I'm unsure how to gently express to them that their eating habits are negatively impacting me, as watching them consume four servings of dinner in one sitting makes me feel disgusted by their bodies. I feel so mean, especially since I am currently overweight myself, and I have also experienced being obese and underweight in the past. It's incredibly triggering, and I don't know if I'm just meant to endure this in silence or if I should share that it's hurting me. Additionally, there's the possibility that even if I did tell them, they might take offense, dislike me, and continue to eat poorly in front of me, which would only trigger me further with arguments and no solutions.
