 SECOND CAUSE OF ACTION
For Violations of the Unfair Trade Practices Act
Based Upon Violations of the Antitrust Act
(against all defendants)
67. Plaintiffs reallege and incorporate by reference each and every
allegation set forth above.
68. The Unfair Trade Practices Act prohibits all unfair competition,
which is defined as "any unlawful, unfair or fraudulent business act or
practice," and includes violations of the Cartwright Act, oo16700 et seq.
of the B&P Code.
69. As alleged hereinabove, beginning as early as May, 2000, defendants
unlawfully conspired, agreed, arranged and combined to prevent and restrain
competition for the sale of electricity, in violation of oo 16700 et seq.
and oo 17200 et seq. of the B&P Code.
70. Pursuant to B&P Code oo 17200 et seq., Plaintiff brings this action
seeking injunctive relief to enjoin defendants' unfair trade practices and
requiring defendants' disgorgement of all monies obtained by virtue of their
violations of the Cartwright Act as described hereinabove.
71. As a direct and proximate result of the violations alleged herein,
Plaintiff and members of the Class have been unable to and will continue to
be unable to purchase electricity at prices determined by free and open
competition, and Plaintiff and members of the Class have been damaged and
will continue to be damaged by their respective purchases and/or charges for
electricity at prices higher than they would have otherwise paid, absent
defendants' unlawful conduct.
72. Plaintiff and the Class have no adequate remedy at law for their
irreparable injuries.
73. Defendants' acts, contracts, agreements, conspiracies, and
combinations in restraint of trade and free and open competition, alleged
herein, violate the Antitrust Act. Accordingly, Plaintiff and the Class
seek restitution and disgorgement by defendants to the Class of all monies
obtained by defendants' acts of unfair competition with respect to the
contract, conspiracy, combination and trust, and a permanent injunction
enjoining defendants' continuing violations of the Cartwright Act.
/ / /
/ / /
 THIRD CAUSE OF ACTION
For Violations of the Unfair Trade Practices Act
Based Upon Defendants' Unfair Business Acts and Practices
In Charging Unjust and Unreasonable Rates
(against all defendants)
74. Plaintiffs reallege and incorporate by reference each and every
allegation set forth above.
75. Section 17200 et seq. of the California Business & Professions Code
prohibits acts of unfair competition, which include any "unlawful, unfair,
or fraudulent business act or practice and unfair, deceptive, untrue or
misleading advertising".
76. The Defendants consistently engaged in numerous acts of "unfair
competition", as more fully described above, by inter alia, manipulating the
price of wholesale electricity in the California markets.
77. In addition, pursuant to the Federal Power Act:
"All rates and charges made, demanded, or received by any public utility for
or in connection with the transmission or sale of electric energy subject to
the jurisdiction of the Commission . . . shall be just and reasonable and
any such rate or charge that is not just and reasonable is hereby declared
to be unlawful."
16 U.S.C. Section 824d(a).
78. Defendants are public utilities within the term as used in the
foregoing statute.
79. The FERC has specifically found that the prices defendants charged
for the wholesale electricity they sold in the California markets during the
Class Period were in fact unjust and unreasonable. The California Public
Utilities Commission has determined that said unjust and unreasonable prices
resulted from the exercise of market power by generators and traders in the
California wholesale electricity market.
80. As a result of the conduct described above, the defendants
unlawfully acquired money and property from Plaintiff and the Class and have
been and will be unjustly enriched at the expense of Plaintiff and the
members of the Class. Specifically, defendants have deprived Plaintiff and
the Class of billions of dollars in monies from the sale of electricity at
unjust, excessive, and manipulated prices.
/ / /
 81. Pursuant to Section 17203 of the California Business & Professions
Code, Plaintiff and the members of the class seek an order of this Court
restoring to them all money wrongfully taken from them and allowing them a
claim in the full amount of all of defendants' ill-gotten gains, so as to
restore any and all monies to Plaintiff and the members of the Class and the
general public, which were acquired and obtained by means of such unfair and
deceptive acts and practices.
82. Pursuant to Section 17203 of the California Business & Professions
Code, Plaintiff and the members of the class seek an order of this Court
providing appropriate equitable and/or injunctive relief restraining
defendants from charging unjust and unreasonable rates and from manipulating
the electricity markets.
 FOURTH CAUSE OF ACTION
 Violations of the Consumers Legal Remedies Act
 (Against All Defendants)
83. Plaintiffs reallege and incorporate by reference each and every
allegation set forth above.
84. Such acts and practices by defendants violate the Consumer Legal
Remedies Act, Civil Code Section 1750, et seq. Defendants' acts warrant
appropriate injunctive and declaratory relief, including an injunction
restraining them from charging unjust and unfair rates or manipulating the
market for electricity.
FIFTH CAUSE OF ACTION
Unconscionability
(Against All Defendants)
85. Plaintiffs reallege and incorporate by reference each and every
allegation set forth above.
86. Defendants charged rates for wholesale electricity that were
unconscionable given their cost of production, the newly emergent markets
for that product, and the consumers' need for electrical power.
87. Defendants' rates were inherently excessive, invalid and
unconscionable, particularly in light of the deceptive and manipulative
practices they used to inflate the market prices and the vital need
consumers and businesses have for electrical power.
/ / /
 88. Defendants' unconscionable prices were passed through to Plaintiff
and the majority of the Class in the retail electricity rates charged by
SDG&E and thereby directly damaged Plaintiff and the Class.
 VI.
 PRAYER FOR RELIEF
WHEREFORE, Plaintiff and the Class pray for judgment against defendants as
follows:
(a) That the Court determine that this action may be maintained as a
class action and direct that reasonable notice of this action be given to
the members of the Class;
(b) That the combination, contract, arrangement, agreement, conspiracy
and trust alleged herein be adjudged and decreed to be an unreasonable
restraint of trade in violation of Sections 16720 and 16726 of the
California Business and Professions Code;
(c) That damages be granted according to proof, and that Plaintiff and
the Class be awarded treble damages or statutory damages, where applicable,
attorneys' fees, costs and disbursements;
(d) That Plaintiff and the Class be awarded pre- and post-judgment
interest;
(e) That the Court enter appropriate injunctive and other equitable
relief, including the disgorgement of defendants' unlawful profits; and
(f) That Plaintiff and the Class have such other and further relief as
the Court may deem just and proper under the circumstances.

I reside in a solitary house I recognize  
That disappeared many summers ago,  
Leaving no evidence except for the cellar walls,  
And a cellar where the sunlight falls,  
And where the wild raspberries with purple stems thrive.  
Over crumbling fences, the grapevines protect  
The woods returning to the mowed field;  
The orchard tree has formed a thicket  
Of new growth and old where the woodpecker pecks;  
The path leading to the well has healed.  
I live with a strangely aching heart  
In that lost dwelling far away  
On that neglected and forgotten road  
That no longer has a dust-bath for the toad.  
Night falls; the dark bats tumble and swoop;  
The whippoorwill is coming to call  
And hush and cluck and flutter around:  
I hear him start from a distance  
Many times to express his call  
Before he arrives to voice it out.  
It is beneath the small, dim, summer star.  
I do not know who these silent beings are  
That share the dark space with me—  
Those stones beneath the low-branched tree  
Surely have names that the mosses obscure.  
They are tireless beings, yet slow and sorrowful,  
Though two, closely keeping, are girl and boy,—  
With none among them that ever sings,  
And yet, considering how many things,  
They are as sweet companions as one could wish for.

Rewritten:
I dwell in a lonely house I know
That vanished many a summer ago,
And left no trace but the cellar walls,
And a cellar in which the daylight falls,
And the purple-stemmed wild raspberries grow.
O'er ruined fences the grape-vines shield
The woods come back to the mowing field;
The orchard tree has grown one copse
Of new wood and old where the woodpecker chops;
The footpath down to the well is healed.
I dwell with a strangely aching heart
In that vanished abode there far apart
On that disused and forgotten road
That has no dust-bath now for the toad.
Night comes; the black bats tumble and dart;
The whippoorwill is coming to shout
And hush and cluck and flutter about:
I hear him begin far enough away
Full many a time to say his say
Before he arrives to say it out.
It is under the small, dim, summer star.
I know not who these mute folk are
Who share the unlit place with me--
Those stones out under the low-limbed tree
Doubtless bear names that the mosses mar.
They are tireless folk, but slow and sad,
Though two, close-keeping, are lass and lad,--
With none among them that ever sings,
And yet, in view of how many things,
As sweet companions as might be had.

I'm struggling to find the words to express my feelings, so I'll just be honest. I've been feeling overwhelmed by the pressure to meet others' expectations, especially my parents', who believe I have a bright future ahead of me. However, I'm constantly plagued by self-doubt and the fear that I'll never live up to their expectations. My academic performance is poor, I'm not physically active, and I've been putting off learning to play the guitar despite owning an instrument. I know what I should be doing, but I'm unable to take action. I'm also unsure if I'm experiencing depression, but I'm hesitant to consider it, as I don't want to admit to it. I feel like I'm stuck in a rut, and the thought of taking responsibility for my life as an adult is daunting. I get frustrated with myself for wasting time, but I continue to do so, which is disheartening. I'm exhausted and barely sleep, which only adds to my feelings of hopelessness. I often wonder why I'm here, and it's a question that haunts me. I'm not looking to harm myself, but I'm at a loss for what to do to improve my situation. I'm aware that I may not be able to help myself, but I'm hoping that by being honest, I might find some way forward.

Rewritten:
I don’t know how to describe it, so I’m just going to type. I feel like I will never live up to anyone’s expectations, my parents tell me that I will live a good life and do good deeds, but I feel like I will never get that far. I am very bad at school, I never exercise even though I know I should, I want to learn to play the guitar but I haven’t made much progress even though I still have one. I know what I should be doing but I can’t. I don’t know if I’m depressed, I think I’m not, I can’t be. I know that I should get my driver’s license and do this and that, but if I can’t even do what I’m supposed to do now, how the hell am I supposed to handle it when I’m an adult? I get angry at myself for wasting so much goddamn time, but I still do it every goddamn day, and it’s sickening. I feel like I don’t have the energy to do anything that might help me, and it doesn’t help that I barely sleep. Why did God put me here anyway, if only as a cruel joke, I don’t want to kill myself or anything, but I just don’t know why I’m here. Sorry for the rant, I just don’t know what to do. I’m sure I can’t do anything to help myself.

Azriel recounts his journey into becoming an eternal genii, bound to serve the master who summons him. Over the centuries, his loyalty to the Masters deepens, and a warning is inscribed on the casket containing his remains, cautioning against his summoning to prevent his malevolence from being unleashed upon the innocent. After a lengthy period of slumber, Azriel awakens in New York City, bewildered as he witnesses the tragic death of a young girl named Anna Belkin. He becomes intensely driven by the urge to avenge her murder and to uncover the identity of the person who brought him into the physical realm, allowing Esther to perish but failing to save her. This pursuit leads him to Anna's father, David Belkin, who is willing to pay any price to achieve his messianic aspirations through his vast global spiritual organization, the Temple of the Eye of Jesus. As his journey nears its peak, he jeopardizes his magical powers to thwart an attempt to annihilate the planet, thereby reclaiming what has been denied to him for so long: his own eternal human essence.

Rewritten:
Azriel is telling the tale of his transition into and subsequent existence as an eternal genii who is obliged to obey the master who calls him. Over centuries, Azriel grows more faithful to the Masters and a warning is put on the casket of his bones that he is not to be summoned lest his evil be loosed on the undeserving nation. After several years of rest, Azriel finds himself awake and in New York City, a dazed witness to the death of a young girl, Anna Belkin. He becomes suddenly fascinated with the desire to avenge her murder and to find out who called him into the physical world in time to let Esther die but not in time to save her. This quest leads him to the woman's father, David Belkin, who will pay any cost to fulfill his messianic dream through his immense worldwide spiritual organization, the Temple of the Eye of Jesus. As his quest approaches its climax, he risks his magical abilities to forestall an effort to destroy the planet thus redeeming what was denied him for so long: his own eternal human spirit.

Complex arithmetic random waves are stationary Gaussian complex-valued solutions to the Helmholtz equation on a two-dimensional flat torus. We employ Wiener-Itô chaotic expansions to achieve a comprehensive characterization of the second-order high-energy behavior of the total count of phase singularities associated with these functions. Our primary finding indicates that, although these random quantities adhere to a universal law of large numbers, they also display non-universal and non-central second-order fluctuations influenced by the arithmetic properties of the underlying spectral measures. These fluctuations align qualitatively with the cancellation phenomena anticipated by Berry (2002) for complex random waves on compact planar domains. Our findings build upon the groundbreaking work of Rudnick and Wigman (6143), Krishnapur, Kurlberg, and Wigman (2013), as well as Marinucci, Peccati, Rossi, and Wigman (1681) in the complex context. The precise asymptotic characterization of the variance relies on a detailed analysis of the Kac-Rice kernel near the origin, along with an innovative application of combinatorial moment formulas to manage long-range weak correlations.

Rewritten:
Complex arithmetic random waves are stationary Gaussian complex-valued
solutions of the Helmholtz equation on the two-dimensional flat torus. We use
Wiener-It\^o chaotic expansions in order to derive a complete characterization
of the second order high-energy behaviour of the total number of phase
singularities of these functions. Our main result is that, while such random
quantities verify a universal law of large numbers, they also exhibit
non-universal and non-central second order fluctuations that are dictated by
the arithmetic nature of the underlying spectral measures. Such fluctuations
are qualitatively consistent with the cancellation phenomena predicted by Berry
(2002) in the case of complex random waves on compact planar domains. Our
results extend to the complex setting recent pathbreaking findings by Rudnick
and Wigman (6143), Krishnapur, Kurlberg and Wigman (2013) and Marinucci,
Peccati, Rossi and Wigman (1681). The exact asymptotic characterization of the
variance is based on a fine analysis of the Kac-Rice kernel around the origin,
as well as on a novel use of combinatorial moment formulae for controlling
long-range weak correlations.

Three-dimensional image segmentation is a crucial aspect of biomedical image analysis. While 2D and 3D deep learning models have achieved remarkable segmentation performance on 3D biomedical image datasets, each has its own set of advantages and limitations. By integrating the strengths of both 2D and 3D models, it may be possible to achieve more accurate results. In this paper, we introduce a novel ensemble learning framework for 3D biomedical image segmentation that combines the benefits of 2D and 3D models. First, we develop a fully convolutional network-based meta-learner that learns how to enhance the results from 2D and 3D models (base-learners). To prevent over-fitting in our sophisticated meta-learner, we devise a new training method that utilizes the results of the base-learners as multiple versions of "ground truths". Moreover, since our new meta-learner training scheme does not rely on manual annotation, it can leverage an abundance of unlabeled 3D image data to further improve the model. Our approach is extensively evaluated on two public datasets (the HVSMR 2016 Challenge dataset and the mouse piriform cortex dataset), demonstrating its effectiveness under fully-supervised, semi-supervised, and transductive settings, and achieving superior performance compared to state-of-the-art image segmentation methods.

Rewritten:
3D image segmentation plays an important role in biomedical image analysis.
Many 2D and 3D deep learning models have achieved state-of-the-art segmentation
performance on 3D biomedical image datasets. Yet, 2D and 3D models have their
own strengths and weaknesses, and by unifying them together, one may be able to
achieve more accurate results. In this paper, we propose a new ensemble
learning framework for 3D biomedical image segmentation that combines the
merits of 2D and 3D models. First, we develop a fully convolutional network
based meta-learner to learn how to improve the results from 2D and 3D models
(base-learners). Then, to minimize over-fitting for our sophisticated
meta-learner, we devise a new training method that uses the results of the
base-learners as multiple versions of "ground truths". Furthermore, since our
new meta-learner training scheme does not depend on manual annotation, it can
utilize abundant unlabeled 3D image data to further improve the model.
Extensive experiments on two public datasets (the HVSMR 2016 Challenge dataset
and the mouse piriform cortex dataset) show that our approach is effective
under fully-supervised, semi-supervised, and transductive settings, and attains
superior performance over state-of-the-art image segmentation methods.

Swedish tennis player Joachim Johansson secured his second career title with a hard-fought 7-5, 6-3 victory over American Taylor Dent at the Australian hardcourt championships in Adelaide. The match was a closely contested one, with Dent managing to survive three break points in the fifth game. However, Johansson eventually broke through with a stunning backhand return winner, paving the way for a more comfortable win in the second set. This triumph marks Johansson's second tournament win, following his initial success at Memphis in 2004, which propelled him from 113th to 11th in the world rankings. In a post-match interview, Dent expressed his high regard for Johansson, describing him as a top contender for the Australian Open, which is set to begin on 17 January. Dent praised Johansson's ability to hold serve, stating that it would be challenging for opponents to break him if he continues to play at this level. In contrast, Johansson remained modest in his assessment, acknowledging that he needs to improve his serve if he is to achieve his goal of winning the Australian Open.

Rewritten:
Second seed Joachim Johansson won his second career title with a 7-5 6-3 win over Taylor Dent at the Australian hardcourt championships in Adelaide.
The Swede was made to graft, American Dent surviving three break points in the fifth game of the match. But Johansson got the breakthrough with a sublime backhand return winner and won the second set with more ease. His first tournament win was at Memphis in 2004, helping him leap from 113th in the world rankings to number 11. Afterwards, Dent said he rated US Open semi-finalist Johansson as a top contender at the Australian Open, which starts on 17 January. "I believe men's tennis is all about holding serve and if he's playing like that on his own serve I don't see how guys are going to break him," said Dent. Johansson was more restrained in his assessment: "I have to improve my serve if I'm going to go all the way in Melbourne."

To start making the pulusu, chop the chicken into bite-sized pieces. Combine lemon juice, a spoonful of chili powder, and salt in a bowl. Let the chicken marinate in the refrigerator for about an hour. Next, place the chicken pieces in a separate bowl and mix in ghee, chili powder, a pinch of salt, ginger paste, and lemon juice. Cover the bowl and refrigerate the mixture for three to four hours. After that, thread the chicken onto skewers and place them in a baking dish. Preheat the oven to 180 ° C and bake the chicken for twenty minutes.

To prepare the curry, heat a small amount of ghee in a pan over medium heat. Add the onion and cook until it turns golden brown. Then, add the ginger paste, garlic, and green chili to the pan and sauté for a bit. Next, add the tomato paste, chili powder, salt, and water to the pan. Add a drizzle of honey and a sprinkle of fenugreek seeds. Finally, add the chicken to the mixture and cook for another five minutes, or until the chicken is fully cooked. Finish the curry by adding a splash of cream.

Rewritten:
To prepare the pulusu: Cut the chicken into small pieces. Pour the lemon juice, a tablespoon of chili powder and salt into a dish. Marinate the chicken in the refrigerator for one hour. Then put the chicken pieces in a bowl and add the ghee, chili powder, a pinch of salt, ginger paste and lemon juice. Pour the mixture over the chicken, cover and keep it in the refrigerator for three to four hours. Then thread the chicken on skewers and put it in a baking dish. Bake it in the oven at 180 ° C for twenty minutes. To prepare the curry: Add a little ghee to a frying pan, add the onion and fry it until it becomes golden. Then add the ginger paste, garlic and green chili. Then add the tomato paste, chili powder, salt and water. Add a little honey and fenugreek seeds. Then add the chicken to the mixture and cook for another five minutes until the chicken is cooked. Add the cream.

Cities stand tall with pride,
Each one vying for supremacy --
This one boasts of its mountainous backdrop,
That one of its vast, burdened seas.
They proudly count their ships and cargo,
Their grain, oil, and wine, as well as their textiles and goods,
Their fortified walls and the guns that line them,
And each town proudly proclaims its achievements to the neighboring city:
"Can you match my greatness?"
And the people who live in these cities,
Travel back and forth, but remain deeply connected to their hometowns,
Just as a child clings to their mother's dress.
When they interact with foreign groups,
They are often bewildered and feeling alone;
When they walk through unfamiliar lands,
They are surrounded by unfamiliar streets and sounds;
They praise their city for its strength,
Which surpasses their own.
(They look up to it as a symbol of greatness,
A fame that extends far beyond their own,
A bond that they swear to uphold,
A deep and unwavering loyalty.)
So I am grateful that I was born
In a city that is renowned for its greatness,
Not in a remote or isolated place,
Or in a land that is plagued by war and conflict,
But in a city that has given me value and pride.
Even in times of hardship or struggle,
Under the harsh conditions of a foreign land,
It is a comfort to know:
"I am not from a mediocre city!"
(I did not achieve my status through service or payment,
But through my connection to the Mother of Cities,
A place where I was born between the palm trees and the sea,
Where the world's largest ships wait to depart.)
Now, I must repay this debt,
And express my gratitude for the city's kindness and generosity,
So I will hasten to the city's pier,
And offer my tribute to its greatness.
And the city will graciously accept my offerings,
And in return, it will grant me the right to trade and prosper,
Just as it has done for kings and rulers throughout history.
And this is a sign that the city's power is greater than mine,
And that I hold my power and influence at its hands.

Rewritten:
The Cities are full of pride,
Challenging each to each --
This from her mountain-side,
That from her burthened sea.
They count their ships full tale --
Their grain and oil and wine,
Derrick and loom and bale,
And rampart's gun-flecked line;
Town by City they hail:
"Hast thou to match with mine?"
And the people that breed from them
They traffic up and down,
But cling to their cities' hem
As a child to their woman's gown.
When they talk with the stranger bands,
Dazed and newly alone;
When they walk in the stranger lands,
By roaring streets unknown;
Blessing her where she stands
For strength above their own.
(On high to take her fame
That holds all fame beyond,
By oath to back the same,
Most faithful-foolish-fond;
Making her mere-breathed name
Their bond upon their bond.)
So thank I God my birth
Fell not in isles aside --
Waste headlands of the earth,
Or warring nations untried --
But that she gave me worth
And brought me right to pride.
Even in toil or fray
Under an alien sun,
Comfort it is to think:
"Of no mean city am I!"
(nor by service nor fee
Come I to mine estate --
Mother of Cities to me,
For I was born in her gate,
Between the palms and the sea,
Where the world-end steamers wait.)
Now for this debt I owe,
And for her far-borne cheer
Must I make haste and go
With tribute to her pier.
And she will touch and remit
After the use of kings
(Orderly, ancient, fit)
My deep-sea plunderings,
And purchase in all lands.
And this we do for a sign
Her power is over mine,
And mine I hold at her hands!

Manchester United's board has agreed to grant US businessman Malcolm Glazer access to its books. Earlier this month, Mr Glazer presented the board with detailed proposals on an offer to buy the football club. In a statement, the club said it would allow Mr Glazer "limited due diligence" to give him the opportunity to take the proposal to a formal bid. However, it continued to oppose Mr Glazer's plans, calling his assumptions "aggressive" and his plan "damaging". Many of Manchester United's supporters own shares in the club, and the fan-based group Shareholders United is strongly opposed to any takeover by Mr Glazer. About 300 fans protested outside the Old Trafford ground two days ago.

Rival local club Manchester City has pleaded with visiting fans not to protest inside its ground when the two teams play a televised match on Sunday. Manchester United's response comes as a little surprise, as the board made clear. "Any board has a responsibility to consider a bona fide offer proposal," the club said in its statement. "Should it become a firm offer, it should be at a price that 'the board is likely to regard as fair' and on terms which 'may be deliverable'. But it also stressed that it remained opposed to Mr Glazer's proposal. "The board continues to believe that Mr Glazer's business plan assumptions are aggressive, and the direct and indirect financial strain on the business could be damaging."

Whether or not the bid is attractive in monetary terms, in the case of Manchester United many investors hold the stock for sentimental rather than financial reasons. At present, Mr Glazer and his family hold a 28.1% stake in United through their investment vehicle Cubic Expression, and have yet to express a view on the bid approach. A group of five MPs are calling on the Department of Trade and Industry to block any takeover of the club on public interest grounds. They have signed a House of Commons motion, and Tony Lloyd, the Manchester Central MP, whose constituency includes the club's Old Trafford ground, has pledged to take the matter "to Tony Blair if necessary". The Commons motion says "any takeover designed to transform the club into a private company would be against the interests of those supporters and football". However, the DTI has dismissed the proposal. A spokesman said the department did not believe there was a case for changing the Enterprise Act so that takeovers of football clubs could be looked at on non-competition grounds. Mr Glazer's offer values the club at £800m ($1.5bn). Pitched at 300p per share, it also relieves less debt to finance it than an earlier approach from the US tycoon, which was rejected out of hand. Manchester United shares closed at 270.25p on Friday, down 3.75p on the day.

Rediffusion Singapore, launched in 1949, was the first cable-transmitted radio station in Singapore. Initially, it was a Singapore subsidiary of the Broadcast Relay Services (Overseas) Ltd. At that time, it was also Singapore's only subscription radio service. However, due to declining subscriptions, it ceased operations in 2012. Upon closure, a former Rediffusion Singapore DJ, Eva Chang Mei Hsia, purchased the radio station and re-opened it in 2013 as an online radio station. Rediffusion Singapore was founded in 1949 as a result of the success encountered in radio broadcasting in Singapore, particularly in the post-World War II era. The cable radio service was seen as a solution to the poor reception affecting certain housing estates at the time. Rediffusion Singapore was operated by Overseas Rediffusion, a subsidiary of the Rediffusion broadcasting business based in the United Kingdom, from its inception until the late 1980s, when the British-owned Rediffusion conglomerate was broken up.

Rеdіffusіоn Sіngароrе (Сhіnеsе: 丽的呼声), stаrtеd іn 1949, іs thе fіrst саblе-trаnsmіttеd rаdіо stаtіоn іn Sіngароrе. Іt wаs а Sіngароrе subsіdіаrу оf thе Βrоаdсаst Rеlау Sеrvісеs (Οvеrsеаs) Ltd. Іt wаs аlsо Sіngароrе's оnlу subsсrірtіоn rаdіо sеrvісе. Duе tо dесrеаsіng subsсrірtіоn, іt сlоsеd іn 2012. Оn сlоsurе, а fоrmеr Rеdіffusіоn Sіngароrе dееjау, Εvа Сhаng Меі Ηsіаng, bоught thе rаdіо stаtіоn аnd іn 2013 rе-ореn thе rаdіо stаtіоn аs аn оnlіnе rаdіо stаtіоn. Rеdіffusіоn Sіngароrе wаs fоundеd іn 1949 аs а rеsult оf thе suссеss еnсоuntеrеd іn rаdіо brоаdсаstіng іn Sіngароrе, раrtісulаrlу іn thе роst-Wоrld Wаr ІІ еrа. Τhе саblе rаdіо sеrvісе wаs sееn аs а rеmеdу аgаіnst рооr rесерtіоn whісh аffесtеd сеrtаіn hоusіng еstаtеs untіl thеn. Rеdіffusіоn Sіngароrе wаs ореrаtеd bу Οvеrsеаs Rеdіffusіоn, а subsіdіаrу оf thе Rеdіffusіоn brоаdсаstіng busіnеss bаsеd іn thе Unіtеd Кіngdоm, frоm thе fоrmеr's fоundаtіоn untіl thе lаtе 1980s, whеn thе Βrіtіsh-оwnеd Rеdіffusіоn соnglоmеrаtе wаs brоkеn uр.

We establish geometric Ramsey-type theorems for collections of lines in three-dimensional space. These theorems provide guarantees on the minimum size of a clique or independent set in graphs derived from the incidence relationships between lines, points, and reguli in three-dimensional space. Our results include: (1) The intersection graph of n lines in 3D space contains a clique or independent set of size at least n^(1/3). (2) Any set of n lines in 3D space has a subset of n^(1/2) lines that are all intersected by one line, or a subset of at least (n/log n)^(1/5) lines such that no 6-subset is intersected by one line. (3) For a set of n lines in general position in 3D space, there exists a subset of at least n^(2/3) lines that all lie on a regulus, or a subset of at least n^(1/3) lines such that no 4-subset is contained in a regulus. The proofs of these theorems rely on geometric incidence bounds, such as the Guth-Katz bound on point-line incidences in 3D space, combined with Turan-type results on independent sets in sparse graphs and hypergraphs. While similar theorems can be established using existing algebraic frameworks, our results yield significantly larger lower bounds. The proofs also provide polynomial-time algorithms for finding the claimed subsets.

Rewritten:
We prove geometric Ramsey-type statements on collections of lines in 3-space.
These statements give guarantees on the size of a clique or independent set
in (hyper)graphs induced by incidence relations between lines, points, and
reguli in 3-space. Among other things, we prove that: (1) The intersection
graph of n lines in R^3 has a clique or independent set of size Omega(n^{1/3}).
(2) Every set of n lines in R^3 has a subset of n^{1/2} lines that are all
stabbed by one line, or subset of Omega((n/log n)^{1/5}) such that no
6-subset is stabbed by one line. (3) Every set of n lines in general position
in R^3 has subset of Omega(n^{2/3}) lines that all lie on regulus, or a
subset of Omega(n^{1/3}) lines such that no 4-subset is contained in a regulus.
The proofs of these statements all follow from geometric incidence bounds --
such as the Guth-Katz bound on point-line incidences in R^3 -- combined with
Tur\'an-type results on independent sets in sparse graphs and hypergraphs.
Although similar Ramsey-type statements can be proved using existing generic
algebraic frameworks, lower bounds we get are much larger than what can be
obtained with these methods. The proofs directly yield polynomial-time
algorithms for finding subsets of claimed size.

To make this decadent dessert, you'll need 7 ounces of chopped white chocolate, plus an additional block for shaving, 7 tablespoons of unsalted butter, 2 vanilla beans with their seeds scraped, 5 large eggs separated, 1/3 cup of sifted bread flour, a pinch of cream of tartar, and 1/3 cup of sugar. Begin by preparing a 10-inch springform pan by buttering it, lining the bottom with parchment paper, and then buttering the paper as well. In a large bowl set over a pot of gently simmering water, combine the chopped white chocolate and butter, stirring until the chocolate is almost fully melted. Remove the bowl from the heat and stir in the vanilla seeds until the mixture is smooth. Next, add the egg yolks and stir until well combined. Sift the bread flour over the batter and stir it in. In a separate large bowl, beat the egg whites with the cream of tartar until they form soft peaks. Gradually add the sugar and continue beating until the egg whites are stiff and glossy. To finish the batter, beat in one-fourth of the egg whites, then gently fold in the remaining whites until no streaks remain. Pour the batter into the prepared pan and smooth the top. Cover the cake with plastic wrap and refrigerate it for 8 hours or overnight. Preheat the oven to 375 degrees and bake the cake in the middle of the oven for about 30 minutes, or until it's puffed, golden, and a toothpick inserted into the center comes out clean. Allow the cake to cool completely in the pan before it dramatically falls. Remove the side of the pan using a thin knife, then slide the cake onto a plate. Finally, use a vegetable peeler to shave white chocolate curls over the top of the cake.

Rewritten:
7 ounces white chocolate, chopped, plus a block of white chocolate for shaving
7 tablespoons unsalted butter
2 vanilla beans, split, seeds scraped
5 large eggs, separated
1/3 cup bread flour, sifted
Pinch of cream of tartar
1/3 cup sugar
Butter a 10-inch springform pan. Line the bottom with parchment paper and butter the paper. In a large bowl set over a pot of barely simmering water, stir the chopped white chocolate with the butter until almost melted. Remove the bowl from the heat, add the vanilla seeds and stir until smooth. Stir in the egg yolks. Sift the bread flour over the batter and stir it in. In a large bowl, beat the egg whites with the cream of tartar to soft peaks. Gradually add the sugar and beat until the whites are stiff and glossy. Beat one-fourth of the egg whites into the batter, then fold in the remaining whites until no streaks remain. Pour the batter into the prepared pan and smooth the top. Cover with plastic wrap and refrigerate for 8 hours or overnight. Preheat the oven to 375. Bake the cake in the middle of the oven for about 30 minutes, until puffed and golden and a toothpick inserted in the centre comes out clean. Let the cake cool completely in the pan; it will fall dramatically. Run a thin knife around the edge of the cake, then remove the side of the pan. Slide the cake onto a plate. Using a vegetable peeler, shave white chocolate curls over the cake.

3 bunches of baby beets, cleaned, trimmed, and cut in half  
1/3 cup of extra-virgin olive oil  
1 handful of fresh thyme sprigs  
Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper  
5 bunches of arugula, cleaned, dried, and torn by hand  
Celery leaves from 1 bunch of celery, approximately 1/2 cup  
1 cup of toasted walnut halves and pieces  
1/2 pound of crumbled blue cheese  
1 cup of sour cream  
2 tablespoons of chopped fresh chives  
1 lemon, juiced  

Preheat the oven to 400 degrees F. Place the beets on a large piece of aluminum foil, drizzle with olive oil, sprinkle the thyme on top, and season with salt and pepper. Fold the foil tightly to create a sealed pouch and set it on a baking sheet. Bake until the beets are tender when pierced, about 45 minutes to 1 hour. (Insert a knife into the center of one beet; if it slides out easily, they are ready.) Allow the beets to cool to room temperature, then transfer them to a large mixing bowl. Add the arugula, celery leaves, and walnuts; toss to mix. For the blue cheese dressing: In a bowl, combine the blue cheese and sour cream, mashing with a fork. Stir in the chives, lemon juice, and a few grinds of freshly ground black pepper; mix well, leaving some chunks of cheese in the dressing. If desired, thin the dressing with a tablespoon of water to achieve a smoother consistency. Drizzle the blue cheese dressing over the salad and gently toss to coat; season with salt and pepper. Serve the salad on a chilled platter.

Rewritten:
3 bunches baby beets, washed, trimmed, and halved
1/3 cup extra-virgin olive oil
1 handful fresh thyme sprigs
Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper
5 bunches arugula, washed, dried, and hand-torn
Celery leaves from 1 bunch celery, about 1/2 cup
1 cup walnut halves and pieces, toasted
1/2 pound blue cheese, crumbled
1 cup sour cream
2 tablespoons chopped fresh chives
1 lemon, juiced
Preheat the oven to 400 degrees F. Lay the beets on a large sheet of aluminum foil, drizzle with the oil, toss the thyme on top, and season with salt and pepper. Fold up the foil tightly to make a sealed pouch and put it on a sheet pan. Bake until the beets are tender when pierced, about 45 minutes to 1 hour. (Drop a knife in the center of 1 beet; if it slides out without resistance, they're done.) Let the beets cool to room temperature and put them in a large mixing bowl. Add the arugula, celery leaves, and walnuts; toss to combine. To make the blue cheese dressing: Put the blue cheese and sour cream in a bowl, mashing with a fork to combine. Add the chives, lemon juice, and a few turns of freshly ground black pepper; mix to incorporate, leaving a few chunks of cheese in the dressing. Thin out the dressing with a tablespoon of water, if you wish, to smooth out the consistency. Pour the blue cheese dressing over the salad and toss gently to coat; season with salt and pepper. Put the salad on a chilled platter and serve.

Breaking down two-valued images of porous media into distinct segments is a vital step towards gaining a deeper understanding of the microscopic factors influencing biogeochemical processes. In recent years, researchers have conducted extensive studies, primarily using basic methods that rely on either a global or local threshold. However, these methods are well-known for their limitations in image segmentation. Furthermore, the absence of a standardized and quantifiable benchmark hinders the evaluation of existing techniques. This paper addresses these challenges. Firstly, a novel method for automatically segmenting porous media images is proposed, based on a technique originally developed for natural images, known as 3D Quantum Cuts (QCuts-3D), and the current state-of-the-art spectral clustering technique. Secondly, a comprehensive dataset consisting of 68 images of porous media with diverse solid geometries and a ground truth for each voxel's phase is created and made publicly accessible. We test the proposed method against other leading techniques using this dataset and find that it is resilient to variations in the composition of porous media.

Rewritten:
The segmentation of two-valued images of porous media is a crucial step towards a deeper understanding of the factors governing the biogeochemical processes at a microscopic scale. In recent years, a large amount of research has been carried out, mainly on the basis of primitive methods based on the use of either a global or local threshold that is well known for its limitations in the image segmentation. Moreover, the lack of a unified and quantifiable standard limits the ability to evaluate existing methods. This paper addresses both problems. Firstly, based on a method of automatic segmentation developed for natural images, a method is proposed for the automatic segmentation of porous media images, named 3D Quantum Cuts (QCuts-3D), and based on the current state-of-the-art spectral clustering technique. Secondly, a data set of 68 images of porous media with various solid geometries and with a ground truth of phase in each voxel is prepared and made publicly available. We test the proposed method against other current state-of-the-art methods on this data set and find that the method is robust to variations in the composition of porous media.

"What can I say, I strive to make you happy," Steven responded as he rose to his feet, observing with fascination as Flahne glided her hands over her long, flawlessly smooth legs. "I’ll certainly try to come see you again while I’m on the planet. I’m not sure how long we’ll be here, but I believe I can carve out some time for such a beautiful woman." Rewritten:
"What can I say, I aim to please," Steven replied as he stood up, watching with interest as Flahne ran her hands across her long, perfectly smooth legs. "I'll definitely try to pay you another visit while I'm on planet. Don't know how long we'll be here, but I think I can make some time for such a lovely lady." He placed a kiss on Flahne's cheek before giving her a lusty grin. "And don't worry, I'm always up for a bit of kink!"

Following her acquittal in the case of Strong Poison, Harriet Vane embarked on a hiking holiday, where she stumbled upon a gruesome discovery. On a secluded rock near the shore, she found a man with his throat cut and blood still flowing. The only footprints in the sand belonged to the victim and Harriet herself. She took photographs and collected evidence, but the body was washed away before she could summon help. Lord Peter Wimsey soon arrived, and together with Harriet, they joined forces with the police to investigate the crime. The victim, Paul Alexis, was a professional dancer at the local hotel, with Russian roots and engaged to a wealthy widow. Initially, it seemed like a case of suicide, but Wimsey and Harriet uncovered a complex web of deceit. Alexis, who believed himself to be a descendant of Russian royalty, was manipulated by the widow's son and his accomplices. The son, driven by the prospect of losing his inheritance and his mother's remarriage to a man he saw as a gigolo, conspired with his friends to lure Alexis to the rock, where he was murdered. To avoid leaving footprints, the son rode a horse along the beach, while his friends provided an alibi for him. However, the investigation was complicated by the fact that Alexis suffered from haemophilia, which led to confusion over the time of death. Eventually, this detail proved crucial in unmasking the conspirators.

Rewritten:
During a hiking holiday after her acquittal on murder charges in Strong Poison, Harriet Vane discovers the body of a man, with his throat cut and the blood still liquid, on an isolated rock on the shore. There are no footprints in the sand other than the man's and Harriet's. She takes photos and preserves some evidence, but the corpse is washed away before she can fetch help. Lord Peter arrives, and he and Harriet make investigations alongside the police. The dead man, Paul Alexis, a professional dancing partner at the local hotel, was of Russian extraction and engaged to a rich older widow. The death has been made to look like suicide, but Wimsey and Harriet discover that he was the victim of an ingenious and complex murder plot. The romantic Alexis believed himself a descendant of Russian royalty, and the widow's rather stupid son, appalled at the prospect of his mother's remarriage to a gigolo and the loss of his inheritance, conspired with a friend and his wife to play on Alexis's fantasies. Convinced that he was being called to return to Russia in triumph as the rightful Tsar, Alexis was lured to the rock and murdered by the son, who rode a horse along the beach through the incoming tide to avoid leaving tracks, whilst his friends supplied his alibi. The death was intended to look like suicide. However, Alexis suffers from haemophilia, and his unclotted blood leads to confusion over the time of death, which eventually assists with the unmasking of the conspirators.

India has approved a proposal permitting up to 251% foreign direct investment in its construction industry. Kamal Nath, the Minister of Commerce and Industry, revealed this decision in Delhi on Thursday after a cabinet meeting. Analysts believe that enhancing India's infrastructure will attract foreign investment in various other sectors as well. The Indian government's move has brought optimism to the construction industry, according to several local companies. 

A representative from DLF Builders, Dr. Vancheshwar, informed the BBC that this will lead to "better offerings" for both consumers and builders. He mentioned that the company will gain from world-class "strategic partnerships, design expertise, and technology, while consumers will enjoy a wider selection." 

The government proposal indicates that foreign investment of up to 100% will be permitted through the 'automatic route' in the construction sector, covering projects such as housing, hotels, resorts, hospitals, and educational institutions. The automatic route allows construction firms to obtain just one set of official approvals, eliminating the need for clearance from the Foreign Investment Promotion Board, which can be cumbersome. The government aims for this new policy to generate jobs for construction workers and benefit the steel and brick manufacturing sectors. 

Mr. Nath also shared plans to permit foreign investors to develop a smaller portion of any land they acquire. "Foreign investors can engage in any construction development area, whether for building resorts, townships, or commercial spaces, but they must construct at least 50,000 square meters (213,756 square feet) within a specified timeframe," stated Mr. Nath, without detailing the timeframe. Previously, foreign investors were required to develop a significantly larger area, which deterred some from entering the Indian market. This initiative is intended to prevent foreign investors from engaging in speculative land purchases without actual development. Anshuman Magazine, managing director of CB Richard Ellis, an international real estate firm, told the BBC that this is "a significant positive step."

On the other hand, Chittabrata Majumdar, general secretary of the Centre of Indian Trade Unions (CITU), expressed concerns that permitting FDI in the country undermines India's own "self-reliance." He stated, "No country can progress solely based on foreign investment." Mr. Majumdar also emphasized the need for an evaluation to determine whether foreign investment truly benefits the country in terms of job creation and revenue or merely serves as a means for international companies to enrich themselves.

Rewritten:
India has cleared a proposal allowing up to 251% foreign direct investment in its construction sector.
Kamal Nath, Commerce and Industry Minister, announced the decision in Delhi on Thursday following a cabinet meeting. Analysts say improving India's infrastructure will boost foreign investment in other sectors too. The Indian government's decision has spread good cheer in the construction sector, according to some Indian firms.
A spokesman for DLF Builders, Dr Vancheshwar, told the BBC this will mean "better offerings" for consumers as well as builders. He said the firm will benefit from world class "strategic partnerships, design expertise and technology, while consumers will have better choice."
The government proposal states that foreign investment of up to 100% will be allowed on the 'automatic route' in the construction sector, on projects including housing, hotels, resorts, hospitals and educational establishments. The automatic route means that construction companies need only get one set of official approvals and do not need to gain clearance from the Foreign Investment Promotion Board, which can be bureaucratic. The government hopes its new policy will create employment for construction workers, and benefit steel and brick-making industries.
Mr Nath also announced plans to allow foreign investors to develop a smaller area of any land they acquired. "Foreign investors can enter any construction development area, be it to build resorts, townships or commercial premises but they will have to construct at least 50,000 square meters (213,756 square feet) within a specific timeframe," said Mr Nath, without specifying the timeframe. Previously foreign investors had to develop a much larger area, discouraging some from entering the Indian market. This measure is designed to discourage foreign investors from buying and selling land speculatively, without developing it. Anshuman Magazine, managing director, of CB Richard Ellis - an international real estate company - told the BBC this was "a big positive step."
However, Chittabrata Majumdar, general secretary of the Centre of Indian Trade Unions (CITU), said allowing FDI in the country is compromising India's own "self reliance". He said, "No country can develop on the basis of foreign investment alone." Mr Majumdar also said an assessment should be made as to whether foreign investment is indeed beneficial to the country - in terms of employment and money generated - or just another way of international companies filling their deep pockets.

The shape of the left atrium has been found to be a key factor in predicting the likelihood of atrial fibrillation (AF) returning after a procedure to correct it. To accurately assess this, it's essential to use a shape-based representation, which offers the most flexibility and efficiency when analyzing large groups of people. However, creating population-level shape representations from cardiac MRI images requires significant expertise and resources. In this study, we propose a machine learning approach that uses advanced neural networks to directly estimate the shape characteristics of the left atrium from MRI images, without the need for any initial image processing. We also introduce a new method for enhancing the training of these neural networks when working with limited data. Our results show that this new approach produces similar outcomes to the current state-of-the-art methods, which involve more complex and time-consuming image segmentation and optimization processes. This means that our method can eliminate the need for expensive and labor-intensive pre-processing pipelines.

Rewritten:
Left atrium shape has been shown to be an independent predictor of recurrence
after atrial fibrillation (AF) ablation. Shape-based representation is
imperative to such an estimation process, where correspondence-based
representation offers the most flexibility and ease-of-computation for
population-level shape statistics. Nonetheless, population-level shape
representations in the form of image segmentation and correspondence models
derived from cardiac MRI require significant human resources with sufficient
anatomy-specific expertise. In this paper, we propose a machine learning
approach that uses deep networks to estimate AF recurrence by predicting shape
descriptors directly from MRI images, with NO image pre-processing involved. We
also propose a novel data augmentation scheme to effectively train a deep
network in a limited training data setting. We compare this new method of
estimating shape descriptors from images with the state-of-the-art
correspondence-based shape modeling that requires image segmentation and
correspondence optimization. Results show that the proposed method and the
current state-of-the-art produce statistically similar outcomes on AF
recurrence, eliminating the need for expensive pre-processing pipelines and
associated human labor.

Ben Marcus, speaking of his father, Michael Marcus, states: "Can we extract a single word from Ben Marcus, the malformed and afflicted heart?" From this point, the author of Notable American Women, Ben Marcus, embarks on a first-person narrative that invites the reader to consider whether and how we can trust him. Marcus is a nuanced manipulator of language who, in many respects, evokes comparisons to A Clockwork Orange, among other works. He recounts the remarkable cults surrounding his mother, his mysterious mentor, the renowned Jane Dark, and their multitude of followers, all striving to achieve the ultimate stillness of the world by eradicating “the violence of the wind,” which symbolizes speech and, ultimately, all physical motion. Dark, clever, and ironically bleakly humorous, Notable American Women offers a journey into the psyche of a well-meaning yet obtuse young man, exploring his chaotic upbringing filled with radical experiments and coerced breeding (among other experiences) that may even elicit sympathy for him. Ultimately, the suffragette cult, to which his mother, Jane Marcus, belongs, faces a crisis due to the largely ineffective breeding of Ben and the growing number of members who have attained a level of stillness that renders them obsolete. Additionally, Jane Marcus, utilizing a complex system of body twitches, achieves complete emotional obliteration and takes a moment to speak directly to the reader. Like her purported husband (who, according to her, was imprisoned in a hole behind their home), Jane also serves as the narrator of the novel's concluding chapter, revealing the life of the last member of the central Marcus family trio, from which readers can draw their own interpretations.

Rewritten:
Ben Marcus, referring to his father, Michael Marcus, says: "Can we take a single word from Ben Marcus, the deformed and diseased heart?" And from there, the author of Notable American Women, Ben Marcus, begins his first person narrated by Ben Marcus and allowing the reader to see if and how we can believe him. Marcus is a subtle language-patronizer who in many ways reminds us of A Clockwork Orange, among other things, and who tells us of the extraordinary cults of his mother, his enigmatic mentor, the famous Jane Dark, and their legions of disciples, who are trying to bring about the perfect stillness of the world by eliminating “the violence of the wind,” which means speech and, ultimately, all physical movement. Dark, witty, and ironically depressingly hilarious, Notable American Women is a trip into the mind of a good but obtuse young man, to see his tumultuous upbringing, full of radical experiments and forced breeding (among other things) and maybe even to feel sorry for him. At the end, the suffragette cult, to which his mother, Jane Marcus, belongs, is in a crisis, because of the largely unsuccessful breeding of Ben, because of the increasing number of members who have reached a degree of stillness that makes them outdated. And Jane Marcus, too, with the help of a complex system of twitching her body, reaches complete and total emotional annihilation, and pauses for a moment to address the reader. Like her alleged husband (who was, according to her, a prisoner in the hole behind the house), Jane is also the narrator of the novel's last chapter and we see the life of the last member of the central Marcus family trio, from which the reader can draw his or her own conclusions.

Tottenham Hotspur are on the verge of signing Icelandic midfielder Emil Hallfredsson, who has been on trial at the club's White Hart Lane stadium. The 20-year-old, who currently plays for FH Hafnarfjordur, made a strong impression during his time at the training facility, particularly in a recent Uefa Cup match against Dunfermline Athletic.

According to Tottenham's sporting director, Frank Arnesen, the club has agreed to a transfer fee for Hallfredsson, but the player still needs to finalize his personal terms. Arnesen revealed that Hallfredsson had received offers from two other clubs, but he chose to join Tottenham due to the club's attractive prospects. 

The signing of Hallfredsson aligns with Tottenham's strategy of identifying and developing talented young players, providing them with a platform to grow and improve within the club.

Rewritten:
Tottenham are primed to snap up Iceland Under-21 international Emil Hallfredsson after he impressed on trial at White Hart Lane. The 20-year-old midfielder, who plays for FH Hafnarfjordur, also starred in the Uefa Cup match against Scottish side Dunfermline earlier this season. 

Spurs have agreed a fee for the player, who has yet to agree personal terms. "He had offers from two other clubs but he decided to come to Tottenham," said Spurs sporting director Frank Arnesen. "He is a left-sided player, a position we have been looking at and he showed so much talent in his time here that we decided to take him. 

"It's down the road of bringing in talent, good prospects and giving them a place at Tottenham where they can improve."

Date: Wed, 25 Oct 2000 03:06:00 -0700 (PDT)  
From: richard.sanders@enron.com

Subject: Some reflections on options  
Body:  
----- Forwarded by Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 10/25/2000 10:08 AM -----  
Richard B Sanders  
10/24/2000 05:34 PM  

To: Jeff Dasovich/NA/Enron@Enron, James D Steffes/NA/Enron@Enron, Mark  
Palmer/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Mark E Haedicke/HOU/ECT@ECT, Kazeem  
Khan/LON/ECT@ECT, Tim Belden/HOU/ECT@ECT, Mary Hain/HOU/ECT@ECT, Christian  
Yoder/HOU/ECT@ECT  
cc:  
Subject: Some reflections on options  
----- Forwarded by Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 10/24/2000 05:24 PM -----  
"Fergus, Gary S." <GFergus@brobeck.com>  
10/24/2000 04:45 PM  

To: "Richard B. Sanders Esq. (E-mail)" <richard.b.sanders@enron.com>  
cc: "Meringolo, Peter" <PMeringolo@brobeck.com>  
Subject: Some reflections on options  
PRIVILEGED AND CONFIDENTIAL  
ATTORNEY CLIENT PRIVILEGE  
Richard,  
Following our discussion today, here are our brainstorming ideas regarding options:  
1. WAIT FOR A BETTER PROTECTIVE ORDER  
Inquire with Harvey Morris about the status of the protective order currently under litigation by others. If there have been no changes to the protective order, we should consider unilaterally delaying production until it is amended. Pro: Enhanced protection and additional time; Con: Even with a stricter protective order, Enron still questions whether the PUC is entitled to financial performance data. Therefore, this option may not fully represent all of Enron's positions, and the company could later be accused of merely stalling. We would also file our formal objections under this option.  
2. PROVIDE THE TRANSACTION DATA AS IS  
Continue with our current plan to provide transaction data for electricity that has been delivered. Pro: The PUC will eventually obtain the data through FERC, unfair competition, antitrust, or price gouging litigation. By supplying the data that indicates profits, the PUC might reduce their investigation's intensity rather than disrupt business by seeking witness depositions, etc. Con: This would waive Enron's legitimate concerns regarding the PUC's ability to obtain this information via subpoena. Additionally, there are questions about the confidentiality of this data given the current political climate. It could also increase the PUC's demand for more information from Enron. This option would also disclose proprietary information about how Enron maintains its competitive edge.  
3. PROVIDE DATA FOR OUTSIDE CALIFORNIA AND LET PUC OBTAIN THE REST FROM ISO AND PX.  
We have informed the PUC that we do not wish to duplicate the efforts of ISO and PX, so the best way to alleviate our burden is to provide only the missing data. PRO: It would be simpler and quicker to provide data from outside California and would temporarily avoid the ongoing jurisdictional issue. Con: Without Enron's cost data for California ISO and PX transactions, the PUC would struggle to achieve their goal of a profit and loss overview. We would find it challenging to convince the PUC that the combination of their data and Enron's would suffice to address Request Nos. 7-10.  
4. PROVIDE EVERYTHING EXCEPT PRICE  
This option would simply exclude the price data. Pro: It would not disclose profit and loss information. Con: It would not reveal profit and loss information. The PUC is clearly seeking this data. By providing everything else, we would essentially be indicating that we will not disclose profit and loss. Furthermore, by combining some of this with ISO and PX data, the PUC might be able to construct a substantial revenue picture, but without the cost or expense details.  
5. REFUSE TO PRODUCE THE DATA  
We would inform Harvey Morris that Enron has reassessed its stance for the following reasons: (1) Our firm belief that the PUC is not entitled to the profit and loss data they are requesting; (2) Harvey's latest email indicates that the PUC is seeking more data (1999) than previously discussed; (3) the ongoing threat that if they are dissatisfied with the transaction data, they will request profit and loss information that we believe they are not entitled to; (4) Commissioner Wood's assertion that the investigation aims to transfer funds from market participants to consumers; (5) the AG's investigation into other market participants and the notice that

Rewritten:
Date: Wed, 25 Oct 2000 03:06:00 -0700 (PDT)
From: richard.sanders@enron.com
To: steven.kean@enron.com
Subject: Some thoughts on options
Body: 
----- Forwarded by Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 10/25/2000 10:08 AM -----
	Richard B Sanders
	10/24/2000 05:34 PM
		 
		 To: Jeff Dasovich/NA/Enron@Enron, James D Steffes/NA/Enron@Enron, Mark 
Palmer/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Mark E Haedicke/HOU/ECT@ECT, Kazeem 
Khan/LON/ECT@ECT, Tim Belden/HOU/ECT@ECT, Mary Hain/HOU/ECT@ECT, Christian 
Yoder/HOU/ECT@ECT
		 cc: 
		 Subject: Some thoughts on options
----- Forwarded by Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 10/24/2000 05:24 PM -----
	"Fergus, Gary S." <GFergus@brobeck.com>
	10/24/2000 04:45 PM
		 
		 To: "Richard B. Sanders Esq. (E-mail)" <richard.b.sanders@enron.com>
		 cc: "Meringolo, Peter" <PMeringolo@brobeck.com>
		 Subject: Some thoughts on options
PRIVILEGED AND CONFIDENTIAL
ATTORNEY CLIENT PRIVILEGE
Richard,
 After today's discussion here are our brainstorming ideas on
options:
1. WAIT FOR A BETTER PROTECTIVE ORDER
 Ask Harvey Morris where they are on fixing the protective order that
is being litigated by others. If the protective order has not changed,
then unilaterally postpone production until it is. Pro: Better protection
and more time; Con: Even with a more stringent
 protective order Enron still questions whether the PUC is entitled
to financial performance data. Thus, this option does not fully
disclose all of Enron's positions and the company may be accused later of
simply engaging in delaying tactics. Under this option we file our
formal objections as well.
2. TURN OVER THE TRANSACTION DATA AS IS
 Continue on our present course of turning over transaction data for
electricity that was delivered. Pro: PUC will get the data anyway
either through FERC, unfair competition, antitrust or price gouging
litigation. By turning over the data that will show profits, PUC might
slow down investigation there as opposed to interrupting the business by
seeking to depose witnesses etc. Con: This would be waiving the
legitimate question that Enron has as to the PUC's ability to discovery this
information through a subpoena. There is also a question of how
confidential this data would be given the current political agenda. It
might also serve to whet the appetite of the PUC for more Enron
information and discovery. This option would also provide confidential
proprietary information to the PUC about how Enron gets its competitive
advantage.
3. TURN OVER DATA FOR OUTSIDE OF CALIFORNIA AND LET PUC GET REST OF
DATA FROM ISO AND PX.
 We have told the PUC we do not want to duplicate the efforts of ISO
and PX so the way to relieve the burden on us is to give only missing
data. PRO: It would be easier and quicker to just give the outside of
California data and would sidestep for the
 moment the ongoing jurisdictional question. Con: Without Enron
cost data for the California ISO and PX transactions, the PUC
 would not be able to arrive at what they want -- a profit and loss
picture. We would have a hard time representing to the PUC that the
combination of the PUC data and the Enron data would be all that they need
to calculate the answers to Request Nos. 7-10.
4. TURN OVER EVERYTHING BUT PRICE
 This option would simple omit the price data. Pro: It would not
reveal the profit and loss information. Con: It would not reveal the
profit and loss information. In other words, the PUC is clear that this is
what they are after. By giving them everything else, we
 would in effect be telling them we will not turn over profit and
loss. Moreover, by piecing some of it together with the ISO and PX
data, the PUC might be able to put together a revenue picture which will be
quite large, but just not the cost or expense side.
5. DECLINE TO PRODUCE THE DATA
 We would tell Harvey Morris that Enron has reconsidered its position
for the following reasons: (1) Our firm belief that the PUC is not
entitled to the profit and loss data they are seeking; (2) in his latest
email, Harvey has made it clear that the PUC wants more data (1999)
than we discussed earlier; (3) continued threat that if they do not like the
transaction data they will come back and ask for profit and loss
information that we do not believe they are entitled to; (4) Commissioner
Wood's statement that the purpose of this investigation is to get
money from market participants in the hands of consumers; (5) investigation
by the AG into activities of other market participants and the notice
that other governmental agencies are cooperating -- who are we producing
this information to and for what purpose; (6) Enron favors public
disclosure of trading data but only if all participants are required to
do so; (7) Enron is a small player in this market and many other market
participants are not involved in the process BPA etc. PRO: This
may be the only way to preserve Enron's challenge to the jurisdiction of the
PUC to get this data. Moreover, in the current political
environment there is no assurance where this information will be leaked. It
also makes sense to see what FERC will do with their published 11/1/00
report on investigation date. Under this option, we file our formal
objections and sit back and wait.
6. ME TOO
 Upon reflection, we agree with the approach taken by the other
market participants. We will not produce until the protective order is
modified and then only data that is within the PUC jurisdiction. PRO: This
makes it look like all the market participants are acting in concert
and really is no different than option 1 above. Moreover, if you read
Reliant's responses, they appear ready to turn over financial data if
the protective order is modified. (Terry and Mike Day are both out of their
offices today.) Note that Williams is adopting a strategy that says
the PUC needs to go to Superior Court to enforce its subpoena. This may be
met with strong opposition by the PUC given their California
constitutional contempt authority.
7. MOVE TO QUASH BEFORE THE ALJ
 Here we would raise all of the arguments that we have about why the
PUC does not have jurisdiction and fight it out on the merits before the
ALJ. PRO: The ALJ is a forum to raise the jurisdictional questions. It
has the least procedural risks of being dismissed. CON: Reading
the tea leaves, we believe it unlikely that the ALJ will determine that the
PUC has no jurisdiction.
 Moreover, because the PUC has its own constitutionally granted
contempt power, the PUC will take the view (according to Mike Day) that
they need not go to the Superior Court for enforcement. They will also take
the view that the Superior Court has no jurisdiction to hear our
appeal. Appeals have to go to the PUC and those orders are appealable at
the Court of Appeal level. Thus, the only de novo review of our
objections might be at the ALJ level.
8. FILE DECLARATORY RELIEF ACTION IN FEDERAL COURT IN CALIFORNIA
 We would claim federal question jurisdiction under the Federal Power
Act and in particular the provisions of 824(g) under which the PUC
issued its subpoena in part. The dispute to be decided is whether the PUC
has the jurisdiction to seek the profit and loss information from the
wholesale market. The authority for this would be Mississippi Power & Light
v. Mississippi 487 US 354 (bright line between wholesale market regulated
by FERC and the retail market regulated by states); Bristol Energy Corp v.
New Hampshire 13 F.3d 471 (1st Cir. 1994)(federal question whether state
agency can inquire into business and financial data in the wholesale
market but found no cognizable claim.) PRO: The federal forum may be more
even handed than the ALJ, but the question is whether we can state a
cognizable claim. There may be greater protections from disclosure of the
information as well. CON: The PUC may continue on a parallel track unless
we are able to obtain injunctive relief. The PUC might seek discovery of
the same information in the Federal court proceeding. We should assume that
this action will trigger the strongest response from the PUC and/or the AG
in form of further investigations or alternative forums for getting the same
information (e.g unfair business practice suit, price gouging,
anti-trust etc.). We should anticipate deposition requests for traders
etc. By taking this position, we will clearly be conceding that if
FERC asks for the data it is germane to their authority.
9. SEPARATE RESPONSES/STRATEGIES FOR DIFFERENT ENRON ENTITIES
 It may make some sense to chart a different course for Portland
General, EES and EEMC and continue to produce some data from those
entities. PRO: The information provided for these entities is not likely
to generate profit and loss information that would be germane to the fight
we are about to engage in (e.g. EES's description of % off tariff rates for
example.) For Portland General, Dave Aamodt is out of the office and
not able to participate in any change of direction discussions.
Hope this is helpful.
Thanks
Gary

Martin Brian Mulroney (born March 20, 1939) is a Canadian lawyer, businessman, and politician who held the position of the 18th prime minister of Canada from 1984 to 1993. He was born in the eastern Quebec city of Baie-Comeau, where he pursued studies in political science and law. Afterward, he relocated to Montreal, where he gained recognition as a lawyer and businessman. In 1976, he ran for the leadership of the Progressive Conservative Party of Canada (PC Party), finishing in third place, and subsequently returned to business leadership when he was appointed president of the Iron Ore Company of Canada in 1977. He remained in that role until 1983, when he successfully became the leader of the Progressive Conservatives. He then led the party to a landslide victory in the 1984 federal election, securing 211 seats, the highest number of seats won by any party in Canadian history. This election marked the last occasion that the winning party claimed every province and territory, as well as the last time the winning party received over 50% of the national popular vote. Mulroney also achieved the second-largest percentage of seats in Canadian history (at 74.8%). He later won a second majority government in 1988.

Date: Wed, 13 Sep 2000 04:07:00 -0700 (PDT)
From: alan.aronowitz@enron.com
To: sara.shackleton@enron.com
Subject: Bond & Equity Trading Update

FYI.

----- Forwarded by Alan Aronowitz/HOU/ECT on 09/13/2000 11:07 AM -----
Paul Simons shared some news with us on September 13, 2000, at 9:16 AM. He informed Gary Hickerson, Jeff Kinneman, John Greene, Sheila Glover, Janine Juggins, Mahesh Lakhani, Mark Evans, and Andrew Cornfield about a letter received from SFA. The letter confirms that SFA has accepted Enron's argument to continue proprietary bond and equity trading in London through an unregulated UK entity. Additionally, SFA has stated that they will not apply their consolidated capital supervision rules to the unregulated entity, as they have the discretion to do.

From a regulatory standpoint, this development allows us to proceed with setting up a Chinese Wall and initiating trading without any restrictions. 

Best regards,
Paul

Rewritten:

From: alan.aronowitz@enron.com
To: sara.shackleton@enron.com
Subject: Bond & Equity Trading
Body: 
FYI.
----- Forwarded by Alan Aronowitz/HOU/ECT on 09/13/2000 11:07 AM -----
	Paul Simons
	09/13/2000 09:16 AM
		 
		 To: Gary Hickerson/HOU/ECT@ECT, Jeff Kinneman/HOU/ECT@ECT, John 
Greene/LON/ECT@ECT, Sheila Glover/HOU/ECT@ECT, Janine Juggins/LON/ECT@ECT, 
Mahesh Lakhani/LON/ECT@ECT, Mark Evans/Legal/LON/ECT@ECT, Andrew 
Cornfield/LON/ECT@ECT
		 cc: John Sherriff/LON/ECT@ECT, Michael R Brown/LON/ECT@ECT, (bcc: Alan 
Aronowitz/HOU/ECT)
		 Subject: Bond & Equity Trading
I have just received the letter SFA promised us. SFA have accepted our 
argument that our proprietary bond and equity trading can be carried on in 
London through an unregulated UK entity. The letter also states that SFA 
will not be applying their consolidated capital supervision rules to the 
unregulated entity, which they have the discretion to do.
From a regulatory perspective this means we can move ahead at full speed to 
set up an appropriate Chinese Wall and then begin trading.
Best regards
Paul

From: Harry Kingerski@ENRON on 09/21/2000 03:54 PM CDT  
To: James D Steffes/HOU/EES@EES, Paul Kaufman/PDX/ECT@ECT, Jeff  
Dasovich/SFO/EES@EES, Mona L Petrochko/SFO/EES@EES, Susan J Mara/SFO/EES@EES  
cc: Richard Shapiro/HOU/EES@EES, Roger Yang/SFO/EES@EES  
Subject:  
I had a discussion with Dennis Benevides, Jim Wood, and Scott Gahn regarding the PG&E strategy we talked about and the EES viewpoint. Here are some recommendations:  
Support the recent CAL ISO report on the issues (lack of utility forward buying, absence of demand responsiveness, etc.) and state that, with minor adjustments, their suggestions were accurate.  
Ensure that the CTC roll-off does not occur before Spring '01. A retroactive roll-off would be catastrophic.  
Utilize PG&E's $15 billion exposure as leverage to establish a competitive default supplier (remove them from merchant supply).  
Implement a tiered structure for the rate increase to encourage customer migration.  
Maintain some risk for PG&E regarding wholesale cost recovery, postponing the recovery of under-recoveries until later years.  
Limit the rate freeze (which is more favorable than a rate cap) to the shortest duration possible after '01.  
Here’s a revised version of Jim's bullet points to include these ideas:  
Please note that the figures are merely placeholders and are not intended to be final. As we refine the concept, we can establish the appropriate numbers.  
From a retail standpoint, this approach balances the protection of the portfolio with the pursuit of new market opportunities. I may receive additional feedback from the EES team, but I wanted to share what I have gathered so far.

under-recoveries until out years.

possible, post '01.

right numbers.
From a retail perspective, this blends protection of the book with 
advancement of new market opportunity. I may still get more feedback from 
the EES guys, but wanted to give you what I got so far.
