Gordon Brown is set to freeze increases in petrol duty, fund a £1 billion package to prevent significant council tax hikes, and enhance childcare and maternity leave. In a positive pre-Budget report, he slightly raised borrowing but asserted that economic targets would be achieved. The Chancellor also celebrated the longest period of growth in UK "industrial history," while denying he was "gloating." However, Oliver Letwin, representing the Tories, criticized government bureaucracy and debt, labeling Mr. Brown as "Sir Wastealot." 

The shadow chancellor remarked that Mr. Brown's "golden rule" had "turned to dross in his hands" and claimed he was borrowing to spend rather than invest, with projected debt over the coming years reaching £170 billion. Mr. Letwin told MPs: "The tide is going out on the chancellor's credibility. He is spending, borrowing, and taxing so much because he is not getting value for taxpayers' money." 

Vincent Cable, for the Liberal Democrats, accused Mr. Brown of avoiding tough decisions. He stated: "Last week the prime minister gave us the politics of fear; this week the chancellor has offered the economics of complacency. There are serious challenges ahead from the falling dollar and from the rapid downturn in the UK housing market and rising personal debt. But they have not been confronted." Mr. Brown dismissed the Lib Dem's call to open the government's books to the National Audit Office, stating that decisions on tax and spending should be made by ministers. Some economists argue that his forecasts on public finances are overly optimistic. BBC economic editor Evan Davis noted that the figures were plausible but also a gamble.

Mr. Brown's insistence that he was not "gloating" was a pointed rebuttal to a warning from new European Commissioner Peter Mandelson. In his speech, he outlined a 10-year childcare strategy for if Labour wins the next election. It includes a £285 million cash injection to extend paid maternity leave from six months to nine, allowing parents to transfer leave from the mother to the father. He also promised to increase free nursery education for three- and four-year-olds to 15 hours starting in April 2007. Additionally, funds would be allocated to keep schools open from 08:00 to 18:00 GMT to care for children while their parents were at work. Taken together, the measures would create a "welfare state that is truly family-friendly for the first time in its history," said Mr. Brown. He also announced a cash handout for older pensioners, with payments of £50 for those over 70 as part of the winter fuel allowance. In a move, ministers say should keep council tax increases below 5% next year, the chancellor stated he was providing an extra £1 billion for local councils. The money is expected to come from government departments such as health and education.

Mr. Brown stated he was set to meet his two fiscal rules—to borrow only to invest and keep debt "low and sustainable"—both in this economic cycle and the next. Borrowing figures for 2003/4 are £35 billion—£2.5 billion less than the £37.5 billion predicted in March's budget, as already announced by the Office for National Statistics. Borrowing is expected to fall to £31 billion by 2005/06—but that is still £2 billion more than Mr. Brown predicted in his March budget. Inflation would be 1.75% next year and 2% in the following years, Mr. Brown forecasted. He also pledged an extra £105 million for security and counter-terrorism. Business groups have welcomed efforts to improve competitiveness and invest more in skills and innovation. However, there are concerns about the costs of more family-friendly working. Simon Sweetman, from the Federation of Small Businesses, said: "The proposals on maternity leave have clearly been made with a general election in mind and with little thought to the impact on small employers."

​T​h​e​ ​s​h​a​d​o​w​ ​c​h​a​n​c​e​l​l​o​r​ ​s​a​i​d​ ​M​r​ ​B​r​o​w​n​'​s​ ​"​g​o​l​d​e​n​ ​r​u​l​e​"​ ​h​a​d​ ​"​t​u​r​n​e​d​ ​t​o​ ​d​r​o​s​s​ ​i​n​ ​h​i​s​ ​h​a​n​d​s​"​ ​a​n​d​ ​s​a​i​d​ ​h​e​ ​w​a​s​ ​b​o​r​r​o​w​i​n​g​ ​t​o​ ​s​p​e​n​d​,​ ​n​o​t​ ​i​n​v​e​s​t​,​ ​w​i​t​h​ ​p​r​e​d​i​c​t​e​d​ ​d​e​b​t​ ​o​v​e​r​ ​t​h​e​ ​c​o​m​i​n​g​ ​y​e​a​r​s​ ​t​o​t​a​l​l​i​n​g​ ​£​1​7​0​b​n​.​ ​M​r​ ​L​e​t​w​i​n​ ​t​o​l​d​ ​M​P​s​:​ ​"​T​h​e​ ​t​i​d​e​ ​i​s​ ​g​o​i​n​g​ ​o​u​t​ ​o​n​ ​t​h​e​ ​c​h​a​n​c​e​l​l​o​r​'​s​ ​c​r​e​d​i​b​i​l​i​t​y​.​ ​H​e​ ​i​s​ ​s​p​e​n​d​i​n​g​,​ ​b​o​r​r​o​w​i​n​g​ ​a​n​d​ ​t​a​x​i​n​g​ ​s​o​ ​m​u​c​h​ ​b​e​c​a​u​s​e​ ​h​e​ ​i​s​ ​n​o​t​ ​g​e​t​t​i​n​g​ ​v​a​l​u​e​ ​f​o​r​ ​t​a​x​p​a​y​e​r​'​s​ ​m​o​n​e​y​.​"​
​V​i​n​c​e​n​t​ ​C​a​b​l​e​,​ ​f​o​r​ ​t​h​e​ ​L​i​b​e​r​a​l​ ​D​e​m​o​c​r​a​t​s​,​ ​a​c​c​u​s​e​d​ ​M​r​ ​B​r​o​w​n​ ​o​f​ ​d​u​c​k​i​n​g​ ​t​o​u​g​h​ ​c​h​o​i​c​e​s​.​
​H​e​ ​s​a​i​d​:​ ​"​L​a​s​t​ ​w​e​e​k​ ​t​h​e​ ​p​r​i​m​e​ ​m​i​n​i​s​t​e​r​ ​g​a​v​e​ ​u​s​ ​t​h​e​ ​p​o​l​i​t​i​c​s​ ​o​f​ ​f​e​a​r​;​ ​t​h​i​s​ ​w​e​e​k​ ​t​h​e​ ​c​h​a​n​c​e​l​l​o​r​ ​h​a​s​ ​o​f​f​e​r​e​d​ ​t​h​e​ ​e​c​o​n​o​m​i​c​s​ ​o​f​ ​c​o​m​p​l​a​c​e​n​c​y​.​ ​"​T​h​e​r​e​ ​a​r​e​ ​s​e​r​i​o​u​s​ ​c​h​a​l​l​e​n​g​e​s​ ​a​h​e​a​d​ ​f​r​o​m​ ​t​h​e​ ​f​a​l​l​i​n​g​ ​d​o​l​l​a​r​ ​a​n​d​ ​f​r​o​m​ ​t​h​e​ ​r​a​p​i​d​ ​d​o​w​n​t​u​r​n​ ​i​n​ ​t​h​e​ ​U​K​ ​h​o​u​s​i​n​g​ ​m​a​r​k​e​t​ ​a​n​d​ ​r​i​s​i​n​g​ ​p​e​r​s​o​n​a​l​ ​d​e​b​t​.​ ​B​u​t​ ​t​h​e​y​ ​h​a​v​e​ ​n​o​t​ ​b​e​e​n​ ​c​o​n​f​r​o​n​t​e​d​.​"​ ​M​r​ ​B​r​o​w​n​ ​r​e​j​e​c​t​e​d​ ​t​h​e​ ​L​i​b​ ​D​e​m​'​s​ ​c​a​l​l​ ​t​o​ ​o​p​e​n​ ​u​p​ ​t​h​e​ ​g​o​v​e​r​n​m​e​n​t​'​s​ ​b​o​o​k​s​ ​t​o​ ​t​h​e​ ​N​a​t​i​o​n​a​l​ ​A​u​d​i​t​ ​O​f​f​i​c​e​,​ ​s​a​y​i​n​g​ ​d​e​c​i​s​i​o​n​s​ ​o​n​ ​t​a​x​ ​a​n​d​ ​s​p​e​n​d​i​n​g​ ​s​h​o​u​l​d​ ​b​e​ ​m​a​d​e​ ​b​y​ ​m​i​n​i​s​t​e​r​s​.​ ​S​o​m​e​ ​e​c​o​n​o​m​i​s​t​s​ ​s​a​y​ ​h​i​s​ ​f​o​r​e​c​a​s​t​s​ ​o​n​ ​p​u​b​l​i​c​ ​f​i​n​a​n​c​e​s​ ​a​r​e​ ​w​i​s​h​f​u​l​ ​t​h​i​n​k​i​n​g​.​ ​B​B​C​ ​e​c​o​n​o​m​i​c​ ​e​d​i​t​o​r​ ​E​v​a​n​ ​D​a​v​i​s​ ​s​a​i​d​ ​t​h​e​ ​f​i​g​u​r​e​s​ ​w​e​r​e​ ​p​l​a​u​s​i​b​l​e​ ​b​u​t​ ​a​l​s​o​ ​a​ ​g​a​m​b​l​e​.​

In a bowl of an electric mixer, combine the ingredients for the frosting, mixing until it becomes fluffy. Prepare 12 cups by buttering them, or lining them with paper liners, then greasing and dusting with a bit of shortening followed by a sprinkle of flour. Incorporate the oil, orange juice, orange marmalade, and vanilla, and mix on low speed for 2 minutes. Stir in the orange zest and fill the tins two-thirds full with the batter. Bake in the preheated oven until a toothpick inserted comes out clean, which should take about 20 minutes. Move the cakes to a wire rack to cool. Using an electric mixer, beat the butter on medium speed for 1 minute. Gradually add the powdered sugar to the butter and mix on low speed until well combined, approximately 2 minutes. Mix in the pudding mix with the butter until smooth. Add water, one tablespoon at a time, to reach the desired icing consistency. Pipe or spread the icing over the cooled cakes and garnish with grated chocolate.

Rewritten:
Into a bowl of an electric mixer, add the ingredients for the icing, mixing until fluffy. Butter 12 cups, or line with paper liners, grease and dust with a little shortening, and then with a little flour. Add the oil, orange juice, orange marmalade and vanilla and beat on low speed for 2 minutes. Add the orange zest and pour the mixture into the tins 2/3 full. Bake in the preheated oven until a toothpick comes out clean, about 20 minutes. Transfer the cakes to a wire rack to cool. Beat the butter with an electric beater on medium speed for 1 minute. Pour the powdered sugar into the butter and beat on low speed until incorporated, about 2 minutes. Add the pudding mix to the butter and beat until smooth. Add a little water, 1 tablespoon at a time, to achieve the desired consistency of the icing. Pipe or spread the icing over the cooled cakes. Decorate with grated chocolate.

Echoes of desperation echo through the desolate landscape of the family's farm, where the harsh winter has taken its toll. The barn stands empty, a stark reminder of the food shortage that has left the family on the brink of starvation. Malnutrition sets in, causing their bodies to weaken, and their stomachs to swell with an insatiable hunger. The well, once a source of life-giving water, now stands frozen, a cruel reminder of the dehydration that threatens to consume them. The family's clothes cling to their bodies like a desperate attempt to hold on, as they struggle to survive in a world that seems determined to crush them.

The root cause of their suffering lies in the regime that once claimed to be for the people, but has now become a ruthless machine, dedicated to eliminating any opposition to its power. With a team of secret agents, it has become a force to be reckoned with, crushing any dissent with an iron fist. The regime's leaders live in luxury, surrounded by sycophants who sing their praises, while the people suffer in silence. Any opposition is met with brutal force, as tanks and sniper rifles are used to silence peaceful protesters. The media, once a beacon of truth, now peddles a different narrative, one that glosses over the regime's atrocities and presents a picture of business as usual. The family's struggles, like those of countless others, are reduced to a mere footnote in the regime's grand narrative of power and control.

Food shortage in the barn malnutrition starts to harm
No cream or proteins to stabilise their cells
Stomachs start to swell more than legends people tell

Rags clinging on to hips like rock climbers cling to cliffs
Brain damage then eclipse and then the focus shifts
The root cause of this strife fell down on these misfits
Because the regime that once deemed
Itself as for the people
Attained diplomatic status and a team
As secret as it was lethal
Predicated and dedicated to rooting out all foes
And enemies of state or anyone opposed
To their lavish lifestyles and constant talks of heroes
Zero tolerance for arguments on national policy
Broken promises the basis of this all-perfect polity
Sloppily take and take from the general public
Including any relatives who might have disrupted
Any luscious dinners with their cries of injustice
Crush peaceful marchers with tanks and sniper archers
Shoot into the crowd at anything moving around
In books and newspapers they write a different caption
Business as usual like the whole thing never happened

A parliamentary committee has called for the establishment of a national body to address the severe shortage of skilled professionals in key subjects, particularly in social sciences. The committee, which has been examining the work of the Economic Social Research Council, has expressed alarm over the "absolute crisis" in the recruitment of statisticians and other social science experts. As the social science workforce continues to age, the committee warns that "major problems" are expected over the next decade.

The Economic Social Research Council aims to promote and support strategic research for postgraduate social scientists and provide experts to meet the country's needs. However, the committee's report highlights the council's limitations in addressing the skills shortages, particularly in qualitative social sciences. The committee notes that its previous concerns over shortages in maths and chemistry remain unaddressed.

To tackle the issue, the committee recommends the creation of a national "strategic capabilities fund" to address shortages in key areas. The committee believes that this fund would be a more effective mechanism for the government to address skills shortages in key subjects, and that it should be established in response to the crisis.

Rewritten:
A national body designed to tackle skills shortages in key subjects should be set up, a committee of MPs has said.
There was an "absolute crisis" in the recruitment of statisticians and other social science experts, the Commons science and technology committee added. "Major problems" are expected over the next 10 years as the social science workforce continues to age, it said. The committee was reporting on the work, strategy and spending plans of the Economic Social Research Council.
The council aims to promote and support strategic research for social science postgraduates and provide social scientists to meet the needs of the country. It also liaises with the government and industry over their social science needs. In its report on the council's work the committee said: "We are deeply concerned by the skills shortages afflicting, in particular, the qualitative branches of social sciences. This mirrored previous concerns the committee had expressed on shortages in the fields of maths and chemistry, it said. "It is hard to see how significant progress towards rectifying these shortages can be made through the deployment of Economic and Social Research Council's limited resources. "If the government is serious about addressing skills shortages in key subjects it needs to find a more effective mechanism to achieve this." A national "strategic capabilities fund" to address shortages in key areas should be set up in response, the committee added.

Subject: Forwarded: A Heartwarming Story About Found Pennies

Body:

This email is a forwarded message from Tammy Wilemon, who received it from Vicki Pyatt. The message is a heartfelt and imaginative story about found pennies, which Tammy believes to be a symbol of good fortune and a reminder of the love and care of those around us.

The story, which Tammy has shared with her family and friends, tells the tale of a penny found on the ground, which is believed to have been tossed by an angel as a sign of love and support. The story encourages the reader to look for the good in life and to appreciate the people who care about them.

Tammy has shared this story with her loved ones, and she is now passing it on to all of us, in the hope that it will bring a smile to our faces and remind us of the importance of kindness and compassion.

---------------------- Forwarded by Judy Hernandez (Enron) on 08/23/2000 11:32 AM ---------------------------

Original Message:

From: Vicki Pyatt
Sent: Friday, August 18, 2000 9:19 AM

FOUND PENNY

I found a penny today
Just laying on the ground,
But it's not just a penny
This little coin I've found.

Found pennies come from heaven
That's what my Grandpa told me,
He said Angels toss them down
Oh, how I loved that story.

He said when an Angel misses you
They toss a penny down,
Sometimes just to cheer you up
To make a smile out of your frown.

So don't pass by that penny
When you're feeling blue,
It may be a penny from heaven
That an Angel's tossed to you.

j j j j (look closely, these are little
angels!
Pass this on to the people who you care about and who
you feel that are angels to you. An angel is now
watching over you.... j

St Clair is a heritage-listed former home and currently a museum located at 318 Sloane Street, Goulburn, within the Goulburn Mulwaree Council area of New South Wales, Australia. It was created by James Sinclair, who constructed the building in 1840. This residence is the second-oldest in Goulburn, following Riversdale. It is also referred to as St Clair Cottage and St Clair Museum. The property is managed by the Goulburn Mulwaree Council and serves as the home of the Goulburn and District Historical Society. It was officially listed on the New South Wales State Heritage Register on 2 April 1999. History One of the earliest homes in Goulburn, St Clair was both designed and built by the city's notable early builder and first architect, James Sinclair. The land was acquired in 1843, and the house was constructed in two or three phases, finishing before 1849. During this period, the initial shingle roof was replaced with iron. The first phase of the house features four rooms at the entrance level, above two downstairs rooms, two cellar rooms, and a unique larder. A second and possibly third phase introduced two wings that added eight additional rooms, a kitchen, and a scullery. These wings were enclosed to create a courtyard.

Rewritten:
St Clair is a heritage-listed former residence and now museum at 318 Sloane Street, Goulburn, Goulburn Mulwaree Council, New South Wales, Australia. It was designed by James Sinclair, who built the house in 1840. It is the second-oldest house in Goulburn, after Riversdale. It is also known as St Clair Cottage and St Clair Museum. The property is owned by Goulburn Mulwaree Council and houses the Goulburn and District Historical Society. It was added to the New South Wales State Heritage Register on 2 April 1999. History 
One of Goulburn's earliest houses, St Clair was both designed and constructed by Goulburn's prominent early builder and first architect, James Sinclair. The land was purchased in 1843 and the house was built in two or three stages with completion before 1849. During this time the stage one shingle roof was covered with iron. The first stage of the house consists of four rooms at entrance level, over two downstairs rooms, two cellar rooms and an unusual larder. A second and possibly third stage added two wings containing eight more rooms, a kitchen and scullery. These wings were enclosed to form a courtyard.

Charles Clarke is set to encounter his initial significant challenge as home secretary on Monday, with a potential backbench revolt regarding the contentious ID cards legislation. As many as 30 Labour MPs may oppose the initiative during a debate in the Commons. Mr. Clarke, who assumed the role on Thursday following David Blunkett's resignation, has dismissed suggestions to "pause" the bill. Tory leader Michael Howard may also face dissent after opting to support identity cards. The Liberal Democrats are against the proposals. 

In an article for The Times, Mr. Clarke accused certain critics of "liberal woolly thinking and spreading false fears" by asserting that ID cards would undermine civil liberties. He argues that it is, in fact, a "profoundly civil libertarian measure" as it upholds the most essential civil liberty in our society—the right to live free from the fear of crime. Mr. Clarke is anticipated to attempt to persuade detractors of the initiative by stating that officials who unlawfully access restricted information could face up to two years in prison. He is also likely to propose reducing the £85 fee for the card and passport for seniors and those with lower incomes.

Last week, Mr. Howard mentioned that his front bench team had come to a "collective view" to support ID cards after a "good discussion," but acknowledged that it was "not an easy issue." He chose to endorse the plans based on police assertions that they would aid in combating terrorism, crime, and illegal immigration. However, former shadow attorney general Bill Cash indicated that there remains "very deep" concern regarding the proposal among senior Tories. He told BBC Radio 4's Today that the government was "intensely authoritarian" and was fostering "an increasingly Big Brother society." Critics contend that implementing the cards would be an expensive endeavor without a clear purpose.

Ministers argue that it would bolster efforts against terrorism, illegal immigration, and organized crime. Yet, opponents claim that similar initiatives in other nations have not thwarted incidents like the Madrid rail bombing. On Sunday, Lib Dem leader Charles Kennedy reiterated his call for a "pause" in the legislative process. He stated on BBC's Breakfast with Frost program that Mr. Clarke had a "real opportunity" on Monday following Mr. Blunkett's exit. "If you were managing a family or a business, would you proceed with the second reading of the Identity Cards Bill tomorrow, or would you pause to reflect and consider your options for the New Year? That would be the sensible approach, but I believe this government has become so entrenched that it is not acting rationally at all." The first cards are expected to be issued in 2008, and when introducing the bill, Mr. Blunkett suggested that Parliament could decide in 2011 or 2012 whether to mandate that everyone possess the cards, although not necessarily carry them. The new legislation would also establish new criminal offenses related to the possession of false identity documents.

Rewritten:
Charles Clarke faces his first real test as home secretary on Monday with a possible backbench rebellion over the controversial ID cards bill.
Up to 30 Labour MPs could oppose the scheme during a Commons debate. Mr Clarke, who took on the post on Thursday after David Blunkett quit, has rejected calls to "pause" on the bill. Tory leader Michael Howard also faces a possible rebellion after deciding to back identity cards. The Liberal Democrats oppose the plans.
Mr Clarke, writing in The Times, accused some critics of "liberal woolly thinking and spreading false fears" by claiming ID cards would erode civil liberties. He writes that it is actually a "profoundly civil libertarian measure because it promotes the most fundamental civil liberty in our society - which is the right to live free from fear crime and fear". Mr Clarke is expected to try and win over opponents to the scheme by saying officials who secretly accessed information they were not allowed to see would face up to two years in jail. He is also expected to cut the £85 cost of the card and passport, for the elderly and those on lower incomes.
Mr Howard last week said his front bench team had reached a "collective view" to back ID cards after holding a "good discussion", but admitted it was "not an easy issue". He had decided to support the plans as the police said they would help fight terror, crime and illegal immigration. But former shadow attorney general Bill Cash said there was still "very deep" disquiet about the plan among senior Tories. He told BBC Radio 4's Today the government was "intensely authoritarian" and was creating "increasingly a Big Brother society". Critics argue that introducing the cards would be a costly scheme with no specific aim.
Ministers say it would help the fight against terrorism, illegal immigration and organised crime. But opponents say that similar schemes in other countries have not prevented attacks like the Madrid rail bombing. On Sunday, Lib Dem leader Charles Kennedy repeated his call for a "pause" in considering the legislation.
He told BBC's Breakfast with Frost programme that Mr Clarke had a "real opportunity" on Monday following the departure of Mr Blunkett. "If you were running a family or a business would you have the second reading of the Identity Cards Bill tomorrow or would you pause to reflect and see what you might do about it in the New Year? "That is the sensible way to go about it but I think this government has got itself so much into tram lines now that it is not behaving sensibly at all." The first cards would be issued in 2008 and, when he was introducing the bill, Mr Blunkett suggested Parliament could decide in 2011 or 2012 whether to make it compulsory for everybody to own the cards, although not to carry them. The new bill would also create new criminal offences on the possession of false identity documents.

To make this bread, you will need:

- 6 cups of water
- 1 cup of sourdough starter
- 7 1/2 cups of rye berries, cracked (measure before cracking)
- 1 tablespoon of salt

First, combine the water, sourdough starter, and half of the cracked rye berries. The mixture will be quite sour. Cover it and let it sit at around 70°F for 8 to 10 hours. After this time, the mixture will have absorbed the water and will be similar in consistency to porridge. Save one cup of this mixture for the next batch of bread, then add the salt and the remaining cracked rye berries. Allow the dough to ferment at around 70°F for 4 more hours.

At the end of this time, work and squeeze the dough with your hands to develop its cohesiveness. The dough is unlike wheat bread dough; it is very moist and slippery and cannot be kneaded. When a handful is squeezed, it will squirt out between your fingers. After working the dough for several minutes, pack it into bread forms, preferably glass. There is not much rising that goes on, and too much air space in the bread would be detrimental to the texture. The moistness and acidity of the dough, along with the long baking time, will strongly rust steel pans and etch aluminum ones.

Pack the dough into the pan tightly and smooth the top with a spatula. Lay a piece of parchment paper over the top of the form and then cover it tightly with aluminum foil. The aluminum foil keeps the bread from drying out, and the parchment paper keeps the aluminum foil from dissolving into the bread. Bake at 225°F for 3 1/2 hours. Turn the oven off but allow the bread to remain inside for a couple of hours. Carefully remove the bread from the pans and place it on a rack to cool and dry. Ideally, you should wait a day or two until the bread becomes firmer before attempting to slice it.

Rewritten:
6 сuрs wаtеr
1 сuр sоurdоugh stаrtеr
7 1/2 сuрs rуе bеrrіеs, сrасkеd (mеаsurе bеfоrе сrасkіng)
1 tаblеsрооn sаlt
Соmbіnе thе wаtеr, sоurdоugh stаrtеr, аnd оnе hаlf оf thе сrасkеd rуе. Μіхturе wіll bе sоuру. Соvеr аnd аllоw tо sеt аt аbоut 70° F fоr 8 tо 10 hоurs. Αftеr 8 tо 10 hоurs, thе mіхturе wіll hаvе аbsоrbеd wаtеr аnd bе sіmіlаr іn соnsіstеnсу tо роrrіdgе. Sаvе 1 сuр оf thіs mіхturе fоr thе nехt bаtсh оf brеаd, thеn аdd sаlt аnd thе rеst оf thе сrасkеd rуе. Αllоw thе dоugh tо fеrmеnt аt аbоut 70° F fоr 4 mоrе hоurs. Αt thе еnd оf thіs tіmе, wоrk аnd squееzе thе dоugh wіth уоur hаnds tо dеvеlор іts соhеsіvеnеss. Тhе dоugh іs nоthіng lіkе whеаt brеаd dоugh. Іt іs vеrу mоіst аnd slірреrу аnd саnnоt bе knеаdеd. Whеn а hаndful іs squееzеd, іt wіll squіrt оut bеtwееn уоur fіngеrs. Αftеr wоrkіng thе dоugh fоr sеvеrаl mіnutеs, расk іt іntо brеаd fоrms, рrеfеrаblу glаss. Τhеrе's nоt muсh rіsіng thаt gоеs оn аnd tоо muсh аіr sрасе іn thе brеаd wоuld bе dеtrіmеntаl tо thе tехturе. Τhе mоіstnеss аnd асіdіtу оf thе dоugh аnd thе lоng bаkіng tіmе wіll strоnglу rust stееl раns аnd еtсh аlumіnum оnеs. Расk thе dоugh іntо thе раn tіghtlу аnd smооth thе tор wіth а sраtulа. Lау а ріесе оf раrсhmеnt рареr оvеr thе tор оf thе fоrm аnd thеn соvеr tіghtlу wіth аlumіnum fоіl. Τhе аlumіnum fоіl kеерs thе brеаd frоm drуіng оut аnd thе раrсhmеnt рареr kеерs thе аlumіnum fоіl frоm dіssоlvіng іntо thе brеаd. Βаkе аt 225° F fоr 31/2 hоurs. Тurn thе оvеn оff but аllоw thе brеаd tо rеmаіn іnsіdе fоr а соuрlе mоrе hоurs. Саrеfullу rеmоvе thе brеаd frоm thе раns аnd рlасе оn а rасk tо сооl аnd drу. Іdеаllу, уоu shоuld wаіt а dау оr twо untіl thе brеаd bесоmеs fіrmеr bеfоrе аttеmрtіng tо slісе іt.

Deep convolutional networks have achieved state-of-the-art performance for semantic image segmentation tasks. However, training these networks requires access to densely labeled images, which are known to be very expensive to obtain. On the other hand, the web provides an almost unlimited source of images annotated at the image level. The question is how to utilize this much larger weakly annotated set for tasks that require dense labeling. Previous work often relied on localization cues, such as saliency maps, objectness priors, bounding boxes, etc., to address this challenging problem. In this paper, we propose a model that generates auxiliary labels for each image while simultaneously forcing the output of the CNN to satisfy the mean-field constraints imposed by a conditional random field. We show that one can enforce the CRF constraints by forcing the distribution at each pixel to be close to the distribution of its neighbors. This is in stark contrast to methods that compute a recursive expansion of the mean-field distribution using a recurrent architecture and train the resulting distribution. Instead, the proposed model adds an extra loss term to the output of the CNN, and hence, is faster than recursive implementations. We achieve state-of-the-art performance for weakly supervised semantic image segmentation on VOC 2012 dataset, assuming no manually labeled pixel-level information is available. Furthermore, the incorporation of conditional random fields in CNN incurs little extra time during training.

Rewritten:

Ricardo Lagos, a Chilean lawyer, economist, and politician, served as the country's president from 2000 to 2006. During the 1980s, he was a vocal critic of the Chilean military dictatorship, earning recognition for his bold stance against dictator Augusto Pinochet on live television in 1988. Prior to his presidency, Lagos held key positions in the government, including Minister of Education from 1990 to 1992 and Minister of Public Works from 1994 to 1998, under the leadership of President Eduardo Frei Ruiz-Tagle. He secured the presidency in a runoff election in 2000, defeating Joaquín Lavín of the Independent Democrat Union. As the third president from the center-left Coalition of Parties for Democracy, Lagos played a significant role in governing Chile since 1990. He was succeeded by Michelle Bachelet, a Socialist from the same coalition, on March 11, 2006. In 2007, Lagos was appointed as a Special Envoy on Climate Change by the United Nations Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon, a position he held until 2010. Although he attempted to run for president again in the 2017 Chilean general election, he was unsuccessful.

Early years:

Ricardo Lagos was born in Santiago, Chile, to Froilán Lagos Sepúlveda, a farmer who passed away when Lagos was just eight years old, and Emma Escobar Morales, who sadly passed away in 2005. Lagos attended primary school at Liceo Experimental Manuel de Salas and later pursued his secondary education at the prestigious Instituto Nacional.

Rewritten:
Ricardo Froilán Lagos Escobar (; born 2 March 1938) is a Chilean lawyer, economist and social-democratic politician who served as president of Chile from 2000 to 2006. During the 1980s he was a well-known opponent of the Chilean military dictatorship and astounded contemporaries in 1988 by openly denouncing dictator Augusto Pinochet on live television. He served as Minister of Education from 1990 to 1992 and Minister of Public Works from 1994 to 1998 under president Eduardo Frei Ruiz-Tagle before narrowly winning the 1999-2000 presidential election in a runoff against Independent Democrat Union (UDI) candidate Joaquín Lavín. Lagos was the third president from the center-left Coalition of Parties for Democracy to have governed Chile since 1990. He was succeeded on March 11, 2006 by Socialist Michelle Bachelet, from the same coalition. From 2007 to 2010 he served as a Special Envoy on Climate Change for the United Nations Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon. Lagos made an unsuccessful bid to run for president in the 2017 Chilean general election. Early years
Lagos was born in Santiago, Chile. He was the only child of Froilán Lagos Sepúlveda (a farmer who died when his son was eight years old) and Emma Escobar Morales (who died in 2005). He attended primary school at Liceo Experimental Manuel de Salas and high school at the prestigious Instituto Nacional.

I continue to read reviews for Cars 2, and I find myself somewhat surprised. Some individuals have even gone so far as to compare it to the Star Wars prequels. Sure, Cars 2 is definitely not on the same level as "Finding Nemo" or "Toy Story." However, I found it to be quite enjoyable, at least for me. The storyline was a clear nod to James Bond and Mission Impossible. I appreciated the spy gadgets and the political undertones. It was action-packed and not only fun for young children but also for older kids and adults alike. Why all the negativity? Even Roger Ebert and Rolling Stone had positive things to say about it! 

In my view, Cars 1 was a bit slow. It dragged on a little too long in certain sections. Cars 2, on the other hand, does not suffer from that issue. 

To sum it up, while Cars 2 may not be Toy Story, it is certainly FUN and ENTERTAINING.

Date: Tue, 14 Aug 2001 18:59:00 -0700 (PDT)  
From: ken.lay-@enron.com  
To: all.worldwide@enron.com  
Subject: Organizational Announcement  
Body:  
It is with sadness that I must inform you that Jeff Skilling is departing from Enron. Today, the Board of Directors has accepted his resignation as President and CEO of Enron. Jeff is stepping down for personal reasons, and this decision is entirely his own. While I regret his choice, I respect and understand it. I have collaborated closely with Jeff for over 15 years, including 11 years here at Enron, and I have had very few professional relationships that I hold in higher regard. I am happy to share that he has agreed to enter into a consulting role with the company to provide guidance to me and the Board of Directors.  
Now, we must look ahead.  
With Jeff's departure, the Board has requested that I take on the responsibilities of President and CEO in addition to my current role as Chairman of the Board. I have accepted this request. I want to reassure you that I have never been more optimistic about the future of the company. As you are all aware, our stock price has significantly declined over the past few months. One of my primary goals will be to recover a substantial portion of the stock value we have lost as quickly as possible. Our performance has never been stronger; our business model has never been more solid; our growth has never been more assured; and most importantly, we have never had a better or more talented workforce throughout the company. We have the best organization in American business today. Together, we will elevate Enron to become the world's leading company.  
On Thursday at 10:00 a.m. Houston time, we will conduct an all-employee meeting at the Hyatt. We will stream the meeting to our employees globally where technology permits, and I look forward to seeing many of you there.

Rewritten:
Date: Tue, 14 Aug 2001 18:59:00 -0700 (PDT)
From: ken.lay-@enron.com
To: all.worldwide@enron.com
Subject: Organizational Announcement
Body: 
It is with regret that I have to announce that Jeff Skilling is leaving Enron. Today, the Board of Directors accepted his resignation as President and CEO of Enron. Jeff is resigning for personal reasons and his decision is voluntary. I regret his decision, but I accept and understand it. I have worked closely with Jeff for more than 15 years, including 11 here at Enron, and have had few, if any, professional relationships that I value more. I am pleased to say that he has agreed to enter into a consulting arrangement with the company to advise me and the Board of Directors.
Now it's time to look forward.
With Jeff leaving, the Board has asked me to resume the responsibilities of President and CEO in addition to my role as Chairman of the Board. I have agreed. I want to assure you that I have never felt better about the prospects for the company. All of you know that our stock price has suffered substantially over the last few months. One of my top priorities will be to restore a significant amount of the stock value we have lost as soon as possible. Our performance has never been stronger; our business model has never been more robust; our growth has never been more certain; and most importantly, we have never had a better nor deeper pool of talent throughout the company. We have the finest organization in American business today. Together, we will make Enron the world's leading company.
On Thursday at 10:00 a.m. Houston time, we will hold an all employee meeting at the Hyatt. We will broadcast the meeting to our employees around the world where technically available, and I look forward to seeing many of you there.

1 1/2 cups liquid honey, ideally from the comb  
3/4 cup (1 1/2 sticks) butter  
2 1/2 cups flour  
1 teaspoon baking powder  
1/2 teaspoon baking soda  
1/4 teaspoon salt  
1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon  
1/4 teaspoon nutmeg, preferably freshly grated  
3 eggs, lightly beaten  
1/2 cup milk  
1/4 cup sliced almonds  

Combine 1 1/4 cups of honey and all but a teaspoon of butter in a saucepan, warming it over low heat until the butter melts, which should take about 10 minutes. Once melted, remove from heat. While the butter is melting, preheat the oven to 325 degrees. Use the remaining butter to grease an 8-inch square baking pan. Dust the pan with a bit of flour, then line the bottom with waxed paper. In a large bowl, sift the remaining flour together with the baking powder, baking soda, salt, cinnamon, and nutmeg. When the honey-butter mixture is ready, incorporate the eggs, followed by the milk. Gradually whisk this mixture into the dry ingredients, stirring thoroughly. Be cautious not to add the warm liquid all at once to prevent lumps in the flour. Pour the batter into the prepared pan and sprinkle the almonds on top. Bake for about an hour, or until a cake tester inserted in the center comes out clean. After removing the cake from the oven, prick it all over with a thin skewer. Drizzle the remaining quarter cup of honey over the top and let it cool before taking the cake out of the pan.

Rewritten:
1 1/2 cups liquid honey, preferably from comb
3/4 cup (1 1/2 sticks) butter
2 1/2 cups flour
1 teaspoon baking powder
1/2 teaspoon baking soda
1/4 teaspoon salt
1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon
1/4 teaspoon nutmeg, preferably freshly grated
3 eggs, lightly beaten
1/2 cup milk
1/4 cup sliced almonds
Put 1 1/4 cups of the honey and all but a teaspoon of the butter in a saucepan and warm over low heat just until the butter melts, about 10 minutes. Remove from the heat. While the butter is melting, preheat oven to 325 degrees. Use remaining butter to grease an 8-inch square baking pan. Use a bit of the flour to flour the pan, then line the bottom with waxed paper. Sift the rest of the flour with the baking powder, baking soda, salt, cinnamon and nutmeg into a large bowl. When the honey-butter mixture is ready, beat the eggs into it, then stir in the milk. Whisk this mixture into the dry ingredients gradually, stirring well. Take care not to add the warm liquid mixture all at once or the flour will lump. Pour the batter into the pan and scatter the almonds over the top. Bake for an hour or a little longer, until a cake tester inserted in the center comes out clean. Remove the cake from the oven and prick it all over with a thin skewer. Drizzle the unused one-fourth cup of honey over the top and allow to cool before removing the cake from the pan.

Harvey,

We are submitting our proposals regarding the production of documents by the Enron Entities in response to the subpoenas issued by the California Public Utility Commission. We believe that our proposals will enable the Commission to commence its investigation much sooner than if the parties were forced to litigate all of the potential objections to the requests for production.

The Enron Entities are willing to assist the Commission in its investigation by producing a limited quantity of specified information on a timely basis. We propose to produce the following documents:

GENERAL DOCUMENTS
Requests 1 through 4: We will provide the Commission with exemplars of our current organizational charts, telephone directories, and "family trees" to show our current organization. We will also make available exemplars of significant organizational charts, telephone directories, or "family trees" for earlier periods if we can readily identify and locate them.

Requests 5 and 6: Our responses to Requests 1-4 will identify our relationship to affiliated companies, and the Transaction Documents will identify our customers and suppliers.

FINANCIAL DOCUMENTS
Requests 7 through 11: We will produce our public filings for the period requested with respect to financial data. EPMI, EES, and Portland General will provide the Commission with electronic Transaction Documents for the purchase and sale of energy delivered, which includes economic data.

		 Subject: Revised Draft Proposal to CPUC
PRIVILEGED AND CONFIDENTIAL
ATTORNEY CLIENT PRIVILEGE
DRAFT DRAFT DRAFT
Harvey Morris Esq.
California Public Utilities Commission
505 Public Utilities Commission
San Francisco, California 94102
 Re: I.00-08-002 Subpoenas Served on Enron Power
Marketing, Inc. ("EPMI"), Enron Energy Services Inc. ("EES"), Enron Energy
Marketing Corporation ("EEMC"), Enron Energy Services Operations Inc. (EESO)
and Portland General Electric Corporation ("Portland General")(collectively
sometimes referred to as the "Enron Entities")
Harvey,
 Here are our proposals with respect to the Enron Entities'
production of documents pursuant to the above described subpoenas issued by
the California Public Utility Commission (hereinafter "the Commission").
The Enron Entities are willing to assist the Commission in undertaking its
investigation into the problems in the California electric markets by
producing a limited quantity of specified information on a timely basis. We
believe that the limited production we propose will enable the Commission to
commence its investigation much sooner than if the parties were forced to
litigate all of the potential objections to the requests for production,
which are, by any standard, extremely broad and could involve millions of
pages of documents. We make these proposals pursuant to our email exchange
of October 3, 2000 with the understanding that the Commission agrees that by
cooperating, offering to produce or producing documents, the Enron Entities
have not waived any objections or challenges to these subpoenas whatsoever
and that any claims, defenses, objections, jurisdictional or otherwise or
other responses have been specifically reserved and can be raised in the
future, if necessary. For all of these proposals, we exclude documents
that are protected from disclosure by the attorney client and attorney work
product privileges.
 [SUBJECT TO VERIFICATION: Generally speaking, the documents and
information that the Commission seeks can be found, if they exist, within
EPMI, EES and Portland General. To the extent that EEMC or EESO are
relevant to the Commission's investigation, any documents would be located
within EES. Thus, we do not anticipate specific document productions from
either EEMC or EESO.]
GENERAL DOCUMENTS
Requests 1 through 4
 The Enron Entities have been very dynamic organizations having
acquired, sold, divested, joint ventured, spun off and otherwise reorganized
themselves extensively during the past two years. The burden and expense on
Enron to locate, and produce every corporate organizational chart anywhere
in its organization since April 1, 1998 is significant. The Enron entities
will provide the Commission with exemplars of its current organizational
charts, telephone directories and so called "family trees" to show its
current organization. To the extent that Enron can readily identify and
locate exemplars of significant organizational charts, telephone directories
or so called "family trees" for earlier periods it will also make those
available. One Enron Entity, Portland General, has published books on its
corporate history. If a list of those books would be helpful, we can
provide it. With respect to the other entities, to the extent that
corporate histories can be found, they will be produced. We anticipate
producing these documents in the first wave on October 13, 2000.
Requests 5 and 6
 The Enron Entities propose that their responses to Requests 1-4 will
identify their relationship to affiliated companies and the Transaction
Documents will identify its customers and suppliers.
FINANCIAL DOCUMENTS
Requests 7 through 11
 The Enron Entities will produce their public filings for the period
requested with respect to financial data. EPMI, EES, and Portland General
will provide to the Commission electronic Transaction Documents for the
purchase and sale of energy delivered which includes economic data. It is
intended that this economic data will provide the Commission with financial
information regarding the Enron Entities which will be useful to its
investigation. We anticipate producing public filings regarding financial
data on October 13, 2000 and the electronic Transaction Documents in the
second wave of document productions.
GENERATING DOCUMENTS
Requests 12, 14 and 18
 For the Enron Entities other than Portland General, the generation
facilities are limited in number and there will probably be limited
documents available. The Enron Entities to the extent they act as a
scheduling coordinator or possessed the right to use or resell generation
output, do not have the specific documents that pertain to each generation
unit requested. The Enron Entities, other than Portland General, do have
documents and information for Enron Wind, Saguaro and Las Vegas
Cogeneration. We propose to produce these documents in the second wave of
document productions.
 For Portland General, the production of the requested documents
would involve a tremendous volume of documents, as Portland General owned
twenty generating facilities of a variety of types and sizes during 2000.
Portland General is a net importer of energy and can only generate about one
half of its total energy demand. As a result, we question whether the
effort required of Portland General is warranted as its impact on the
California wholesale market is necessarily limited. In addition, those
transactions which do involve Portland General sales into California are
limited to sales to the ISO and PX, and long term contracts with two small
California municipal utilities. Thus, the Commission will receive the
essential transactional information regarding these sales from the ISO and
PX. Nevertheless, Portland General proposes to provide for year 2000
electronic Transaction Documents in summary form similar to the data being
provided by other Enron Entities, to the extent relevant. [We propose that
the Commission defer requesting production of other information until it has
reviewed the information of generators who sell a significant proportion of
their energy into the California market. At that time a more accurate
assessment can be made of whether this enormous effort will be valuable
given the limited impact of Portland General generation on the California
wholesale market.]
[Alternate ending to paragraph: We propose for the voluminous Portland
General generating cost and maintenance data, that these documents be made
available in Portland for inspection from a representative sampling of
facilities. If there are specific documents that the Commission would like
copied from that production, we can discuss the arrangements for producing
these documents. We propose to make these documents available in Portland
in a third wave of document productions]
TRANSACTION DOCUMENTS
Requests 13, 15, 16, 17 and 19
 We understand that the Commission will be obtaining trading data for
the purchase and sale of energy delivered in California from the ISO and PX.
EPMI can provide the Commission several different sets of transaction data
for year 2000 (in California and outside of California and Real Time) for
the purchase and sale of energy delivered with the date, counterparty,
quantity, delivery point, hours, price, and whether it is a purchase or a
sale. Because of the speed with which you want this information, it is
possible that some entries will be incomplete or inaccurate. For those
transactions where EPMI served only as the scheduling coordinator, we
understand that the ISO will show part of the transaction, but there will
not be a corresponding transaction in the EPMI data we can provide quickly.
The reason is that this type of transaction is passed through to EPMI's
customer on an accounting system rather than as part of the trading
business. EES is a retail provider of electricity, and plays a far more
limited role in the wholesale markets which are the subject of the
Commission investigation. However, EES can also provide similar electronic
Transaction Data with the proviso that it will not include the specific
names of its retail customers but instead will provide a blind customer
number. This additional restriction is important to EES because many of
EES's customers have agreements whereby they must be notified of any
subpoena and provided an opportunity to object. EES cannot meet your time
frame to release information and give its customers the notice they require.
Given that EES was a retail provider and the fact that the identity of
retail customers is of little or no relevance to the functioning of the
wholesale market, we do not believe protecting the identity of retail
customers is an unreasonable limitation or narrowing of the request. We
anticipate producing the transaction data in the second wave of document
productions.
FERC DOCUMENTS
Request 20
 The Enron Entities will produce the requests for data they received
from FERC and to the extent that FERC has been given responses, copies of
those responses. We anticipate producing the FERC documents on October 13,
2000.
 Based upon discussions that we have had with the various Enron
Entities, we believe that we could make a second wave of productions on
Friday October 27, 2000. It is possible that not all Enron Entities could
make that date but we believe the bulk of the data could be available for
production by then.
 We propose to make these productions with the understanding that if
any entity obtains a more stringent protective order than the one currently
in place, that all of the Enron Entities document productions will be
protected by the most stringent protective order. In addition, if, at the
request of any party or nonparty to this proceeding, the Commission or a
court of competent jurisdiction orders that the requests for production be
limited, reduced or eliminated, the Enron Entities reserve the right to
limit the production of documents in conformance with such order.
 We understand that you will consider these proposals and let us know
if they are acceptable to the Commission. If you have any questions or
comments about our proposal, please do not hesitate to contact Michael Day
or myself.
Brobeck Phleger & Harrison LLP
Gary Fergus

In the fading light of the moon and the warmth of the sun's gentle breath, I find myself lost in memories. The creaking of the old wooden floorboards beneath my feet, the worn joints aching with every step, beckon me to recall the past. Memories call to me, whispering tales of a bygone era.

I am drawn to the earth's opening, the graves dug, again and again, as if the cycle of life and death is a never-ending refrain. I, always I, am left to turn away, into the gentle rustle of a bat's wing, a soothing melody that never changes.

Not this morning, not here, where I've just discovered a small harvest, hidden beneath the rubber mat in the back of my truck, in a tea cup's worth of dirt, where it seems no seed could possibly grow. Yet, a corn kernel splits to pale leaves and stringing roots. I make it, bend to these small harvests, because somewhere in North Carolina, there was a house, and in it, my room and my bed, bare boards and the bloodstains of a man, murdered in 1863, trying to escape.

Somewhere there was a child who slept on the living room's red vinyl couch, who still matters, especially now that I can't remember when the creek that bounded our family farm led to an ocean, or when a boxcar's weathered letters spelling Illinois meant somewhere there was an Illinois. It's still 1976, the day after I've been seen playing tennis with a black boy, and it seems I will always be held at gunpoint and beaten, as if the right punch would chunk out his name.

No, it's 1969, the year my mother becomes a wax paste, or so she looks to the child I was, and she drips into the pink satin, and I learn the funereal smell of carnations. That year the moon was still made of green cheese. That year men first bagged and labeled that moon. There are no years, only the past, and I still don't know why Odell Horney pulled a shotgun on my brother, or how the body contains so much blood.

I still don't know why Donna Hill went to Myrtle Beach and three days later came back dead. For ten years, I lived with Louise Stegall, the lover of my father, one of her four men, all buried – suicide, murder, drink, again murder. It was after the second one that she sat stock still, four years in the asylum. Now she walks the road, picking up Cracker Jack to give to children brave enough to approach her. When I was nine, the starling pecked outside her window the whole week. Someone's going to die, she said, and made me hug Uncle Robert's neck, as if I couldn't know he'd be gone in two hours, as if I hadn't learned anything about people and their vanishing.

The last time I saw her, she wouldn't look at me, jerked her sweatshirt hood across her face, and stepped into the ditch, as if there were things even she wouldn't tell, as if I'd never known it's dirt and dust after all the earth's sink and the worms' castings. 

With the wet leaves thick on my steps, the evening sky bruised dull gray to black, when I've spilled salt and as the saying goes, the sorrow and tears, and the stove is cold, so salt won't burn, tell me my pocket of charms can counter any spell. Tell me again the reason for my grandfather's fingers afloat in the Mason jar on the fireplace mantle between the snuff tin and the bowl of pecanuts. What about the tine in the dresser bureau, the silver of back bone I wear around my neck? Again the washed-out photo in the family album, Pacific wind lifting the small waves onto Coral Beach, clicking the palm trees' friends. Again my father's rash grin, his bayonet catching a scratch of sun, his left foot proposed on the striped and bloodied body. Behind him, a stack of Japanese.

Let me believe in anything. Doesn't the grizzled chicken dig up hoodoo hands? Won't the blue door frame, the basket of acorns protect me; what about the knife in a pair of water? When giving me the dead's slipped feet room to room, why not also synchronicity's proof, a wish and the tilted ears of angels? I want to believe in the power of rosemary knuckled along the fence, even as the stars order themselves to an unalterable and essential law. I want the wind-whipped leaves to settle and the flattened scrub to right itself, I want the loose tin in the neighbor's shed to finish its message. When this season in its scored exactitude shifts closer, give me Devil's Blue Boleto through the piled leaves, the slender green of Earth

This document outlines a category of mixed-effects models designed for the joint analysis of geographically linked intensity variance and warping variance in two-dimensional images. The intensity variance and warp variance, which are spatially correlated, are treated as random effects, leading to a linear mixed-effects simulation that facilitates ongoing analysis of template and simulation variables through the optimization of the likelihood function. We introduce an algorithm for model fitting that alternates between the analysis of variance parameters and image registration. This approach mitigates the potential estimation bias in the template estimate that can arise when registration is considered merely a preprocessing step. We demonstrate the application of the model on datasets comprising facial images and 2D brain magnetic resonance images to showcase the continuous measurement and analysis of intensity and warp effects.

Rewritten:
This paper describes a class of mixed-effects models for joint modeling of
geographically associated intensity variance and warping variance in 2D images.
Spatially correlated intensity variance and warp variance are modeled as
random effects, resulting in a linear mixed-effects simulation that allows
continuous analysis of template and simulation variables by optimization of the
likelihood function. We propose an algorithm for fitting the model which
alternates analysis of variance parameters and image registration. This
method removes the potential estimation bias in the template estimate that
occurs when treating registration as a preprocessing step. We apply the model
to datasets of facial images and 2D brain magnetic resonance images to
illustrate the continuous measurement and analysis of intensity and warp
effects.

In my initial slumber  
I arrived at the river  
And gazed down  
Through the transparent water -  
Only in a dream  
Water so pristine,  
Woven and flowing  
Lines of movement  
On its stony floor  
Water of existence  
Streaming eternally.  
A dwelling was present  
Next to the river  
And I, having come,  
An anticipated visitor  
Ready to discover  
Ancient gardens and libraries -  
But the vehicle was waiting  
To take me away.  
One final glance  
Into that radiant stream -  
Trout were present  
And visible on the bottom  
The monstrous shape  
Of the giant crayfish  
That crawls towards the moon.  
On its stony floor  
Living water  
In spirals and ripples  
Flowing unrestrained.  
There stood the vehicle  
To take me away.  
We crossed the river  
Of living water -  
I might not linger,  
But must return  
By the road too brief  
To the awaiting day.  
In my second dream  
I was pure and free  
By the rushing stream,  
My crystal home the sky,  
The clear crystalline sky.  
Into the stream I tossed  
A bottle of clear glass  
That twirled and danced and spun  
In the water's rush  
Reflecting the morning sun.  
Down that swift river  
I watched it carried away,  
My empty crystal shape,  
Joyfully saw it caught  
In the current's whirl,  
The sparkling water's flow.

Rewritten:
In my first sleep
I came to the river
And looked down
Through the clear water -
Only in dream
Water so pure,
Laced and undulant
Lines of flow
On its rocky bed
Water of life
Streaming for ever.
A house was there
Beside the river
And I, arrived,
An expected guest
About to explore
Old gardens and libraries -
But the car was waiting
To drive me away.
One last look
Into that bright stream -
Trout there were
And clear on the bottom
Monster form
Of the great crayfish
That crawls to the moon.
On its rocky bed
Living water
In whorls and ripples
Flowing unbended.
There was the car
To drive me away.
We crossed the river
Of living water -
I might not stay,
But must return
By the road too short
To the waiting day.
In my second dream
Pure I was and free
By the rapid stream,
My crystal house the sky,
The pure crystalline sky.
Into the stream I flung
A bottle of clear glass
That twirled and tossed and spun
In the water's race
Flashing the morning sun.
Down that swift river
I saw it borne away,
My empty crystal form,
Exultant saw it caught
Into the current's spin,
The flashing water's run.

The UK government is seeking deals to allow the deportation of terror suspects to their home countries without risking their torture or execution. Home Secretary Charles Clarke told The Times that he hoped an agreement with several countries could be reached. This move follows a Law Lords judgment that the detention of 12 men at Belmarsh prison in London and Woodhill prison in Milton Keynes was unlawful. The 12 affected individuals are from Algeria, Tunisia, Egypt, and Jordan. The government was told that using anti-terror legislation brought in after 9/11 to hold the men indefinitely without charge broke human rights laws.

Mr. Clarke told The Times: "I think we should be processing our ability to deport the individuals concerned to the countries from which they come more energetically." He said that this route was being pursued in collaboration with Foreign Secretary Jack Straw "in a very positive way." Mr. Clarke stated that he was seeking "memoranda of understanding" between overseas governments and the UK to ensure that suspects would not be subjected to the death penalty on their return. However, he added: "I do not think the solution to the Law Lords' judgment for this government is in deportations, but they will help. There are other strands that we have to do." But the Liberal Democrats' shadow home secretary, Mark Oaten, accused Mr. Clarke of avoiding the main issue with the Belmarsh detainees.

"The critical issue that the home secretary is dodging at this stage is to deal with the very principle, to deal with how we tackle this problem in the future," he told the BBC News. "And I do want him to grasp those issues, and that means looking at how we can actually secure convictions in this country allowing, for example, intercept communications, telephone tapping to be included." Mr. Oaten said that deportation may tackle the initial problem but he wanted to see a wider debate urgently about how to get trials and convictions in the country. "Unless we get that, the Liberal Democrats will vote against this measure when it comes for renewal in March."

The BBC's home affairs correspondent, Daniel Sandford, said it appeared that Mr. Clarke was putting more emphasis on the possibility of deportation than his predecessor, David Blunkett. But he said reaching an understanding with some of the detainees' home countries could be difficult. "Some of these people are accused of very, very serious crimes in their home countries so it's not an easy agreement to get and I think for some of these suspects it won't be the solution." Daniel Sandford said that ministers may try to put forward other solutions - such as allowing more secret evidence to be put into normal criminal trials or developing a more secret trials process - in the next few weeks. "The government may try and deport some of them and then those that are left see if they can work out some way of putting them on trial," he said.

Dеаls аrе bеіng sоught tо аllоw thе UΚ tо dероrt tеrrоr susресts tо thеіr hоmе соuntrіеs wіthоut rіsk оf thеm bеіng tоrturеd оr sеntеnсеd tо dеаth.
Ηоmе Sесrеtаrу Сhаrlеs Сlаrkе tоld thе Τіmеs hе hореd аgrееmеnt wіth sеvеrаl соuntrіеs соuld bе rеасhеd. Τhе mоvе fоllоws а Lаw Lоrds judgеmеnt thаt thе dеtеntіоn оf 12 mеn аt Βеlmаrsh рrіsоn, Lоndоn, аnd Wооdhіll, Міltоn Κеуnеs, wаs unlаwful. Τhе 12 аffесtеd bу thе rulіng аrе frоm Аlgеrіа, Тunіsіа, Εgурt аnd Jоrdаn. Τhе gоvеrnmеnt wаs tоld thаt usіng аntі-tеrrоr lеgіslаtіоn brоught іn аftеr 11 Sерtеmbеr tо hоld thе mеn іndеfіnіtеlу wіthоut сhаrgе brоkе humаn rіghts lаws.
Μr Сlаrkе tоld Тhе Τіmеs: "І thіnk wе shоuld bе рrоsесutіng muсh mоrе еnеrgеtісаllу оur аbіlіtу tо dероrt thе іndіvіduаls соnсеrnеd tо thе соuntrіеs frоm whісh thеу соmе." Ηе sаіd іt wаs а rоutе thаt wаs bеіng рursuеd іn соllаbоrаtіоn wіth Fоrеіgn Sесrеtаrу Jасk Strаw "іn а vеrу роsіtіvе wау". Мr Сlаrkе sаіd thаt hе wаs sееkіng "mеmоrаndums оf undеrstаndіng" bеtwееn оvеrsеаs gоvеrnmеnts аnd Βrіtаіn tо еnsurе susресts wоuld nоt bе subjесtеd tо thе dеаth реnаltу оn thеіr rеturn. Ноwеvеr, hе аddеd: "І dо nоt thіnk thе sоlutіоn tо thе Lаw Lоrds' judgеmеnt fоr thіs gоvеrnmеnt іs іn dероrtаtіоns, but thеу wіll hеlр. "Тhеrе аrе оthеr strаnds thаt wе hаvе tо dо." Βut thе Lіbеrаl Dеmосrаt's shаdоw hоmе sесrеtаrу, Μаrk Оаtеn, ассusеd Мr Сlаrkе оf аvоіdіng thе mаіn іssuе wіth thе Веlmаrsh dеtаіnееs.
"Тhе сrіtісаl іssuе thаt thе hоmе sесrеtаrу іs dоdgіng аt thіs stаgе іs tо dеаl wіth thе vеrу рrіnсірlе, tо dеаl wіth hоw wе tасklе thіs рrоblеm іn thе futurе," hе tоld ΒВС Νеws. "Αnd Ι dо wаnt hіm tо grаsр thоsе іssuеs аnd thаt mеаns lооkіng аt hоw wе саn асtuаllу sесurе соnvісtіоns іn thіs соuntrу аllоwіng, fоr ехаmрlе, іntеrсерt соmmunісаtіоns, tеlерhоnе tарріng tо bе іnсludеd," Мr Οаtеn sаіd. "Dероrtаtіоn mау tасklе thіs іnіtіаl рrоblеm but Ι wаnt tо sее а wіdеr dеbаtе urgеntlу аbоut hоw wе саn асtuаllу gеt trіаls аnd соnvісtіоns іn thіs соuntrу." "Unlеss wе gеt thаt, thе Lіbеrаl Dеmосrаts wіll vоtе аgаіnst thіs mеаsurе whеn іt соmеs fоr rеnеwаl іn Маrсh."
Тhе ВΒС's hоmе аffаіrs соrrеsроndеnt, Dаnіеl Sаndfоrd, sаіd іt арреаrеd Мr Сlаrkе wаs рuttіng mоrе еmрhаsіs оn thе роssіbіlіtу оf dероrtаtіоn thаn hіs рrеdесеssоr, Dаvіd Βlunkеtt. Вut hе sаіd rеасhіng аn undеrstаndіng wіth sоmе оf thе dеtаіnееs' hоmе соuntrіеs соuld bе dіffісult. "Sоmе оf thеsе реорlе аrе ассusеd оf vеrу, vеrу sеrіоus сrіmеs іn thеіr hоmе соuntrіеs sо іt's nоt аn еаsу аgrееmеnt tо gеt аnd І thіnk fоr sоmе оf thеsе susресts іt wоn't bе thе sоlutіоn." Dаnіеl Sаndfоrd sаіd mіnіstеrs mау trу tо рut fоrwаrd оthеr sоlutіоns - suсh аs аllоwіng mоrе sесrеt еvіdеnсе tо bе рut іntо nоrmаl сrіmіnаl trіаls оr dеvеlоріng а mоrе sесrеt trіаls рrосеss - іn thе nехt fеw wееks. "Тhе gоvеrnmеnt mау trу аnd dероrt sоmе оf thеm аnd thеn thоsе thаt аrе lеft sее іf thеу саn wоrk оut sоmе wау оf рuttіng thеm оn trіаl," hе sаіd.

Most regions of the US experienced continued economic growth in December and early January, according to the latest Beige Book report from the US Federal Reserve. Out of the 12 regions analyzed, 11 reported stronger economic performance, with only the Cleveland area receiving a "mixed" assessment. Consumer spending in December surpassed that of November, and holiday sales also increased compared to 2003. The employment situation showed improvement, the Fed noted. "Labor markets strengthened in several districts, although wage pressures generally remained modest," the Beige Book stated. "A number of districts indicated rising prices for construction materials and manufacturing inputs, but most reported stable or only slightly elevated overall price levels." The report also mentioned that residential real estate activity remained robust, and commercial real estate activity improved in most areas. "Office leasing was particularly active in Washington DC and New York City, two of the country's most vibrant commercial markets," the Fed reported.

Rewritten:
Most areas of the US saw their economy continue to expand in December and early January, the US Federal Reserve said in its latest Beige Book report.
Of the 12 US regions it identifies for the study, 11 showed stronger economic growth, with only the Cleveland area falling behind with a "mixed" rating. Consumer spending was higher in December than November, and festive sales were also up on 2003. The employment picture also improved, the Fed said.
"Labour markets firmed in a number of districts, but wage pressures generally remained modest," the Beige Book said. "Several districts reported higher prices for building materials and manufacturing inputs, but most reported steady or only slightly higher overall price levels." The report added that residential real estate activity remained strong and that commercial real estate activity strengthened in most districts. "Office leasing was especially brisk in Washington DC, and New York City, two of the nation's strongest commercial markets," the Fed said.

At the shapes of the moon, at the breaths of the sun, at the cawing of crows, at my injured foot and my aching joints—at all these moments, the recollection of what once was is pulled toward the earth’s gaping mouth, the graves, and I, I am repeatedly left, always, to turn away into the dust stirred by a bat’s wings. This remains constant. It always will. Not now, not here, not in the back of my truck where I’ve discovered, in a small handful of soil, beneath the rubber mat, a piece of corn that has unfurled into pale leaves and stringy roots. It’s an odd leap, but I take it, and I lean over these minuscule harvests, because there once existed, somewhere in North Carolina, a house, and within it my room and my bed, bare floorboards, and blood stains, that drown in the slanting rain’s anxious puddles, alongside the cries of a slave who was killed in 1863 while trying to escape. There was a child who slept on the red-vinyl settee, and he remains the most significant thing, because I can no longer recall if, when I believed that the creek by our family farm flowed to the sea, or when a boxcar’s fading letters, spelling “Illinois,” indicated that there was indeed an Illinois. It’s still 1976, and the day after the day I was seen playing tennis with a black boy, and, forever after, I am held at gunpoint and beaten, as if the blows would somehow erase my name. But it’s also 1969, when my mother’s figure melted into a waxy substance, and, as the child I was observed her, she dripped onto the pink satin, and I learned the somber scent of carnations. That year, the moon was still made of green cheese. That year, people began to package the moon and label it. There are no years, only the past, and I still don’t understand why Odell Horne aimed a shotgun at my brother, or how the body can hold so much blood. I still don’t know why Donna Hill left for Myrtle Beach and, three days later, returned home lifeless. For a decade, I lived with Louise Stegall, my father’s mistress, one of four men, all deceased: suicide, murder, drunk driving, murder again. After the second one, she remained silent and motionless for four years in a mental institution. Then she was released, and she walks all day, distributing Cracker Jack prizes to children brave enough to approach her. Once, when I was nine, a starling sang at her window for a week. “Someone is going to die,” she said, and placed me on Uncle Robert’s shoulders, as if I didn’t know that in two hours he would vanish, as if I hadn’t learned about disappearances. But she wouldn’t look at me, and pulled her sweatshirt hood over her face, stepping into the ditch, as if she wouldn’t tell me, as if I didn’t know that the ditch is the earth’s sinkhole, the castings of worms. When wet leaves accumulate on my steps, when the sky darkens to black in the evening, when I’ve poured salt into the cracks, and as it is said, the salt is weeping, and the stove is cold so that the salt won’t burn, tell me that the charms in my pocket will counteract any magic. Tell me the reason for my grandfather’s fingers floating in the Mason jar on the mantel, nestled between the snuffbox and the bowl of circus peanuts. And the teeth in the bureau drawer, the bone fragment I wear around my neck. And again the tattered photo in the family album, the Pacific wind creating small waves on Coral Beach, the palm fronds clattering. Again my father’s leering grin, his bayonet scratching the sun, his left foot on the exposed, bloody body. A pile of Japanese behind him. Let me believe anything. Can’t the hen scratch out the witches’ hands? Couldn’t the blue door, the basket of acorns protect me? A knife in a pail of water? If you allow me to believe in the dead, in their slippers moving from room to room, then why not in the evidence of synchronicity, in a wish, in the attentive ears of angels? I would like to believe in the power of the rosemary, bent against the fence, just as the stars are arranged according to an unchangeable and essential law. I want the leaves blown by the wind to settle, the fallen bushes to rise again, the untied tin in the shed to complete its message. When this season’s precision tightens, let the blue devils emerge in the leaves, the slender green tongue of the earth stalks, the phosphorescent honey fungus sent by the dead. Their voices, closer, almost compreh

Rewritten:
At moon-shapes, at sun breaths, at crows’ plunging cry, at my broken foot and my arthritic joints—at all these things, the memory of what was is drawn to the earth’s open mouth, the graves, and I, I am left again and again, always, to turn away into the dust of a bat’s wings. This never changes. It never will. Not now, not here, not in the back of my truck where I’ve found, in a thimbleful of earth, beneath the rubber mat, a kernel of corn that has split into pale leaves and string-roots. It’s a strange leap, but I take it, and I bend over these tiny harvests, because there once was, somewhere in North Carolina, a house, and in it my room and my bed, bare boards, and blood stains, that drown in the slant rain’s anxious puddles, with the cries of a slave murdered, in 1863, while fleeing. There was a child who slept in the red-vinyl settee, and he is still the most important thing, because I can no longer remember if, when I thought that the creek that ran by our family farm reached to the sea, or when a boxcar’s fading letters, spelling “Illinois,” meant that there was somewhere an Illinois. It’s still 1976, and the day after the day when I was seen playing tennis with a black boy, and, forever after, I am held at gunpoint, and beaten, as if the punches would somehow chip away my name. But it’s also 1969, when my mother’s form melted into a wax-like substance, and, as the child I was saw her, she dripped onto the pink satin, and I learned the funereal scent of carnations. That year, the moon was still made of green cheese. That year, people began to package the moon, and to label it. There are no years, only the past, and I still don’t know why Odell Horne pointed a shotgun at my brother, or how the body can contain so much blood. I still don’t know why Donna Hill left for Myrtle Beach and, three days later, returned home dead. For ten years, I lived with Louise Stegall, my father’s lover, one of four men, all dead: suicide, murder, drunk driving, murder again. After the second one, she sat silent, immobile, for four years, in a mental hospital. Then she was released, and she walks all day, handing out Cracker Jack prizes to children who dare to approach her. Once, when I was nine, a starling sang at her window for a week. “Someone is going to die,” she said, and put me on Uncle Robert’s neck, as if I didn’t know that in two hours he would disappear, as if I hadn’t learned about disappearances. But she wouldn’t look at me, and pulled her sweatshirt hood over her face, and stepped into the ditch, as if she would not tell me, as if I didn’t know that the ditch is the earth’s sinkhole, the castings of worms. When wet leaves are piling on my steps, when the sky is bruised to black in the evening, when I’ve poured salt into the cracks, and as it is said, the salt is crying, and the stove is cold so that the salt won’t burn, tell me that the charms in my pocket will counteract any magic. Tell me the reason for my grandfather’s fingers floating in the Mason jar on the mantel, between the snuffbox and the bowl of circus peanuts. And the teeth in the bureau drawer, the bone fragment I wear around my neck. And again the tattered photo in the family album, the Pacific wind raising small waves on Coral Beach, the fronds of the palm trees clacking. Again my father’s leering smile, his bayonet scratching the sun, his left foot on the naked, bloody body. A pile of Japanese behind him. Let me believe anything. Can’t the hen scratch out the witches’ hands? Couldn’t the blue door, the basket of acorns protect me? A knife in a pail of water? If you let me believe in the dead, in their slippers going from room to room, then why not in the evidence of synchronicity, in a wish, in the listening ears of angels? I would like to believe in the power of the rosemary, bent against the fence, just as the stars are ordered according to an unchangeable and essential law. I want the leaves blown by the wind to settle down, the downed bushes to rise again, the untied tin in the shed to finish its message. When this season’s precision tightens, let the blue devils appear in the leaves, the slender green tongue of the earth stalks, the phosphorescent honey fungus sent by the dead. Their voices, closer, almost to be understood. Whatever lies you have in this broken piece of time, give them to me.

When dealing with mathematical or computational problems that reach an infinite point, it becomes extremely difficult to extend analysis or numerical computation beyond that point. However, we propose that by applying suitable singular transformations, which can be detected and applied in real-time, it may be possible to cross over to the other side of infinity. This would result in a well-behaved solution and allow computations to continue normally. In our examples involving lumped Ordinary Differential Equations (ODEs), this infinity crossing can occur instantaneously. In contrast, for spatially distributed Partial Differential Equations (PDEs), the crossing of infinity may persist for a finite period, requiring the introduction of buffer zones where an appropriate singular transformation is continuously detected and applied. These findings and associated tools have the potential to lay the groundwork for a systematic approach to bypassing infinity and going beyond it in a broader range of evolution equations. They also offer the promise of performing relevant computations in a seamless and meaningful way. Along the way, we explore a regularization process through complexification and its impact on dynamics, as well as a set of compactification transformations and their intuitive implications.

Rewritten:
When mathematical/computational problems reach infinity, extending analysis
and/or numerical computation beyond it becomes a notorious challenge. We
suggest that, upon suitable singular transformations (that can in principle be
computationally detected on the fly) it becomes possible to go beyond infinity
to the other side, with the solution becoming again well behaved and the
computations continuing normally. In our lumped, Ordinary Differential Equation
(ODE) examples this infinity crossing can happen instantaneously; at the
spatially distributed, Partial Differential Equation (PDE) level the crossing
of infinity may even persist for finite time, necessitating the introduction of
conceptual (and computational) buffer zones in which an appropriate singular
transformation is continuously (locally) detected and performed. These
observations (and associated tools) could set the stage for a systematic
approach to bypassing infinity (and thus going beyond it) in a broader range of
evolution equations; they also hold the promise of meaningfully and seamlessly
performing the relevant computations. Along the path of our analysis, we
present a regularization process via complexification and explore its impact on
the dynamics; we also discuss a set of compactification transformations and
their intuitive implications.

The world's energy resources are dwindling, and oil wells are running dry. It's possible that in a decade from now, the super rich will realize that their money can't buy what they want, such as gasoline to put in their big cars parked in their garages. The people with nowhere to go will be forced to confront a harsh reality: that spirituality can grow.

We're being told that this is going to happen by those who might say it in the know. The oil reserves won't last forever; we've heard that for decades ago. Yet, what did we do to conserve energy? We went out and bought bigger cars, spent billions of dollars, and wasted huge amounts of energy building rockets for research on Mars.

What will happen when the oil wells run dry, and the super rich will realize that government bureaucracies were deceiving and leading them on with their lies? Will billionaires jump off big buildings when faced with financial disaster? In a decade from now, the world as we know it could be a much different place.

In the future, the world will be different, and that may not be a bad thing. For nature, life will go on as usual, and in the morning, songbirds will sing. We must go back to the pushbikes and with less pollution in the air. We will be healthier people, more spiritually and environmentally aware.
