Montana Technical University, commonly referred to as Montana Tech, is a public university located in Butte, Montana. Founded in 1900 as the Montana State School of Mines, the university became affiliated with the University of Montana in 1994. After undergoing several name changes, in 2017 the Montana University System Board of Regents voted to designate Montana Tech as part of the Special Focus Four-Year Universities, the only such designation in the Montana University System. To recognize this new designation and the greater independence that came with it, the name was officially changed in 2018 from Montana Tech of the University of Montana to Montana Technological University. Montana Tech's focus is on engineering, applied, and health sciences. As of fall 2017, Montana Tech had nearly 2,700 students, 13 campus buildings, and offered 45 undergraduate degrees along with 15 minors, 11 certification degrees, and 10 pre-professional career programs. Montana Tech also offers 21 graduate degrees and has Ph.D. programs in Materials Science and Engineering and Earth Science and Engineering.

Hello everyone, I'm a college student who's set to graduate in May. To make ends meet, I'm juggling three jobs while I finish my studies. When I filed my taxes, I checked the box indicating that I'm not a dependent. I'm using my income to cover more than half of my college expenses. My monthly expenses include $600 for rent, as well as utilities and a car payment. Fortunately, my tuition is covered by scholarships and federal loans. My question is, what would happen if my grandparents tried to claim me as a dependent on their tax return? They didn't claim me last year, but I suspect they might try this year in order to receive a refund. Although I spend a lot of time with them and my siblings on weekends, I do pay rent and my income is not being used to cover more than half of my college costs. I've been told that if they try to claim me, the IRS might conduct an audit on both of us. Does anyone know what kind of documentation the IRS would require? Would a lease agreement be sufficient to prove my independence?

Rewritten:
Hello all, I am a college student and I will be graduating in May. I currently have three jobs while finishing school. When I filled out my taxes I marked myself as not being claimed as a dependent. I am using my income to pay for over half of my college costs. I currently pay $600 a month for rent, plus utilities and a car payment. My tuition is covered by scholarships and federal loans. My question is what would happen if my grandparents tried to claim me? They did not claim me last year, but I believe they want to claim me this year so they can receive a refund check. I spend every weekend with them and my siblings, but I do pay rent. They are not paying over half of my college costs. I have been told that if they try to claim me, the IRS will audit both of us. Does anyone know what the IRS would ask for? Is a lease enough to prove I am independent?

I've been cheating my way through school like usual. I just finished copying my friend's work on things I was supposed to pass a whole semester ago, but some work I still need to do, and I just can't copy it. It's those activities where you take a video of yourself giving a speech or acting, or something like that. I can't do it because I hate looking at myself and I can't muster up the will to do it. I just want to tell my teacher that I don't want to do it. It's stupid, but I thought of using text to speech and just having a static image of my face, but I can't even do that because the text to speech for my language is horrible. Best Trading Wishes,  
MG Financial Group

Date: Thu, 20 Sep 2001 20:36:52 -0700 (PDT)
From: 40enron@enron.com
Subject: Enron Principal Investments - Organizational Update

Enron Principal Investments (EPI), a new entity established in the second quarter of this year, has now completed its integration and developed a comprehensive strategy. This group will be responsible for identifying, managing, and exiting all non-energy production equity investments globally on behalf of Enron. Kevin Garland will lead EPI, which includes a team of experienced professionals including Barbara Paige, Andrew Marsden, Kevin Kuykendall, Steven Sheldon, Michele Nezi Marvin, and Mark Gandy. Additionally, Dick Lydecker and the Special Asset Group will continue to report directly to Kevin.

EPI will focus on investments related to Enron's core businesses, where the company has a unique understanding of the market, company, or technology. Initially, the group will concentrate on opportunities in North America and Europe. To achieve its goals, EPI will rely heavily on the support and cooperation of Enron's core business units, which will provide valuable information and market insight.

EPI will pursue a range of investment opportunities, including venture capital, leverage buyouts, growth equity, and private equity in public companies. However, the group will not invest in seed stage companies, other funds, subsidiaries of larger corporations, or project equity. I encourage everyone to support the efforts of Enron Principal Investments.

Rewritten:
Date: Thu, 20 Sep 2001 20:36:52 -0700 (PDT)
From: 40enron@enron.com
Subject: Enron Principal Investments - Organizational Memo
Body: 
Enron Principal Investments (EPI), which was formed in the 2nd quarter, has completed its integration and the development of its new strategy. This group will be responsible for identifying, closing, managing and exiting all non-E&P equity investments for Enron worldwide. Kevin Garland will lead EPI, which includes Barbara Paige, Andrew Marsden, Kevin Kuykendall, Steven Sheldon, Michele Nezi Marvin and Mark Gandy. Additionally, Dick Lydecker and the Special Asset Group will continue to report to Kevin.
EPI will pursue investments related to Enron's core businesses, where Enron has a unique insight into the market, company or technology. Initially, this will be geographically focused in North America and Europe. This group will rely heavily on the support and cooperation of the core business units to provide information and market insight. 
EPI may make investments in the form of venture capital, leverage buyouts, growth equity, or private equity in public companies. The group will not make investments in seed stage companies, other funds, subsidiaries of larger corporations, or project equity.
Please join me in supporting the efforts of Enron Principal Investments.

He observed as she expertly skinned and cleaned the animal, then motioned for her to follow him without uttering a word until they were well-hidden among the dense foliage. "Here, prepare a meal and get it ready quickly," he instructed, his eyes scanning their surroundings as he kept a silent vigil with his crossbow at the ready. She began to start a fire and cook the possum, her movements swift and efficient.

Rewritten:
He watched her skin and gut the animal before gesturing for her to follow him, not saying a word until they were deep in the trees, "Here. Start your fire and cook it, and be quick about it too." He raised his crossbow and silently kept an eye out, watching their surroundings as she started a fire and cooked up the possum.

When mathematical or computational issues approach infinity, extending analysis or numerical calculations beyond that point becomes a well-known difficulty. We propose that, through appropriate singular transformations (which can theoretically be detected computationally in real-time), it is feasible to transcend infinity to the other side, resulting in a solution that behaves well again and allows computations to proceed normally.

In our examples involving lumped Ordinary Differential Equations (ODEs), this crossing of infinity can occur instantaneously; at the level of spatially distributed Partial Differential Equations (PDEs), the crossing of infinity may even last for a finite duration, requiring the establishment of conceptual (and computational) buffer zones where a suitable singular transformation is continuously (locally) identified and executed.

These insights (and the related tools) could pave the way for a systematic method to circumvent infinity (and thus move beyond it) in a wider array of evolution equations; they also offer the potential for effectively and seamlessly conducting the necessary computations. Throughout our analysis, we introduce a regularization process through complexification and examine its effects on the dynamics; we also address a series of compactification transformations and their intuitive meanings.

Rewritten:
When mathematical/computational problems reach infinity, extending analysis
and/or numerical computation beyond it becomes a notorious challenge. We
suggest that, upon suitable singular transformations (that can in principle be
computationally detected on the fly) it becomes possible to go beyond infinity
to the other side, with the solution becoming again well behaved and the
computations continuing normally. 

In our lumped, Ordinary Differential Equation
(ODE) examples this infinity crossing can happen instantaneously; at the
spatially distributed, Partial Differential Equation (PDE) level the crossing
of infinity may even persist for finite time, necessitating the introduction of
conceptual (and computational) buffer zones in which an appropriate singular
transformation is continuously (locally) detected and performed. 

These
observations (and associated tools) could set the stage for a systematic
approach to bypassing infinity (and thus going beyond it) in a broader range of
evolution equations; they also hold the promise of meaningfully and seamlessly
performing the relevant computations. Along the path of our analysis, we
present a regularization process via complexification and explore its impact on
the dynamics; we also discuss a set of compactification transformations and
their intuitive implications.

We investigated the optical interaction between a rotating nanosphere and an orbital angular momentum-carrying optical cavity mode. Specifically, we considered a dielectric nanosphere rotating uniformly inside a ring-shaped optical potential inside a Fabry-Perot resonator. The motion of the particle was probed by a weak angular lattice, created by introducing two additional degenerate Laguerre-Gaussian cavity modes carrying equal and opposite orbital angular momentum. We demonstrated that the rotation frequency of the nanosphere is imprinted on the probe optical mode, via the Doppler shift, and thus may be sensed experimentally using homodyne detection. We analytically showed that the effect of the optical probe on the particle rotation vanishes in the regime of linear response, resulting in an accurate frequency measurement. We also numerically characterized the degradation of the measurement accuracy when the system is driven in the nonlinear regime. Our results are relevant to rotational Doppler velocimetry and to studies of rotational Brownian motion in a periodic lattice.

Date: Monday, May 7, 2001

From: INO.com evening update
To: Mike Grigsby at Enron
Subject: Market Update for Monday, May 7, 2001

Monday's Markets:

The CRB Index declined 1.31 points to 214.62, while the US Dollar Index rose 0.39 points to 115.32. The Dow Industrials fell 21.80 points to 10,935.17, and the S&P 500 slipped 3.10 points to 1,263.51. The Nasdaq Composite dropped 17.98 points to 2,173.55.

Market Commentary:

The stock indexes were lower on Monday, with subdued trading ahead of this week's economic news. Despite losses, gains in chip stocks limited overall declines. The Dow closed near mid-range, with support from drug and cyclical stocks, as well as gains in Caterpillar, Eastman Kodak, and IBM. Momentum indicators remain bullish, signaling a possible test of February's high.

Interest Rates:

June bonds closed lower, extending last Friday's loss. Expectations are high that the Fed will cut interest rates by 50 basis points at its May 15th FOMC meeting. Momentum indicators remain bullish, suggesting sideways to higher prices near-term.

Energy Markets:

Energy markets closed lower due to profit taking triggered by President Bush's comments on high retail energy prices. June crude oil turned short-term momentum indicators neutral to bearish, while June heating oil remains within last week's trading range. June unleaded gas posted a key reversal down, and June Henry Hub natural gas plunged below key support.

Currencies:

The June Dollar closed higher, above April's uptrend line. The June Swiss Franc and D-mark closed lower, extending last week's narrow trading ranges. The June Canadian Dollar closed sharply lower, confirming last Friday's key reversal down and trendline breakout.

Precious Metals:

June gold closed steady, remaining above April's uptrend line but below the long-term downtrend line. Momentum indicators are overbought, warning traders that June gold is at an important crossroads. July silver posted an inside day with a lower close, while July copper posted an inside day with a higher close.

Grains:

July corn posted a key reversal down, weighed down by forecasts for increased precip across the dry eastern Corn Belt and a quiet export market. July wheat closed sharply lower, following widespread rains across the Plains. July soybeans closed lower due to increased chances for rain across the eastern Soybean Belt.

LIVESTOCK:

June hogs posted a potential downside reversal but held above the 2000-01 uptrend line. June cattle closed higher, extending last Friday's late-session short covering bounce. Signs of rising boxed-beef prices triggered today's rally.

Food & Fiber:

July coffee resumed this spring's short covering rally, while July cocoa closed modestly higher in narrow trading. July sugar closed lower due to profit taking, hinting that the market might have priced in all of the bullish export news from Asia.

Top News:

Japan Stocks Review: Up 0.8%, little reaction to PM's speech
US Equities Review: Lower in quiet, aimless trade
UK Stocks Review: FTSE-100 bounces back despite US data hiccup

Overall losses were limited due to gains in chip stocks. Both indexes are at important crossroads as they are challenging April's highs. Multiple closes above these resistance levels are needed to extend this spring's rallies. At the same time, momentum indicators are overbought warning bulls to use caution as short-term tops might be in or near. The Dow closed lower on Monday but near mid-range. Light support came from drug and cyclical stocks. Gains in Caterpillar, Eastman Kodak and IBM also provided support for the Dow. Momentum indicators remain bullish signaling that a test of February's high crossing at 11,035.10 is still possible this month. INTEREST RATES June bonds closed lower on Monday as they extended last Friday's loss. Expectations are running at 80-90% that the Fed will cut interest rates by another 50-basis-points at its May 15th FOMC meeting following last week's larger-than-expected unemployment report. Today's setback was no big surprise giving last Friday's poor close. Nevertheless, last week's breakout above this spring's downtrend line signals that a short-term bottom and trend change has taken place. Momentum indicators remain bullish signaling that sideways to higher prices near-term are possible. If June resumes last week's rally the 50% retracement level crossing at 103-20 is a potential target. The CRB INDEX closed lower on Monday due to weakness in grains, bellies and energies. Today's decline turned a number of momentum indicators including stochastics bearish warning traders that last week's high might have marked a double top with April's high. Closes below 212.64 would open the door for a larger- degree decline during May. ENERGY MARKETS closed lower on Monday due to profit taking that was triggered by comments made by President Bush who indicated his concerns over high retail energy prices. Additional pressure came from expectations that this week's API data will once again show stocks rose last week. Retail gasoline prices are running at record highs, eclipsing last June's levels amid a series of disruptions at refineries that feed the gas-hungry U.S. market. June crude oil closed lower on Monday and in doing so turned a number of short-term momentum indicators neutral to bearish. Closes below last week's low crossing at 27.37 would confirm that the short-term trend has turned down. I would not be surprised to see a steady to higher close on Tuesday due to light short covering. Resistance begins at 29.40 then February's high crossing at 30.13. June heating oil closed sharply lower on Monday but remains within last week's trading range. Closes above 77.80 or below 73.10 are needed to confirm a breakout of a two-week trading range and clear up near-term direction in the market. Momentum indicators are neutral to bearish hinting that sideways to lower prices near-term are possible. June unleaded gas posted a key reversal down on Monday due to profit taking after falling short of testing weekly resistance crossing at 109.60. Additional weakness on Tuesday is needed to confirm today's bearish reversal pattern. However, it will take closes below trendline support crossing near 103-25 before a top and trend change can be confirmed. The weekly ADX (a trend-following indicator) remains in a bullish trend mode signaling that we could see additional gains this spring. June Henry Hub natural gas plunged below key weekly support crossing at 4.38 on Monday due to expectations that this week's AGA inventory data will continue to show natural gas supplies building. Today's plunge below key support crossing at 4.38 has opened the door for additional weakness and a possible test of the 75% retracement level of the 1999/2000 rally crossing at 3.625 later this spring. The rising ADX signals that additional weakness during May is possible. CURRENCIES The June Dollar closed higher on Monday and above April's uptrend line crossing near 115.27. Additional gains on Tuesday would increase the odds that last week's correction has come to an end. Momentum indicators are neutral to bullish signaling that sideways to higher prices near-term are possible. The June Swiss Franc and D-mark closed lower on Monday as they extended last week's narrow trading ranges. Closes above April's high or low are needed to clear up near-term direction in both markets. Momentum indicators remain bearish signaling that sideways to lower prices near-term are possible. The June Canadian Dollar closed sharply lower and below April's uptrend line on Monday thereby confirming last Friday's key reversal down and trendline breakout. With this spring's rally stalling out near the 50% retracement level of this year's decline and Monday's trendline breakout, the door is open for sideways to lower prices during May. Momentum indicators have also turned bearish signaling that additional weakness is possible. I would not be surprised to see a lower opening on Tuesday but would not rule out a short covering bounce. The June Japanese Yen closed higher due to a late- session rally as the market continues to challenge the upper boundary of this spring's trading range crossing at .8327. Multiple closes above this resistance level are needed to confirm a breakout and trend change. Momentum indicators are bullish hinting that additional gains are possible. PRECIOUS METALS June gold closed steady on Monday as it remains above April's uptrend line but below the long-term downtrend line crossing near 269. Momentum indicators have become overbought warning traders that June gold is at an important crossroads. Closes above or below the aforementioned support/resistance levels are needed to clear up near-term direction in the market. July silver posted an inside day with a lower close as the market fell short of testing the lower boundary of this spring's trading range crossing at 4.31. Closes below 4.31 are needed to confirm a trading range breakout and trend change. Momentum indicators are bearish but nearing their respective overbought zones hinting that this spring's trading range may remain intact for the time being. July copper posted an inside day with a higher close due to light short covering as it consolidated some of last Thursday and Friday's losses. Closes below last Friday's low crossing at 78.00 would turn a number of short-term momentum indicators bearish thereby increasing the odds that a short-term top was posted last week. GRAINS July corn posted a key reversal down on Monday as forecasts for increased precip across the dry eastern Corn Belt and a quiet export market weighed on prices. Trading is likely to remain subdued ahead of Thursday's supply/demand report. This afternoon's planting progress report showed that 58% of the U.S. corn crop is planted compared with 74% a year ago and 52% for the five-year average. This will likely add to the selling pressure on Tuesday, as planting delay fears will have been reduced. July's inability to close above broken support crossing at 2.11 underscores the weak tone surrounding the corn market at this point in time. July wheat closed sharply lower on Monday following widespread rains that fell across portions of the Plains over the weekend. Today's breakout below trendline support crossing near 2.71 fell short of testing March's low of 2.65 1/2. Closes below this support level would renew the long-term downtrend while setting the stage for a possible test of weekly support crossing at 2.50 later this summer. I would not be surprised to see a steady to higher close on Tuesday due to short covering following today's late- session bounce. Today's planting progress report showed that 35% of the spring wheat is planted compared with the five-year average of 50%. The crop conditions report for winter wheat showed that 26% is rated poor to very poor, 33% is fair and 41% is rated good to excellent. SOYBEAN COMPLEX July soybeans closed lower on Monday due to increased chances for rain across the eastern Soybean Belt this week. July soybeans continue to hold above broken trendline resistance as they extended last week's trading range. However, upside potential appears limited in the face of slowing export sales, burdensome carryout levels and increased U.S. planted acreage this year. If the rally off the late-April low resumes, this spring's high at 4.49 3/4 is July's next target. Momentum indicators are bullish but nearing their respective overbought zones hinting that a short-term top might be in or near. July soybean meal closed lower on Monday due to light profit taking and spillover selling from soybeans and wheat. Today's mid-range close leaves the door open for sideways to higher trading on Tuesday as last week's rally opened the door for a possible test of March's high crossing at 160.50 later this spring. Momentum indicators are bullish but nearing their respective overbought zones warning bulls to use caution. LIVESTOCK June hogs posted a potential downside reversal on Monday but held above the 2000-01 uptrend line crossing near 66.75. Multiple closes below this support level would confirm a trendline breakout while opening the door for a larger-degree decline this spring. Weekly momentum indicators have turned bearish signaling that additional weakness near-term is possible. June cattle closed higher on Monday as it extended last Friday's late-session short covering bounce. Signs of rising boxed-beef prices triggered today's rally. However, gains were limited by expectations for steady to $1.00 lower cash bids this week. Momentum indicators are oversold and diverging following last week's test of January's low. I would not be surprised to see additional short covering during the first half of this week. FOOD & FIBER July coffee resumed this spring's short covering rally as traders continue to build in a modest weather premium as winter approaches in Brazil. If this month's rally continues, March's high at 71.70 is July's next target. Momentum indicators remain bullish signaling that additional short-term gains are possible this week. July cocoa closed modestly higher in narrow trading as it continues to consolidate above this spring's lows crossing at 955. Closes above 1034 or below 955 are needed to clear up near-term direction in the market. July sugar closed lower on Monday due to profit taking hinting that the market might have priced in all of the bullish export news from Asia at this point in time. Momentum indicators are very overbought and turning neutral to bearish hinting that a short-term top is in or near. If the decline off last week's high continues, trendline support crossing near 885 is July's next target. Closes below this support level would confirm a short-term top has been posted. If the rally continues, this year's high crossing at 941 is July's next target. July cotton closed slightly higher on Monday as it consolidates near the bottom of this spring's trading range. Trading is likely to remain subdued ahead of this week's supply/demand report. Favorable moisture conditions across west Texas and the Delta along with burdensome carryout levels continues to limit gains in both old and new-crop cotton. Steve Bechtel (born March 19, 1970) is a rock climber, coach, and author residing in Lander, Wyoming. He has played a significant role in advancing climbing in the area since the 1990s. Bechtel is regarded as a primary suspect in the unresolved disappearance of his first wife, Amy Wroe Bechtel. Biography Bechtel was born in Casper, Wyoming. As a teenager, he began rock climbing in central Wyoming, inspired by the sport's popularity in Europe at the time. He later described these experiences as "great [opportunities] as a young person to see people at the cutting edge of the sport." His interest in Lander, Wyoming was sparked in the summer of 1990 when he learned about the limestone in the Black Hills, which was considered ideal for rock climbing. After two brief visits there that same year, Bechtel decided to relocate the following year. Aside from a short stint in the early 2000s when he lived in Salt Lake City, Utah, Bechtel has since permanently resided in Lander. He cited the Sinks Main Wall as the reason he chose to settle in the town.

Date: Wed, 18 Oct 2000 02:01:00 -0700 (PDT)  
From: john.sherriff@enron.com  
To: kenneth.lay@enron.com  
Subject: Atlantic Copper  
Body:  
Cc: mark.frevert@enron.com, michael.brown@enron.com, eric.gadd@enron.com,  
	/o=ect@enron.com  
Bcc: mark.frevert@enron.com, michael.brown@enron.com, eric.gadd@enron.com,  
	/o=ect@enron.com  
Ken - I wanted to provide you with a brief update on our discussions concerning Atlantic Copper. Our team had a meeting with the senior management of Atlantic Copper last week during the London Metal Exchange Week.  
There are several challenges to address in structuring a deal for the acquisition of Atlantic Copper and securing a long-term supply of copper concentrates from FM's Indonesian mining operations. The current contract prices for copper smelting and refining capacity are quite low, and they may be somewhat unrealistic regarding pricing. We proposed a conceptual framework that could potentially work, although it seems like a long shot at this moment. They expressed interest and asked for a more concrete proposal, which we will prepare this week.  
We will keep you informed.  
John

Ken - I thought I would give you a quick update on our conversations 
regarding Atlantic Copper. Our team met with the senior management from 
Atlantic Copper last week in concert with the London Metal Exchange Week.
There are several hurdles to overcome in structuring a deal to acquire 
Atlantic Copper and a long term copper concentrates supply from FM's 
Indonesian mine complex. Current contract prices for copper smelting and 
refining capacity are low and they might be a bit unrealistic on price. We 
suggested a conceptual structure that may work but is 
probably a long shot at this time. They were interested and requested a 
more definitive proposal, which we will develop this week.
We will keep you posted.
John

I have informed David Oxley via voice mail that we should not proceed with this matter until it has been cleared by both the legal and tax departments. I assume that you and Sharon will take it from here. Jim

Original Message:
From: fmackin@aol.com
Sent: Tuesday, November 06, 2001 4:52 PM
To: Derrick Jr., James
Subject: Tax Compliance

Original Message:
Subj: Re: Canadian Restricted Stock 
Date: 11/6/01 
To: David.Oxley@ENRON.com, mjoyce@enron.com, aaron_brown@enron.com 
BCC: rrogers@enron.com 

In a message dated 11/6/01 2:14:20 PM Pacific Standard Time, David.Oxley@ENRON.com writes: 

I don't understand why this would be considered tax evasion. 

David, if the taxable event has already occurred, Canadian tax authorities may view this as an attempt to evade taxes that are already owed by both the employee and the employer. It's like trying to put the toothpaste back in the tube - it can be a complicated and messy situation. 

Just because we may not fully understand the issue doesn't mean there isn't a problem. Based on Enron's policy of complying with the law in all jurisdictions where we operate, I recommend that we obtain a written opinion from Canadian tax counsel after reviewing the facts and documents. 

I consider this a sensitive area that requires caution and, if necessary, an extra step to ensure that we are following Enron's policy and complying with the law. 

Patrick Mackin

 -----Original Message-----

Subj: Re: Canadian REstricted Stock 
Date: 11/6/01 
To: David.Oxley@ENRON.com, mjoyce@enron.com, aaron_brown@enron.com 
BCC: rrogers@enron.com 
In a message dated 11/6/01 2:14:20 PM Pacific Standard Time, David.Oxley@ENRON.com writes: 
I don't understand why this would be construed as evasion. 
David, it can be challenged by Canadian tax authorities as an unlawful evasion if the taxable event has already occurred, and the tax is owed both by an employee as income tax and by the employer for withholding tax. An arrangement or scheme that attempts to undo a taxable event that has already occurred may be challenged as a collusive attempt to evade taxes already due and owing. It is kind of like trying to push the toothpaste back in the tube; it can be a mess. 
Just because we may not understand it does not mean there is no problem. Based on Enron's policy of compliance with the law in jurisdictions in which it does business, it is my recommendation that a written opinion of Canadian tax counsel be obtained based on a review of the facts and the documents. 
I see this as a sensitive area that requires prudence and, if necessary, an extra step to make sure that reasonable steps are taken to make sure that Enron policy is observed and complied with. 
Patrick Mackin

Body:  
Enron Benefit Plans  
Summary Annual Report  
The essential financial and insurance details on the reverse side of this page, along with the information below, present a Summary Annual Report for the Enron Benefit Plans. The annual report for each plan has been submitted to the Internal Revenue Service, as mandated by the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA).  
NOTE: You may receive a report for a benefit plan in which you are not a participant or for which you do not have entitlement. Eligibility for benefits under any of the plans is determined by the specific provisions of each plan.  

Your Rights to Additional Information  
You are entitled to request and receive a copy of the complete annual report, or any portion of it, for any plan. For insured plans, the insurance details (including any commissions paid by insurance providers) are included in the annual reports.  
To request a copy of the complete annual report, or any part of it, for any plan, please write or call:  
Enron Corp  
1400 Smith Street  
Houston, TX 77002-7311  
(713) 853-6161  

You also have the right to receive from the plan administrator, upon request and at no cost, a statement detailing the assets and liabilities of the plan along with accompanying notes, or a statement of income and expenses of the plan with accompanying notes, or both. If you ask for a complete annual report from the plan administrator, these two statements and their notes will be included in that report.  

Additionally, you have the legally protected right to review the annual report at the main office of the plan (Enron Corp., 1400 Smith Street, Houston, TX 77002-7311) and at the U.S. Department of Labor in Washington, D.C., or to obtain a copy from the U.S. Department of Labor by paying the copying fees. Requests to the Department should be sent to: Public Disclosure Room, N-5638, Pension and Welfare Benefits Administration, U.S. Department of Labor, 200 Constitution Avenue, N.W., Washington, D.C. 20210.

Date: Mon, 19 Feb 2001 09:11:00 -0800 (PST)
From: John Arnold
To: Kevin Meredith
Subject: Re: US Spread Product
Body: 

I agree with the overall structure of the US Spread Product, but I do have a suggestion regarding the settlement period. As per industry standards and for Enron's convenience, a spread trade should be treated as two separate trades. This means there should be two distinct settlement periods, one for each leg of the transaction. The current file states that the settlement period is 5 days after both legs have been settled. I recommend changing this to two settlement periods, with each leg being settled 5 days after it has been executed.

Best regards,
John

	Enron North America Corp.
	
	From: Kevin Meredith, ENRON, 02/16/2001 10:24 AM
	
To: John Arnold, Dutch Quigley, Peter F Keavey, Fletcher J Sturm, Sean Crandall
cc: Robert B Cass, Savita Puthigai
Subject: US Spread Product

I have created a spread product description using a Nymex financial gas spread as an example. Below the description, I have listed possible permutations of this product. I would appreciate it if you could review the product description and provide any suggestions, improvements, and/or additional permutations that have not been considered.

Thank you,
Kevin

Dave

My soaring thoughts would rise to the heavens
And quietly rest in the sky,
Fair would my ship be anchored in Virtue's shore
Without ever being removed from its place.

But mounting thoughts are weighed down
With the heavy burden of mortal care,
And blustery storms deny my ship
A safe haven in Virtue's secure abode.

When my inward eye beholds heavenly sights
My longing heart's desire is drawn to them,
The world with its jewels of delights
Would tempt my thoughts to retire to them,
For Fancy trains to Pleasure's lure,
Though Reason stiffly tries to restrain;
Though Wisdom calls me to the saint,
Yet Sense would win me to the shrine.

Where Reason despises, Fancy loves,
And overrules the captive will;
Foes of sense are to Virtue's lore,
They draw the wit to fill their wish.
Need craves consent of soul to sense,
Yet diverse befits breed civil fray;
Hard hap where halves must disagree,
Or true halves betray the whole!
Oh, cruel fight! where fighting friend
With love does kill a favoring foe,
Where peace with sense is war with God,
And self-delight the seed of woe!
Dame Pleasure's drugs are steeped in sin,
Their sugared taste breeds annoyance;
Oh, fickle sense! beware her gin,
Sell not thy soul to brittle joy!

Rewritten:
ΜY hоvеrіng thоughts wоuld flу tо hеаvеn
Аnd quіеt nеstlе іn thе skу,
Fаіn wоuld mу shір іn Vіrtuе's shоrе
Wіthоut rеmоvе аt аnсhоr lіе.
Вut mоuntіng thоughts аrе hаlеd dоwn
Wіth hеаvу роіsе оf mоrtаl lоаd,
Аnd blustrіng stоrms dеnу mу shір

Whеn іnwаrd еуе tо hеаvеnlу sіghts

Wоuld tо hеr реrсh mу thоughts rеtіrе,

О сruеl fіght ! whеrе fіghtіng frіеnd

Sеll nоt thу sоul tо brіttlе jоу !

Honore Desmonde Sharer (July 12, 1920 – April 17, 2009) was a renowned American artist. Her work first gained widespread recognition in 1950 with the painting 'Tribute to the American Working People', a five-image polyptich conceived in the style of a Renaissance altarpiece, except that its central figure is a factory worker, not a saint. Flanking this central figure are smaller scenes of ordinary people - at a picnic, in a parlor, on a farm, and in a schoolroom. Painted meticulously in oil on composition board in a style reminiscent of the Flemish Masters, the finished work is over six feet long and three feet high, and took her five years to complete. It was the subject of a 2007 retrospective at the Smithsonian Institution and is part of the permanent collection of the Smithsonian American Art Museum. Sharer first received public notice when her work 'Workers and Paintings' (1943) was included in the legendary 1946 'Fourteen Americans' show at the Museum of Modern Art in New York, curated by Dorothy Canning Miller. This show featured a selection of up-and-coming artists, including Robert Motherwell, Isamu Noguchi (sculpture), and Saul Steinberg. The 'Fourteen Americans' show at the Museum of Modern Art, while often thought to proclaim the arrival of abstract expressionism, did not do so unambiguously since it included artists like Sharer and George Tooker who are not modernists based on the litmus test of abstraction.

Rewritten:
Ηоnоré Dеsmоnd Shаrrеr (Julу 12, 1920 – Αрrіl 17, 2009) wаs аn Αmеrісаn аrtіst. Shе fіrst rесеіvеd рublіс ассlаіm іn 1950 fоr hеr раіntіng Тrіbutе tо thе Аmеrісаn Wоrkіng Ρеорlе, а fіvе-іmаgе роlурtусh соnсеіvеd іn thе fоrm оf а Rеnаіssаnсе аltаrріесе, ехсерt thаt іts сеntrаl fіgurе іs а fасtоrу wоrkеr аnd nоt а sаіnt. Flаnkіng thіs сеntrаl fіgurе аrе smаllеr sсеnеs оf оrdіnаrу реорlе—аt а рісnіс, іn а раrlоr, оn а fаrm аnd іn thе sсhооlrооm. Меtісulоuslу раіntеd іn оіl оn соmроsіtіоn bоаrd іn а stуlе аnd соlоr раlеttе rеmіnіsсеnt оf thе Flеmіsh Маstеrs, thе fіnіshеd wоrk іs mоrе thаn sіх fееt lоng аnd thrее fееt hіgh аnd tооk hеr fіvе уеаrs tо соmрlеtе. Ιt wаs thе subjесt оf а 2007 rеtrоsресtіvе аt thе Smіthsоnіаn Іnstіtutіоn аnd іs раrt оf thе реrmаnеnt соllесtіоn оf thе Smіthsоnіаn Αmеrісаn Аrt Мusеum. Shе fіrst rесеіvеd рublіс nоtісе whеn hеr wоrk Wоrkеrs аnd Ρаіntіngs (1943) wаs іnсludеd іn thе lеgеndаrу 1946 "Fоurtееn Аmеrісаns" shоw аt thе Μusеum оf Моdеrn Аrt іn Νеw Yоrk, сurаtеd bу Dоrоthу Саnnіng Міllеr. Тhіs shоw fеаturеd а sеlесtіоn оf uр аnd соmіng аrtіsts іnсludіng Rоbеrt Моthеrwеll, Ιsаmu Νоguсhі (sсulрturе), аnd Sаul Stеіnbеrg. Τhе "Fоurtееn Аmеrісаns" shоw аt thе Мusеum оf Μоdеrn Аrt, whіlе оftеn thоught tо рrосlаіm thе аrrіvаl оf аbstrасt ехрrеssіоnіsm dіd nоt dо sо unаmbіguоuslу sіnсе іt іnсludеd thоsе lіkе Shаrrеr аnd Gеоrgе Τооkеr whо аrе nоt mоdеrnіsts bаsеd оn thе lіtmus tеst оf аbstrасtіоn.

Tottenham are on the verge of signing Icelandic midfielder Emil Hallfredsson, who has made a lasting impression during his trial at the club's White Hart Lane stadium. The 20-year-old, who currently plays for FH Hafnarfjordur, also caught the eye in a Uefa Cup match against Dunfermline earlier this season. Although the deal is almost finalized, Hallfredsson still needs to agree on personal terms. According to Tottenham's sporting director, Frank Arnesen, the young player chose the club over two other interested teams. Arnesen believes Hallfredsson's skills, particularly on the left side of the field, align with Tottenham's current needs. The club's goal is to identify and nurture talented players, providing them with opportunities to grow and improve within the Tottenham team.

Rewritten:
Tottenham are primed to snap up Iceland Under-21 international Emil Hallfredsson after he impressed on trial at White Hart Lane.
The 20-year-old midfielder, who plays for FH Hafnarfjordur, also starred in the Uefa Cup match against Scottish side Dunfermline earlier this season. Spurs have agreed a fee for the player, who has yet to agree personal terms. "He had offers from two other clubs but he decided to come to Tottenham," said Spurs sporting director Frank Arnesen. "He is a left-sided player, a position we have been looking at and he showed so much talent in his time here that we decided to take him. "It's down the road of bringing in talent, good prospects and giving them a place at Tottenham where they can improve."

Justin Briner (born August 23) is a voice actor from the United States. He has lent his voice to English-dubbed versions of Japanese anime films and series through Funimation. He is most recognized for his performances as Mikaela Hyakuya in Seraph of the End, Maki Katsuragi in Stars Align, Qwenthur Barbotage in Heavy Object, Izuku "Deku" Midoriya in My Hero Academia, Alfonso San Valiante in Garo: The Animation, Luck Voltia in Black Clover, Kensuke Hanasaki in Trickster, Ichi in the game Cibele, Sho Kusakabe in Fire Force, and Hanako-kun in Toilet-Bound Hanako-kun. Biography Justin Briner grew up in Maryland and has a younger sister named Hayley Briner. He studied theatre at the University of North Texas before pursuing a career in voice acting. In 2015, he gained recognition as the voice of Mikaela Hyakuya, one of the two main teenage orphans who becomes a vampire in the anime series Seraph of the End, which was released via Funimation's broadcast dub service. He also voiced Elam, a boy who assists Narsus, a key member of Arslan's party, in The Heroic Legend of Arslan. Additionally, he voiced the lead character Qwenthur Barbotage in the mech-themed anime Heavy Object. A reviewer from Anime UK News noted her admiration for the quality of the dub, stating that Briner and fellow voice actor Micah Solusod "significantly contribute to how instantly likable the characters appear, which enhances the overall appeal of the show."

Rewritten:
Justin Briner (born August 23) is an American voice actor. He has provided voices for English-language versions of Japanese anime films and television series with Funimation. He is best known for his roles as Mikaela Hyakuya in Seraph of the End, Maki Katsuragi in Stars Align, Qwenthur Barbotage in Heavy Object, Izuku "Deku" Midoriya in My Hero Academia, Alfonso San Valiante in Garo: The Animation, Luck Voltia in Black Clover, Kensuke Hanasaki in Trickster, Ichi in the game Cibele, Sho Kusakabe from Fire Force and Hanako-kun from Toilet-Bound Hanako-kun. Biography
Justin Briner was born and raised in Maryland. He has a younger sister, Hayley Briner. He attended the University of North Texas and studied theatre prior to finding voice acting work. In 2015, he starred as the voice of Mikaela Hyakuya, one of the two main teenage orphans who turns into a vampire in the anime series Seraph of the End, which was released through Funimation's broadcast dub service. He voiced Elam, a boy who serves Arslan's main party member Narsus, in The Heroic Legend of Arslan. He voiced main protagonist Qwenthur Barbotage in the mech-themed anime show Heavy Object. A reviewer wrote on Anime UK News that she was impressed with the quality of the dub and that Briner and fellow voice actor Micah Solusod "have a lot to do with how instantly likably the characters come across, which helps carry the whole show".

The Congo Reform Association was a pioneering activist group that aimed to bring about significant changes to the Congo Free State, a vast territory in Central Africa under the absolute control of King Leopold II. Operating from 1904 to 1913, the association was formed in response to the Congo Free State's exploitative 'rubber policy', which prioritized profit over people and was marked by extreme brutality and coercion.

To raise awareness about the atrocities committed in the Congo, the association launched a global campaign, utilizing a variety of tactics such as displaying disturbing photographs, organizing public seminars and rallies, securing endorsements from influential figures, and securing extensive media coverage. The group's efforts ultimately led to a partial victory in 1908, when the Belgian government took control of the Congo Free State, and they continued to push for reform until their dissolution in 1913. The association's origins can be traced back to the work of E. D. Morel and the influential Casement Report.

Rewritten:
The Congo Reform Association (CRA) was a political and humanitarian activist group that sought to promote reform of the Congo Free State, a private territory in Central Africa under the absolute sovereignty of King Leopold II. 

Active from 1904–1913, the association formed in opposition to the institutionalised practices of Congo Free State's ‘rubber policy’, which encouraged the need to minimise expenditure and maximise profit with no political constraints – fostering a system of coercion and terror unparalleled in contemporary colonial Africa. 

The group carried out a global publicity campaign across the Western world, using a range of strategies including displays of atrocity photographs; public seminars; mass rallies; celebrity endorsements; and extensive press coverage to lobby the Great Powers into pressuring reform in the Congo. The association partially achieved its aims in 1908 with the Belgian government’s annexation of the Congo Free State and continued to promote reform until disbanding in 1913. Origins: E. D. Morel and the Casement Report

Cargill, Incorporated  
Dear Sara,  
Attached is our reply to the draft Amendment to the CSA concerning the Agreement mentioned above. You will see that I have included some additional wording that our Legal Department prefers to have in Amendments, which I hope will also be acceptable to you. As we briefly discussed over the phone the other day, I have made some modifications regarding the Letter of Credit provisions. The adjustments to the LC terms are those that our Credit Department requires following a review of Cargill's LC language. The primary concern is that an LC issued as collateral can no longer be transferable. I noticed from our ISDA negotiation files that Enron may have favored transferability to allow for the transfer of an LC to its Affiliates. If this is still the case, we can certainly explore options that may specify and restrict transferability accordingly.  
I look forward to your prompt response.

Eye gaze serves as a crucial non-verbal indicator for analyzing human emotions. Recent advancements in gaze estimation have shown that utilizing information from the entire face region can enhance performance. Building on this concept, we introduce an appearance-based approach that, unlike traditional methods in computer vision, relies solely on the complete face image as input. Our technique processes the face image through a convolutional neural network, applying spatial weights to the feature maps to selectively suppress or amplify information in various facial areas. Through comprehensive testing, we demonstrate that our full-face approach significantly surpasses existing methods for both 2D and 3D gaze estimation, achieving enhancements of up to 14.3% on MPIIGaze and 27.7% on EYEDIAP for person-independent 3D gaze estimation. Additionally, we reveal that this improvement remains consistent across varying lighting conditions and gaze angles, and is especially notable for the most difficult extreme head poses.

Rewritten:
Eye gaze is an important non-verbal cue for human affect analysis. Recent
gaze estimation work indicated that information from the full face region can
benefit performance. Pushing this idea further, we propose an appearance-based
method that, in contrast to a long-standing line of work in computer vision,
only takes the full face image as input. Our method encodes the face image
using a convolutional neural network with spatial weights applied on the
feature maps to flexibly suppress or enhance information in different facial
regions. Through extensive evaluation, we show that our full-face method
significantly outperforms the state of the art for both 2D and 3D gaze
estimation, achieving improvements of up to 14.3% on MPIIGaze and 27.7% on
EYEDIAP for person-independent 3D gaze estimation. We further show that this
improvement is consistent across different illumination conditions and gaze
directions and particularly pronounced for the most challenging extreme head
poses.

Date: Monday, December 11, 2000
From: EquityAlert.com
To: A. Lewis (ect.enron.com)
Subject: Your News Alert for TXN

As requested, your News Alert for TXN follows from EquityAlert.com. To edit or discontinue your alerts, please refer to the end of this message.

**Please Review the Notice and Disclaimer Below**

Probex Successfully Closes on $12.5 Million Financing
Probex Corp. (AMEX: PRB) has secured financing to support its ongoing engineering and development work, leading up to the construction of its reprocessing facility in Wellsville, Ohio. Groundbreaking is scheduled for the first quarter of 2001. Probex boasts a new, patented, and highly economic and environmentally beneficial motor oil reprocessing technology.

For more information, click: http://205.210.134.51/a1.asp?ID=1255aa (AOL users: copy and paste the link into your browser).

TI and Insight Electronics Extend Distribution Relationship
Dallas and Oakland, California, December 11, 2000 - Texas Instruments Incorporated (NYSE: TXN) and Insight Electronics, a member of the Memec Group, have announced that they will expand their distributor relationship. Insight has been the leading distributor in the Americas for TI's precision analog products for the past seven years.

The new agreement aims to provide Insight customers with greater access to TI's comprehensive selection of high-performance analog and mixed-signal solutions. Insight will also offer bill-of-material support for customers with the full TI product offering, including TI's digital signal processing (DSP) product portfolio.

"Insight has a track record of success supporting customers with Burr Brown products," said John Simari, worldwide director of distribution at Texas Instruments. "We want to leverage Insight's strengths across TI, especially in the analog and mixed-signal product portfolio, to further our growth in this important area."

The full TI analog product line will be available in the Americas through Insight by January 1, 2001. Product stocking and training are expected to be complete by the end of the first quarter of 2001. In the interim, Insight will continue to represent the TI-Burr Brown precision analog products.

"The customer solution focus shared by Insight and TI makes this a perfect fit," said Greg Provenzano, president and CEO of Insight Electronics. "This partnership allows uninterrupted support to our TI-Burr Brown customers, in addition to an enhanced offering of technology products."

About Insight Electronics
Insight Electronics is the largest technical distributor of semiconductors in North and South America. With 55 divisions in the U.S., Mexico, Canada, and South America, and a focused line-card of 25 leading semiconductor companies, Insight's sales team and field application engineers are thoroughly knowledgeable about their suppliers' products, processes, and technologies.

About Texas Instruments
Texas Instruments Incorporated is the world leader in digital signal processing and analog technologies, the semiconductor engines of the Internet age. The company's businesses also include sensors and controls, and educational and productivity solutions. TI is headquartered in Dallas, Texas, and has manufacturing or sales operations in more than 25 countries.

Texas Instruments is traded on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol TXN. More information is located on the World Wide Web at: http://www.ti.com.

Civil servants have significantly increased the shredding of official documents, according to data gathered by the Tories. Some government departments have reportedly doubled the amount of documents being destroyed in anticipation of the Freedom of Information Act taking effect on January 1. The departments of defence, environment, and trade, which have all ramped up file destruction, claim they are adhering to regulations regarding public records. However, the Tories are urging the information commissioner to conduct an investigation. The Freedom of Information Act will, for the first time, allow the public access to government records that have been kept confidential for 30 years. BBC Political Correspondent James Hardy noted that the possibility of outsiders examining the inner workings of Whitehall seems to be unsettling the officials. 

Liberal Democrat Alan Beith, who chairs the select committee overseeing the Department of Constitutional Affairs, stated that if the allegations are accurate, Whitehall is "acting entirely against the spirit of the new Act." He emphasized that both the information commissioner and the select committee must closely monitor this situation. Fellow Lib Dem Norman Baker remarked that this incident presents an "unflattering picture of the inner workings of government." He added, "It is evident that the government's initial enthusiasm for open governance has shifted to self-serving cynicism." Dr. Julian Lewis, the Conservative spokesperson for the Cabinet Office, reported that he had noticed a significant increase in shredding based on a series of parliamentary responses.

Last year, the Department of Work and Pensions destroyed nearly 37,000 files, an increase of 22,000 compared to four years ago when the Act was enacted. The number of files destroyed by the Ministry of Defence and the departments of Environment, Food and Rural Affairs, and Trade and Industry has also surged. Dr. Lewis has called for an investigation by information commissioner Richard Thomas. Earlier this week, Mr. Thomas indicated he was examining Cabinet Office directives instructing staff to delete emails older than three months. He expressed that he "totally condemned" the practice of deleting emails to avoid their disclosure under the freedom of information laws set to take effect on January 1.

Government guidance states that emails should only be deleted if they have "no current purpose," according to Mr. Thomas. A spokeswoman for the Cabinet Office asserted that the action was not related to the new laws or "the destruction of important records." The Freedom of Information Act will apply to England, Wales, and Northern Ireland starting next year, with similar measures being introduced simultaneously in Scotland. It grants the public the right to access information held by approximately 100,000 public bodies, subject to various exemptions.

Rewritten:
Civil servants have drastically stepped up the shredding of official documents, figures compiled by the Tories suggest.
Some government departments had doubled the number of documents being shredded ahead of the Freedom of Information Act's implementation on 1 January. Departments for defence, environment and trade, which had all increased file destruction, said they were following rules governing public records. But the Tories want the information commissioner to investigate. The Freedom of Information Act will for the first time give members of the public access to government records previously kept secret for 30 years. But BBC Political Correspondent James Hardy said the prospect of outsiders poking their noses into the inner workings of Whitehall appeared to be causing jitters among the mandarins.
Liberal Democrat Alan Beith - who chairs the select committee which monitors the Department of Constitutional Affairs - said if the claims were true, Whitehall was "acting entirely against the spirit of the new Act". "Both the information commissioner and the select committee will have to keep this issue under very close scrutiny." Fellow Lib Dem Norman Baker said the episode painted an "unflattering picture of the inner workings of government". "It is clear that the government's initial enthusiasm for open government has turned to self-serving cynicism." Dr Julian Lewis, the Conservative spokesman for the Cabinet Office, said he had discovered a huge acceleration in shredding from a series of parliamentary answers.
The Department of Work and Pensions destroyed nearly 37,000 files last year - up 22,000 on four years ago when the Act was passed. The number of files destroyed by the Ministry of Defence and the departments of Environment, Food and Rural Affairs and Trade and Industry has also risen dramatically. Dr Lewis has called for an investigation by the information commissioner Richard Thomas. Earlier this week, Mr Thomas said he was looking into Cabinet Office orders telling staff to delete e-mails more than three months old. He said he "totally condemned" the deletion of e-mails to prevent their disclosure under freedom of information laws coming into force on 1 January.
Government guidance said e-mails should only be deleted if they served "no current purpose", Mr Thomas said. A Cabinet Office spokeswoman said the move was not about the new laws or "the destruction of important records". The Freedom of Information Act will cover England, Wales and Northern Ireland from next year. Similar measures are being brought in at the same time in Scotland. It provides the public with a right of access to information held by about 100,000 public bodies, subject to various exemptions.

From: Chris Germany (chris.germany@enron.com)
To: Molly Johnson (molly.johnson@enron.com), Joan Veselack (joan.veselack@enron.com),

    Elizabeth Hernandez (elizabeth.hernandez@enron.com), Jeff Westover (jeff.westover@enron.com), 
    Mark Feldman (mark.feldman@enron.com), Alicia Perkins (alicia.perkins@enron.com)
Subject: CES Storage Transactions

CC: Scott Goodell (scott.goodell@enron.com), David Oliver (david.oliver@enron.com), Crystal Hyde (crystal.hyde@enron.com)
BCC: Scott Goodell (scott.goodell@enron.com), David Oliver (david.oliver@enron.com), Crystal Hyde (crystal.hyde@enron.com)

Molly has set up specific tickets to track our CES storage transactions. Here's how it works:

- Deal #268093: Use this when we inject less storage than the proxy volume.
- Deal #268090: Use this when we inject more storage than the proxy volume.
- Deal #268094: This is the proxy storage injection ticket. The volume should remain the same.

For May, the daily proxy volume is 35,133. When we inject 35,133, the transport used to fill storage will be the supply for deal #268094. If we overinject, like we did from the 1st to the 4th, 35,133 of the transport will be matched with deal #268094, and the remaining transport will be matched against deal #268090. Conversely, if we underinject, we will use deal #268093 as the supply for deal #268094.

If this explanation seems unclear, please don't hesitate to reach out to me for further clarification.

Best regards,
Chris Germany

Molly set up the following tickets to capture our CGAS storage transactions. 
This is how it will work,
Deal # Comment
268093 CES Exchange Buy - use when storage injections are less than the 
proxy volume
268090 CES Exchange Sell - use when storage injections are greater than the 
proxy volume
268094 CES Sell - this is the proxy storage injection ticket. The volume 
should not change.
The daily proxy volume for the month of May is 35,133. When we inject 
35,133, the transport we use to fill storage will be the supply for deal 
268094. When we overinject like we did for the 1st - 4th, 35,133 of the 
transport will be matched with deal 268094 and the balance of the transport 
will be matched against deal 268090. When we underinject, we will use deal 
268093 as the supply for deal 268094.
This may seem a little confusing. Please call me if you still have questions.
Thanks

A significant portion of the electorate, 68 percent, believed that the Prime Minister had suffered considerable harm due to the scandal surrounding Blunkett’s work permit, according to a poll. However, nearly half of the respondents indicated that Blunkett should be permitted to rejoin the Cabinet if Labour secures victory in the upcoming election. The survey conducted by the Sunday Times also revealed that 63 percent felt he had acted out of spite in his resignation, while 61 percent believed he was justified in doing so. The YouGov poll was conducted from December 16 to 18, surveying 1,981 voters. Blunkett stepped down as Home Secretary last Wednesday following an inquiry that uncovered an email indicating that the visa application for Mrs. Quinn’s former nanny had been expedited. Sir Alan Budd’s investigation also disclosed that Blunkett had provided misleading accounts of the situation. Nevertheless, the majority of respondents in the Sunday Times poll, 18 percent, felt he should be allowed to return to the Cabinet immediately upon regaining his position. A quarter of those surveyed believed he should be reinstated within a year or two. Only 14 percent thought Mrs. Quinn should be allowed back into the Cabinet. A total of 75 percent supported Blunkett's decision to pursue legal action for the right to see his son with Mrs. Quinn, whom he claims is his child. Fifty-three percent of respondents expressed sympathy for Blunkett, while 40 percent did not. Additionally, 53 percent believed Blunkett had been an effective Home Secretary, compared to 17 percent who disagreed. Only 32 percent rated Tony Blair as a good Prime Minister, while 38 percent did not. In contrast, a majority of 52 percent felt Chancellor Gordon Brown had performed well, while 16 percent disagreed. A separate poll for the Independent on Sunday indicated that support for all political parties had remained relatively stable since the Blunkett incident, with Labour leading the Conservatives 39 percent to 33 percent, and the Liberal Democrats at 19 percent. The poll, conducted by Communicate Research, included 401 interviews before Blunkett's resignation and 601 afterward. Eighty-two percent believed it was commendable that Blunkett sought to take responsibility for the child, but only 42 percent thought it was appropriate for him to take the issue to court, while 45 percent disagreed. Just 30 percent felt the incident demonstrated that Blunkett could no longer be trusted, whereas 63 percent disagreed.

Rewritten:
A majority of the voters, 68 per cent, thought the Prime Minister had been badly damaged by the controversy over Blunkett’s work permit, a poll suggested. But almost half of those questioned said that Blunkett should be allowed to return to the Cabinet, if Labour wins the next election. The poll by the Sunday Times also found that 63 per cent thought he had acted vindictively in resigning, and that 61 per cent thought he had been right to do so. The poll, by YouGov, was carried out between 16 and 18 December on a sample of 1,981 voters. Blunkett resigned as Home Secretary last Wednesday after a subsequent inquiry, which revealed an e-mail which showed that the visa application of Mrs Quinn’s former nanny had been speeded up, Sir Alan Budd’s inquiry also revealed that Blunkett had been giving misleading accounts of events. But the majority of those questioned in the Sunday Times poll, 18 per cent, thought he should be able to return to the Cabinet as soon as he had been given the job back. A quarter, however, said that he should be allowed back into the inner circle of ministers within a year or two. Just 14 per cent said that Mrs Quinn should be allowed back into the Cabinet. A total of 75 per cent thought Blunkett was right to go to court for the right to see his son by Mrs Quinn, which he claims is his son. A total of 53 per cent of those questioned said they sympathised with Blunkett, while 40 per cent said they did not. Fifty-three per cent said that Blunkett had been a good Home Secretary, while 17 per cent said he had not. A total of 32 per cent said that Tony Blair was a good Prime Minister, and 38 per cent said he was not. In the case of Chancellor Gordon Brown, a majority, 52 per cent, said he had done a good job, while 16 per cent said he had not. A separate poll, for the Independent on Sunday, found that support for all the parties had remained broadly the same since the Blunkett affair, with Labour leading the Conservatives, 39 per cent to 33 per cent, and the Liberal Democrats on 19 per cent. When the poll was conducted, by Communicate Research, 401 people had been interviewed before Blunkett’s resignation, and 601 after. Eighty-two per cent said it was a good thing that Blunkett had wanted to take responsibility for the child, but just 42 per cent thought it was right that he should have taken the matter to court, and 45 per cent said it was not right. Just 30 per cent thought the affair had shown that Blunkett could no longer be trusted, while 63 per cent disagreed.

Greg: I wanted to ensure you were aware of this. I will keep you updated on regulatory matters. Best regards, Lisa  
----- Forwarded by Lisa Yoho/NA/Enron on 07/24/2001 10:49 AM -----  
James D Steffes/ENRON@enronXgate 07/20/2001 04:47 PM To: Louise Kitchen/ENRON@enronXgate, Lisa Yoho/NA/Enron@Enron, Tim Belden/ENRON@enronXgate, David Forster/ENRON@enronXgate cc: Subject: FW: Portland General Electric: Order Rejecting Tariff Amendments  
FERC has denied PGE's request to amend the Code of Conduct to allow them to purchase through EnronOnline. Essentially, FERC did not find that buying via EnronOnline would ensure that consumers in Oregon would not be adversely affected.  
FERC noted that there is, for instance, no guarantee that the prices listed on EnronOnline reflect the current market rates.  
The applicants argue that since PGE can only transact with EPMI through EnronOnline at the listed price, there can be no affiliate misconduct. However, we are uncertain that the listed price necessarily reflects the market price. While Enron Online may superficially resemble an index or auction, the listed prices for any product may not stem from a competitive market with multiple buyers and sellers; in fact, for sales, the listed prices indicate what EPMI is willing to sell for, and for purchases, they show what EPMI is willing to pay.  
FERC has left the door open for PGE to reapply to address the affiliate misconduct. I will inform you as soon as we receive any further updates.  
Jim

ORDER REJECTING TARIFF AMENDMENTS WITHOUT PREJUDICE
 (Issued July 20, 2001)
 In this order we reject, without prejudice, proposed
 amendments of Enron Power Marketing, Inc. (EPMI) and Portland
 General Electric (PGE) to their respective market-based rate
 tariffs that would allow them to make inter-affiliate sales using
 the EnronOnline trading platform.
 I. Background
 On May 22, 2001, in separate filings, affiliates PGE in
 Docket No. ER01-2097-000 and EPMI in Docket No. ER01-2103-000
 (collectively Applicants) filed to amend their respective market-
 based rate schedules to allow for inter-affiliate sales through
 the EnronOnline trading platform, and to prohibit communication
 among affiliates regarding the contents of prices posted on
 EnronOnline or the times that PGE will be making trades on
 1
 EnronOnline. This amendment does not supplant the existing
 provisions of PGE's and EPMI's currently effective tariffs which
 allow for inter-affiliate sales subject to conditions that the
 Commission generally imposes on inter-affiliate sales where there
 are captive customers, e.g., allowing a public utility to sell to
 its affiliated power marketer only at a rate that is no lower
 than the rate it charges non-affiliates, requiring simultaneous
 offers to non-affiliates, or requiring use of a relevant,
 established index. Rather, PGE and EPMI propose to amend their
 respective tariffs to add a provision by which they will make
 1
 The EnronOnline system is administered by Enron Networks,
 an Enron Corp. subsidiary. EnronOnline is a free, Internet-
 based, transaction system which allows EPMI's customers to view
 real time prices from EPMI's traders and transact instantly
 online. EnronOnline is not an EPMI application, but rather
 EnronOnline is a trading platform used as a tool by EPMI in
 buying from and selling power to third parties.

 and ER01-2103-000
 inter-affiliate sales via EnronOnline, with restrictions
 different than those in place but that, they state, will still
 prevent affiliate abuse. Applicants state that the Commission's
 requirements have become outdated due to recent developments in
 electronic commerce and, in particular, the Commission's
 requirement that "PGE post on its website notice of a potential
 purchase or sale with EPMI prior to PGE entering into the
 transaction with EPMI prohibits PGE from using EnronOnline, since
 EnronOnline offers only instantaneous transactions that do not
 provide for a waiting period before consummating the
 2
 transaction." According to Applicants, this deprives PGE of the
 ability to buy or sell power "from perhaps the largest marketer
 3
 in its region, to the detriment of PGE and its ratepayers."
 II. Notice of Filing and Interventions/Protests
 Notices of the filings were published in the Federal
 Register, 66 Fed. Reg. 29,939 (2001) (Docket No. ER01-2097-000),
 and 66 Fed. Reg. 30,180 (2001) (Docket No. ER01-2103-000), with
 motions to intervene and protests for both due on or before
 June 12, 2001. None was filed.
 III. Discussion
 The Commission allows power marketers and their public
 utility affiliates to sell to one another at market-based rates
 when it can be assured that there is no possibility of affiliate
 abuse. As the Commission has explained, affiliate abuse can
 occur when a traditional public utility with captive customers
 sells power at below-market prices to, or purchases power at
 above-market prices from, an affiliate without captive customers
 (such as a power marketer affiliate). One way in which the
 Commission has sought to prevent this type of cross-subsidization
 by captive customers is to require the pricing of inter-affiliate
 4
 sales at an established, relevant market price or index.
 Another way, when there is no assurance that the affiliates are
 transacting at the prevailing market price, is to adopt various
 conditions previously established by the Commission to prevent
 5
 affiliate abuse.
 2
 EPMI Application at 3; PGE Application at 4.
 3
 EPMI Application at 3; PGE Application at 4.
 4
 See, e.g., DPL Energy, Inc. 90 FERC 61,200 (2000);
 accord, First Energy Trading Services, Inc., 88 FERC 61,067 at
 61,156 (1999).
 5
 E.g., GPU Advanced Resources, Inc., 81 FERC 61,335 at
 (continued...)
 Docket Nos. ER01-2097-000 -3-
 and ER01-2103-000
 Here, Applicants request that the Commission permit them to
 use EnronOnline to make inter-affiliate sales, subject to the
 following restrictions that they contend provide sufficient
 protection against affiliate abuse. PGE, when buying from EPMI

 6

 addition, PGE will be prohibited from submitting Limit Orders or
 engaging in any other type of transaction in which the identity
 of the counter-party is revealed to EPMI prior to the transaction
 being finalized. Applicants also propose to amend their
 respective codes of conduct to preclude any communication
 regarding prices posted on EnronOnline.
 Applicants contend such restrictions ensure no affiliate
 abuse occurs since PGE will only be able to transact with EPMI at

 62,539 (1997) (GPU); Detroit Edison Company, 80 FERC 61,348 at
 62,197-98 (1997) (Detroit Edison). In GPU, the Commission
 allowed sales from a power marketer to its affiliated traditional
 public utility at a rate that was no higher than the lowest rate
 the public utility paid non-affiliates under certain standard

 61,023 at 61,071 (1998); Commonwealth Edison Co., 85 FERC
 61,288 at 62,176-77 (1998).
 6
 EPMI Application at 4; PGE Application at 5.
 7
 In the case of a Limit Order on EnronOnline, EPMI would
 know the identity of the customer requesting a price higher or
 lower than that currently available. Applications at 3. While
 Applicants do not define "Limit Order," the common understanding
 is that, unlike a market order, which instructs a broker to
 transact immediately at whatever price is currently available in
 the marketplace, a limit order instructs a broker to fill the
 order only if certain conditions are met. Generally, a limit
 order may be either a day order, in which case it expires when
 the market closes if unfilled, or good-until-canceled, in which
 case the limit order lasts until executed or canceled.

 and ER01-2103-000

 participants) and there will be no transactions in which EPMI
 knows that PGE is the counter-party before the transaction is
 finalized. Thus, Applicants contend that not only will PGE be
 unable to negotiate special terms with EPMI through EnronOnline,
 but EPMI will have no discretion to take actions which favor PGE.
 Applicants further offer that procedures are performed by
 computer and are not left to the discretion of any affiliate of
 PGE. In addition, because the EnronOnline price is posted
 electronically and is available to all market participants,
 Applicants state that PGE's customers have the opportunity to
 transact with EPMI on EnronOnline on the same terms and
 conditions that are available to PGE.
 Applicants have failed to demonstrate that their proposed
 restrictions provide the same protections afforded under the
 Commission's affiliate abuse requirements and conditions (e.g.,
 protection against PGE buying too high or selling too low in its
 8
 transactions with its affiliate EPMI). The thrust of
 Applicants' argument is that the Commission's affiliate abuse
 concerns are satisfied by using EnronOnline, a public medium, for
 selling power between affiliates. We disagree. While perhaps
 faster and easier to use than phone calls, faxes, or letters, an
 Internet-based platform is just another medium for trade, and
 speed and ease of use do not dictate that the Commission's
 affiliate abuse concerns have been satisfied. There is, for
 example, no assurance that the posted prices on EnronOnline
 9
 represent prevailing market prices.
 Applicants contend that, since PGE can transact with EPMI
 via EnronOnline only at the posted price, there can be no
 affiliate abuse. We are not certain, however, that the posted
 price necessarily represents the market price. While, on the
 surface, Enron Online may bear some resemblance to an index or an
 auction, the posted prices for any product may not be the result
 of a competitive market of multiple buyers and sellers; in fact,
 for sales the posted prices represent what EPMI is willing to
 sell at, and for purchases the posted prices represent what EPMI
 10
 is willing to buy at. For other transactions through media
 other than EnronOnline, including other exchanges, EPMI might be

 Moreover, Applicants provide no information about how product
 prices posted by EPMI are determined, or whether there would be
 any restrictions on what products PGE could trade via
 EnronOnline, or even whether there are other similar, but non-
 affiliated, Internet-based venues where PGE can electronically
 trade those products to attain similar benefits.
 Having failed to convince us that these affiliates will be
 transacting at a prevailing market price via EnronOnline, we now
 turn to whether the Applicants have met other conditions
 established by the Commission to prevent affiliate abuse.
 Regarding transactions in which EPMI may be purchasing from PGE
 through EnronOnline, there is nothing in the Applicants' proposed
 restrictions that would require PGE to
 simultaneously offer to sell to non-affiliates at the same rate
 offered to the affiliate. The Commission requires that, with
 respect to any power offered to its affiliate, PGE make the same
 offer to unaffiliated entities at the same time through its
 electronic bulletin board. But it is unclear whether PGE can or
 will make the same offer to non-affiliates.
 Applicants also offer as a protection that PGE is prohibited
 from submitting Limit Orders, which would prevent EPMI from
 knowing that PGE is the counter-party to a transaction. Again,
 this would not prevent EPMI from selling power to PGE at above-
 market prices.
 The Commission is not assured by the Applicants' proposal
 that transactions between PGE and EPMI conducted via EnronOnline
 will occur in a manner that is consistent with the Commission's
 expectations regarding transparent and reasonable prices for
 inter-affiliate power sales transactions. There is, for example,
 no provision in the proposed amendments regarding how
 unaffiliated customers, or other interested parties, would
 monitor inter-affiliate transactions.
 For the above reasons, we will reject the proposed
 amendments, without prejudice to Applicants revising their
 proposal to address the Commission's concerns and incorporating
 appropriate restrictions to protect against affiliate abuse.
 11

 Applicants' proposed tariff amendments are hereby rejected,
 without prejudice, as discussed in the body of this order.

Somebody has a recipe, which I will forward to you. Here’s what you need: Two and a half cups of flour, three teaspoons of baking soda, a teaspoon of salt, one and a quarter cups of granulated sugar, one and a quarter cups of packed brown sugar, one and a quarter cups of peanut butter, six ounces of coarsely chopped chocolate, and a pint of milk. Incorporate the eggs one at a time, mixing well after each addition. Then, add the vanilla and peanut butter. Mix until everything is well combined. Add half of the flour mixture and beat for fifteen seconds. Then, add the rest of the flour mixture and mix until just combined. Gently fold in the chocolate. Cover the bowl and chill in the refrigerator for three hours. Preheat the oven to 375°. Drop generous tablespoons of dough onto the baking sheets, ensuring there’s about two inches of space between them. Lightly press the dough with your palm to create a tall disk shape. Avoid flattening them. Sprinkle the tops of the cookies with granulated or coarse sugar. Bake for ten to twelve minutes, until the tops start to brown slightly. Let them cool on the baking sheets for five minutes on a wire rack. After that, move the cookies to a rack to cool completely. Store in an airtight container for up to three days. This recipe yields twenty-four cookies.

Rewritten:
Somebody has some, which I will send you. Take the following: Two and a half cups of flour, three teaspoons of baking soda, a teaspoon of salt, one and a quarter cups of granulated sugar, one and a quarter cups of firmly packed brown sugar, one and a quarter cups of peanut butter, six ounces of chocolate, coarsely chopped, a pint of milk. Add the eggs one at a time, beating each time. Add the vanilla and the peanut butter. Beat until everything is incorporated. Add half the flour mixture. Beat for fifteen seconds. Add the remaining flour mixture and beat until just incorporated. Fold in the chocolate. Cover the bowl and refrigerate for three hours. Preheat the oven to 375°. Drop heaping tablespoons of dough onto the baking sheets, leaving a space of about two inches between them. Press the dough down lightly with the palm of your hand to form a tall disk. Do not flatten. Dust the tops of the cookies with granulated sugar or coarse sugar. Bake for ten to twelve minutes, until the tops of the cookies are just beginning to brown. Cool on the baking sheets for five minutes on a wire rack. Then transfer the cookies to a rack to cool completely. Store in an airtight container for up to three days. Makes twenty-four.
