Date: Thu, 1 Nov 2001 09:15:22 -0800 (PST)
From: no.address@enron.com
Subject: Daily Update

Today, we've made significant progress in our efforts to regain the trust of our shareholders and the market, strengthen our financial position, and maintain our credit rating. We've secured a commitment letter with two long-standing banking partners, JPMorgan and Salomon Smith Barney, which will provide us with an additional $1 billion in secured credit lines. These lines of credit will be supported by our Northern Natural Gas Company and Transwestern Pipeline Company assets. The funds will be used to supplement our short-term liquidity and refinance maturing obligations.

It's essential to note that we're not selling these pipelines; instead, we're utilizing them as collateral for this new credit line. This type of secured financing allows us to quickly increase our liquidity and restore confidence. We also have the option to increase this facility by an additional $200 million if we can bring in more participating banks.

This new credit line is in addition to the $3 billion in credit lines we accessed last week to pay off short-term commercial debt and retain over $1 billion in cash. I understand that the negative media coverage about our company can be disheartening. On a more positive note, I'd like to draw your attention to an editorial in last Sunday's Houston Chronicle, which can be found at <http://www.chron.com/cs/CDA/story.hts/editorial/outlook/1107504>. I appreciate your hard work and dedication during this challenging time.

Please take a moment to review the voice mail and e-mail transcripts covering these developments on the Enron Updates intranet site at (<http://home.enron.com/updates/>).

Thank you.

I've finally reached a point where I'm 10 grams per day down from my previous 25-30 grams. It's taken a while, but I've slowly tapered off. However, I feel like I'm stuck in a rut. Three months ago, 10 grams per day would have been unheard of for me, and it seemed like such a small amount. Now that I'm here, I realize that's great, but I'm still taking 10 grams per day. I want it to be less, I'm getting kind of fed up with how long this is taking, and I'm not trying to take another four months to get completely off 10 grams per day. How did you guys feel when you were at 10 grams? Am I close to the finish line? Not even close, still have a far way to go? Does anyone know how quickly I can be done by tapering? I'm sure if I CT (cold turkey) I would still experience WD (withdrawal), I feel slightly each morning until I do 1.5 grams. I've been using kratom for the past 6-7 years.

Body:  
SIVY ON STOCKS from money.com  
December 4, 2000  
=========================================  
CHAT TONIGHT:  
Monday, December 4 at 8pm ET, 5pm PT  
Michael Sivy highlights sectors and stocks that  
offer genuine value in a turbulent market.  
AOL users go to Keyword: Live  
http://www.money.com/chat/  
=========================================  
Nasdaq crash casualty  
Applied Materials has dropped to bargain prices.  
By Michael Sivy  
While the Dow is down just 10 percent from its 52-week peak, the Nasdaq is experiencing a severe bear market, having plummeted nearly 50 percent since its high in March. Technology stocks, especially PC manufacturers, have been significantly affected: Compaq has decreased by 34 percent from its peak, Dell has fallen 68 percent, and Gateway has dropped 76 percent.  
This downturn is impacting the entire supply chain. Intel, which relies heavily on PC manufacturers for a substantial portion of its semiconductor sales, has seen a 56 percent decline. Meanwhile, Applied Materials [AMAT], the top producer of semiconductor equipment, has experienced a 66 percent drop.  
I don't think the future for these stocks is as dire as their recent performance indicates. Admittedly, the crucial fourth-quarter season does not appear very promising. The most pessimistic analysts suggest that PCs are becoming akin to television sets—commodities that are primarily differentiated by price. They argue that without the ability to command premium prices for additional features, already slim profit margins will further erode. However, over the next five years, sales for leading companies in the PC sector are expected to grow by 12 percent to 15 percent annually, with earnings potentially increasing by 16 percent to 20 percent or more.  
The upcoming months may be challenging, but they should present excellent long-term buying opportunities for investors. In my opinion, the standout opportunity is Applied Materials, which has the potential to grow profits by an average of 25 percent annually.  
The main drawback of the stock is its significant volatility. Even when it appears inexpensive, it can decline further if the technology sector continues to struggle. Additionally, since two-thirds of its sales come from international markets, Applied Materials is vulnerable to global economic fluctuations, including the weak euro and issues in Asia. In fact, I have previously recommended this stock at higher prices, only to see it drop even lower.  
At this juncture, however, I don't foresee it falling much further. Analysts have revised earnings projections for the current fiscal year (ending October 1, 2001) from $3.50 per share two months ago to as low as $2.10 today. Yet, even based on these lowered estimates, at $38.50 per share, the stock is trading at under 19 times earnings, or just 0.8 times its long-term growth rate.  
Business conditions may remain tough through the first half of 2001, and some analysts predict the stock could dip to $33 or $34 before hitting a bottom. However, conditions should improve in the latter half of the year. Given that the stock could easily trade at more than double its current price in a more favorable market, the potential upside appears ten times greater than the downside.  
###

Nasdaq crash victim
Applied Materials has fallen to fire-sale prices.
By Michael Sivy
The Dow may be down only 10 percent from its 52-week high, but the Nasdaq
is in the middle of a screaming bear market, down nearly 50 percent from
its high in March. Computer stocks have been among the hardest hit,
particularly PC makers: Compaq is down 34 percent from its peak, Dell is
off 68 percent and Gateway, 76 percent.
The weakness extends down the food chain. Intel, which counts on PC makers
for a large slice of its semiconductor sales, has lost 56 percent. And
Applied Materials [AMAT], the leading producer of semiconductor equipment,
is off 66 percent.
I don't believe that the outlook for these stocks is nearly as bleak as
their recent performance suggests. It's true that the crucial
fourth-quarter season isn't looking very bright. And the most pessimistic
analysts argue that PCs are becoming like television sets -- commodities
distinguished only by price. Without the ability to charge premium prices
for added bells and whistles, the thinking goes, already-thin profit
margins will deteriorate even more. But over the next five years, sales for
top companies in the PC sector are projected to grow 12 percent to 15
percent annually, and earnings could rise 16 percent to 20 percent or more.
The next few months may be trying, but they should offer investors great
long-term buying opportunities. And the best one, to my mind, figures to be
Applied Materials, which is capable of growing profits an average of 25
percent a year.
The stock's big drawback is its extraordinary volatility. Even when it
looks cheap, it's capable of falling further if the technology sector is
doing poorly. And since two-thirds of sales come from overseas, Applied
Materials is fully exposed to the vagaries of international economics, from
the weak euro to Asian financial problems. In fact, I've recommended the
stock several times before at higher prices, only to watch it go even lower.
At this point, however, I don't see how it could fall much more. Analysts
have reduced earnings estimates for the current fiscal year (ending Oct. 1,
2001) from $3.50 a share two months ago to as little as $2.10 today. But
even based on these reduced estimates, at $38.50 a share the stock is
trading at less than 19 times earnings, or just 0.8 times its long-term
growth rate.
Business conditions may well be tough through the first half of 2001, and
some analysts see the stock going as low as $33 or $34 before bottoming.
But business conditions should improve by the second half. Given that the
stock could easily trade at more than double today's price in a more
favorable market, the potential upside looks 10 times greater than the

The BBC's premier pop music show, Top of the Pops, is set to transition from BBC One on Fridays to Sundays on BBC Two. The revamped program will merge with the archival series TOTP2, blending contemporary music with clips of legendary bands. The corporation stated that the new format "aims to attract a varied audience of music enthusiasts." This change marks the most significant transformation in the show's history, which debuted in 1964 and has consistently aired on BBC One. Top of the Pops was reintroduced with much fanfare last December in an effort to counter a prolonged decline in viewership.

The All New Top of the Pops was hosted by newcomer Tim Kash and produced by Andi Peters, who returned to the BBC from Channel 4 to rejuvenate the series. Approximately three million viewers tuned in on Fridays, which is less than half of the audience it garnered in the mid-1990s, as it competed with the popular ITV soap Coronation Street. However, despite the relaunch, audience numbers did not improve and remained around the three million mark. Tim Kash has since been succeeded as host by Fearne Cotton. The new format is set to debut in Spring next year with an expanded presentation. BBC Two controller Roly Keating remarked: "It's an exciting new chapter for Top of the Pops. We aim to enhance it so that it becomes the ultimate pop music program for fans of all ages." Mr. Keating referred to BBC Two as the "natural home" for Top of the Pops and added: "The inclusion of Top of the Pops will also broaden BBC Two's appeal to younger viewers."

A BBC spokesperson confirmed that Andi Peters will continue as the executive producer of the show. She mentioned that discussions regarding the precise format and time slot of the program are still ongoing. The show will maintain a close connection with the BBC Radio 1 chart show, indicating that the relaunched version may air around 1900 on Sundays. "We hope that the audience for Top of the Pops will find it on BBC Two. We believe that the new time slot will generate excitement around the program, as viewers will discover who is number one in real-time for the first time."

Rewritten:
The BBC's flagship pop music programme Top of the Pops is to move from BBC One on Fridays to Sundays on BBC Two.
The new programme will combine with archive show TOTP2, mixing new music with footage of classic bands. The corporation said the new show "aims to appeal to a diverse audience of music lovers". The move is the biggest shake-up in the history of the show, which was first broadcast in 1964 and has always been on BBC One. Top of the Pops was relaunched in a blaze of publicity in December last year in an attempt to reverse a long-term decline in audience figures.
The All New Top of the Pops was fronted by newcomer Tim Kash and was put together by producer Andi Peters, who was brought back to the BBC from Channel 4 to revitalise the series.
About three million people a week were watching the show on Fridays - less than half the total it was attracting in the mid-1990s - as the programme went up against popular ITV soap Coronation Street. But despite the relaunch audience figures failed to rise and still remain around the three million mark. Tim Kash has since been replaced as host by Fearne Cotton. The new show will launch in Spring next year in an extended format. BBC Two controller Roly Keating: "It's an exciting new era for Top of the Pops. We want to make it bigger and better so that it becomes the ultimate pop music show for music lovers of every generation." Mr Keating described BBC Two as the "natural home" of Top of the Pops. He added: "The addition of Top of the Pops will also extend BBC Two's offering to younger audiences."
A BBC spokeswoman said Andi Peters would continue as executive producer on the show. She said that issues over the exact format of the programme and a time slot were still to be decided. The programme will have a close relationship with the BBC Radio 1 chart show, which suggests the relaunched show may be transmitted at about 1900 on Sundays. "Hopefully the audience for Top of the Pops will find it on BBC Two. "We think that the new slot will create a buzz around the programme as for the first time viewers will discover the news of who is number one as it happens."

Separating and labeling each instance of a nucleus (instance-aware segmentation) presents a significant challenge when segmenting individual cell nuclei in fluorescence microscopy images.

Deep Neural Networks have the capability to learn the implicit transformation of a nuclear image into a probability map that indicates the class membership of each pixel (nucleus or background). However, relying on post-processing steps to convert the probability map into a labeled object mask can lead to errors. This is particularly true for nuclear images derived from tissue sections and those obtained from various tissue preparation methods.

In this study, we aim to assess the effectiveness of cutting-edge deep learning architectures for segmenting nuclei in fluorescence images from diverse tissue sources and sample preparation techniques without the need for post-processing. We compare architectures that function on pixel-to-pixel translation with one that focuses on object detection followed by localized segmentation.

Additionally, we introduce an innovative approach to generate artificial images to enhance the training dataset.

We investigate how the quality of ground truth annotations, image scale, and the complexity of segmentation affect segmentation performance. The results indicate that three out of four deep learning architectures (U-Net, U-Net with ResNet34 backbone, Mask R-CNN) can effectively segment fluorescent nuclear images across most sample preparation types and tissue origins, achieving satisfactory segmentation results. Among these, Mask R-CNN, which is specifically designed for instance-aware segmentation tasks, outperforms the other architectures. Consistent nuclear annotations, equal nuclear mean size, and the incorporation of artificially generated images contribute to overall acceptable precision and recall across various tissues and sample preparation methods.

Rewritten:
Separating and labeling each instance of a nucleus (instance-aware
segmentation) is the key challenge in segmenting single cell nuclei on
fluorescence microscopy images. 

Deep Neural Networks can learn the implicit
transformation of a nuclear image into a probability map indicating the class
membership of each pixel (nucleus or background), but the use of
post-processing steps to turn the probability map into a labeled object mask is
error-prone. This especially accounts for nuclear images of tissue sections and
nuclear images across varying tissue preparations. 

In this work, we aim to
evaluate the performance of state-of-the-art deep learning architectures to
segment nuclei in fluorescence images of various tissue origins and sample
preparation types without post-processing. We compare architectures that
operate on pixel to pixel translation and an architecture that operates on
object detection and subsequent locally applied segmentation. 

In addition, we
propose a novel strategy to create artificial images to extend the training
set. 

We evaluate the influence of ground truth annotation quality, image scale
and segmentation complexity on segmentation performance. Results show that
three out of four deep learning architectures (U-Net, U-Net with ResNet34
backbone, Mask R-CNN) can segment fluorescent nuclear images on most of the
sample preparation types and tissue origins with satisfactory segmentation
performance. Mask R-CNN, an architecture designed to address instance aware
segmentation tasks, outperforms other architectures. Equal nuclear mean size,
consistent nuclear annotations and the use of artificially generated images
result in overall acceptable precision and recall across different tissues and
sample preparation types.

Joseph Woelfel (born June 3, 1940) is an American sociologist. He was born in Buffalo, New York, and is currently a professor in the Department of Communication at the University at Buffalo, The State University of New York. Career Woelfel earned his BA in Sociology from Canisius College in 1962, followed by an MA in Sociology from the University of Wisconsin–Madison in 1963. He completed his Ph.D. in Sociology, also at the University of Wisconsin, in 1968. During his academic journey, he minored in philosophy. After serving as an instructor at Canisius College (1965–1966) and as a research associate at the University of Wisconsin while pursuing his studies, Woelfel began his career as an assistant professor at the University of Illinois at Urbana–Champaign in 1968. In 1972, he transitioned to Michigan State University as an associate professor. Then in 1978, he joined the University at Albany, SUNY as a visiting professor, where he was subsequently appointed as an associate professor in 1979. In 1981, he was promoted to professor and in 1982 served as chair of the Department of Communication. By 1988, he was the director of research and a founding fellow of the Institute for the Study of Information Science. Ultimately, he returned to the University at Buffalo as a professor and chair (1989–1995) of the Department of Communication and has continued as a professor since 1995.

Rewritten:
Jоsерh Wоеlfеl (bоrn Junе 3, 1940) іs аn Аmеrісаn sосіоlоgіst. Воrn іn Βuffаlо, Νеw Yоrk, hе іs сurrеntlу рrоfеssоr іn thе Dераrtmеnt оf Соmmunісаtіоn аt thе Unіvеrsіtу аt Βuffаlо, Τhе Stаtе Unіvеrsіtу оf Νеw Yоrk. Саrееr
Wоеlfеl оbtаіnеd hіs ВΑ іn Sосіоlоgу frоm Саnіsіus Соllеgе іn 1962, аnd аn МА іn Sосіоlоgу frоm thе Unіvеrsіtу оf Wіsсоnsіn–Маdіsоn іn 1963. Не оbtаіnеd hіs Рh.D. іn Sосіоlоgу, аlsо frоm thе Unіvеrsіtу оf Wіsсоnsіn, іn 1968. Тhrоughоut hіs studіеs hе mіnоrеd іn рhіlоsорhу. Аftеr асtіng аs аn іnstruсtоr аt Саnіsіus Соllеgе (1965–1966) аnd аs а rеsеаrсh аssосіаtе аt Unіvеrsіtу оf Wіsсоnsіn durіng hіs studіеs, Wоеlfеl bеgаn wоrk аs аn аssіstаnt рrоfеssоr аt thе Unіvеrsіtу оf Іllіnоіs аt Urbаnа–Сhаmраіgn іn 1968. Ιn 1972 hе mоvеd tо Μісhіgаn Stаtе Unіvеrsіtу аs аn аssосіаtе рrоfеssоr. Тhеn іn 1978 hе mоvеd tо Unіvеrsіtу аt Аlbаnу, SUΝY аs а vіsіtіng рrоfеssоr, whеrе hе wаs thеn hіrеd аs аn аssосіаtе рrоfеssоr іn 1979. Ιn 1981 hе wаs рrоmоtеd tо рrоfеssоr аnd іn 1982 асtеd аs сhаіr оf thе Dераrtmеnt оf Соmmunісаtіоn. Ιn 1988 hе wаs dіrесtоr оf rеsеаrсh аnd fоundіng fеllоw оf thе Ιnstіtutе fоr thе Studу оf Іnfоrmаtіоn Sсіеnсе. Fіnаllу, hе mоvеd tо Unіvеrsіtу аt Βuffаlо аs рrоfеssоr аnd сhаіr (1989–1995) оf thе Dераrtmеnt оf Соmmunісаtіоn аnd hаs rеmаіnеd аs рrоfеssоr (sіnсе 1995).

Date: October 24, 2001
From: no.address@enron.com
Subject: Enhancing Our Natural Gas Origination Strategy

Our natural gas business is thriving due to our effective approach to account management and resource allocation, which allows us to cater to the diverse needs of our customers. To maintain our optimal organizational structure and facilitate further growth, we are implementing the following changes:

Producer/Wellhead Group
The current natural gas origination and wellhead pricing activities in the Central and Eastern Gas Regions will be consolidated under Fred Lagrasta, who will lead a single business unit focused on serving the needs of the producing industry in the Eastern U.S. Meanwhile, the producer focus in the Western U.S. and Texas will remain unchanged, with Mark Whitt and Brian Redmond continuing to oversee these regions.

Strategic Asset Development
Laura Luce will be transitioning from her role in the Central Region to lead a new initiative focused on identifying and securing long-term strategic partnerships in the Central and Eastern Regions. This effort will concentrate on a select number of markets that offer opportunities for collaborative asset development, management, and optimization. The initiative will maintain close ties with the regional leads.

Central Origination and Mid-Market
Frank Vickers will continue to lead the Eastern Region and assume responsibility for Mid-Market and Origination activities in the Central Region.

There will be no changes to the West and Texas Origination groups, which will remain under the leadership of Barry Tycholiz and Brian Redmond, respectively.

We would like to extend our congratulations to Fred, Laura, and Frank on their new roles.

Best regards,
Louise & John

Rewritten:
Date: Wed, 24 Oct 2001 19:22:28 -0700 (PDT)
From: no.address@enron.com
Subject: Natural Gas Origination
Body: 
Our natural gas business continues to benefit from effective account management and resource allocation focused on identifying and responding to the needs of our varied customers. In order to keep our organization optimally structured and to facilitate additional growth, we are making the following changes:
Producer/Wellhead Group 
The current mid-market, origination and wellhead pricing activity currently within the Central and Eastern Gas Regions will be consolidated with the Derivatives group under Fred Lagrasta. This will create a single business unit focused upon the needs of the producing industry within the Eastern U.S. The producer focus in the Western U.S. and Texas will remain unchanged reporting to Mark Whitt and Brian Redmond respectively.
Strategic Asset Development
Laura Luce will move from her role in the Central Region to lead an effort focused strictly on identifying and entering into long-term strategic arrangements within the Central and Eastern Regions. This initiative will focus on a limited number of selected markets that provide strategic opportunities for partnering in asset development, asset management and optimization. This effort will continue to work very closely with the regional leads.
Central Origination and Mid-Market
Frank Vickers will continue his current role in the Eastern Region and will assume the leadership role for Mid-Market and Origination activity in the Central Region. 
 
There will be no changes to the West and Texas Origination groups headed respectively by Barry Tycholiz and Brian Redmond. 
Please join us in congratulating Fred, Laura and Frank in their new roles.
Louise & John

This film is far more profound and certainly richer than one might assume from the overly sentimental trailers that many have encountered. The underlying narrative, which slowly unveils the early years of P.L. Travers, the creator of Mary Poppins, and illustrates how her troubled family influenced her to write Mary Poppins, forms the genuine essence of this film. I will never view Mary Poppins in the same light again. The performances are outstanding, and the soundtrack is remarkable. This is not the superficial, childish film that many might anticipate. I would advise against it for children aged 11 and under, depending on the individual child. Otherwise, I strongly endorse this film, even if you are not particularly fond of the original Mary Poppins movie.

Rewritten:
This movie is much more than and definitely deeper than one would suspect from the 'syrupy' trailers most people have seen. The understory, gradually revealing the early life of P.L. Travers, the author of Mary Poppins, and depicting how the people in her dysfunctional family led her to write Mary Poppins, is the true core of this movie. I will never see Mary Poppins in quite the same way. All of the acting is superior, and the score is excellent. This is not the shallow, childlike movie that many will expect. I would not recommend it for children 11 and under, depending on the child. Otherwise, I highly recommend this movie, even if you are not a big fan of the original Mary Poppins film.

Date: April 2, 2001
From: stelzer@aol.com
To: klay@enron.com
Subject: Advisory Council Meeting Update

CC: skean@enron.com
BCC: skean@enron.com

I wanted to summarize the current status for our upcoming meeting on April 10-11. 

1. I've spoken with Gavyn and asked him to provide additional insights on the recent developments and their impact on Enron.
2. I've also asked Bill Kristol to share his thoughts on the significance of these developments.
3. Paul Portney will be reviewing the current state of environmental policy.
4. Since we couldn't find a speaker to discuss how Enron can continue to attract top talent, I've asked Pankaj to give a brief presentation on the relevant research from his colleagues.
5. Unfortunately, I was unable to secure a speaker to address the issue of Enron's size and influence, but I'm still working on it.

I assume the team will provide updates on the California and national energy supply situation. I also wanted to check if we've heard back from the author of "When Genius Fails".

Let me review where we stand for the April 10-11 meeting.
1. I have spoken with Gavyn and asked him to add to his usual review
comments on the significance of recent developments for Enron.
2. I have asked Bill Kristol to do the same.
3. I have asked Paul Portney to review "the lay of the land" in the
environmental policy area.
4. Since we couldn't locate a speaker to address the question of how Enron,
now larger and more corporate than in the past, can continue to attract the
best, the brightest (and the oddest?), I have asked Pankaj to give a brief
talk about what the literature generated by his colleagues has to tell us on
this subject.
5. I couldn't get anyone on the "monopoly-too-big-and-powerful" question,
although I am still trying.
I assume you folks will brief us on California and the national energy supply
picture. Have we heard from the author of "When Genius Fails"?

Fеаr оf Lоvе  
Hаvе уоu еvеr cаrеԁ fоr sоmеоnе sо dееplу thаt fеаr tаkеs оvеr еvеrу еmоtіоn?  
Fеаr оf lоvіng.  
Fеаr оf lоsіng thаt sеnsаtіоn оf bеіng lіftеd.  
Fеаr оf оnе dаy hеаrіng thе wоrds…gооdbуе…  
Hоw саn lоvе & fеаr bе entwіnеd sо thаt уоu cаn't еvеn dіstіnguіsh bеtwееn thеm?  
Pеrhаps, lоvіng mеаns tаkіng thе rіsk оf еvеrуthіng fоr thаt оnе pеrsоn whо mаkеs уоu fееl lаrgеr thаn lіfе.  
I fееl thаt wіth уоu, fеаr.  
Fеаr оf fееlіngs І prоmіsеd mуsеlf І wоuld nоt еxpеrіеncе аgаіn.  
Fеаr оf gіvіng mуsеlf tо bе hurt оncе mоrе.  
Fеаr оf sауіng gооdbуе аnd nеvеr fееlіng lоvе аgаіn.  
Whеrе dо І gо frоm hеrе?  
Dо І lеt mу fеаr оf nоt bеіng еnоugh tаkе mе аwау?  
Dо І lеt gо nоw аnd lеt fеаr wіn?  
Dо І hоld оn аnd аllоw fеаr tо drіvе уоu аwау?  
Оr dо І hоld оn аnd shun fеаr, knоwіng thаt trulу lоvе wіll prevаіl?  
Whаtеvеr jоurnеy оur lоvе tаkеs us оn, оnе thіng І knоw fоr cеrtаіn.  
Yоur lоvе hаs hеlpеd mе rеаlіzе whаt іt mеаns tо lоvе sо dееplу thаt fеаr tаkеs оvеr.  
Whеthеr thаt іs bеnеfіcіаl оr nоt rеmаіns tо bе sееn.  
Lоvе knоws nо bоundаrіеs, nо tіmе, аnd nо fеаr.  
Wе dеаl wіth thаt оn оur оwn.  
Wе trу tо rаtіоnаlіzе sоmеthіng, lоvе, thаt dеfіеs rаtіоnаl thоught.  
Аlwауs frоm а dіstаncе, І sаw уоu.  
Until оnе dаy, уоu wеrе thеrе wіth thе wаrmth оf yоur smіlе thаt І cоuldn't rеjеct.  
Nоw уоu аrе thе mаn І drеаm оf.  
А fеаr І nеvеr sаw cоming whеn І lооkеd аt уоu.  
А lоvе thаt glоws lіkе а cаndlе іn а dаrk, quіеt spаcе.  
Іn а sрlіt sеcоnd, уоu lіt

Rewritten:
Fеаr оf Lоvе
Наvе уоu еvеr lоvеd sоmеоnе sо muсh thаt fеаr tаkеs соntrоl оf еvеrу еmоtіоns.
Fеаr оf lоvіng.
Fеаr оf lоsіng thаt fеllіng оf flоаtіng оn аіr.
Fеаr оf оnе dау hеаrіng thе wоrds…gооdbуе…
Ηоw саn lоvе & fеаr bе twіstеd іn оnе sо thаt уоu саn't еvеn tеll thеm араrt.
Μауbе, lоvіng mеаns rіskіng еvеrуthіng fоr thаt оnе реrsоn whо mаkеs уоu fееl lаrgеr thеn lіfе.
І fееl thаt wіth уоu, fеаr.
Fеаr оf fееlіngs І рrоmіsеd mуsеlf Ι wоuld nоt fееl аgаіn.
Fеаr оf gіvіng mуsеlf tо bе hurt аgаіn.
Fеаr оf sауіng gооdbуе аnd nеvеr lоvіng аgаіn.
Whеrе dо І gо frоm hеrе?
Dо Ι lеt mу fеаr оf nоt bеіng еnоugh drіvе mе аwау?
Dо І lеt gо nоw аnd lеt fеаr wіn?
Dо Ι hоld оn аnd аllоw fеаr tо drіvе уоu аwау?
Оr dо Ι hоld оn аnd shut fеаr оut аnd knоw thаt rеаl lоvе wіll wіn?
Whаtеvеr раth оur lоvе lеаds us dоwn оnе thіng Ι knоw іs truе.
Yоur lоvе hаd mаdе mе rеаlіzе whаt іt іs tо lоvе sо muсh thаt fеаr tаkеs соntrоl.
Whеthеr thаt іs gооd оr bаd rеmаіns tо bе sееn.
Lоvе knоws nо tіmе, nо рlасе, аnd nо fеаr.
Wе dо thаt оn оur оwn.
Wе trу tо rеаsоn sоmеthіng, lоvе, thаt hаd nо rеаsоnіng аbоut іt.
Αlwауs frоm а fаr І sаw уоu.
Untіl оnе dау уоu wеrе thеrе wіth wаrmth іn уоu fасе Ι соuld nоt rеfusе.
Νоw уоu аrе thе mаn І drеаm оf.
Α fеаr І nеvеr ехресtеd whеn Ι lооkеd аt уоu.
Α lоvе thаt lіt lіkе а саndlе іn а dаrk stіll rооm.
Ιn оnе flаsh уоu lіghtеd mу hеаrt wіth wаrmth аnd fеаr.
Ι dо nоt knоw іf fеаr оf lоsіng уоu wіll wіn.
Οr іf Ι hаvе thе strеngth tо hоld оn аnd wаіt fоr оur lоvе tо flоurіsh іntо а lіfеtіmе оf sесurіtу аnd hарріnеss.
Τhе оnе thіng Ι dо knоw іs thаt mу fеаr оf lоsіng уоu іs mу hеаrt аdmіttіng thаt thеrе іs а раrt оf уоu І hоld dеаr.
Аnd thаt іs thе lоvе І fееl fоr уоu grоwіng еасh dау.
-Fеаr оf Lоvе-

To make this delicious and flavorful chicken broth, you will need the following ingredients:

- 8 cups of Reduced Fat/Reduced Sodium Chicken Broth
- 2 cups of Water
- 2-1/2 pounds of Boneless, Skinless Chicken Breast (I used Frozen)
- 1 whole Medium Yellow Onion, Quartered
- 1 bunch of Cilantro (washed, Stems Trimmed)
- 6 cloves of Garlic, Peeled
- 2 whole Serano Peppers (stems Removed, Seeds Removed if Desired for Less Heat, See Note)
- 1 can (10 Oz. Size) of Ro-tel (diced Tomatoes with Green Chilies)
- 1 can (15 Oz. Size) of Tomato Sauce
- 1 can (6 Oz. Size) of Tomato Paste
- 4 teaspoons of Cumin
- 2 teaspoons of Garlic Salt
- 1/2 teaspoon of Chili Powder
- 2-1/2 tablespoons of Cornstarch Combined with Below Amount of Water
- 1/2 cups of Water
- 1 can (15 Oz. Size) of Corn, Drained
- Optional Toppings: Shredded Cheese or Sour Cream

Instructions:

1. In your largest soup pot, combine the broth, water, chicken breasts, and bring to a slow boil.
2. Using a large food processor or blender, combine the onion, cilantro, garlic, peppers, and Ro-tel, and blend until smooth.
3. Once the chicken is cooked through and no longer pink inside, remove from the broth and set aside.
4. Pour the spicy blend from the food processor into the broth and set to simmer.
5. Add the tomato sauce, paste, cumin, salt, and chili powder. Continue to simmer, stirring occasionally.
6. Once the tomato paste has dissolved, combine the cornstarch with the cold water in a small bowl or cup and stir until completely dissolved. Stir into the broth and continue to simmer.
7. It's time to shred the chicken. You can do this using 2 forks (and perhaps a little kitchen helper) but I prefer to use the shredding attachment on my food processor.
8. Turn the heat down to just below a simmer or slow boil. Add the shredded chicken.
9. Stir in the corn and cook until heated through.
10. Top with cheese or sour cream and serve with tortilla chips or corn bread. The leftovers are fabulous, as the flavors continue to develop over time. This soup freezes well. Note: Serano peppers can pack some serious heat. 2 small peppers provided the perfect amount of heat for me. My husband loves this soup when I make it using 2 medium or large peppers. Adjust the size of the peppers to fit your preferences.

Marco Anelli (born October 31, 1968, in Roma) is an Italian photographer. He commenced his career in Paris, where he focused on black-and-white printing techniques. His photographic research projects have developed over extended periods and have explored various subjects. His publications feature works on architecture, landscape, portraiture, sports, and classical music. In 2010, he conducted Portraits in the Presence of Marina Abramovic, (Damiani, 2010) capturing the 1,545 participants in The Artist Is Present by Marina Abramovic at the MoMA, New York. In Building Magazzino (Rizzoli, 2017), he documented the transformation of an old computer factory into Magazzino Italian Art, a new art space in Cold Spring, NY, co-founded by Nancy Olnick and Giorgio Spanu. Artist Studios New York (Damiani, 2020) examines the character and creative space of globally renowned artists such as Alex Katz, Cecily Brown, Francesco Clemente, Joan Jonas, John Giorno, Julian Schnabel, Kiki Smith, Lawrence Weiner, Matthew Barney, Robert Longo, Shirin Neshat, Ugo Rondinone, and Urs Fisher. TINO, Nivola in America is his most recent published book (Silvana Editoriale and Magazzino Italian Art, 2021), in which Anelli’s photographic research centers on Costantino Nivola’s sculptures scattered throughout the US.

Date: July 25, 2000
From: Randall Gay
To: Rob Gay
Subject: Rescheduling Critical Path Call

On July 25, 2000, John Barquin forwarded an email to several recipients, including Randall Gay, Rick Lammers, Chris Dutton, Michael Nelson, Steve Tarry, Cliff Rankin, and John Novak. The email was copied to Melissa Raciti. 

The email inquired about rescheduling the critical path call from Wednesday to Friday. Melissa Raciti had requested this change, as Frank would be returning from vacation on the following day. The lenders were also hoping to use the 10am EDT time slot for an internal call. The email asked if anyone objected to this change in schedule.

Rewritten:
Date: Tue, 25 Jul 2000 03:57:00 -0700 (PDT)
From: randall.gay@enron.com
To: rob.gay@enron.com
Subject: Critical Path Call
Body: 
---------------------- Forwarded by Randall L Gay/HOU/ECT on 07/25/2000 10:50 
AM ---------------------------
"Barquin, John" <jbarquin@velaw.com> on 07/25/2000 10:51:07 AM
To: "'rgay@enron.com'" <rgay@enron.com>, "Lammers, Rick (Enron)" 
<richard.a.lammers@enron.com>, "'Chris.M.J.Dutton@SI.SHELL.COM'" 
<Chris.M.J.Dutton@SI.SHELL.COM>, "'mnj@dentonwildesapte.com'" 
<mnj@dentonwildesapte.com>, "Tarry, Steve" <STarry@velaw.com>, "Rankin, 
Cliff" <CRankin@velaw.com>, "Novak, John (Enron)" <john.novak@enron.com>
cc: 
Subject: Critical Path Call
Melissa Raciti is asking whether we can hold the critical path call on
Friday rather than Wednesday. Frank will be back from vacation tomorrow,
and the Lenders are hoping to use the 10am EDT time slot for an internal
call. Does anyone object to this change in schedule?
It would be helpful if MTS could provide users with timely notifications when significant events occur.

Rewritten:
I wish MTS would publish a notification when stuff happens.

	cindy.richardson@enron.com
Subject: JDF Walk

Hi everyone,

I wanted to express my gratitude to each of you for your generous donations to the JDF walk. The event took place on Sunday, and it was wonderful to see such a great turnout. According to the latest information, Enron employees, including those who participated in the company's matching program, collectively contributed a total of $468,000. I truly appreciate your kindness and hope that it will make a significant difference in the search for a cure for diabetes.

Thank you again,
Allison

Date: Fri, 27 Oct 2000 09:19:00 -0700 (PDT)  
From: timothy.vail@enron.com  
To: kenneth.lay@enron.com  
Subject: Meeting with Mick Seidl Regarding MyHomeKey  
Body:  
Cc: gene.lockhart@enron.com  
Bcc: gene.lockhart@enron.com  

Ken -  
Following your recommendation, Gene Lockhart and I had a discussion with Mick Seidl about his new project, MyHomeKey.com. Mick has developed an intriguing business aimed at becoming the top vertical home services portal in the country. Notably, they are aggressively working on an online home maintenance scheduling system.  

MyHomeKey.com has received significant funding from TXU and KeySpan Energy. As you know, these utilities are among our main competitors. With this in mind, we explored some potential ideas. Mick will look into their exclusivity agreements and will update us accordingly.  

I will keep you posted on any developments.  
I hope the Huntington Condo is finally completed and that you are enjoying it. Please send my regards to Linda.  
Tim

Rewritten:
Date: Fri, 27 Oct 2000 09:19:00 -0700 (PDT)
From: timothy.vail@enron.com
To: kenneth.lay@enron.com
Subject: MyHomeKey Meeting With Mick Seidl
Body: 
Cc: gene.lockhart@enron.com
Bcc: gene.lockhart@enron.com
Ken -
On your suggestion, Gene Lockhart and I met with Mick Seidl about his new 
venture, MyHomeKey.com. Mick has put together an interesting business based 
on becoming the nation's leading vertical home services portal. Of 
particular note is their aggressive creation of an on-line home maintenance 
scheduling system. 
MyHomeKey.com has been funded in large part by TXU and KeySpan Energy. As 
you well know these utilities are some of our primary competitors. With this 
in mind we discussed some potential ideas. Mick is to check to see if they 
can work through their exclusivity agreements and get back to us.
I will keep you informed of the progress. 
I hope they finally finished the Huntington Condo and you are enjoying it. 
Please give my best to Linda.
Tim

Stone Sour's self-titled debut album spawned the hit single "Bother," which initially appeared as a solo track by the band's lead vocalist, Corey Taylor. However, the song's credits were later revised to feature Stone Sour as the performing artist. This song marked a significant milestone for the band, catapulting them into the mainstream music scene. The album cover showcases Taylor's hands adorned with distinctive rings, including a Spider-Man ring that pays homage to the band's contribution to the Spider-Man film soundtrack. The other ring bears the number eight, a nod to Taylor's affiliation with the band Slipknot. According to Taylor, the song's inspiration stems from his personal experience of returning to Des Moines from Denver, where he sought to revitalize his music career.

The music video for "Bother" features Taylor facing off against a duplicate of himself in a spacious room. As the two engage in a haunting duet, Taylor's duplicate rapidly ages and eventually meets its demise, disintegrating into dust as the rest of the band members surround the two Taylors. The only remaining relic of the duplicate is the Spider-Man ring, which Taylor's original self places on his own finger, merging it with his own Spider-Man ring. The video was skillfully directed by Gregory Dark.

Rewritten:
"Bother" is the second single from the hard rock band Stone Sour's self-titled debut album. It was originally released as a solo song by frontman Corey Taylor, but the billing was later changed to Stone Sour. The song was one of Stone Sour's first songs to put them into the mainstream. The cover features Taylor's hands and rings, one of them being a Spider-Man ring which is a reference to the song being featured on the soundtrack to the film Spider-Man (although the track is credited to Taylor as the performer, not Stone Sour) and to Taylor being a fan of Spider-Man. The other has the number eight on it, representing Taylor's number in Slipknot. Taylor has stated that the song is about when he moved back to Des Moines from Denver, where he hoped to try to move forward with his music. Music video
The music video shows Taylor standing face-to-face with an exact copy of himself in a large room. As the two sing, Taylor's copy begins to rapidly age, and eventually dies and turns to dust as the other band members surround the two Taylors. All that is left of the copy is his Spider-Man ring, which the other Taylor puts on his own finger, encompassing his own Spider-Man ring. This video was directed by Gregory Dark.

She returned his smile as he embraced her tightly and submerged them both beneath the surface. She pressed her lips gently against his and relished the sensation of the warm water cascading over her delicate skin, savoring the comfort of being in his arms and submerged. Cora laughed at his remark and kissed him in return, letting out a contented sigh as he kept her close.

She kissed his lips softly and let the warm water wash over her soft skin, enjoying the feel of being in his arms and under the water. Cora chuckled at his comment and kissed him back, sighing in pleasure as he held her there.

Italy's Illva Saronno has reached an agreement to acquire a 33% stake in Changyu, the largest wine producer in China. Changyu announced in a statement to the Shenzhen stock exchange that Illva will invest 481.42 million yuan ($58.16 million; £30.7 million), pending government approval of the transaction.

The Italian liqueur manufacturer will purchase the shares from the Yantai State Asset Management Bureau. According to the US Agriculture Department, wine sales in China are on the rise, with a reported 25% increase in 2003, reaching 61.1 billion yuan.

China is promoting the sale of shares in state-owned enterprises to foreign investors. In the past two years, Anheuser-Busch, Heineken, and Scottish & Newcastle have all made investments in the Chinese beer sector, and now Illva Saronno is making a move into the Chinese wine market. The Yantai State Asset Management Bureau, a government entity located in the northeastern city of Yantai, holds a 55% stake in Changyu. This agency will also divest 10% of its holdings in Changyu to another foreign company, although the identity of that company has not been disclosed.

The Yantai city government will keep the remaining 12%.

The US Agriculture Department noted that wine consumption in China remains low, at only 0.22 liters per capita.

In comparison, France consumes 59 liters per capita, the US 12 liters, and Japan 3 liters.

Rewritten:
Italy's Illva Saronno has agreed to buy 33% of Changyu, the largest wine maker in China. Changyu said in a statement to the Shenzhen stock exchange that Illva will pay 481.42m yuan ($58.16m; £30.7m), once the government approves the deal. 

The Italian liqueur maker will acquire the shares from the Yantai State Asset Management Bureau. Chinese wine sales are growing, the US Agriculture Department said, with wine sales in 2003 up 25% at 61.1bn yuan. 

China is encouraging state-owned companies to sell shares to foreign investors. Anheuser-Busch, Heineken and Scottish & Newcastle have all invested in the Chinese beer industry in the last two years and now Illva Saronno is betting on the Chinese wine market. Yantai State Asset Management Bureau - a government agency in the north-eastern city of Yantai - owns 55% of Changyu. The state agency will also sell 10% of its stake in Changyu to another overseas company, although it didn't say who. 

The remaining 12% will be retained by the Yantai city government. 

The consumption of wine in China is still low, at just 0.22 litres per capita, said the US Agriculture Department. 

This compares with 59 litres in France, 12 litres in the US and three litres in Japan.

Date: Wed, 25 Apr 2001 15:55:00 -0700 (PDT)  
From: enron.announcements@enron.com  
To: all.houston@enron.com  
Subject: Enron AstroWorld Tickets  
Body:  
Enron is excited to announce UNLIMITED discounted AstroWorld tickets for our employees.  
In response to the enthusiastic feedback from employees, we have arranged for unlimited discounted AstroWorld tickets for you and your family, replacing the usual "Enron Day At AstroWorld." We hope this change will enable Enron families to organize their enjoyable summer visits to AstroWorld at their own pace. Enron AstroWorld tickets are priced at $20.56 (Retail $50), which includes admission for one person, along with a $7 meal voucher valid at one of five restaurants within AstroWorld.  
Six Flags AstroWorld is a premier family entertainment venue featuring thrilling rides and attractions, including 10 exhilarating roller coasters, over 40 spectacular shows, interactive street performers, and star-studded concerts. Enron families will have the opportunity to buy unlimited tickets for use at any time during the 2001 season.  
Tickets will be available for purchase at Enron's Federal Credit Union, EB0399. Please visit the credit union in person to buy your tickets. Note that AstroWorld tickets will not be sent by mail. Enron employees who are not current members of Enron FCU may only pay with cash or money order. All Enron employees are encouraged to take advantage of this fantastic summer offer and can purchase tickets until August 30th.

Cluster states can be utilized to carry out measurement-based quantum computation. The cluster state serves as a valuable resource, as once it is generated, only local operations and measurements are required to execute universal quantum computation. In this paper, we investigate methods for rapidly and deterministically constructing a cluster state. Specifically, we focus on generating cluster states on a qubus quantum computer, a computational architecture that employs a continuous variable ancilla to facilitate interactions between qubits. We examine various techniques for building the cluster, with the number of operations needed varying based on whether we permit the ability to eliminate previously established controlled-phase links between qubits. In scenarios where we cannot destroy these links, we demonstrate how to create an n x m cluster using just 3n - 2n - 3m/2 + 3 operations. This results in more than a factor of 2 savings compared to a naive method. Additional savings can be achieved if we incorporate the ability to destroy links, in which case we only need (8n - 4n - 4m - 8)/3 operations. Unfortunately, the latter scheme is more complex, making the selection of the correct order to interact the qubits considerably more challenging. A halfway scheme, which maintains a modular generation while saving additional operations over never destroying links, requires only 3n - 2n - 2m + 4 operations. The first scheme and the last scheme are the most practical for constructing a cluster state because they break down the generation into the repetition of simple sections.

Manager John Robertson is optimistic that a successful run in the knockout rounds of the UEFA Cup will encourage some of his players whose contracts are expiring to remain with the team. “That could be beneficial. If we advance and secure another European match, perhaps some players will choose to stay with us at least until the season concludes,” he stated. “And if we progress to the next round, it will demonstrate the club's success. They might question whether they could find a better opportunity elsewhere if they decide to leave.” A victory for Rangers against Ferencvaros on Tuesday night will secure their place in the knockout stages, provided Basle does not defeat Feyenoord. “It’s ultimately up to the individual, but it serves as a strong motivation for them to have played in Europe over the past few years,” Robertson continued. “However, we want players who are eager to be part of the club and are dedicated to our mission. A successful run in Europe certainly helps, I suppose.” The match is being held at Murrayfield due to UEFA regulations, and Robertson mentioned there are both advantages and disadvantages to this arrangement. “The pitch isn’t in the best shape. There was a Heineken Cup match there on Saturday, and the surface is somewhat worn,” he noted. “It’s not perfect, but it’s the same for both teams. We’ll just have to deal with it.” “If Tynecastle could have hosted 30,000, it would have been fantastic, but that’s one of the benefits of playing at Murrayfield. It’s advantageous for our fans. The most important thing is to secure the win.” “We need their backing, and we need them to fully support the players. Hopefully, they’ll respond positively, and I’m confident they will, as it’s a significant night for the club in Europe.”

Rewritten:
Manager John Robertson is hopeful that a run in the knock-out stages of the UEFA Cup will keep some of his out-of-contract players at the club. “That might help. If we win through and have another European tie, then maybe some players will stay with us at least until the end of the season,” he said. “And if we win through to the next round, it will show how well the club is doing. They might wonder if they would get a better club somewhere else if they leave.” A win for Rangers over Ferencvaros on Tuesday night will put them into the knock-out stages if Basle fail to beat Feyenoord. “It’s up to the individual, but it’s a good incentive for them to play in Europe the last few years,” Robertson added. “But we want players who want to be at the club, and who are committed to the cause. A good run in Europe helps, I suppose.” The game is being played at Murrayfield because of UEFA regulations, and Robertson said there were good and bad points about the move. “The pitch is not in the best of conditions. There was a Heineken Cup game there on Saturday, and the pitch is a bit bare,” he said. “It’s not ideal, but it’s the same for both sides. We’ll just have to get on with it.” “If Tynecastle could have accommodated 30,000, it would have been great, but that’s one of the advantages of playing at Murrayfield. It’s good for our supporters. The main thing is to win the game.” “We need their support, and we need them to get right behind the players. Hopefully they’ll respond to that, and I’m sure they will, because it’s a great night for the club in Europe.”

Preheat the oven to 450 °F. Remove the skin from the butternut squash and cut it into small pieces, approximately a quarter of an inch in size. Peel and dice a sweet onion. Combine the squash and onion with half of the butter, honey, garlic, rosemary, salt, and pepper, mix well, and set aside. Distribute the mixture onto two baking sheets lined with parchment paper. Bake for 20-25 minutes, flipping once, until tender (rotate the sheets halfway through the cooking time). Allow to cool slightly, then incorporate cottage cheese, milk, broth, and Gorgonzola cheese. Preheat the oven to 350 °F. Grease a 3-liter baking dish. Layer a quarter of the cottage cheese mixture in the dish. Add a layer of noodles, trimming them with a knife to fit. Repeat this layering process twice. Spread the remaining cottage cheese mixture over the noodles. Cover with aluminum foil and bake for 45 minutes. Remove the foil and continue baking for an additional 15 minutes. In the meantime, combine the breadcrumbs with the chopped walnuts, parsley, and the remaining butter, then sprinkle this mixture over the noodles and return to the oven for 15 minutes. Broil for 3 minutes, or until golden brown. Allow to rest for 20 minutes before slicing.

Rewritten:
Preheat the oven to 450 ° F. Peel the butternut squash and chop it into small pieces about a quarter of an inch. Peel and chop a sweet onion. Add the squash and onion with half the butter, honey, garlic, rosemary, salt and pepper, stir and put aside. Spread on two baking sheets, covered with parchment paper. Bake for 20-25 minutes, turning once, until soft (turn the sheets once in the middle of cooking). Let cool slightly and add cottage cheese, milk, broth and Gorgonzola cheese. Preheat the oven to 350 ° F. Butter a 3-liter dish. Spread out a quarter of the cottage cheese mixture in the dish. Cover with a layer of noodles and cut them with a knife to make them fit. Repeat the layering twice. Spread out the remaining cottage cheese mixture over the noodles. Cover with aluminum foil and bake for 45 minutes. Take off the aluminum foil and bake for another 15 minutes. Meanwhile, mix the breadcrumbs with the chopped walnuts, parsley and the remaining butter, sprinkle over the noodles and put in the oven for 15 minutes. Broil for 3 minutes, until golden brown. Leave for 20 minutes before cutting.

The trend of prioritizing individual storylines and moments in creative writing has become increasingly prevalent. This shift began after Bryan's success at WrestleMania 30, where he was subsequently deemed to have had his moment and it was time for Roman to take the spotlight. Since then, it seems like every major event revolves around a specific wrestler's turn or moment. While it's heartwarming to see multiple individuals achieve memorable moments, this approach leads to a never-ending cycle of wrestlers entering and exiting the main event scene, only to make way for the next person. A prime example of this would be if, after Austin's win at WrestleMania 14, it was said that he had had his moment and now it was Jeff Jarrett's time to shine. Unfortunately, many of these moments feel more like an opportunity for a random wrestler to gain relevance rather than a genuine narrative-driven plot. For instance, did Nia Jax truly need a moment after beating Bliss, or was it simply a case of giving her something to do? This overemphasis on individual moments detracts from the overall storytelling experience.

Rewritten:
It's the death of creative and narrative driven writing. It's been a common thing ever since Bryan won at wm30, and then the next year it wasn't "fair" for him to be in the main event again because he had his moment and now it's Roman's turn. Since then it feels like everything is about someone getting their moment, or their turn. It's nice, of course, that a lot of people get to do something memorable but it leads to this constantly cycling people in and out of main events and then stepping aside for someone else. Imagine after Austin won at WM14 it was said that he had his moment and now it was time for Jeff Jarrett to have his? And so many of them aren't even moments so much as "random wrestler finally gets something useful to do" or something. Like did Nia Jax need a moment the year she beat Bliss, for example? It's just one of those branding things that really, really takes me out of the whole thing.

Ethiopia produced 14.27 million tonnes of crops in 2004, which is 24% higher than in 2003 and 21% more than the average of the previous five years, according to a report. In 2003, crop production amounted to 11.49 million tonnes, as stated in a joint report from the Food and Agriculture Organization and the World Food Programme. Favorable rainfall, increased fertilizer usage, and improved seeds contributed to the rise in production. However, 2.2 million Ethiopians will still require emergency assistance. The report estimated emergency food needs for 2005 to be 387,500 tonnes. Additionally, 89,000 tonnes of fortified blended food and vegetable oil will be necessary for "targeted supplementary food distributions for a survival program for children under five and pregnant and lactating women." In eastern and southern Ethiopia, a prolonged drought has devastated crops and depleted wells. Last year, a total of 965,000 tonnes of food assistance was required to support seven million Ethiopians. The Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) recommends that food assistance be procured locally. "Local purchase of cereals for food assistance programs is advised as much as possible, to support domestic markets and farmers," said Henri Josserand, chief of FAO's Global Information and Early Warning System. Agriculture is the primary economic activity in Ethiopia, accounting for 45% of gross domestic product. Approximately 80% of Ethiopians rely directly or indirectly on agriculture.

Rewritten:
Εthіоріа рrоduсеd 14.27 mіllіоn tоnnеs оf сrорs іn 2004, 24% hіghеr thаn іn 2003 аnd 21% mоrе thаn thе аvеrаgе оf thе раst fіvе уеаrs, а rероrt sауs.
Іn 2003, сrор рrоduсtіоn tоtаllеd 11.49 mіllіоn tоnnеs, thе jоіnt rероrt frоm thе Fооd аnd Аgrісulturе Оrgаnіsаtіоn аnd thе Wоrld Fооd Ρrоgrаmmе sаіd. Gооd rаіns, іnсrеаsеd usе оf fеrtіlіzеrs аnd іmрrоvеd sееds соntrіbutеd tо thе rіsе іn рrоduсtіоn. Νеvеrthеlеss, 2.2 mіllіоn Εthіоріаns wіll stіll nееd еmеrgеnсу аssіstаnсе.
Τhе rероrt саlсulаtеd еmеrgеnсу fооd rеquіrеmеnts fоr 2005 tо bе 387,500 tоnnеs. Οn tор оf thаt, 89,000 tоnnеs оf fоrtіfіеd blеndеd fооd аnd vеgеtаblе оіl fоr "tаrgеtеd suррlеmеntаrу fооd dіstrіbutіоns fоr а survіvаl рrоgrаmmе fоr сhіldrеn undеr fіvе аnd рrеgnаnt аnd lасtаtіng wоmеn" wіll bе nееdеd.
Ιn еаstеrn аnd sоuthеrn Εthіоріа, а рrоlоngеd drоught hаs kіllеd сrорs аnd drаіnеd wеlls. Lаst уеаr, а tоtаl оf 965,000 tоnnеs оf fооd аssіstаnсе wаs nееdеd tо hеlр sеvеn mіllіоn Εthіоріаns. Тhе Fооd аnd Αgrісulturе Οrgаnіsаtіоn (FАΟ) rесоmmеnd thаt thе fооd аssіstаnсе іs bоught lосаllу. "Lосаl рurсhаsе оf сеrеаls fоr fооd аssіstаnсе рrоgrаmmеs іs rесоmmеndеd аs fаr аs роssіblе, sо аs tо аssіst dоmеstіс mаrkеts аnd fаrmеrs," sаіd Неnrі Jоssеrаnd, сhіеf оf FАΟ's Glоbаl Іnfоrmаtіоn аnd Еаrlу Wаrnіng Sуstеm. Аgrісulturе іs thе mаіn есоnоmіс асtіvіtу іn Еthіоріа, rерrеsеntіng 45% оf grоss dоmеstіс рrоduсt. Αbоut 80% оf Εthіоріаns dереnd dіrесtlу оr іndіrесtlу оn аgrісulturе.

Date: October 16, 2001
From: no.address@enron.com
Subject: Precautions Against Suspicious Mail and Packages

As concerns about the potential use of biological agents like Anthrax in terrorist attacks persist globally, Enron has taken proactive measures to ensure employee safety. The mail center and Business Controls/Corporate Security have put in place protocols to screen all mail entering Enron buildings, following established procedures for identifying suspicious packages. Enron is also in close communication with the U.S. Postal Service and the Centers for Disease Control to stay informed about the latest guidelines for handling potential Anthrax exposure.

If you receive an envelope or package that makes you uneasy about opening it, please contact Corporate Security at extension 3-6200, and they will re-screen it. To provide Enron employees with a better understanding of Anthrax and its risks, a bulletin has been posted on the Corporate Security intranet site at http://home.enron.com:84/security/002_bull_001.html, which includes links to valuable resources from the CDC and USPS.

Rewritten:
Date: Tue, 16 Oct 2001 15:05:17 -0700 (PDT)
From: no.address@enron.com
Subject: Questionable Mail/Suspicious Packages
Body: 
The potential use of biological agents such as Anthrax in a terrorist attack continues to raise concerns worldwide. Here at Enron, the mail center and Business Controls/Corporate Security have already implemented safeguards so that all mail entering the Enron buildings will be screened in accordance with procedures for identifying suspicious packages. We are also in touch with the U.S. Postal Service and the Centers for Disease Control to ensure we have the most complete and up-to-date guidance for handling any possible Anthrax exposures.
However, should you receive an envelope or package that you do not feel comfortable opening, please contact Corporate Security at extension 3-6200 and we will screen it again.
To provide Enron employees with a better understanding of Anthrax and the potential danger it poses, we have posted a bulletin on the Corporate Security intranet site http://home.enron.com:84/security/002_bull_001.html that includes links to the CDC and USPS resources.

In this June night, so serene and pure,
You shine like a beacon, a holy allure,
Are you gazing at the moon's gentle rise?
I'm gazing at it now, and I sense your eyes.
We've sat together on countless nights like this,
Watching the moonlit sky, with clouds drifting and misting.
Our hands were intertwined, a bond so strong and true,
When will we be linked again, my heart beats for you?
The starlight and moonbeams may still be bright,
But without your slender fingers, they hold no delight.
Summer nights may be clear and warm and long,
But without your presence, they're just an empty song.
The roses on my threshold, they stir and sway,
As if beckoning you to come and stay,
The honeysuckle wreathes its golden hue,
Around my home, a sweet and tender clue.
Why don't you come to me, my love, my heart's desire?
If you did, the roses would bloom, and the flowers would conspire,
To fill the air with scents of spice and sweet perfume,
As the stars and trees would whisper a gentle tune.
I'd take you to where the leaves shine bright,
In the moon's soft light, and we'd lean in, listening tight,
For the song of that sweet bird, that sings in April's night,
And when our eyelids grow heavy, and our heads droop low,
I'd kiss your lips, a gentle, silent vow,
I'd give you all I own, and you'd borrow all you need,
And I'd keep from you the fears, the doubts, and the sorrow's creed.
All that's tender in my heart, I'd give to you,
To make you mine, and to see you through.
Oh, moonlight, please wander to other skies,
Don't mock my eyes, and don't waste love's light on this dark place,
For my lady comes not, and my heart is filled with pain,
A love so strong, yet unrequited, a heart in vain.

Rewritten:
Lady! in this night of June
Fair like thee and holy,
Art thou gazing at the moon
That is rising slowly?
I am gazing on her now:
Something tells me, so art thou.
Night hath been when thou and I
Side by side were sitting,
Watching o'er the moonlit sky
Fleecy cloudlets flitting.
Close our hands were linkèd then;
When will they be linked again?
What to me the starlight still,
Or the moonbeams' splendour,
If I do not feel the thrill
Of thy fingers slender?
Summer nights in vain are clear,
If thy footstep be not near.
Roses slumbering in their sheaths
O'er my threshold clamber,
And the honeysuckle wreathes
Its translucent amber
Round the gables of my home:
How is it thou dost not come?
If thou camest, rose on rose
From its sleep would waken;
From each flower and leaf that blows
Spices would be shaken;
Floating down from star and tree,
Dreamy perfumes welcome thee.
I would lead thee where the leaves
In the moon-rays glisten;
And, where shadows fall in sheaves,
We would lean and listen
For the song of that sweet bird
That in April nights is heard.
And when weary lids would close,
And thy head was drooping,
Then, like dew that steeps the rose,
O'er thy languor stooping,
I would, till I woke a sigh,
Kiss thy sweet lips silently.
I would give thee all I own,
All thou hast would borrow;
I from thee would keep alone
Fear and doubt and sorrow.
All of tender that is mine,
Should most tenderly be thine.
Moonlight! into other skies,
I beseech thee wander.
Cruel, thus to mock mine eyes,
Idle, thus to squander
Love's own light on this dark spot;-
For my lady cometh not!

Sir Anthony Meyer, a long-serving Tory backbencher who famously challenged Margaret Thatcher for the party leadership in 1989, has passed away. He was 84 years old and had been battling cancer for several months before his death at his London home. Meyer's leadership challenge, though unsuccessful, inadvertently paved the way for Michael Heseltine's bid, which ultimately led to John Major's rise to power at 10 Downing Street. As a result of his challenge, Meyer's constituency party, Clwyd North West, which he had represented in Parliament for over two decades, decided not to reselect him.

Born on October 27, 1920, Sir Anthony John Charles Meyer was educated at Eton and New College, Oxford. During World War II, he served in the Scots Guards from 1941 to 1945 and was injured while fighting in tanks in Normandy. Meyer later worked under Edward Heath at the Foreign Office, focusing on European affairs. He secured a seat in Parliament for the Tories in 1964, winning the Eton and Slough constituency by a narrow margin of 11 votes. However, Labour regained the seat two years later, and Meyer had to wait until 1970 to re-enter Parliament. Despite his long parliamentary career, Meyer's prospects of securing a frontbench position remained slim due to his tendency to defy the party line.

Rewritten:
Sir Anthony Meyer, the Tory backbencher who challenged Margaret Thatcher for the party leadership in 1989, has died.
He was 84, had been suffering from cancer for many months, and died at his London home. That failed "stalking horse" leadership challenge made it easier for Michael Heseltine to mount his own bid. That in turn paved the way for John Major to move into 10 Downing Street, after the second ballot. Meyer's constituency party, Clwyd North West, which he had represented as an MP for more than 20 years, deselected him as a result of that challenge. Sir Anthony John Charles Meyer was born on 27 October, 1920. Educated at Eton, and at New College, Oxford, he served in the Scots Guards from 1941 to 1945 and was wounded in tanks in Normandy. He worked under Edward Heath on Europe at the Foreign Office and subsequently won the Eton and Slough seat for the Tories in 1964 - by 11 votes. Labour regained the seat two years later, and Meyer had to wait until 1970 before he could re-enter Parliament. His prospects of a front bench slot remained remote because he tended to defy the party line.

This film is for anyone who has ever felt like the underdog, overlooked by those who were larger or more popular. "Rudy" may have a somewhat unexciting title for a sports movie, but I distinctly remember the first time I watched a preview of it; I was completely moved and captivated by the scenes. I even burst out laughing at the end when the announcer declared, "RUDY." That moment had the entire theater laughing as well, so you can imagine my surprise when I saw it a few months later and rated it a perfect 10 out of 10. I'm not even a sports enthusiast, yet this movie resonated with me. It illustrates the strength of faith in overcoming life's frustrations, the performances are outstanding, and it's unfortunate that Sean Astin had to wait eight years for another significant role in "The Lord of the Rings." His performance in this film is exceptional; consider it one of the most inspiring movies you'll ever watch.

The book starts by delving into the history of war crimes, dating back to the medieval period's "knightly chivalry." These rules were established to minimize unnecessary cruelty during warfare and protect civilian populations from massacres and the spread of disease. As a result, the immunity granted to soldiers from being held criminally responsible for murder committed during warfare had to be carefully balanced to discourage wartime atrocities.

Until 1863, when U.S. President Abraham Lincoln approved the "Instructions for the Government of Armies of the United States in the Field," the laws of war remained largely unwritten. This 159-article document facilitated the formation of military tribunals and later led to a demand for the formalization of international laws of warfare. The Hague and Geneva conventions, a series of treaties, codified these international laws of warfare, binding all nations, whether signatory or not, to international laws of war.

The Nuremberg Trials, in which Taylor played a leading role, had significant consequences for international law as applied to warfare. It granted international jurisdiction to the prosecution of war crimes and obligated individuals engaged in warfare to adhere to international laws of conduct over and above those of their respective armies. The United States, as a result of its participation in the Nuremberg trials, emerged as legally, morally, and politically bound to the principles that resulted from the trials.

Taylor's primary concern in this book is how the principles of the Nuremberg trials would apply to the United States' conduct of the Vietnam War. When "Nuremberg and Vietnam: An American Tragedy" was published, those in favor and opposition to the United States' involvement in Vietnam frequently cited the Nuremberg trials in support of their positions. Those in favor of U.S. involvement argued that North Vietnam's attack on South Vietnam justified the use of force, and this allowed the United States to join with South Vietnam. Those opposed to U.S. involvement asserted that both South Vietnam and the United States violated the Geneva Declaration of 1954 by attacking North Vietnam and preventing national elections.

Taylor points out that the definition of "aggressive warfare" is ambiguous, hindering any attempt to determine which belligerent power involved in the Vietnam War could be deemed the "aggressor." This ambiguity raises related questions, such as the legality of refusing to serve in Vietnam. Many conscientious objectors refused to serve in Vietnam on the grounds that their complicity in an illegal war made them guilty of crimes against humanity. Taylor cites possible war crimes in regard to the Son My incident, also known as the My Lai Massacre of 1968.

In this portion of the book, Taylor makes a compelling comparison of Nuremberg to the Vietnam War by juxtaposing two eyewitness accounts: one from the Holocaust and the other from the My Lai Massacre. Taylor explains the differences between the two accounts and shows the difficulty in determining whether or not crimes were committed by the United States. He also raises domestic problems with regard to the United States' involvement in the Vietnam War, arguing that both the President and the Congress bear responsibility for officially declaring military action in Vietnam. According to Taylor, the Vietnam War could only be ended by an act of national will, rather than by judicial means.

Rewritten:
The book begins with a lengthy history of war crimes beginning with the “knightly chivalry” of the medieval period. 

These rules were put into place in order to minimize unnecessary cruelties during the course of warfare. 

The rules protected civilian populations from massacre and the needless spread of disease. Thus, the blanket of immunity that protects soldiers from being held criminally responsible for murder committed during the course of warfare had to be carefully balanced so as to discourage wartime atrocities. 

The laws of war remained largely unwritten until U.S. President Abraham Lincoln approved the “Instructions for the Government of Armies of the United States in the Field”, in 1863. 

Concerning spies, prisoners of war, and the punishment of war crimes, this document comprising 159 articles facilitated the formation of military tribunals and later led to a demand for the formalization of international laws of warfare. Thus, international laws of warfare were codified by means of a series of treaties known as the Hague and Geneva conventions. 

The most important consequence of these treaties is that all nations, whether signatory or otherwise, were bound by international laws of war. The Nuremberg Trials, for which Taylor served as a leading figure, gave rise to several developments in regard to international law as applied to warfare. 

First, it gave international jurisdiction to the prosecution of war crimes; and second, it obligated individuals engaged in warfare to adhere to international laws of conduct over and above those of their respective armies. 

Of greatest importance with respect to this book however is that the United States as a result of its participation emerged as legally, morally, and politically bound to the principles that resulted from the Nuremberg trials. Thus, Taylor is concerned by how the principles of the Nuremberg trials would apply to the United States’ conduct of the Vietnam War. 

When Nuremberg and Vietnam: An American Tragedy was published, those in favor and opposition to the United States involvement in Vietnam frequently cited the Nuremberg trials in support of their positions. Those in favor of United States involvement argued that North Vietnam attacked South Vietnam in violation of Article 2 of the United Nations Charter; South Vietnam was justified in using force to repel such an attack; and this in turn allowed the United States to join with South Vietnam as provided by Article 51. Those opposed to the United States involvement in the Vietnam War asserted that both South Vietnam and the United States violated the Geneva Declaration of 1954 by attacking North Vietnam, rearming illegally, preventing the 1956 national elections which were provided for in the Declaration, and subsequently bombing North Vietnam. 

Such actions would constitute “aggressive warfare” by the standards of Nuremberg. 

Taylor points out that the definition of “aggressive warfare” is ambiguous, thus severely hindering any attempt to determine which of the belligerent powers involved in the Vietnam War could be deemed the “aggressor.” What’s more, such ambiguities lead to several related questions, such as the legality of refusing to serve in Vietnam. At the time, many conscientious objectors refused to serve in Vietnam on the grounds that their complicity in an illegal war made them, by implication, guilty of crimes against humanity. Taylor cites possible war crimes in regard to the Son My incident, which is more commonly known as the My Lai Massacre of 1968 (). It is in this portion of the book that Taylor makes the most convincing comparison of Nuremberg to the Vietnam War. In this section, Taylor quotes two eyewitness accounts, each from a different war. One account, written by a German construction engineer, describes the killing of Jews during the Holocaust by German SS officers in 1942. 

This account is juxtaposed on the adjacent page by an eyewitness account of the My Lai Massacre. 

The accounts are eerily similar, yet Taylor explains all of the differences, and in characteristically unbiased fashion shows the difficulty in determining whether or not crimes were committed by the United States. Taylor also raises domestic problems with regard to the United States’ involvement in the Vietnam War. According to Taylor, it remains to be seen whether the United States Congress or the Executive branch of government held responsibility for officially declaring military action in Vietnam. 

It is the opinion of Taylor that both the President and the Congress bear responsibility, and that the Vietnam War could only be ended by an act of national will, rather than by judicial means.

Virgin Blue's stock plummeted by a third after the airline issued a warning about a significant decline in its annual profits. According to the company, its profit after tax for the year ending March 31 is expected to be between 10 and 15 percent lower than the previous year. Virgin Blue's CEO cited the continued poor demand experienced in November and December of last year, which has now carried over into January. As a major player in the Australian market, Virgin Blue has been facing stiff competition from Jetstar, a low-cost carrier launched by Qantas in May last year. In response, Virgin Blue has reduced its forecast for annual passenger numbers by approximately a quarter. This is not the first time the company has faced challenges; in August, Virgin Blue reported a 22% drop in its first-quarter profits due to increased competition. In November, the company warned that its first-half profits would decline due to lower demand and higher fuel costs. Despite its significant market share of a third of the domestic Australian market, Virgin Blue's struggles have been exacerbated by the entry of Jetstar. The Virgin Blue share price experienced a slight recovery, closing at 12 percent down on Wednesday. Meanwhile, shares in Patrick Holdings, Virgin Blue's major shareholder, which owns 46% of the company, fell by 31 percent.

Rewritten:
Virgin Blue's shares fell by a third, after it warned of a substantial fall in annual profits. Virgin Blue's profit after tax for the year ending March 31 was to be between 10 and 15 percent lower than in the previous year. “The poorer than expected demand we experienced in November and again in December last year has continued into January.” Virgin Blue, a quarter-owner of Virgin Records, has been struggling to counter the competition from Jetstar, and slashed its forecasts for annual passenger numbers by about a quarter. In August of last year, Virgin Blue reported a 22% drop in its first-quarter profits, blamed on the competition. In November, the company warned that first-half profits would fall on the back of lower demand and higher fuel costs. Virgin Blue, which took off four years ago, has a third of the domestic Australian market. But Qantas, the national carrier, fought back by launching Jetstar, a low-cost carrier, in May last year. The Virgin Blue share price rallied to close at 12 percent down on Wednesday. Shares in the company's major shareholder, Patrick Holdings, which owns 46% of Virgin Blue, fell by 31 percent.

The field of view (FOV) in convolutional neural networks is closely linked to the precision of inference. Dilated convolutions are recognized as an effective approach to address issues that necessitate large FOVs. However, when it comes to general-purpose hardware or specialized hardware, it typically requires additional time to process dilated convolutions compared to standard convolutions. In this paper, we introduce a network module, Cascaded and Separable Structure of Dilated (CASSOD) Convolution, along with a dedicated hardware system designed to efficiently manage CASSOD networks. A CASSOD-Net features multiple cascaded $2 \times 2$ dilated filters, which can replace the conventional $3 \times 3$ dilated filters without compromising inference accuracy. Two example applications, face detection and image segmentation, are evaluated using dilated convolutions and the proposed CASSOD modules. The new network for face detection achieves superior accuracy compared to previous work, utilizing only 47% of the filter weights in the dilated convolution layers of the context module. Furthermore, the proposed hardware system can significantly speed up the computations of dilated convolutions, operating 2.78 times faster than traditional hardware systems when the filter size is $3 \times 3$.

LONDON, March 22, 2021 – Stephen, Lyndsay, the son of Peter Murray, a professional golfer, achieved victory at the South Australian Open at the age of twenty-four. There were great expectations for him, but he did not consistently meet them. Throughout the remainder of the eighties, he finished in second place at least seven times, but victories were rare. Stephen Murray transitioned from playing golf to coaching in the early nineties. However, he soon returned to competitive play, and in his later years, he secured wins at the South Australian PGA in 1996 and the Australian PGA Seniors in 2010. He hailed from Donnybrook in Western Australia. He turned professional at the start of 1978, and by the end of that year, he had joined the PGA Tour of Australia. In October of that year, he first gained public attention by finishing second in the West Lakes Classic. He recorded a bogey-free 67 in the opening round, tying with Bob Shearer. Although his performance dipped on the second day, he still managed to sink a five-metre putt on the final hole to maintain his lead, ultimately finishing tied for 13th.

There were high hopes for him, but he did not always fulfil them. In the course of the rest of the eighties he was second at least seven times, but seldom won. Stephen Murray gave up golf in the early nineties to coach. He was soon back on the circuit and, during his last years, he won the South Australian PGA in 1996 and the Australian PGA Seniors in 2010. He was from Donnybrook in Western Australia. He became a professional at the beginning of the year 1978, and, towards the end of that year, he joined the PGA Tour of Australia. In October that year he was first in the public eye, when he came second in the West Lakes Classic. He made a bogey-free 67 in the first round to tie Bob Shearer. On the second day he did not play so well, but still made a five-metre putt at the last hole to keep the lead. He finished tied for 13th.
