The primary focus of the book is the Big East Tournament championship game of 2001. However, it weaves together play-by-play coverage of the game with background information about the entire season, along with commentary on the players, coaches, and other elements of both programs. The game highlighted in the book was neither the first nor the last encounter between the two teams during the season. In January, UConn faced Notre Dame at Notre Dame. The UConn team was undefeated and held the top ranking in the country at the beginning of the game. Notre Dame won the match 92–76, remained unbeaten, and advanced from third to the number one ranking in the subsequent poll. Both teams would also clash in the semifinals of the NCAA Tournament, where Notre Dame triumphed and subsequently went on to win the national championship. All the meetings between the two teams that year were significant for each side, but the game in March had multiple storylines—a championship title on the line, a tightly contested match where neither team led by more than eight points at any moment, a devastating injury to one of the game’s top players, and ultimately, a game decided by a single basket scored in the final moments by one of the best players in the sport, Sue Bird.

-----Original Message-----
From: Gustafson, Mollie On Behalf Of Calger, Christopher F.
Sent: Thursday, December 06, 2001 6:40 PM
To: DL-Portland World Trade Center
Subject: Cell Phones

AT&T may start suspending some Enron Corporate cell phone accounts from this Friday, 12/7. All remaining cell phone accounts in Portland will be closed by December 11th. However, individual users can keep their phones and phone numbers if they take over the account's financial responsibility. They can either convert their phone to a personal account and keep the same number or request a new one. Susan Nothnagel, an AT&T representative, will be available at the office on Friday, 12/7, from 1:00 p.m. to 4:00 p.m. to answer any questions and assist with switching the account. If this time doesn't work, Susan will visit again next week as needed. AT&T will waive the activation fee for changing the account.

It's worth noting that company-approved cell phones are eligible for reimbursement based on business needs. Please consult your manager for more information on cell phone reimbursement.

Best regards,
Chris

To make this marshmallow recipe, you will need the following ingredients:

- 1 1/4 cups of water, divided
- 4 (1/4-oz.) envelopes of unflavored gelatin
- 2 cups of granulated sugar
- 1 cup of light corn syrup
- 1/4 teaspoon of table salt
- 1 tablespoon of vanilla extract
- 1/2 cup (about 2 1/8 oz.) of powdered sugar
- 1/4 cup of cornstarch

First, place 1/2 cup of the water in a microwave-safe bowl and stir in the gelatin. Set it aside for now. In a large saucepan over medium-high heat, combine the sugar, corn syrup, salt, and the remaining 3/4 cup of water. Bring the mixture to a boil, stirring occasionally, until the sugar dissolves, about 5 minutes. Continue cooking without stirring until the candy thermometer inserted into the mixture registers 250°F.

Next, pour the sugar mixture into the bowl of a heavy-duty stand mixer fitted with a whisk attachment. Let the mixture stand until it reaches 210°F, about 5 minutes. Meanwhile, microwave the gelatin mixture on high until the gelatin melts, about 20 seconds, stirring after 10 seconds. On low speed, gradually pour the gelatin mixture into the sugar mixture in a thin stream, adding the vanilla extract. Increase the speed to high and beat until the mixture is light and fluffy, about 9 to 10 minutes.

Using a lightly greased spatula, spread the mixture evenly in a lightly greased 13- x 9-inch glass or ceramic baking dish. Let the mixture stand until it's dry and firm, about 2 hours. Sift together the powdered sugar and cornstarch, and spread them on a rimmed baking sheet. Using a lightly greased offset spatula, remove the marshmallow mixture from the dish and place it in the powdered sugar mixture. Using kitchen shears well coated with the powdered sugar mixture, cut the marshmallows into 1-inch squares. Coat all the cut sides of the marshmallows with the powdered sugar mixture, tossing lightly to remove excess. Store the marshmallows in an airtight container.

Rewritten:
1 1/4 сuрs wаtеr, dіvіdеd
4 (1/4-оz.) еnvеlореs unflаvоrеd gеlаtіn
2 сuрs grаnulаtеd sugаr
1 сuр lіght соrn sуruр
1/4 tеаsрооn tаblе sаlt
1 tаblеsрооn vаnіllа ехtrасt
1/2 сuр (аbоut 2 1/8 оz.) роwdеrеd sugаr
1/4 сuр соrnstаrсh
Ρlасе 1/2 сuр оf thе wаtеr іn а mісrоwаvе-sаfе bоwl; stіr іn gеlаtіn. Sеt аsіdе. Соmbіnе sugаr, соrn sуruр, sаlt, аnd rеmаіnіng 3/4 сuр wаtеr іn а lаrgе sаuсераn оvеr mеdіum-hіgh; brіng tо а bоіl, аnd сооk, stіrrіng оссаsіоnаllу, untіl sugаr dіssоlvеs, аbоut 5 mіnutеs. Сооk, wіthоut stіrrіng, untіl а саndу thеrmоmеtеr іnsеrtеd іn mіхturе rеgіstеrs 250°F. Роur sugаr mіхturе іntо thе bоwl оf а hеаvу-dutу stаnd mіхеr fіttеd wіth whіsk аttасhmеnt; lеt stаnd untіl mіхturе rеасhеs 210°F, аbоut 5 mіnutеs. Місrоwаvе gеlаtіn mіхturе оn НΙGΗ untіl gеlаtіn mеlts, аbоut 20 sесоnds, stіrrіng аftеr 10 sесоnds. Βеаtіng оn lоw sрееd, grаduаllу роur gеlаtіn mіхturе іn а thіn strеаm іntо sugаr mіхturе; аdd vаnіllа. Ιnсrеаsе sрееd tо hіgh, аnd bеаt untіl lіght аnd fluffу, 9 tо 10 mіnutеs. Usіng а lіghtlу grеаsеd sраtulа, sрrеаd mіхturе еvеnlу іn а lіghtlу grеаsеd 13- х 9-іnсh glаss оr сеrаmіс bаkіng dіsh. Lеt stаnd untіl drу аnd fіrm, аbоut 2 hоurs. Sіft tоgеthеr роwdеrеd sugаr аnd соrnstаrсh; sрrеаd оn а rіmmеd bаkіng shееt. Usіng а lіghtlу grеаsеd оffsеt sраtulа, rеmоvе mаrshmаllоw mіхturе frоm dіsh, аnd рlасе іn роwdеrеd sugаr mіхturе. Usіng kіtсhеn shеаrs wеll соаtеd wіth роwdеrеd sugаr mіхturе, сut mаrshmаllоws іntо 1-іnсh squаrеs. Соаt аll сut sіdеs оf mаrshmаllоws wіth роwdеrеd sugаr mіхturе, tоssіng lіghtlу tо rеmоvе ехсеss. Stоrе mаrshmаllоws іn аn аіrtіght соntаіnеr.

Date: Mon, 5 Nov 2001 08:20:00 -0800 (PST)  
From: colleen.sullivan@enron.com  
To: john.hodge@enron.com  
Subject: NYSEG  
Body:  
John-  
I have been assisting David Draper in evaluating the NYSEG positions we currently hold, aiming to accurately represent our exposure in light of LDC restrictions. One aspect where I hope you can provide assistance is the physical limitations in delivering gas to NYSEG from certain pipelines. It seems that the majority of our position relies on deliveries from CNG, which I believe does not have any physical limitations. However, we also have minor positions that necessitate deliveries from TCO, Iroquois, and Algonquin.  
From the pricing I observe in RGS, there seems to be a clear issue with delivering from TCO during the winter months. I would appreciate it if you could clarify this, along with any other concerns you might be aware of.  
It might be simpler to discuss this over the phone rather than through email, but I assumed you were trading. Feel free to call me at x35514 when you have a moment. (If David has already reached out to you regarding this, just let me know, and you won’t need to go over it again.)

Rewritten:

From: colleen.sullivan@enron.com
To: john.hodge@enron.com
Subject: NYSEG
Body:

I have been helping David Draper to review the NYSEG positions we currently have, and accurately reflect our exposure, based on LDC restrictions. The one factor that I hope you can help with is the physical constraints in delivering gas to NYSEG off of certain pipes. It appears as if most of our position is based upon deliveries off CNG, which I don't believe has any physical constraints. However, we also have small positions requiring us to deliver off of TCO, Iroquois and Algonquin.
Based on the pricing I see in RGS, there is obviously some issue with delivering off of TCO in the winter. I'm wondering if you can help explain this, as well as any other issues you are aware of here. 
It's probably easiest to talk through it rather than e-mail about it, but I assumed you were trading. You can call me at x35514 when you have some time. (If David has already contacted you about this, let me know and you don't have to repeat yourself.)

UK condom manufacturer SSL International has declined to comment on reports that it may be subject to a takeover early in 2005. A Financial Times report said that business intelligence firm GPW was understood to be starting diligence work on SSL International for a corporate client. An SSL spokesperson, which makes the famous Durex brand of condoms, would not comment on "market speculation." However, the news sent shares in SSL, which also makes Scholl footwear, up more than 6%, or 16.75% to 293.5p.

The FT said that most of the high-profile firms that might woo SSL was Anglo-Dutch household products group Reckitt Benckiser. Eighteen months ago Reckitt Benckiser was at the centre of a rumoured takeover bid for SSL - but that came to nothing. Other firms that have been seen as potential suitors include Kimberly-Clark, Johnson & Johnson, and private equity investors. Analysts have seen SSL as a takeover target for years. It sold off its surgical gloves and antiseptic businesses for £173m to a management team in May. SSL was formed by a three-way merger between Seton Healthcare, footwear specialists Scholl and condom-maker London International Group. Its other brands include Syndol analgesics, Meltus cough medicine, Sauver compression hosiery and deodorant products, and Mister Baby.

​T​h​e​ ​F​T​ ​s​a​i​d​ ​m​o​s​t​ ​t​h​e​ ​h​i​g​h​-​p​r​o​f​i​l​e​ ​f​i​r​m​ ​t​h​a​t​ ​m​i​g​h​t​ ​w​o​o​ ​S​S​L​ ​w​a​s​ ​A​n​g​l​o​-​D​u​t​c​h​ ​h​o​u​s​e​h​o​l​d​ ​p​r​o​d​u​c​t​s​ ​g​r​o​u​p​ ​R​e​c​k​i​t​t​ ​B​e​n​c​k​i​s​e​r​.​ ​E​i​g​h​t​e​e​n​ ​m​o​n​t​h​s​ ​a​g​o​ ​R​e​c​k​i​t​t​ ​B​e​n​c​k​i​s​e​r​ ​w​a​s​ ​a​t​ ​t​h​e​ ​c​e​n​t​r​e​ ​o​f​ ​a​ ​r​u​m​o​u​r​e​d​ ​t​a​k​e​o​v​e​r​ ​b​i​d​ ​f​o​r​ ​S​S​L​ ​-​ ​b​u​t​ ​t​h​a​t​ ​c​a​m​e​ ​t​o​ ​n​o​t​h​i​n​g​.​ ​O​t​h​e​r​ ​f​i​r​m​s​ ​t​h​a​t​ ​h​a​v​e​ ​b​e​e​n​ ​s​e​e​n​ ​a​s​ ​w​o​u​l​d​-​b​e​ ​s​u​i​t​o​r​s​ ​i​n​c​l​u​d​e​ ​K​i​m​b​e​r​l​y​-​C​l​a​r​k​,​ ​J​o​h​n​s​o​n​ ​&​ ​J​o​h​n​s​o​n​,​ ​a​n​d​ ​p​r​i​v​a​t​e​ ​e​q​u​i​t​y​ ​i​n​v​e​s​t​o​r​s​.​ ​A​n​a​l​y​s​t​s​ ​h​a​v​e​ ​s​e​e​n​ ​S​S​L​ ​a​s​ ​a​ ​t​a​k​e​o​v​e​r​ ​t​a​r​g​e​t​ ​f​o​r​ ​y​e​a​r​s​.​ ​I​t​ ​s​o​l​d​ ​o​f​f​ ​i​t​s​ ​s​u​r​g​i​c​a​l​ ​g​l​o​v​e​s​ ​a​n​d​ ​a​n​t​i​s​e​p​t​i​c​s​ ​b​u​s​i​n​e​s​s​e​s​ ​f​o​r​ ​£​1​7​3​m​ ​t​o​ ​a​ ​m​a​n​a​g​e​m​e​n​t​ ​t​e​a​m​ ​i​n​ ​M​a​y​.​ ​S​S​L​ ​w​a​s​ ​f​o​r​m​e​d​ ​b​y​ ​a​ ​t​h​r​e​e​-​w​a​y​ ​m​e​r​g​e​r​ ​b​e​t​w​e​e​n​ ​S​e​t​o​n​ ​H​e​a​l​t​h​c​a​r​e​,​ ​f​o​o​t​w​e​a​r​ ​s​p​e​c​i​a​l​i​s​t​s​ ​S​c​h​o​l​l​ ​a​n​d​ ​c​o​n​d​o​m​-​m​a​k​e​r​ ​L​o​n​d​o​n​ ​I​n​t​e​r​n​a​t​i​o​n​a​l​ ​G​r​o​u​p​.​ ​I​t​s​ ​o​t​h​e​r​ ​b​r​a​n​d​s​ ​i​n​c​l​u​d​e​ ​S​y​n​d​o​l​ ​a​n​a​l​g​e​s​i​c​,​ ​M​e​l​t​u​s​ ​c​o​u​g​h​ ​m​e​d​i​c​i​n​e​,​ ​S​a​u​b​e​r​ ​c​o​m​p​r​e​s​s​i​o​n​ ​h​o​s​i​e​r​y​ ​a​n​d​ ​d​e​o​d​o​r​a​n​t​ ​p​r​o​d​u​c​t​s​,​ ​a​n​d​ ​M​i​s​t​e​r​ ​B​a​b​y​.​

Mitsubishi Motors, a Japanese car manufacturer struggling with financial difficulties, is reportedly in discussions with PSA Peugeot Citroen, a French automotive company, about a potential partnership. On Tuesday, Mitsubishi confirmed the ongoing negotiations, but declined to comment on speculation surrounding the possibility of manufacturing cars for PSA or even its Japanese competitor, Nissan. Mitsubishi has faced significant challenges, including a major recall scandal and the loss of financial support from its former majority shareholder, DaimlerChrysler. The US-German firm had initially provided substantial backing but decided to withdraw its support in April last year. As a result, Mitsubishi's sales have plummeted by 41% over the past year, largely due to the company's admission of systematically concealing records of defects and secretly repairing vehicles. Mitsubishi is expected to unveil a recovery plan in January, and analysts believe that forming alliances with other car manufacturers will be a crucial component of its strategy, given its underutilized manufacturing capacity and sluggish sales.

Rewritten:
Trouble-hit Mitsubishi Motors is in talks with French carmaker PSA Peugeot Citroen about a possible alliance.
On Tuesday Mitsubishi, the only major Japanese car firm in the red, confirmed earlier reports of negotiations. But a spokesman refused to comment on speculation that Mitsubishi could end up building cars for PSA and perhaps its Japanese rival Nissan. Mitsubishi has been hit by a recall scandal and the withdrawal of support from shareholder DaimlerChrysler. The US-German firm, once a majority shareholder, decided last April to stop providing financial backing. Mitsubishi's sales have slid 41% in the past year, catalysed by the revelation that the company had systematically been hiding records of faults and then secretly repairing vehicles. Mitsubishi is due to unveil a recovery plan later in January. Analysts said that alliances with other carmakers would be a necessary part of whatever it came up with, not least because its own slow sales have left its manufacturing capacity under-used.

Date: Fri, 6 Oct 2000 01:20:00 -0700 (PDT)  
From: david.delainey@enron.com  
To: joseph.short@enron.com  
Subject: Follow-up to ENA Orientation  
Body:  
Joe, EnronOnline serves as the online distribution platform for our gas and power sectors. My emphasis on the legacy channel aims to boost the chances that more originators can finalize transactions and create deal flow. Additionally, it seeks to minimize the friction between the trading and origination teams, allowing us to spend more time engaging with the market rather than getting caught up in internal matters. As for the details, you will need to wait and see.  
Thanks,  
Delainey

I appreciated your presentation this morning. You mentioned that one of your current objectives is "advancing the legacy origination/structuring model to the next level." What do you mean by that? Do you foresee utilizing the internet or other technologies to improve the existing origination framework?  
[End of text]

Rewritten:
Date: Fri, 6 Oct 2000 01:20:00 -0700 (PDT)
From: david.delainey@enron.com
To: joseph.short@enron.com
Subject: Follow-up to ENA Orientation
Body: 
Joe, EnronOnline is essentially the internet distribution channel for our gas 
and power business. Rather, my focus on the legacy channel is an attempt to 
increase the probability that more originators can complete transactions and 
generate deal flow. As well, to reduce the conflict between the trading and 
origination organizations in order to keep us spending more time in the 
market than focused on internal issues. As far as specifics, you will have 
to wait and see.
Thanks
Delainey

Rewritten:
I've never understood why people do that.

The story begins on a fictional planet called Per, where the inhabitants discover the unique abilities of the watch-whers or wherevers, distant relatives of the dragons. These beasts are then used in mines to warn miners of gas pockets and also to locate stranded miners, should there be a cave-in. The story takes place several years before the 3rd Pass in Camp Natalon, a mining camp. There, the reader is introduced to a young boy named Kindan, whose father owns a watch-wher called Dark. During a mining cave-in, Kindan loses his entire family as well as Dark, and is adopted by the Master Harper Zist, who begins to train him to be both an entertainer and a spy, something that Harpers do. This is how Kindan learns that the camp is divided into two parts, Natalon's and his uncle, Tari's. Meanwhile, the camp is without a watch-wher and minor accidents keep delaying the work. Despite the protests from Tari and his group, Natalon decides to trade an entire winter's worth of coal for a chance for Kindan to ask a queen watch-wher for an egg. He succeeds and begins the difficult task of raising a nocturnal animal. As no records exist on how to raise or train a watch-wher, Kindan has no clue but is luckily aided by the mysterious Nuella. Together, they train Kisk and, in the process, learn a great deal about this species. This proves to be vital as, towards the end of the novel, Kisk's abilities will save many lives, including that of the camp leader, Natalon.

You can now access Enron in Action through the company's new Community Relations website at http://cr.enron.com/eia.html. This week's issue includes information on various events and activities:

- Enron Happenings: Stay updated on the latest news and updates from Enron.
- BEAR Holiday Fundraiser: Support a good cause and participate in the holiday fundraiser.
- 2001 Holiday Shopping Card benefiting the American Cancer Society: Purchase a holiday shopping card that supports the American Cancer Society.
- Enron Kids 2001 Holiday Program: Get involved in the Enron Kids holiday program.
- Support the Museum of Natural Science at the Crate & Barrel Opening Night Preview Party: Attend the preview party and support the museum.
- Enron Night with the Houston Aeros: Enjoy a fun night with the Houston Aeros.
- Free Carwashes for Enron Employees: Take advantage of free carwashes for Enron employees.
- American Heart Association "Heart Walk": Participate in the heart walk and support a good cause.
- Enron Volunteer Opportunities: Find out about volunteer opportunities available at Enron.
- Volunteer for the 2001 Nutcracker Market "A World of Holiday Shopping": Get involved in the Nutcracker Market.
- Enron Wellness: Stay healthy and informed through Enron's wellness program.
- CPR/First Aid Training: Learn CPR and first aid skills.
- Mammogram Screening: Take advantage of free mammogram screenings.
- November is Lung Cancer Awareness Month: Show support for lung cancer awareness.

Additionally, Enron in Action is also available through a channel on my.home.enron.com. To add this channel to your setup, click on the channels link at the top of the screen and check the Enron in Action box.

If you would like to add an announcement to Enron in Action, please fill out the attached form and submit it to eia@enron.com by 12 PM on Thursday each week.

Subject: FROM CINDY OLSON, COMMUNITY RELATIONS: Body Shop Reopening  
Body: Exciting news for Body Shop members!  
The Body Shop will reopen on Monday, January 7, 2002.  
While we acknowledge that the Body Shop is a valuable resource for the health and wellness of all our employees, we must reopen it without financial support from Enron.  
As a result, the membership fee will rise from $25 to $30 per month for all Enron employees and contractors.  
Spouse memberships will stay at $15 per month.  
Locker fees will remain at $10 per month, and members can retain their current locker.  
(If you cleared your locker after the Body Shop closed in December, please inform the Body Shop reception desk that you wish to reclaim it.)  
The overall fee increase, along with reduced expenses, will allow the Body Shop to reopen and operate on a cash-neutral basis to satisfy creditors' requirements.  
Payroll deductions will resume with the January 15th payroll and will reflect the increased fee.  
If you choose not to continue your membership, please email the Body Shop at <mailto:Body.Shop@enron.com> to cancel.  
Membership details and enrollment forms can be found below: The Body Shop's new hours will be 6:00 a.m. - 7:00 p.m. from Monday to Thursday, and 6:00 a.m. - 6:00 p.m. on Friday.  
Saturday hours are not available at this time.  
Although laundry service has been discontinued, towels will still be provided for your convenience.  
Once the membership base and related revenues are stabilized to support staffing and maintenance, exercise classes will be scheduled.  
We expect exercise classes to be available within a few weeks.  
Massage therapy services will continue and can be booked by calling extension 3-3047.  
Whether you are a returning member or thinking about joining, there is no better time than now, at the start of 2002, to take advantage of the Body Shop and prioritize your health and well-being.  
Your ongoing support is greatly appreciated.

Body: Good news for Body Shop members!
The Body Shop will reopen Monday, January 7, 2002.
While we recognize that the Body Shop is a tremendous asset to all of our employees' health and wellness, we must reopen it without an Enron subsidy.
Therefore, the membership fee will increase from $25 to $30 per month for all Enron employees and contractors.
Spouse memberships will remain at $15 per month.
Locker fees will remain at $10 per month and members may keep their current locker.
(If you emptied your locker after the Body Shop closed in December, please notify the Body Shop reception desk that you would like to reoccupy it.)
The overall price increase, coupled with reduced expenses, will enable the Body Shop to reopen and remain open on a cash-neutral basis to meet creditors' requirements.
Payroll deductions will be reactivated with the January 15th payroll and will include the increased fee.
If you do not wish to continue your membership, please contact the Body Shop to cancel your membership via email only at <mailto:Body.Shop@enron.com>.
Membership information and enrollment forms can be accessed below: 	 The Body Shop's new hours will be 6:00 a.m. - 7:00 p.m. Monday through Thursday, and 6:00 a.m. - 6:00 p.m. on Friday.
Saturday hours are not offered at this time.
Although laundry service has been discontinued, towels will continue to be available for your convenience.
Once the ongoing membership base and associated revenues have been stabilized to support staffing and housekeeping, exercise classes will be scheduled.
We anticipate exercise classes to be available within a few weeks.
Massage therapy services will continue and are available by appointment by calling extension 3-3047.
Whether you are a continuing member or considering new membership, there is no better time for you to take advantage of the Body Shop and to take care of your personal health and well being than right now, at the beginning of 2002.
Your continued support is greatly appreciated.

Tony Blair has committed to "never, ever, ever" criticize Tory leader Michael Howard regarding his Jewish faith. The prime minister stated to the Jewish Chronicle: "If you observe my actions, I challenge Michael Howard on political grounds." Mr. Blair also distanced himself from recent Labour campaign posters featuring Mr. Howard, which some critics labeled as "anti-Semitic." He asserted that these were "not meant to offend anyone in the Jewish community." One poster illustrated Mr. Howard and his shadow chancellor Oliver Letwin, who is also Jewish, as flying pigs. Another showed the Tory leader swinging a pocket watch on a chain, which critics argued resembled the Jewish moneylender Shylock from Shakespeare's Merchant of Venice. Others likened the image to the character Fagin from Charles Dickens' Oliver Twist. Labour has since removed the designs from its website, stating that members preferred alternative designs. During his conversation with the Jewish Chronicle, Mr. Blair remarked: "I have been a staunch supporter of the Jewish community and Israel, and I will always remain so." When asked if he would highlight Mr. Howard's Jewish beliefs to gain Muslim support, he responded: "The notion that I would permit anyone to make such an accusation is outrageous. It's false. If you examine my actions, I challenge Michael Howard politically. I would never, ever, ever attack him on that basis." Mr. Blair also defended his party's stance towards the Jewish community, noting that it was his government that established Holocaust Memorial Day. He emphasized that Labour actively combats all forms of racism. Neither the Conservatives nor the Liberal Democrats chose to comment on Mr. Blair's statements. The prime minister was addressing the situation as London's Labour mayor Ken Livingstone remains involved in controversy over remarks he made to a Jewish reporter from the Evening Standard newspaper. Mr. Blair reiterated calls for the mayor to apologize for comparing the reporter, Oliver Finegold, to a concentration camp guard. Mr. Livingstone "should have retracted the comment immediately" upon realizing the journalist was Jewish, said Mr. Blair. "I'm certain that is what he truly wishes to do. Well, he should do it." Mr. Livingstone has stated that he cannot genuinely apologize for his remarks and claims he has been targeted by the newspaper. He acknowledged that his comments may have been offensive but insisted they were not racist, and earlier this week he stated he would not apologize even if Mr. Blair requested it.

Rewritten:
Tony Blair has pledged to "never, ever, ever" attack Tory leader Michael Howard over his Jewish beliefs.
The prime minister told the Jewish Chronicle: "If you look at what I do, I attack Michael Howard politically." Mr Blair also distanced himself from recent Labour campaign posters featuring Mr Howard, which critics claimed were "anti-Semitic". These were "not intended to cause any offence to anyone on the Jewish community," Mr Blair insisted.
One poster depicted Mr Howard and his shadow chancellor Oliver Letwin, who is also Jewish, as flying pigs. Another pictured the Tory leader swinging a pocket watch on a chain, which critics said echoed the Jewish money lender Shylock in Shakespeare's Merchant of Venice.
Others compared the image to the character Fagin in Charles Dickens' Oliver Twist. Labour has since taken the designs of its website, saying members had preferred other designs. During his interview with the Jewish Chronicle, Mr Blair said: "I've been a very strong supporter of the Jewish community and Israel, and will always be so." Pressed on whether he would draw attention to Mr Howard's Jewish beliefs in an attempt to attract Muslim support, he replied: "The idea that I would allow anybody to make such a charge is outrageous. It's untrue. "If you look what I do, I attack Michael Howard politically. I would never, ever, ever attack him on that basis."
Mr Blair also defended his party's attitude towards the Jewish community, pointing out that it was his government that had introduced the Holocaust Memorial Day. He added that Labour also aggressively fought all forms of racism.
Neither the Conservatives nor the Liberal Democrats wished to comment on Mr Blair's words. The prime minister was speaking as London's Labour mayor Ken Livingstone remains embroiled in a row over comments he made to a Jewish reporter from the city's Evening Standard newspaper. Mr Blair repeated calls for the mayor to apologise for likening the reporter, Oliver Finegold, to a concentration camp guard. Mr Livingstone "should have withdrawn the comment immediately" once he realised the journalist was Jewish, said Mr Blair. "I'm sure that is what in truth he wants to do. Well, he should do it." Mr Livingstone has said he could not sincerely say sorry for the comments he made, and claims he has been targeted by the newspaper. He conceded his comments may have been offensive but were not racist, and said earlier this week he would not apologise even if Mr Blair asked.

Wales may take inspiration from England and engage in a three-day training session with a prominent club. England has already gained from a similar experience with Leeds Rhinos, and it is believed that Wales is interested in arranging a comparable session with their rivals, Saints. Saints' coach Ian Millward has expressed his support, but if it occurs, it will not be during this season. Saints are set to embark on a week-long training camp in Portugal next week, while Wales is scheduled to face England on February 5, marking the first match of the Six Nations. “Wales have reached out to us,” a spokesman for Saints confirmed. “It is still in the early stages, but it is something we are seriously contemplating.” Saints, who share a strong bond with Wales, are the clear choice for the Welsh RFU, despite recent disputes regarding the failed £500,000 transfer of Kieron Cunningham to Swansea. However, the transfer was successfully finalized in July when Iestyn Harris moved from Leeds to Cardiff for an estimated £100,000. It is also understood that Cunningham was later convinced to return to the 13-man game with the Bulls in Bradford. Kel Coslett, who notably joined Saints from Wales in the 1960s, currently serves as the club's head of the game and, along with Wales’ head coach Clive Griffiths, a former Saints player, is believed to be spearheading this new initiative. Scott Gibbs, the ex-Wales and Lions centre, played for Saints from 1994 to 1996 and was part of their victorious Challenge Cup team in 1996.

Rewritten:
Wales could follow England’s example and take part in a three-day session with a leading club. England have already benefited from a similar three-day session with Leeds Rhinos, and it is thought Wales would like to have a similar session with their rivals Saints. Saints coach Ian Millward has given his approval, but if it happens, it will not be in this season. Saints are on a week-long training camp in Portugal next week, and Wales have a clash with England on February 5, the first game of the Six Nations. “Wales have approached us,” confirmed a Saints spokesman. “It is very early stage but it is something we are seriously considering.” Saints, who have a strong connection with Wales, are the obvious choice for the Welsh RFU, despite their recent rows over the collapse of Kieron Cunningham’s £500,000 move to Swansea. However, the deal was successfully concluded in July when Iestyn Harris moved from Leeds to Cardiff for a reported £100,000. And, it is understood, Cunningham was then persuaded to return to the 13-man game with the Bulls in Bradford. Kel Coslett, who famously came to Saints from Wales in the 1960s, is now the club’s head of their game and, along with Wales’ head coach Clive Griffiths, a former Saints player, is thought to be the man driving this latest initiative. Scott Gibbs, the former Wales and Lions centre, played for Saints between 1994 and ’96 and was in their winning Challenge Cup side in 1996.

... [footnote] The archives of his documents are housed at the Smithsonian Institution and the University of Pennsylvania. He was born in Keokuk, Iowa, to Moses Calvin Sawyer and his English wife, Helen Jane Cass Sawyer. He graduated as a lawyer in 1882, but subsequently pursued art studies under John Vanderpoel at the Art Institute of Chicago. He worked as an illustrator for the Chicago News and the Chicago Times before taking on the role of draftsman for the Geological Survey of the United States in Washington, D.C. The photographs, drawings, and watercolors that Mr. Sawyer collected during the expedition led by the renowned Sir Edwin James are the only remnants preserved from many items that decayed shortly after their discovery.

Date: Wed, 30 Jan 2002 09:42:04 -0800 (PST)  
From: mivancic@zoo.uvm.edu  
To: klay@enron.com  
Subject: Request for Ken Lay to Contribute Earnings from Enron Stock Sales  
Body:  
Monika Ivancic  
mivancic@zoo.uvm.edu  
To Mr. Ken Lay,  
I am reaching out to implore you to contribute the substantial profits you gained from selling Enron stock prior to the company's bankruptcy to organizations like the Enron Employee Transition Fund and REACH. These funds support the employees of Enron who lost their retirement savings and offer assistance to low-income consumers in California struggling to pay their energy bills. Enron, along with yourself, profited immensely at the expense of California consumers and the hard work of your employees.  
While you personally gained over $100 million, many Enron employees faced severe financial hardship when the company went bankrupt and their retirement plans were erased. Furthermore, Enron reaped enormous profits during the California energy crisis last year. Consequently, there are countless consumers unable to meet their basic energy expenses, and the largest utility in the state has gone bankrupt.  
The New York Times reported that you sold $101 million worth of Enron stock while actively encouraging the company's employees to continue purchasing it. I urge you to donate this amount to the funds established to help restore the lives of those Americans affected by Enron's unethical practices.  
Sincerely,  
Monika Ivancic

Based on the parallels between the mathematical representations of paraxial diffraction and dispersion, the temporal imaging of optical pulses integrates linear dispersive filters with quadratic phase modulations that function as time lenses. We explore the programming of a dispersive filter situated near atomic resonance in crystals doped with rare earth ions, resulting in exceptionally high dispersive power values. This filter is employed in a simplified imaging approach, which merges a single time lens with a single dispersive section, acting as a time-reversing device, and holds potential for applications in radio-frequency signal processing. This approach is closely linked to the three-pulse photon echo involving chirped pulses, yet the relationship with temporal imaging and dispersive filtering highlights novel characteristics.

Rewritten:
Based on the similarity of paraxial diffraction and dispersion mathematical
descriptions, the temporal imaging of optical pulses combines linear dispersive
filters and quadratic phase modulations operating as time lenses. We consider
programming a dispersive filter near atomic resonance in rare earth ion doped
crystals, which leads to unprecedented high values of dispersive power. This
filter is used in an approximate imaging scheme, combining a single time lens
and a single dispersive section and operating as a time reversing device, with
potential applications in radio-frequency signal processing. This scheme is
closely related to three-pulse photon echo with chirped pulses but the
connection with temporal imaging and dispersive filtering emphasizes new
features.

In a market with incomplete information and a non-tradable random factor, we examine a continuous-time investment problem where the goal is to maximize returns while minimizing risk, based on a specific set of preferences. We model this problem as a stochastic differential game and use a set of equations known as Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman-Isaacs equations to find the optimal investment strategy and a value function that represents the maximum return. Notably, our solution also applies to the traditional Markowitz problem, and we show that any optimal solution for the Markowitz problem is also optimal for our specific set of preferences. This is significant because the original Markowitz approach does not meet certain criteria, and previous studies have shown that the solutions to the Markowitz and our approach can differ in certain cases. Furthermore, we derive explicit investment strategies for a specific type of market model known as the square root factor model.

Rewritten:
We consider an incomplete market with a nontradable stochastic factor and a
continuous time investment problem with an optimality criterion based on
monotone mean-variance preferences. We formulate it as a stochastic
differential game problem and use Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman-Isaacs equations to
find an optimal investment strategy and the value function. What is more, we
show that our solution is also optimal for the classical Markowitz problem and
every optimal solution for the classical Markowitz problem is optimal also for
the monotone mean-variance preferences. These results are interesting because
the original Markowitz functional is not monotone, and it was observed that in
the case of a static one-period optimization problem the solutions for those
two functionals are different. In addition, we determine explicit Markowitz
strategies in the square root factor models.

In Ireland, an ordinary referendum is a vote on a bill that does not aim to amend the Constitution. The Constitution outlines the process in Articles 27 ("Reference of Bills to the People") and 47 ("The Referendum"). Unlike a constitutional referendum, which is mandatory for a constitutional amendment bill, an ordinary referendum only occurs if the bill "contains a proposal of such national importance that the will of the people thereon ought to be ascertained." This decision is made by the President, after a petition by Oireachtas members, including a majority of Senators. No such petition has ever been presented, and thus no ordinary referendum has ever been held.

Overview
The Oireachtas is a bicameral legislature in which the Dáil Éireann, the lower house, is much more powerful than the Seanad Éireann, the upper house. The Seanad cannot veto bills passed by the Dáil; it can at most delay them for 90 days before they are deemed to have been passed. The ordinary referendum in theory allows the Seanad to exercise a check on the Dáil by providing a mechanism for it to prevent the passing of a bill with which it disagrees. However, the composition of the Seanad, especially the fact that 11 of the 60 Senators are nominated by the Taoiseach, means that it usually has a pro-government majority and will not oppose a government bill.

Leonid Karev is a composer, organist, and pianist, born in Moscow in 1969. He has resided in France since 1992 and serves as a professor of organ and piano accompaniment at the Conservatories of Paris and Yerres (France). Additionally, he is the organist at the Notre-Dame-de-l’Assomption church in Paris and plays the organ at Bertrand Cattiaux's instrument in the Saint-Médard church in Brunoy (France). He pursued his studies at the Moscow Tchaikovsky Conservatory and the Conservatoire de Paris, focusing on composition and organ performance. His instructors included Michel Chapuis, André Isoir, Jean Guillou, Alain Banquart, Michel Merlet, and Guillaume Connesson. He earned his degree as a composer from the École Normale de Musique de Paris. His symphony, Dulce Memoriae, received the Sacem prize and a recognition at the Gino Contilli competition in Italy, while his choral work, Ave Maria, was honored at the Guido d’Arezzo competition in Italy. He is also the First Prize winner of the Marcel Dupré organ Competition in Chartres (1998) and received the First Prize of honor from the UFAM in Paris (1996).

Rewritten:
Leonid Karev is a composer, organist and pianist, born in Moscow in 1969. He has lived in France since 1992, and is a professor of organ and piano accompaniment at the Conservatories of Paris and Yerres (France) and organist at the Notre-Dame-de-l’Assomption church in Paris and the Bertrand Cattiaux's organ in the Saint-Médard church in Brunoy (France). He studied at the Moscow Tchaikovsky Conservatory and at Conservatoire de Paris both as composer and organist. His professors included Michel Chapuis, André Isoir, Jean Guillou, Alain Banquart, Michel Merlet, and Guillaume Connesson. He graduated from the École Normale de Musique de Paris as a composer. His symphony Dulce Memoriae was awarded the Sacem prize and a prize at the Gino Contilli competition in Italy and his piece for choir Ave Maria was awarded at the Guido d’Arezzo competition in Italy. He is also the First Prize winner of Marcel Dupré organ Competition in Chartres (1998), and the First Prize of honor winner of the UFAM in Paris (1996).

Date: Thu, 20 Sep 2001 13:21:07 -0700 (PDT)  
From: e..haedicke@enron.com  
To: mary.cook@enron.com  
Subject: RE: Implementation of Form Setoff Language: EOL Transactions  
Body:  
That sounds reasonable. What is the process for informing our trading counterparties? Mark  
-----Original Message-----  
From: Cook, Mary  
Sent: Thursday, September 20, 2001 11:12 AM  
To: Haedicke, Mark E.  
Subject: Implementation of Form Setoff Language: EOL Transactions  
Given the significant effort needed to update our annexes, GTCs, etc. regarding EOL (including IT coordination, notifying counterparties, and so forth) and the traders' strong inclination to avoid frequent changes to EOL product documentation, we suggest implementing the EOL form modification in a single comprehensive revision once the trading forms committee completes its work on events of default and termination valuation/remedies. If you believe this should be approached differently, please let me know. Mary  
Best regards,  
Mary Cook  
Enron North America Corp.  
1400 Smith, 38th Floor, Legal  
Houston, Texas 77002-7361  
(713) 345-7732  
(713) 646-3393 (fax)  
mary.cook@enron.com

Everything I do seems to spark some kind of narrative in her mind, along with various scenarios about what I should be doing. She’s not pleased that I’m attending my sister’s graduation because I might “know someone there and engage in conversation,” and she’s frustrated that I’m an usher and will have to walk alongside a girl. Additionally, she constantly inquires about my phone, even though I’m not doing anything inappropriate. On top of that, we live together and literally share every moment of our day. I enjoy gaming with my friends, but since we’ve been together, I’ve been playing less frequently than I used to. She gets upset if I play for more than three hours, and I only play at night. She insists that we don’t spend enough time together, even though we watch various movies daily, eat meals together, and share a bed. I care for her deeply, but I’m beginning to feel overwhelmed.

Rewritten:
Everything I do, she makes up some kind of story in her head, and some sort of scenario or what I should do. She doesn’t like that I’m going to my sister’s graduation because I might “know somebody there and talk to them,” she’s upset that I’m an usher and will have to walk with a girl, and she’s constantly asking about my phone, even though I’m not doing anything wrong. On top of that, we live together and literally spend every waking moment together. I enjoy playing games with my friends, but since we’ve been together I play less often than before. She gets upset if I play for more than three hours, and I only play at night. She claims we don’t spend enough time together, although we watch all kinds of movies together every day, eat together, and sleep together. I love her, but I’m starting to feel it’s a bit much.

She wouldn't have minded if he went to the mall with Daphne, but a heads-up would have been appreciated. Her expression turned stern as she crossed her arms over her chest. Tifa wouldn't reveal the truth to him, instead choosing to brush it off. "I'm still in the middle of something," she said with a hint of annoyance, shifting her weight onto one leg. She locked eyes with Vao for a moment, taking in his appearance before a sly smile spread across her face. "Daphne mentioned what happened," she said, trying to extract information from him.

Rewritten:
She didn't care if he went to the mall with Daphne, but an invitation would have been nice. She glared at him, folding her arms against her chest. Tifa wouldn't tell him, she would just shrug it off. "I'm actually not done..." she sneered, her hands now finding her hips. She stared at Vao for a moment, admiring his features before she smirked. "Daphne told me what happened," she lied, hoping to get something out of him.

Bom, primeiramente, que escrevo aqui, não sei dizer como funciona, então faz uns 4 a 5 meses que não converso com meu irmão, mesmo ele morando em casa comigo e com meus pais, ele vai completar 20 anos... O problema que eu tenho com ele é que eu sinceramente não suporto mais, porque ele sempre me humilhou e me pôs para baixo, ele fala coisas absurdas, briga comigo na frente das pessoas, e fala mal de mim pelas costas, já pedi desculpas, mas fiquei com tanta raiva por ele rir da minha cara, aqui em casa não somos muito bons financeiramente, mas conseguimos pagar as contas às vezes meio atrasadas, ele não quer trabalhar, fica 24h no computador e nem estuda, eu tento fazer o máximo que posso para ajudar em casa, mas a presença dele me deixa incomodada demais, acabei criando ansiedade, não durmo direito à noite, e tenho indícios de depressão... eu me abalo demais pelas coisas que ele fala e faz, e eu tento não ligar, mas é bem difícil... eu não sei mais o que fazer.

PC first-person shooter Half-Life 2 has garnered six Bafta Awards, including accolades for best game and best online game. Developed by Valve, the title was launched last year to widespread acclaim, receiving notable recognition for its engaging storyline and physics engine. The game also secured Baftas for best action adventure, best PC game, art direction, and animation. Burnout 3 took home three awards in the categories of racing, technical direction, and best PlayStation 2 game. Grant Dean, chairman of the Bafta games awards, remarked at a ceremony in London on Tuesday: "The past year has been an exceptional year for the interactive entertainment sector. These awards highlight the remarkable achievements, advancements, and variety we have witnessed during this period." Halo 2 was awarded the best Xbox game, while Prince of Persia: Warrior Within was recognized as the best GameCube title. The sports award was presented to Konami's Pro Evolution Soccer 4. Bafta noted that a "notable aspect" of this year's awards was the prevalence of "non-traditional games." The originality award was claimed by the PlayStation 2 game Singstar, while the children's award went to the GameCube rhythm game Donkey Konga. The Handheld Award was given to Colin McRae Rally 2005, and the mobile category was won by Blue Tooth Byplanes. The audio award was awarded to Call of Duty: Finest Hour, while Hitman: Contracts received the music award.

Rewritten:
PC first person shooter Half-Life 2 has won six Bafta Awards, including best game and best online game.
The title, developed by Valve, was released last year to universal acclaim - receiving special praise for its immersive plot and physics engine. The game also won Baftas for best action adventure, best PC game, art direction and animation. Burnout 3 won three awards in the categories for racing, technical direction and best PlayStation 2 game. Grant Dean, chairman of the Bafta games awards, said at a ceremony in London on Tuesday: "The last year has been a great year for the interactive entertainment industry.
"These awards reflect the enormous achievements, progress and diversity that we have seen in that time." Halo 2 won the best Xbox game category, while Prince of Persia: Warrior Within was adjudged the best GameCube title. The sports award went to Konami's Pro Evolution Soccer 4. Bafta said the "significant feature" of this year's awards was the number of "non-traditional games". The originality award was won by PlayStation 2 title Singstar while the children's award went to GameCube bongo rhythm game Donkey Konga. The Handheld Award went to Colin McRae Rally 2005 while the mobile category was won by Blue Tooth Byplanes. The audio award was won by Call of Duty: Finest Hour and Hitman: Contracts won the music award.

Republic of Ireland manager Brian Kerr expressed his disappointment that his team only managed to score one goal in their friendly win over Croatia. Robbie Keane's first-half goal, which marked his 24th Republic of Ireland goal, proved to be enough for the victory. However, Kerr felt that his team had more opportunities to score, but unfortunately, they were unable to capitalize on them against a technically gifted Croatian team.

Despite the limited goal-scoring, Kerr was pleased with the overall performance of his team, particularly considering the challenging conditions and the high standard of the Croatian team. The Republic of Ireland side maintained a clean sheet for the eighth time in 11 matches and have now gone 14 home games unbeaten since Kerr took over from Mick McCarthy.

Kerr praised the decisive goal, which was scored by Robbie Keane, and credited Damien Duff for his brilliant play that led to the goal. "It was a fantastic goal, and Damien's skill was outstanding," Kerr said. "Robbie might have had a slight misstep, but it was still a great goal."

Matchwinner Keane also praised Duff's role in the goal, saying, "It was great play from Damien. I always try to be in the right position because I know that nine times out of ten, Duffer will get the ball into the box." Keane also appreciated the opportunity to play with three strikers, which was a new formation that Kerr wanted to try out. He was pleased to see young Stephen Elliott getting a run-out and doing well despite the difficult conditions.

Man-of-the-match Duff explained what went wrong when he had a chance to make it 2-0 midway through the second half. He opted to shoot against the bar instead of heading the ball close-range, which he would have done every time. "I completely lost it in the lights," Duff said. "I was desperate to get on the scoresheet myself, but the result is the most important thing."

Duff was pleased with the team's performance and the result, which has set them up nicely for the qualifiers. "We've had a good year, and we're going nicely in the qualifiers," he said. "Hopefully, we can continue this momentum in 2005."

Rewritten:
Republic of Ireland manager Brian Kerr admitted he was frustrated his side did not score more than one goal in their friendly win over Croatia. 

Robbie Keane took his Republic record to 24 with a first-half goal which proved enough for victory. "We had more good chances. 

It is just a shame we did not take them against such a technically gifted team," said Kerr. 

"But, given the conditions and the standard of the Croatian team, we should be very happy with the win." The Republic side kept a clean sheet for the eighth time in 11 matches and are unbeaten in 14 home games since Kerr succeeded Mick McCarthy. Kerr applauded the decisive move which earned the victory. "It was a brilliant goal, fantastic skill by Damien Duff. 

Robbie might have scuffed it a little but it was a good goal." Matchwinner Keane was another full of praise for Duff's role in the goal. "It was great play from Damien," said the Tottenham striker. 

"I always try to be sniffing around because you know nine times out of 10 Duffer is going to get it in the box. "Playing three up was something different. Brian Kerr wanted to try it out and it was good to see young Stephen Elliott getting a run-out. 

"The conditions were difficult but he did well and is definitely one for the future. It is nice to see young players coming through." 

Man-of-the-match Duff explained what went wrong when he fluffed a chance to make it 2-0 midway through the second half. He opted to bring Steve Finnan's cross down and shoot against the bar when a close-range header looked the best option. 

"I would have headed that every time but I completely lost it in the lights," said the Chelsea star. 

"I was desperate to get on the scoresheet myself but the result is the important thing. 

"We have had a good year and are going nicely in the qualifiers. Hopefully that can continue in 2005."

Bcc: r-help@r-project.org  
On Mon, 4 Feb 2002, Stuart Leask wrote:  
%Is there an easy method to eliminate variables from a dataframe?  
%  
%- rm(dataframe$VAR) doesn't appear to function  
%- Transferring all but the undesired variables into a new data frame is cumbersome  
%when there are numerous variables.  
%- I haven't located any information regarding this in the help documentation.  
dataframe$VAR<-NULL  
%

6 Fresh 6" Sub Rolls  
1 26 oz Bag Lean Frozen Meatballs  
2 cans 24 oz Hunts Garlic & Herb Spaghetti Sauce  
1 can 14.5 oz Stewed Tomatoes [with oregano, garlic & basil]  
1 can 6 oz Black Olives [halved]  
1/3 cup Chopped Celery  
1/2 cup Diced White Onions  
1/4 cup Fresh Parsley [chopped]  
1 tsp Each: Onion Powder - Garlic Powder - Italian Seasoning - Dried Basil  
1 tbsp Sugar  
2 cups Shredded Mozzarella Cheese  
1 cup Shredded Parmesan Cheese  
1 Banana Peppers Or Sport Peppers [garnish]  
1/4 tsp Baking Soda [to reduce acidity - more may be needed]  
Combine all ingredients in a crock pot [except for bread & cheeses] and allow to cook for 4 hours on high and 6 to 7 hours on medium. If cooking on the stove top, place frozen meatballs in the oven and bake according to manufacturers' instructions. Typically 25 minutes at 350. Feel free to lightly season your meatballs any way you prefer before placing them in the oven. Add everything else except for bread, peppers, and cheeses in a large pot and simmer for 25 minutes. Add fully baked meatballs and simmer an additional 25 minutes. If your sauce tastes a bit too acidic due to the tomatoes, add 1/4 tsp Baking Soda to your simmering pot. Your sauce will foam up but no worries. Stir in, simmer again, then taste and add 1/4 tsp more if the acidic taste persists. Repeat if necessary. Toast your rolls but be careful not to fully split your bread through the middle. Place meatballs [leave whole or cut in half] and sauce on fresh sub bread. Top with Mozzarella and Parmesan Cheese; Provolone works well too, along with Banana Peppers or Sport Peppers. Serve with a side bottle of Tabasco. Enjoy!

1 cup warm water (between 100° and 110°), divided  
12 ounces bread flour (approximately 2 1/2 cups)  
1 packet dry yeast (around 2 1/4 teaspoons)  
4 teaspoons olive oil  
1/2 teaspoon kosher salt  
Cooking spray  
1 1/4 cups (5 ounces) shredded part-skim mozzarella cheese, divided  
2 ounces pepperoni slices  
2 tablespoons grated Parmigiano-Reggiano cheese  

Begin by pouring 3/4 cup of warm water into the bowl of a stand mixer fitted with a dough hook. Measure the flour by weight or lightly spoon it into dry measuring cups, then level it off with a knife. Add the flour to the 3/4 cup of water and mix until well combined. Cover the mixture and let it rest for 20 minutes. In a small bowl, combine the remaining 1/4 cup of water and the yeast, allowing it to sit for 5 minutes or until it becomes bubbly. Incorporate the yeast mixture, olive oil, and salt into the flour mixture; mix for 5 minutes or until a soft dough is formed. Transfer the dough to a large bowl that has been coated with cooking spray; cover the dough's surface with plastic wrap that has also been lightly sprayed. Refrigerate for 24 hours. After refrigeration, take the dough out and let it sit, covered, for 1 hour or until it reaches room temperature. Punch the dough down. On a lightly floured surface, roll the dough into a rectangle measuring 14 x 11 inches. Press the dough into the bottom and partially up the sides of a 13 x 9-inch metal baking pan that has been sprayed with cooking spray. Loosely cover the dough with plastic wrap. Place a baking sheet on the bottom rack of the oven and preheat it to 450°. Evenly distribute 3/4 cup of mozzarella over the dough; add Basic Pizza Sauce, pepperoni, Parmigiano-Reggiano, and the remaining 1/2 cup of mozzarella on top. Position the pan on the baking sheet in the oven; bake at 450° for 25 minutes or until the crust turns golden. Slice the pizza into 6 rectangles.

Rewritten:
1 cup warm water (100° to 110°), divided
12 ounces bread flour (about 2 1/2 cups)
1 package dry yeast (about 2 1/4 teaspoons)
4 teaspoons olive oil
1/2 teaspoon kosher salt
Cooking spray
1 1/4 cups (5 ounces) shredded part-skim mozzarella cheese, divided
2 ounces pepperoni slices
2 tablespoons grated Parmigiano-Reggiano cheese
Pour 3/4 cup warm water in the bowl of a stand mixer with dough hook attached. Weigh or lightly spoon flour into dry measuring cups; level with a knife. Add flour to 3/4 cup water; mix until combined. Cover and let stand 20 minutes. Combine remaining 1/4 cup water and yeast in a small bowl; let stand 5 minutes or until bubbly. Add yeast mixture, oil, and salt to flour mixture; mix 5 minutes or until a soft dough forms. Place dough in a large bowl coated with cooking spray; cover surface of dough with plastic wrap lightly coated with cooking spray. Refrigerate for 24 hours. Remove dough from refrigerator. Let stand, covered, 1 hour or until dough comes to room temperature. Punch dough down. Roll dough out to a 14 x 11-inch rectangle on a lightly floured surface. Press dough into bottom and partially up sides of a 13 x 9-inch metal baking pan coated with cooking spray. Cover dough loosely with plastic wrap. Place a baking sheet in oven on bottom rack. Preheat oven to 450°. Arrange 3/4 cup mozzarella evenly over dough; top with Basic Pizza Sauce, pepperoni, Parmigiano-Reggiano, and remaining 1/2 cup mozzarella. Place pan on baking sheet in oven; bake at 450° for 25 minutes or until crust is golden. Cut pizza into 6 rectangles.

To prepare a delicious spaghetti dish, start by gathering the necessary ingredients. You will need 400 grams of spaghetti, 75 milliliters of extra virgin olive oil, 1 clove of garlic, smashed and cut in half, 2 anchovies, finely chopped, 150 grams of black truffle, washed in tepid water and brushed with a medium firm brush until clean, then grated or pounded or jared black truffle paste, and sea salt.

Begin by bringing 7 liters of water to a boil in a large pot with 3 tablespoons of salt. Place your spaghetti in the water and cook until the desired texture has been achieved (typically the cooking time indicated on the pasta packaging). Meanwhile, in a separate pan, fill the bottom with water and in the top pan place the olive oil, garlic, anchovy, and heat. Be careful not to fry the garlic but rather infuse the oil with its flavor. The anchovy should be fully dissolved when heated (about 5 minutes after the water starts to boil). Remove the garlic and discard. Add the truffle to the oil. Stir the truffle and oil with a fork to create an emulsion. Make sure not to boil this mixture. Stir for 5 minutes and then turn off the heat.

Drain the pasta but not too much so that there is still plenty of water on the pasta. Add the pasta to the truffle emulsion. If the sauce is too thick, you can add spoonfuls of water one at a time, stirring to loosen the sauce. Stir until the pasta is evenly coated and then divide between 4 serving bowls. Serve immediately.

The novel begins with Orleanna Price's narrative, which sets the tone for the story. The narrative then shifts to the four daughters - Adah, Leah, Rachel, and Ruth May - each with their unique voice and perspective. Leah's outspoken nature makes her voice stand out, while the others contribute to the story in their own way. As the girls mature, they develop different coping mechanisms for dealing with their father Nathan's strict and often misogynistic views, as well as the turmoil that grips the Congo in the 1960s. Initially, the Congolese villagers are portrayed as mysterious and unfamiliar, but as the girls grow, they begin to see the villagers as complex and multifaceted individuals with their own culture and traditions. However, Nathan's refusal to adapt to the local culture and his stubbornness ultimately lead to his family's isolation. It takes a series of tragic events, including the loss of one of the daughters, for the women to finally leave Nathan behind. The novel concludes with the surviving daughters embarking on different paths in life, with Rachel building a successful business, Leah raising a large family, Adah returning to the United States to pursue her education and medical career, and Orleanna finding solace in her life on the Georgian coast. The story comes full circle with Adah's visits to her mother, while the backdrop of the Congo's tumultuous history is marked by the passing of time, including the death of Mobutu Sese Seko in the 1990s.

Rewritten:
Orleanna Price narrates the introductory chapter in five of the novel's seven sections. The narrative then alternates among the four daughters, with a slight preference for the voice of the most outspoken one, Leah. The four girls increasingly mature, as each adapts differently to African village life, to the misogyny of their father Nathan, and the political turmoil that overtakes The Congo in the 1960s. Since the Congolese villagers are seen through the eyes of the growing daughters, the view changes. At first, they appear as ridiculous savages. But as the girls mature, the villagers become fully fleshed-out human beings, immersed in a complex and sophisticated culture. Nathan's lack of responsiveness to this culture wears out his family's welcome, but he refuses to leave. Only after a series of misfortunes—culminating in the death of one of the daughters—do the women leave Nathan Price to his folly. The survivors take different paths into their futures, the novel ending at the time of Mobutu Sese Seko's death in the 1990s. Rachel, the eldest, marries Axelroot at seventeen, and after two more marriages is the owner of a luxury hotel close to what is now Brazzaville. Leah marries Anatole, has a large family of four boys, and remains in the impoverished Congo. Adah returns to the United States with their mother Orleanna, attending college and later, medical school. She undergoes a lengthy experimental treatment that restores full use of her legs and she begins to speak. Orleanna herself returns to spending life on the Georgian coast, enjoying Adah's occasional visits.

Theodore Scott-Dabo, commonly known as Scott Dabo, was a French-American tonalist landscape artist born on November 16, 1865, and passed away on November 17, 1928. Initially thought to be from Detroit, Michigan, it is now known that he was born in Saverny, France. Active in both New York and Paris, he was the younger brother of Leon Dabo. Both artists were Impressionist landscape painters who shared a similar style and tone. When they worked together, their subjects typically featured landscapes and seascapes at twilight, utilizing sparse composition and reduced color schemes to evoke mood. The Dabo brothers' style, characterized by a Whistlerian quality, would later be labeled as Tonalist, much like James McNeill Whistler. The youngest brother, Louis, a writer and publicist, also used the name Scott Dabo. 

The Dabo family lived in Detroit, Michigan, between 1870 and the early 1880s under the surname Scott. Both Theodore and his elder brother Leon received their initial artistic training from their father, Ignace Scott. Theodore's work, as well as that of his brother Leon, demonstrate the influence of James McNeill Whistler and J.M.W. Turner, whom the brothers discussed in their correspondence.

Lawrence VanKoughnet was a key figure in Canada's Department of Indian Affairs in the late 19th century. He rapidly rose through the ranks of the department, starting as a clerk with family connections to Prime Minister John A. Macdonald. From chief civil servant to deputy superintendent, VanKoughnet achieved a great deal during his tenure. However, after a three-month sick leave due to a "disordered nervous system," he struggled to regain his momentum. Despite this setback, VanKoughnet was noted by many historians to be the man who cut costs on the ratios the government supplied to the reserves. Despite only visiting the reserves once, where he was reluctant to socialize with the chiefs, VanKoughnet announced his change of policy plans in Battleford shortly afterwards: Indians would only be supplied with rations if they were unable to sustain themselves. As deputy superintendent of the Department of Indian Affairs, VanKoughnet's goal was to keep costs to a minimum. He believed that as long as they were supplying reserve people with rations, they would remain dependent on the government and therefore a significant burden to their expenses. The Department of Indian Affairs and the loss of the buffalo played a significant role in shaping VanKoughnet's policies.

A significant open question in the research of synchronization of coupled oscillators is to determine the necessary and sufficient conditions for a system to synchronize within a specified family of graphs. This is a challenging inquiry that necessitates a clear understanding of how the nonlinear interactions among local entities develop over the underlying graph. Another open question is to establish bounds on the time complexity of synchronization, which has crucial practical implications in clock synchronization algorithms. We address these inquiries for a one-parameter family of discrete pulse-coupled inhibitory oscillators known as the $kappa$-color firefly cellular automata (FCA). Specifically, we demonstrate that for $kappa \le 6$, the recurrence of each oscillator is a necessary and sufficient condition for synchronization on finite trees, while for $kappa \ge 7$, this condition is only necessary. Additionally, we show that any non-synchronizing dynamics for $kappa \le 6$ on trees decompose into synchronized subtrees partitioned by 'dead' oscillators. Furthermore, on trees with diameter $d$ and maximum degree at most $kappa$, we establish that the worst-case number of iterations until synchronization is of order $O(kappa d)$ for $kappa \in \{3,4,5\}$, $O(kappa d^{2})$ for $kappa=6$, and infinite for $kappa \ge 7$. Lastly, we report simulation results of FCA on lattices and conjecture that on a finite square lattice, any arbitrary initial configuration is synchronized under $kappa$-color FCA if and only if $kappa=4$.

Dillon Brooks, born on January 22, 1996, is a Canadian professional basketball player for the Memphis Grizzlies of the National Basketball Association (NBA). He played college basketball for the Oregon Ducks, where he was named a consensus second-team All-American and earned conference player of the year honors in 2017. Brooks is a member of the Canadian national team. 

College career
Brooks, a small forward from Mississauga, Ontario, came to Oregon after playing at Findlay Prep in Henderson, Nevada. As a freshman, he averaged 11.5 points per game and was named to the Pac-12 all-freshman team. As a sophomore, Brooks led the Ducks to the Pac-12 regular season title and a top-ten national ranking. At the end of the season, he was named first-team All-Pac-12 and third-team All-American by the Sporting News. Brooks was also named the District XI player of the year by the United States Basketball Writers Association (USBWA). As a sophomore, Brooks averaged 16.7 points, 5.4 rebounds, and 3.1 assists per game.

Hidemune's grip on the bars tightened, his anger boiling over as he exclaimed, "How could you be so reckless and thoughtless?! We taught you better than to put our lives in danger like this! What possible reason could you have had for taking such a risk?"

Well-intentioned, this film narrates the fictional tale of Brandon King (Ryan Phillippe), an American soldier who, after completing a heroic yet harrowing tour of duty in Iraq, is informed that, against his wishes, he must return to Iraq for additional combat duty due to a real-life contingency known as "stop-loss." It’s a fate that neither King nor real-life soldiers desire or deserve, yet the U.S. government justifies it in lieu of a wartime draft. 

The film's opening minutes present a montage of images and scenes depicting King and his comrades in Iraq, as they bond together as protective buddies and endure a violent urban ambush, during which several of their friends are killed or seriously injured. 

Back home in Texas, King and a few of his men briefly celebrate their hero status. However, life for them quickly deteriorates, as their wartime trauma leaves both physical and mental scars. Then, King receives his "stop-loss" notice, setting the stage for the remainder of the film's plot. 

The theme here is clear. The brave soldier, having faced more than enough danger and trauma, remains just a powerless individual. As such, he finds himself caught between having to resubmit to the horrors of war or submit to a perilous and life-altering AWOL status in the U.S., or elsewhere, forever on the run from an overpowering American political system. It’s a timely and significant subject for a film. 

A great deal of effort and care went into the creation of the film, from background research to attention to detail in costumes, production design, and military protocol. 

Additionally, the film's color cinematography is quite impressive. There are numerous close-ups that capture the characters' emotional experiences. Many scenes utilize natural lighting in clever ways. At times, the film has an almost documentary-like appearance and feel. The acting is generally credible. I particularly appreciated the performances of Linda Emond as King’s mother and Abbie Cornish as a young woman who tries to assist King. 

The main issue lies with the script. Characters are somewhat stereotyped and two-dimensional. The plot is fairly predictable. Moreover, the story and its accompanying theme are a tad too direct. I would have preferred a bit more depth, along with a plot twist or two. The film's ending is not very satisfying. 

Yet, "Stop-Loss" is a commendable effort to document the brutality not only of war but also of an American government that uses, then essentially discards, people to ensure the preservation of an American war industry and the continued power of faceless bureaucrats and corrupt politicians.

Building on the similarity between parallel differential and dispersion mathematical descriptions, the temporal imaging of optical pulses combines linear dispersive filters and quadratic phase modulations operating as time lenses. We consider programming a dispersive filter near atomic resonance in rare earth ion doped crystals, which leads to unprecedented high values of dispersive power. This filter is used in an approximate imaging scheme, combining a single time lens and a single dispersive section and operating as a time reversing device, with potential applications in radio-frequency signal processing. This scheme is closely related to three-pulse photon echo with chirped pulses but the connection with temporal imaging and dispersive filtering emphasizes new features.

A mysterious incident unfolds in the English Channel when a fishing boat suddenly sinks in the dead of night, and the investigation reveals signs of a deliberate act of destruction. Former Special Branch agent Dominic Elder, driven by a long-standing obsession with a notorious female assassin known as Witch, is pulled back into the world of espionage to help unravel the mystery surrounding the boat's explosion. As it appears that Witch may be involved, she leaves behind a trail of subtle clues, hinting at her presence and warning Elder to stay away. However, this is only the beginning of the challenges that Special Branch will face if Elder's instincts are correct. With Witch's reputation for being one step ahead of her pursuers, the stakes are high, especially with a crucial summit of world leaders scheduled to take place in London. Young detective Michael Barclay's meticulous approach leads him to follow Witch's trail, with valuable assistance from his liaison in the French police, Dominique. As Michael develops feelings for Dominique, he must navigate the complex web of alliances and rivalries between the detectives, MI5 agents, and the elusive Witch, who seems to be always one move ahead. The cat-and-mouse game between them unfolds across multiple countries, including Scotland, England, France, and even a brief visit to a former associate of Witch in prison in Germany.

Rewritten:
A fishing boat sinks in the English Channel in the middle of the night, and the evidence points to murder. Ex-Special Branch agent Dominic Elder comes out of retirement to help investigate the explosion of the boat, as it appears that his long-time obsession, a female assassin known as Witch, may be responsible. Using the boat to get to England from France, Witch left a subtle trail of clues to announce her arrival and to warn off Elder. But that is the least of Special Branch's worries, if Elder's well-honed intuition is correct. He has seen her work before and knows her to be a resourceful enemy, who always seems a step ahead of the authorities. With an imminent summit of world leaders to be held in London, Witch's target seems obvious. Young Michael Barclay's thoroughness leads him onto Witch's trail, with the help of his liaison in the French police, Dominique. Apart from her language help and guidance around Paris, Michael is sexually attracted to her. The team of detectives and MI5 agents, and the terrorist, play cat-and-mouse with each other in Scotland, England, France, and even briefly visit a former associate of Witch in prison in Germany.

Trinity stood still, waiting for something to unfold. The prolonged silence was oppressive, but then her senses picked up on a subtle change. She detected the unmistakable smell of his blood, which sent a surge of longing through her, making her fangs ache with anticipation. Her gaze locked onto his neck, and she began to gently lick the skin there. Trinity's simple yet alluring panties caught her eye, adorned with delicate lace along the edges and a charming heart-shaped design at the center.

Rewritten:
Trinity froze. First nothing happened, the silence dragging on. Then...she sniffed the air. It was the scent of his blood that drew her attention, that made her fangs throb all the more. Once she located his neck, she began to lick the skin there. The panties she wore were rather simple in design. However, they were a bit sexy, with lace all along the edges. There was a stitched heart right in the center.
The Real Wheels bar is beginning to improve in appearance.

Rewritten:
The Real Wheels bar is starting to look better.
... however, after it dries, it acts similarly to other types of paint.

Rewritten:
but yes, once dry, it behaves a lot like other paint.

To put it simply, I'll express my thoughts in a straightforward way.

Rewritten:
So I'll say it like this.

There is little doubt that Cloud Atlas will emerge as a classic that will be revisited time and again by its loyal fans, much like the earlier works of Stanley Kubrick and Ridley Scott. Even though I left the theater with numerous questions and experienced moments of disappointment or confusion during the film, I recognized this truth, and I have been unable to stop contemplating the movie and yearning to return to the screen.

It's easy to critique this film, as some have, for being overly ambitious, catering to poor taste, being either too simplistic or too intricate, featuring too few or too many actors, or even for glorifying revenge against critics who deliver unfavorable reviews. They might all be right, yet these critics will find themselves in the same group as those who cautioned viewers against 2001 or Blade Runner. The reality is that Cloud Atlas is deep in its scope, its visual and auditory effects, its captivating rhythm, and its entirely innovative narrative, and audiences will experience it and feel it deeply.

This film is a reflection of our era of internet-fueled global knowledge and perspective, as well as the freedom we possess to traverse the world and shift between times, genres, images, and identities at our discretion. It serves as a reminder of our humanity and that we can still sense our heartbeat, if we take the time to listen.

Rewritten: There can be little doubt that Cloud Atlas will become a classic that will be watched over and over again by its devoted followers, just like its predecessors by Stanley Kubrick and Ridley Scott. Despite the many questions I had in my mind when I left the theater and the moments during the film when I felt disappointed or confused, I knew this, and I have not stopped thinking about the movie and longing to be back in front of the screen.

It is easy to criticize this movie as some have done for being overly ambitious, pandering to low taste, being too simple or too complex, with too few actors or too many, or even for celebrating revenge violence against professional critics who write negative reviews. They may all be correct, but these critics will still put themselves in the same category as those that warned audiences against 2001 or Blade Runner. The truth is that Cloud Atlas is profound in its reach, its visual and acoustic impact, its mesmerizing flow and its completely ground-breaking storytelling, and movie goers will see it and feel it in their guts.

It is a movie that is a product of our age of internet-driven universal knowledge and vision, and the freedom we have to travel the world and jump between ages, genres, images and identities at our will. It reminds us that we are human and that we can still hear our heart beat, if we listen.

Wood and Spekkens (2015) claim that any causal model attempting to explain the EPRB correlations while adhering to the no-signalling principle must also compromise the assumption that it accurately reflects statistical relationships and dependencies. This compromise, known as "fine-tuning," involves adjusting causal parameters in a way that is particularly problematic for retrocausal explanations of the EPRB correlations. I will examine this argument in the context of possible responses from advocates of retrocausal explanations, focusing on Nager's (2015) suggestion that the core ideas of causal explanations can be preserved by accepting the possibility of stable fine-tuning of causal parameters. I will argue that, given this perspective, a violation of faithfulness does not necessarily preclude retrocausal explanations of the EPRB correlations, although it does impose significant constraints on such explanations. Finally, I will consider the implications of this type of response for retrocausal explanations.

Rewritten:
Wood and Spekkens (2015) argue that any causal model explaining the EPRB
correlations and satisfying no-signalling must also violate the assumption that
the model faithfully reproduces the statistical dependences and
independences---a so-called "fine-tuning" of the causal parameters; this
includes, in particular, retrocausal explanations of the EPRB correlations. I
consider this analysis with a view to enumerating the possible responses an
advocate of retrocausal explanations might propose. I focus on the response of
N\"{a}ger (2015), who argues that the central ideas of causal explanations can
be saved if one accepts the possibility of a stable fine-tuning of the causal
parameters. I argue that, in light of this view, a violation of faithfulness
does not necessarily rule out retrocausal explanations of the EPRB
correlations, although it certainly constrains such explanations. I conclude by
considering some possible consequences of this type of response for retrocausal
explanations.
