Hello, I'm reaching out for the first time. I'm a 19-year-old woman, and I've had some experience with work in the past. However, I've been struggling with depression for a few years now, and it tends to come and go depending on my surroundings. According to my doctor, my depression is situational, meaning it's triggered by specific events or circumstances.

Recently, I left my previous job and started a new one, but I'm still unsure if I'm truly ready for this new chapter. Today, I called in sick, and I wasn't entirely honest with my boss about my reasons. To be honest, I'm drawn to the comfort of my own home and the convenience of staying indoors, rather than facing the challenges of my job.

My main concern is adjusting to a new routine, particularly waking up at 7 am every day. As someone who's accustomed to a much later sleep schedule, I'm worried about my ability to adapt and get back into a regular routine.

If anyone has any advice or insights on how to overcome this hurdle, I would greatly appreciate it.

Rewritten:
Hi everyone, first time posting here. I’m 19 and female, I’ve worked before but I’ve been depressed for a few years and it goes on and off depending on the things happening around me since the doctor said it was more situational depression than anything else. 

That being said, I quit my old job a few months ago, and I just started a new job but I’m not sure if I am ready. I called out today because I genuinely didn’t want to go and I lied to my boss. It’s a pretty neat job, it’s not that I don’t like it, it’s that I just would rather stay inside and sit on my computer than do anything else. 

I’m just not sure if I’m ready or if I can get myself up at 7 every morning when I’m so used to waking up at 5pm. 

Does anyone have any advice?

We present the concepts of a differentiable groupoid and a differentiable stratified groupoid, which are extensions of Lie groupoids where the object and arrow spaces possess the characteristics of differentiable spaces and differentiable stratified spaces, respectively, in a manner that aligns with the groupoid structure. After examining fundamental properties of these groupoids, including Morita equivalence, we establish a de Rham theorem applicable to locally contractible differentiable stratified groupoids. Subsequently, we concentrate on the inertia groupoid linked to a proper Lie groupoid. We demonstrate that both the loop and inertia spaces of a proper Lie groupoid can be equipped with a natural Whitney B stratification, which we refer to as the orbit Cartan type stratification. With this stratification in place, the inertia groupoid of a proper Lie groupoid is transformed into a locally contractible differentiable stratified groupoid.

Rewritten:
We introduce the notions of a differentiable groupoid and a differentiable
stratified groupoid, generalizations of Lie groupoids in which the spaces of
objects and arrows have the structures of differentiable spaces, respectively
differentiable stratified spaces, compatible with the groupoid structure. After
studying basic properties of these groupoids including Morita equivalence, we
prove a de Rham theorem for locally contractible differentiable stratified
groupoids. We then focus on the study of the inertia groupoid associated to a
proper Lie groupoid. We show that the loop and the inertia space of a proper
Lie groupoid can be endowed with a natural Whitney B stratification, which we
call the orbit Cartan type stratification. Endowed with this stratification,
the inertia groupoid of a proper Lie groupoid becomes a locally contractible
differentiable stratified groupoid.

Date: Wed, 30 Jan 2002 09:51:11 -0800 (PST)  
From: joanna@groupdesigninc.com  
To: klay@enron.com  
Subject: Request for Ken Lay to Contribute Earnings from Enron Stock Sales  
Body:  
Joanna Carina  
3027 Garfield St NE  
Minneapolis, MN 55418  
joanna@groupdesigninc.com  
To Mr. Ken Lay,  
I am reaching out to implore you to contribute the substantial profits you earned from selling Enron stock prior to the company's bankruptcy to organizations like the Enron Employee Transition Fund and REACH. These funds support the employees who lost their retirement savings and offer assistance to low-income consumers in California struggling to pay their energy bills. Enron, along with yourself, profited significantly at the expense of California consumers and the hard work of your employees.  
While you amassed over $100 million, many of Enron's employees faced severe financial hardship when the company went bankrupt and their retirement funds were erased. Furthermore, Enron reaped enormous profits during last year's California energy crisis. Consequently, thousands of consumers are unable to meet their basic energy expenses, and the state's largest utility is now bankrupt.  
The New York Times highlighted that you sold $101 million worth of Enron stock while actively encouraging the company's employees to continue purchasing it. I urge you to donate this amount to the funds established to help restore the lives of those Americans affected by Enron's unethical practices.  
Sincerely,  
Joanna Carina

The European stock market, Euronext, has met with the London Stock Exchange (LSE) amid speculation that it may be ready to launch a cash bid. Euronext's chief, Jean-Francois Theodore, held talks with LSE boss Clara Furse the day after rival Deutsche Borse put forward its own bid case. The German exchange said it had held "constructive, professional, and friendly" talks with the LSE. However, Euronext declined to comment after the talks ended on Friday. Speculation is mounting that the Germans may raise their bid to £1.5 billion. Deutsche Borse previously offered £1.3 billion, which was rejected by the LSE, while Euronext is rumored to have facilities in place to fund a £1.4 billion cash bid. So far, neither has tabled a formal bid. However, a deal with either bidder would create the biggest stock market operator in Europe and the second biggest in the world after the New York Stock Exchange.

There was speculation that Euronext would use Friday's meeting as an opportunity to take advantage of growing discontent over Deutsche Borse's own plans for dominance over the London market. Unions for Deutsche Borse staff in Frankfurt have reportedly expressed fears that up to 300 jobs would be moved to London if the takeover is successful. "The works council has expressed concerns that the equities and derivatives trade could be managed from London in the future," Reuters news agency reports a union source as saying. German politicians are also said to be angry over the market operator's promise to move its headquarters to London if a bid is successful.

Meanwhile, LSE shareholders fear that Deutsche Borse's control over its Clearstream unit - the clearing house that processes security transactions - would create a monopoly situation. This would weaken the position of shareholders when negotiating lower transaction fees for share dealings. The LSE and Euronext do not have control over their clearing and settlement operations, a situation which critics say is more transparent and competitive. The German group's ownership of Clearstream has been seen as the main stumbling block to a London-Frankfurt merger. Commentators believe Deutsche Borse, which has now formally asked German authorities to approve its plan to buy the LSE, may offer to sell Clearstream to gain shareholder approval. Euronext, so far, has given little away as to what sweeteners it will offer the LSE - Europe's biggest equity market - into a deal.

​E​u​r​o​n​e​x​t​ ​c​h​i​e​f​ ​J​e​a​n​-​F​r​a​n​c​o​i​s​ ​T​h​e​o​d​o​r​e​ ​h​e​l​d​ ​t​a​l​k​s​ ​w​i​t​h​ ​L​S​E​ ​b​o​s​s​ ​C​l​a​r​a​ ​F​u​r​s​e​ ​t​h​e​ ​d​a​y​ ​a​f​t​e​r​ ​r​i​v​a​l​ ​D​e​u​t​s​c​h​e​ ​B​o​e​r​s​e​ ​p​u​t​ ​f​o​r​w​a​r​d​ ​i​t​s​ ​o​w​n​ ​b​i​d​ ​c​a​s​e​.​ ​T​h​e​ ​G​e​r​m​a​n​ ​e​x​c​h​a​n​g​e​ ​s​a​i​d​ ​i​t​ ​h​a​d​ ​h​e​l​d​ ​"​c​o​n​s​t​r​u​c​t​i​v​e​,​ ​p​r​o​f​e​s​s​i​o​n​a​l​ ​a​n​d​ ​f​r​i​e​n​d​l​y​"​ ​t​a​l​k​s​ ​w​i​t​h​ ​t​h​e​ ​L​S​E​.​ ​B​u​t​ ​E​u​r​o​n​e​x​t​ ​d​e​c​l​i​n​e​d​ ​t​o​ ​c​o​m​m​e​n​t​ ​a​f​t​e​r​ ​t​h​e​ ​t​a​l​k​s​ ​e​n​d​e​d​ ​o​n​ ​F​r​i​d​a​y​.​ ​S​p​e​c​u​l​a​t​i​o​n​ ​i​s​ ​m​o​u​n​t​i​n​g​ ​t​h​a​t​ ​t​h​e​ ​G​e​r​m​a​n​s​ ​m​a​y​ ​r​a​i​s​e​ ​t​h​e​i​r​ ​b​i​d​ ​t​o​ ​£​1​.​5​b​n​.​ ​D​e​u​t​s​c​h​e​ ​B​o​e​r​s​e​ ​p​r​e​v​i​o​u​s​l​y​ ​o​f​f​e​r​e​d​ ​£​1​.​3​b​n​,​ ​w​h​i​c​h​ ​w​a​s​ ​r​e​j​e​c​t​e​d​ ​b​y​ ​t​h​e​ ​L​S​E​,​ ​w​h​i​l​e​ ​E​u​r​o​n​e​x​t​ ​i​s​ ​r​u​m​o​u​r​e​d​ ​t​o​ ​h​a​v​e​ ​f​a​c​i​l​i​t​i​e​s​ ​i​n​ ​p​l​a​c​e​ ​t​o​ ​f​u​n​d​ ​a​ ​£​1​.​4​b​n​ ​c​a​s​h​ ​b​i​d​.​ ​S​o​ ​f​a​r​,​ ​h​o​w​e​v​e​r​,​ ​n​e​i​t​h​e​r​ ​h​a​v​e​ ​t​a​b​l​e​d​ ​a​ ​f​o​r​m​a​l​ ​b​i​d​.​ ​B​u​t​ ​a​ ​d​e​a​l​ ​w​i​t​h​ ​e​i​t​h​e​r​ ​b​i​d​d​e​r​ ​w​o​u​l​d​ ​c​r​e​a​t​e​ ​t​h​e​ ​b​i​g​g​e​s​t​ ​s​t​o​c​k​ ​m​a​r​k​e​t​ ​o​p​e​r​a​t​o​r​ ​i​n​ ​E​u​r​o​p​e​ ​a​n​d​ ​t​h​e​ ​s​e​c​o​n​d​ ​b​i​g​g​e​s​t​ ​i​n​ ​t​h​e​ ​w​o​r​l​d​ ​a​f​t​e​r​ ​t​h​e​ ​N​e​w​ ​Y​o​r​k​ ​S​t​o​c​k​ ​E​x​c​h​a​n​g​e​.​
​T​h​e​r​e​ ​w​a​s​ ​s​p​e​c​u​l​a​t​i​o​n​ ​E​u​r​o​n​e​x​t​ ​w​o​u​l​d​ ​u​s​e​ ​F​r​i​d​a​y​'​s​ ​m​e​e​t​i​n​g​ ​a​s​ ​a​n​ ​o​p​p​o​r​t​u​n​i​t​y​ ​t​o​ ​t​a​k​e​ ​a​d​v​a​n​t​a​g​e​ ​o​f​ ​g​r​o​w​i​n​g​ ​d​i​s​q​u​i​e​t​ ​o​v​e​r​ ​D​e​u​t​s​c​h​e​ ​B​o​e​r​s​e​'​s​ ​o​w​n​ ​p​l​a​n​s​ ​f​o​r​ ​d​o​m​i​n​a​n​c​e​ ​o​v​e​r​ ​t​h​e​ ​L​o​n​d​o​n​ ​m​a​r​k​e​t​.​ ​U​n​i​o​n​s​ ​f​o​r​ ​D​e​u​t​s​c​h​e​ ​B​o​e​r​s​e​ ​s​t​a​f​f​ ​i​n​ ​F​r​a​n​k​f​u​r​t​ ​h​a​s​ ​r​e​p​o​r​t​e​d​l​y​ ​e​x​p​r​e​s​s​e​d​ ​f​e​a​r​s​ ​t​h​a​t​ ​u​p​ ​t​o​ ​3​0​0​ ​j​o​b​s​ ​w​o​u​l​d​ ​b​e​ ​m​o​v​e​d​ ​t​o​ ​L​o​n​d​o​n​ ​i​f​ ​t​h​e​ ​t​a​k​e​o​v​e​r​ ​i​s​ ​s​u​c​c​e​s​s​f​u​l​.​ ​"​T​h​e​ ​w​o​r​k​s​ ​c​o​u​n​c​i​l​ ​h​a​s​ ​e​x​p​r​e​s​s​e​d​ ​c​o​n​c​e​r​n​s​ ​t​h​a​t​ ​t​h​e​ ​e​q​u​i​t​i​e​s​ ​a​n​d​ ​d​e​r​i​v​a​t​i​v​e​s​ ​t​r​a​d​e​ ​c​o​u​l​d​ ​b​e​ ​m​a​n​a​g​e​d​ ​f​r​o​m​ ​L​o​n​d​o​n​ ​i​n​ ​t​h​e​ ​f​u​t​u​r​e​,​"​ ​R​e​u​t​e​r​s​ ​n​e​w​s​ ​a​g​e​n​c​y​ ​r​e​p​o​r​t​s​ ​a​ ​u​n​i​o​n​ ​s​o​u​r​c​e​ ​a​s​ ​s​a​y​i​n​g​.​ ​G​e​r​m​a​n​ ​p​o​l​i​t​i​c​i​a​n​s​ ​a​r​e​ ​a​l​s​o​ ​s​a​i​d​ ​t​o​ ​b​e​ ​a​n​g​r​y​ ​o​v​e​r​ ​t​h​e​ ​m​a​r​k​e​t​ ​o​p​e​r​a​t​o​r​'​s​ ​p​r​o​m​i​s​e​ ​t​o​ ​m​o​v​e​ ​i​t​s​ ​h​e​a​d​q​u​a​r​t​e​r​s​ ​t​o​ ​L​o​n​d​o​n​ ​i​f​ ​a​ ​b​i​d​ ​w​e​r​e​ ​s​u​c​c​e​s​s​f​u​l​.​
​M​e​a​n​w​h​i​l​e​,​ ​L​S​E​ ​s​h​a​r​e​h​o​l​d​e​r​s​ ​f​e​a​r​ ​t​h​a​t​ ​D​e​u​t​s​c​h​e​ ​B​o​e​r​s​e​'​s​ ​c​o​n​t​r​o​l​ ​o​v​e​r​ ​i​t​s​ ​C​l​e​a​r​s​t​r​e​a​m​ ​u​n​i​t​ ​-​ ​t​h​e​ ​c​l​e​a​r​i​n​g​ ​h​o​u​s​e​ ​t​h​a​t​ ​p​r​o​c​e​s​s​e​s​ ​s​e​c​u​r​i​t​i​e​s​ ​t​r​a​n​s​a​c​t​i​o​n​s​ ​-​ ​w​o​u​l​d​ ​c​r​e​a​t​e​ ​a​ ​m​o​n​o​p​o​l​y​ ​s​i​t​u​a​t​i​o​n​.​ ​T​h​i​s​ ​w​o​u​l​d​ ​w​e​a​k​e​n​ ​t​h​e​ ​p​o​s​i​t​i​o​n​ ​o​f​ ​s​h​a​r​e​h​o​l​d​e​r​s​ ​w​h​e​n​ ​n​e​g​o​t​i​a​t​i​n​g​ ​l​o​w​e​r​ ​t​r​a​n​s​a​c​t​i​o​n​ ​f​e​e​s​ ​f​o​r​ ​s​h​a​r​e​ ​d​e​a​l​i​n​g​s​.​ ​L​S​E​ ​a​n​d​ ​E​u​r​o​n​e​x​t​ ​d​o​ ​n​o​t​ ​h​a​v​e​ ​c​o​n​t​r​o​l​ ​o​v​e​r​ ​t​h​e​i​r​ ​c​l​e​a​r​i​n​g​ ​a​n​d​ ​s​e​t​t​l​e​m​e​n​t​ ​o​p​e​r​a​t​i​o​n​s​,​ ​a​ ​s​i​t​u​a​t​i​o​n​ ​w​h​i​c​h​ ​c​r​i​t​i​c​s​ ​s​a​y​ ​i​s​ ​m​o​r​e​ ​t​r​a​n​s​p​a​r​e​n​t​ ​a​n​d​ ​c​o​m​p​e​t​i​t​i​v​e​.​ ​T​h​e​ ​G​e​r​m​a​n​ ​g​r​o​u​p​'​s​ ​o​w​n​e​r​s​h​i​p​ ​o​f​ ​C​l​e​a​r​s​t​r​e​a​m​ ​h​a​s​ ​b​e​e​n​ ​s​e​e​n​ ​a​s​ ​t​h​e​ ​m​a​i​n​ ​s​t​u​m​b​l​i​n​g​ ​b​l​o​c​k​ ​t​o​ ​a​ ​L​o​n​d​o​n​-​F​r​a​n​k​f​u​r​t​ ​m​e​r​g​e​r​.​ ​C​o​m​m​e​n​t​a​t​o​r​s​ ​b​e​l​i​e​v​e​ ​D​e​u​t​s​c​h​e​ ​B​o​e​r​s​e​,​ ​w​h​i​c​h​ ​h​a​s​ ​n​o​w​ ​f​o​r​m​a​l​l​y​ ​a​s​k​e​d​ ​G​e​r​m​a​n​ ​a​u​t​h​o​r​i​t​i​e​s​ ​t​o​ ​a​p​p​r​o​v​e​ ​i​t​s​ ​p​l​a​n​ ​t​o​ ​b​u​y​ ​t​h​e​ ​L​S​E​,​ ​m​a​y​ ​o​f​f​e​r​ ​t​o​ ​s​e​l​l​ ​C​l​e​a​r​s​t​r​e​a​m​ ​t​o​ ​g​a​i​n​ ​s​h​a​r​e​h​o​l​d​e​r​ ​a​p​p​r​o​v​a​l​.​ ​E​u​r​o​n​e​x​t​,​ ​s​o​ ​f​a​r​,​ ​h​a​s​ ​g​i​v​e​n​ ​l​i​t​t​l​e​ ​a​w​a​y​ ​a​s​ ​t​o​ ​w​h​a​t​ ​s​w​e​e​t​e​n​e​r​s​ ​i​t​ ​w​i​l​l​ ​o​f​f​e​r​ ​t​h​e​ ​L​S​E​ ​-​ ​E​u​r​o​p​e​'​s​ ​b​i​g​g​e​s​t​ ​e​q​u​i​t​y​ ​m​a​r​k​e​t​ ​-​ ​i​n​t​o​ ​a​ ​d​e​a​l​.​

David Luchins (born 1946) is a professor at Touro College and the head of its political science department. He holds the position of national vice-president of the Orthodox Union and is a national officer of the Jewish Council for Public Affairs (JCPA). Luchins is recognized as a "highly regarded longtime Orthodox Jewish activist" who participates actively in Jewish community affairs and frequently speaks on topics related to education, politics, and Judaism. He previously worked as an aide to then-Vice President Hubert Humphrey and spent two decades on the Senate staff of New York Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan. 

Life and career 
Luchins was born in New York City, the oldest son of Abraham Luchins, a Gestalt psychologist, and Edith Hirsch Luchins, a mathematician and psychologist who was among the first women to be on the national board of the Orthodox Union. He graduated from Yeshiva College, where he studied under Rabbi Ahron Soloveichik during his sophomore year and spent four years learning from Rabbi Joseph B. Soloveitchik. In 1977, Luchins received his Ph.D. from the Graduate Center of the City University of New York. He has been the chair of the political science department at Touro College since 1978, where he teaches courses in American politics and international relations and also serves as the founding dean of Touro's Lander College for Women.

2 tablespoons Szechuan peppercorns  
1 tablespoon coriander seeds  
1 tablespoon black peppercorns  
1 tablespoon star anise  
1 tablespoon garlic powder  
3 tablespoons kosher salt  
1 tablespoon curry powder  
1 (5-pound) duck  
1 tablespoon duck spice  
8 (6-inch) flour tortillas  
1 egg yolk  
1 tablespoon peeled and chopped fresh ginger  
2 teaspoons soy sauce  
2 teaspoons rice vinegar  
1/2 teaspoon Asian sesame oil  
1/4 cup honey  
1/2 teaspoon salt  
2 teaspoons Dijon mustard  
1 teaspoon Thai garlic-chili paste, see Cook's Note  
2 teaspoons freshly squeezed lemon juice  
3/4 cup canola oil  
3/4 pound mixed baby salad greens  
1/2 cup peeled and julienned carrot  
1/2 cup julienned jicama  
1/4 cup sliced green onion, white part only  
1/4 cup dried cranberries  
2 tablespoons macadamia nut pieces, toasted  
1/2 cup diced mango  
1/2 cup wonton chips, for garnish  

In a sauté pan, toast the Szechuan peppercorns, coriander seeds, black peppercorns, and star anise over medium-high heat for 3 to 4 minutes, until fragrant. Remove from heat and let cool. Grind the toasted spices in a coffee grinder to a coarse salt consistency and pour into a small bowl. Add the garlic powder, salt, and curry powder and mix well. Preheat the oven to 400 degrees F. Prick the skin of the duck all over with the point of a very sharp knife. Rub the duck with the spice mixture. Place in a roasting pan and roast for 20 minutes. Decrease the temperature to 350 degrees F and cook for another 40 minutes, until the juices run clear when a thigh is pierced. Transfer the duck to a platter, reserving the duck fat in the pan. When the duck cools, remove the skin and the meat and julienne both. Place the skin in a small sauté pan. Add 2 tablespoons of the reserved duck drippings and sauté slowly over low heat. Cook for about 15 minutes, until the fat is rendered from the skin and the skin is crispy. Transfer to paper towels to drain.  

For the dressing: Place all the ingredients except the canola oil in a blender. Blend for 1 minute. With the motor running, slowly add the canola oil. If the dressing is too thick, add a small amount of water to thin it to desired consistency.  

For the salad: In a large bowl, mix the greens, carrot, jicama, green onion, cranberries, macadamia nuts, and mango. Drizzle with 3/4 cup of the dressing and toss to coat. To assemble the dish, divide the dressed greens among the tortillas and mound in the center. Divide the duck meat among the salads. Top with the wonton strips and duck skin cracklings and serve.  

*Cook's Note: We suggest using Sriracha Thai-chili paste for a spicier dressing.

At first, I thought she was waltzing, but then I realized the error in my observation. She was waddling, all that blubber, garnished with shoulder pads, cover suspenders, and duct tape, size called 'infinity', a wave of air preceded the mass, mostly the temperature was high but in the noise of raucous laughter, it was hard to tell what happened. Yes, men were at her feet, all over the dancing hall, though hardwood on a polished floor is without comfort. No one was able to keep standing, it was too much to grin and bear. Majestic gestures emanated, clearly, there was confusion as to the identity and origin, was this thing human then? And, in the end, it was decided that it had been good to have this episode, though fleeting pay its short visit, although the most intriguing part about the thing, consisted of its skills to speak of things that human beings hold dear, some rather raunchy stuff included. And all were shocked, though pretty glad when hardwood planks did give and cracked, and Blueberry sank through the hole, from where some devils must have grabbed to commander the energy, all the triglycerides, not food for thought but something quite substantial.

Date: Mon, 14 May 2001 21:02:35 -0700 (PDT)
From: wsmith@wordsmith.org
To: linguaphile@wordsmith.org
Subject: A.Word.A.Day--fourth estate

The term 'fourth estate' refers to the journalistic profession, or the press in general. This concept is derived from the idea that there are three main estates in the UK: the Lords Spiritual, the Lords Temporal, and the House of Commons. However, the 'fourth estate' suggests that the press holds a significant amount of power, separate from these traditional institutions.

As noted by Akre, journalists often adhere to an unwritten rule that prohibits them from reporting on themselves or the media industry. This reluctance to self-examine is at the heart of the crisis facing the 'fourth estate', as it implies that no one is holding the press accountable for its actions.

A wise English proverb reminds us that "Write down the advice of him who loves you, though you like it not at present." In the context of language and communication, this means that the gift of words can be a powerful tool for self-improvement and growth.

If you'd like to give the gift of language to someone, consider subscribing them to A.Word.A.Day. You can do so by visiting http://wordsmith.org/awad/gift.html or by asking them to subscribe themselves at http://wordsmith.org/awad/subscribe.html

fourth estate (forth i-STAYT) noun
 Journalistic profession, the press.
[Supposedly, a power other than the three estates (the Lords Spiritual, the
Lords Temporal, and the House of Commons) in UK.]
 "According to Akre, reporters see the case as `too inside baseball' -
 media code for the unwritten rule that news organizations avoid writing
 about themselves or the industry. It's the crux of the crisis in the
 Fourth Estate: no one is watching the watchdogs."
 Fox Guilty of Playing Chicken, Adbusters Magazine (Vancouver, Canada),
 March/April 2001.

I was supposed to see either Flight or Argo today, but to my disappointment, I missed both showtimes, and I was in a tight time frame where I could see anything. So, my friend really convinced me to check this one out. Boy, what a great time it was.

Wreck-It Ralph is really wonderfully created. Its visual design is brilliant, and its action pieces are pretty amazing. The world it builds, and all of the little details from various video games, is pretty wonderful to look at and experience. Even some characters move in the precise way they actually do in video games. But what makes this glorious, colorful spectacle of a world work is the screenplay. The jokes hit all the right places, the characters are all lively and written with skill that goes beyond what we have come to expect from a simple kids' film like this. The few commercials and trailers I saw had been sure to let audiences know just how "pretty" this film looked, but what makes it a truly great film is that it has a great story and great dialogue to back up the visuals. The voice performances are pretty incredible, and perhaps because I recognized such people like Reilly, Silverman, McBride, and Lynch, but even others did wonders with their characters. 

Overall, the film follows a clear pattern and formula for kids, but the real surprise is that none of it made me roll my eyes or cringe. It's incredibly entertaining and enjoyable for anyone. Pretty much everything is done in a very respectful manner, and the film hits greatness in writing, direction, voice performances, and visual design. The only real flaw I gathered was the inclusion of a Rihanna song, which really took me out of the world the film created and kind of put a plaster on it from pop culture. Or maybe it's because I hate the song... Still, this is another truly great animated film that stands out from others this year in its own way, and one that's admirable and satisfying in all the best ways. I loved it. Highly recommended.

or just part of it?

Parmalat has taken legal action against 45 banks in an attempt to reclaim money paid to them before the Italian dairy company's collapse last year. The firm, which had debts of around 14 billion euros ($19 billion; £10 billion), has already taken action against a number of lenders. Its new boss, Enrico Bondi, claims the banks were aware of the company's financial problems but continued to work with it in order to earn commissions. Parmalat has not identified which banks it is targeting this time. Under Italian law, administrators can seek to recover money paid to financial institutions prior to insolvency if there is a suspicion that the institutions knew the company was in trouble. The firm also said it is preparing further lawsuits.

According to the Reuters news agency, 35 of the companies sued on Thursday are Italian while the remaining 10 are international. The unidentified Parmalat source also told Reuters that the company is planning to take action against a total of 80 financial institutions. Among those already targeted are Bank of America, UBS, Credit Suisse First Boston, Deutsche Bank, and Citigroup. It has also gone after auditor Grant Thornton. They have all denied any wrongdoing. Parmalat was declared insolvent in December 2003 after it emerged that 4 billion euros thought to be held in an offshore account did not exist. In the investigation that followed, it became apparent that the company, among other things, had been billing clients twice in order to boost sales and bolster the balance sheet. That enabled Parmalat to borrow heavily and expand overseas, allowing it to become a darling of the Italian stock exchange.

​T​h​e​ ​f​i​r​m​ ​c​o​l​l​a​p​s​e​d​ ​w​i​t​h​ ​d​e​b​t​s​ ​o​f​ ​a​b​o​u​t​ ​1​4​b​n​ ​e​u​r​o​s​ ​(​$​1​9​b​n​;​ ​£​1​0​b​n​)​ ​a​n​d​ ​n​e​w​ ​b​o​s​s​ ​E​n​r​i​c​o​ ​B​o​n​d​i​ ​h​a​s​ ​a​l​r​e​a​d​y​ ​t​a​k​e​n​ ​l​e​g​a​l​ ​a​c​t​i​o​n​ ​a​g​a​i​n​s​t​ ​a​ ​n​u​m​b​e​r​ ​o​f​ ​l​e​n​d​e​r​s​.​ ​H​e​ ​c​l​a​i​m​s​ ​t​h​e​ ​b​a​n​k​s​ ​w​e​r​e​ ​a​w​a​r​e​ ​o​f​ ​t​h​e​ ​p​r​o​b​l​e​m​s​ ​b​u​t​ ​c​o​n​t​i​n​u​e​d​ ​t​o​ ​w​o​r​k​ ​w​i​t​h​ ​t​h​e​ ​c​o​m​p​a​n​y​ ​s​o​ ​t​h​e​y​ ​c​o​u​l​d​ ​e​a​r​n​ ​c​o​m​m​i​s​s​i​o​n​s​.​ ​P​a​r​m​a​l​a​t​ ​h​a​s​ ​n​o​t​ ​i​d​e​n​t​i​f​i​e​d​ ​w​h​i​c​h​ ​b​a​n​k​s​ ​i​t​ ​h​a​s​ ​g​o​n​e​ ​a​f​t​e​r​ ​t​h​i​s​ ​t​i​m​e​.​ ​U​n​d​e​r​ ​I​t​a​l​i​a​n​ ​l​a​w​,​ ​a​d​m​i​n​i​s​t​r​a​t​o​r​s​ ​c​a​n​ ​s​e​e​k​ ​t​o​ ​g​e​t​ ​b​a​c​k​ ​m​o​n​e​y​ ​p​a​i​d​ ​t​o​ ​f​i​n​a​n​c​i​a​l​ ​i​n​s​t​i​t​u​t​i​o​n​s​ ​p​r​i​o​r​ ​t​o​ ​i​n​s​o​l​v​e​n​c​y​,​ ​i​f​ ​t​h​e​r​e​ ​i​s​ ​a​ ​s​u​s​p​i​c​i​o​n​ ​t​h​a​t​ ​t​h​e​ ​i​n​s​t​i​t​u​t​i​o​n​s​ ​k​n​e​w​ ​t​h​a​t​ ​t​h​e​ ​c​o​m​p​a​n​y​ ​w​a​s​ ​i​n​ ​f​i​n​a​n​c​i​a​l​ ​t​r​o​u​b​l​e​.​ ​T​h​e​ ​f​i​r​m​ ​a​l​s​o​ ​s​a​i​d​ ​i​t​ ​i​s​ ​p​r​e​p​a​r​i​n​g​ ​f​u​r​t​h​e​r​ ​l​a​w​ ​s​u​i​t​s​.​
​A​c​c​o​r​d​i​n​g​ ​t​o​ ​t​h​e​ ​R​e​u​t​e​r​s​ ​n​e​w​s​ ​a​g​e​n​c​y​,​ ​3​5​ ​o​f​ ​t​h​e​ ​c​o​m​p​a​n​i​e​s​ ​s​u​e​d​ ​o​n​ ​T​h​u​r​s​d​a​y​ ​a​r​e​ ​I​t​a​l​i​a​n​ ​w​h​i​l​e​ ​t​h​e​ ​r​e​m​a​i​n​i​n​g​ ​1​0​ ​a​r​e​ ​i​n​t​e​r​n​a​t​i​o​n​a​l​.​ ​T​h​e​ ​u​n​i​d​e​n​t​i​f​i​e​d​ ​P​a​r​m​a​l​a​t​ ​s​o​u​r​c​e​ ​a​l​s​o​ ​t​o​l​d​ ​R​e​u​t​e​r​s​ ​t​h​a​t​ ​t​h​e​ ​c​o​m​p​a​n​y​ ​w​a​s​ ​p​l​a​n​n​i​n​g​ ​t​o​ ​t​a​k​e​ ​a​c​t​i​o​n​ ​a​g​a​i​n​s​t​ ​a​ ​t​o​t​a​l​ ​o​f​ ​8​0​ ​f​i​n​a​n​c​i​a​l​ ​i​n​s​t​i​t​u​t​i​o​n​s​.​ ​A​m​o​n​g​ ​t​h​o​s​e​ ​a​l​r​e​a​d​y​ ​t​a​r​g​e​t​e​d​ ​a​r​e​ ​B​a​n​k​ ​o​f​ ​A​m​e​r​i​c​a​,​ ​U​B​S​,​ ​C​r​e​d​i​t​ ​S​u​i​s​s​e​ ​F​i​r​s​t​ ​B​o​s​t​o​n​,​ ​D​e​u​t​s​c​h​e​ ​B​a​n​k​ ​a​n​d​ ​C​i​t​i​g​r​o​u​p​.​ ​I​t​ ​h​a​s​ ​a​l​s​o​ ​g​o​n​e​ ​a​f​t​e​r​ ​a​u​d​i​t​o​r​s​ ​G​r​a​n​t​ ​T​h​o​r​n​t​o​n​.​ ​T​h​e​y​ ​h​a​v​e​ ​a​l​l​ ​d​e​n​i​e​d​ ​a​n​y​ ​w​r​o​n​g​d​o​i​n​g​.​ ​P​a​r​m​a​l​a​t​ ​w​a​s​ ​d​e​c​l​a​r​e​d​ ​i​n​s​o​l​v​e​n​t​ ​i​n​ ​D​e​c​e​m​b​e​r​ ​2​0​0​3​ ​a​f​t​e​r​ ​i​t​ ​e​m​e​r​g​e​d​ ​t​h​a​t​ ​4​b​n​ ​e​u​r​o​s​ ​t​h​o​u​g​h​t​ ​t​o​ ​b​e​ ​h​e​l​d​ ​i​n​ ​a​n​ ​o​f​f​s​h​o​r​e​ ​a​c​c​o​u​n​t​ ​d​i​d​ ​n​o​t​ ​i​n​ ​f​a​c​t​ ​e​x​i​s​t​.​ ​I​n​ ​t​h​e​ ​i​n​v​e​s​t​i​g​a​t​i​o​n​ ​t​h​a​t​ ​f​o​l​l​o​w​e​d​ ​i​t​ ​b​e​c​a​m​e​ ​a​p​p​a​r​e​n​t​ ​t​h​a​t​ ​t​h​e​ ​c​o​m​p​a​n​y​,​ ​a​m​o​n​g​ ​o​t​h​e​r​ ​t​h​i​n​g​s​,​ ​h​a​d​ ​b​e​e​n​ ​b​i​l​l​i​n​g​ ​c​l​i​e​n​t​s​ ​t​w​i​c​e​ ​i​n​ ​o​r​d​e​r​ ​t​o​ ​b​o​o​s​t​ ​s​a​l​e​s​ ​a​n​d​ ​b​o​l​s​t​e​r​ ​t​h​e​ ​b​a​l​a​n​c​e​ ​s​h​e​e​t​.​ ​T​h​a​t​ ​e​n​a​b​l​e​d​ ​P​a​r​m​a​l​a​t​ ​t​o​ ​b​o​r​r​o​w​ ​h​e​a​v​i​l​y​ ​a​n​d​ ​e​x​p​a​n​d​ ​o​v​e​r​s​e​a​s​,​ ​a​l​l​o​w​i​n​g​ ​i​t​ ​t​o​ ​b​e​c​o​m​e​ ​a​ ​d​a​r​l​i​n​g​ ​o​f​ ​t​h​e​ ​I​t​a​l​i​a​n​ ​s​t​o​c​k​ ​e​x​c​h​a​n​g​e​.​

Rewritten:
Date: Tue, 10 Jul 2001 11:06:50 -0700 (PDT)
From: beth.cherry@enform.com
To: beth.cherry@enform.com
Subject: TASK
Body: 
GO!

For me, discovering a key exception has been the turning point in allowing me to continue riding my bike, while also alleviating my family's concerns about my safety and preventing them from worrying that I might get hurt.

Rewritten:
So for me, I found the loophole that allows me to still ride, my family to not freak out and say that I'm going to die on my bike, and keeps me safer in the end.

As I stand before the familiar landscape of my childhood home, a mix of emotions swirls within me. While the memories that flood my mind bring a sense of nostalgia, they also evoke a deep sadness. Memory, a realm that exists between the earthly and the divine, has the power to transform even the most painful experiences into something beautiful and pure. It's as if the shadows of the past are illuminated by a soft, ethereal light, revealing scenes that are both haunting and enchanting.

Just as the twilight hours can be mesmerizing, and the distant sound of a waterfall can be hauntingly beautiful, memory has the ability to sanctify all that we've known and lost. Twenty years have passed since I last visited this place, and yet, the memories remain vivid. I'm reminded of the friends I left behind, and how time has changed them. Many have grown old, and some have even passed away. I hear the whispers of those who remain, speaking of the inevitability of death, and how it's a fate that none can escape.

As I wander through the empty rooms and fields, I'm struck by the sense of loss that pervades this place. I feel like a friend of the dead, walking among the tombs that hold the memories of those who've gone. But there's something even more haunting than the graves themselves – the human form that's been left behind, a shell of a person where the mind has fled. Poor Matthew, a brilliant and talented individual, now trapped in a world of madness, a wild and savage place where reason has been lost.

I remember the day when Matthew first succumbed to his illness, and how it changed him forever. I recall the struggles he faced, the fear that gripped those around him, and the desperate attempts to contain his destructive strength. And even though time has passed, and the worst of his torment has subsided, the memories of his suffering remain. I've often heard his plaintive cries, like a distant knell, a reminder of the pain that he endured. And I've crept away to listen, stealing moments to hear the whispers of a mind that's been lost.

This is a past that's been left behind, a reminder of the fragility of the human mind. Matthew's piercing cries and sweet lullabies are now nothing more than a distant memory, a reminder of what's been lost. And yet, even in death, he remains a source of pain, a reminder of the terror that death inspires. O Death, why do you leave him lingering here, a shadow of a person that once was?

Rewritten:
My childhood's home I see again, and I am saddened by the sight; and still, while my memory fills my brain, there is a pleasure in it too. O memory! you middle-world 'twixt earth and paradise, where rotten things and people who are gone, rising from the shadows of sleep, are cleansed of all earthly blemishes, and, sanctified, pure and bright, appear like scenes from some enchanted isle, All bathed in liquid light. And as the dusky mountains charm our eye, When twilight drives away day; And as the bugles we hear are soon forgotten, In the distance far away; And as, leaving a great waterfall, we linger to listen to its roar, So memory will sanctify all that we have known and do not know any more. Twenty years have passed since I bowed my head to the memory of this home and those who lived here, and left a place where many things, but now few remain, of old, familiar things, yet, seeing them, my mind's eye summons up, The lost and departed. My friends of the past I left behind; How time has changed them since! Young childhood gray, And half the men are dead. I hear the beloved ones say How none could escape death, And all the things they see seem like knells and tombs. I roam the fields with a thoughtful step, I walk through the silent rooms, And feel, friend of the dead, I live in the tombs. But here's a thing more terrible Than all the grave contains, A human form, where the mind has fled, Where life is still left. Poor Matthew! a whirling genius, A child of fortune, Now locked in a mental night, A wild and savage madman. Poor Matthew! I have never forgotten When first you struck a blow of madness, And maimed your own self; And father fought you, and mother tried to kill you; When fear spread out the frightened neighbors, Who tried to bind your dangerous strength; And soon, a howling maniac, Your limbs were confined. How then you struggled, you shrieked, You bared your bones and sinews, How dreadful were the signs The torment in your brain. And when at last, though slow and bleak, Time hushed your cruel woes, How plaintive were your lamentations, In the silent night. I have heard them often, as in a dream, distant, shrill, sweet, a knell of reason. And I have stolen away to hear them, listened with stealth, before the sun climbed over the eastern hill. The air seemed still; the trees, by the spell, seemed the faces of mourning angels, whose tears fell in dewdrops on the ear of the listening earth. This is past, and there is no more, That once had raised you above the brutes. Your piercing cries, your sweet lullabies, Are muted for all eternity. Now farewell, you are the cause rather than the subject of woe. And all mental pain, by the gentle laws of time, has lost the power to know. O Death, thou terror of men, that holds the world in dread, Why dost thou leave him lingering here?

Date: Fri, 4 Jan 2002 14:45:56 -0800 (PST)
From: chairman.enron@enron.com
To: dl-ga-all_enron_worldwide1@enron.com
Subject: Northern Natural Gas Update

Yesterday, Enron reached a settlement with Dynegy regarding the Northern Natural Gas pipeline. This agreement allows Dynegy to proceed with its option to acquire the pipeline, dismisses Dynegy's lawsuit in Texas, and extends Enron's right to repurchase the pipeline until June 30. The decision to settle was made as part of Enron's efforts to exit bankruptcy and rebuild its core businesses. Although we would have liked to retain Northern Natural Gas, we still have a substantial network of 9,000 miles of safe and profitable interstate pipelines to serve as a foundation for our future growth.

The settlement provides the best opportunity to resolve the pipeline issue efficiently and pursue our $10 billion damage claim against Dynegy. It also enables us to avoid the significant costs and distractions associated with prolonged litigation in state courts.

We are committed to ensuring a positive future for the employees working with Northern Natural Gas. Below is a message from Stan Horton, further explaining this decision to the employees of Enron Transportation Services.

Ken

Dear ETS Colleague,

On Thursday, Enron entered into a settlement with Dynegy regarding the exercise of its option to acquire the Northern Natural Gas pipeline. The agreement allows Dynegy to assume interim control of the pipeline while Enron pursues its damage claim against Dynegy.

After careful consideration, Enron has decided not to contest interim possession and allow the transfer of Northern Natural Gas to Dynegy, while the larger issues affecting its future are resolved. This decision was made to avoid the substantial costs and disruptions associated with protracted litigation in state courts.

The company believes that this settlement will enable us to resolve the issue more quickly and avoid the legal costs and distractions that would have resulted from prolonged litigation. For the Northern Natural Gas employees, this decision should allow them to focus on the day-to-day operations of a valuable and successful business.

We will begin working immediately to achieve a smooth transition and align the necessary resources to ensure continued safe, reliable, and efficient operation of Northern Natural Gas.

Over the years, we have run high-quality, cost-conscious, and profitable businesses in ETS. I want to thank you for your hard work and dedication.

Stan

Rewritten:
Date: Fri, 4 Jan 2002 14:45:56 -0800 (PST)
From: chairman.enron@enron.com
To: dl-ga-all_enron_worldwide1@enron.com
Subject: Northern Natural Gas
Body: 
Yesterday, Enron settled a procedural dispute with Dynegy over Northern Natural Gas. Our settlement allows Dynegy to exercise its option to acquire the pipeline, dismisses their Texas lawsuit and extends Enron's right to repurchase until June 30. We reached this settlement as part of our efforts to bring Enron out of bankruptcy. While we would like to keep Northern Natural, we still have some 9,000 miles of safe, profitable interstate pipelines as a base to rebuild our core businesses. 
The settlement provides the best opportunity to resolve the pipeline issue quickly and pursue our $10 billion damage claim against Dynegy. It also allows us to avoid the very substantial costs and distractions from protracted litigation in state courts. 
We want to see a positive future for the employees working with Northern Natural Gas. Below is a copy of a message from Stan Horton further explaining this decision to the employees of Enron Transportation Services.
Ken
Dear ETS Colleague:
On Thursday, Enron entered into a settlement over Dynegy's exercise of its option to acquire the Northern Natural Gas pipeline. The settlement allows Dynegy to exercise the option and assume interim control of the pipeline while Enron pursues its damage claim against Dynegy. 
In this respect, Enron Corp. has carefully weighed the substantial costs and turmoil that litigating this possession issue would create for the company and the employees of Northern Natural Gas. Consequently, Enron Corp. has decided not to contest interim possession and allow the transfer of Northern Natural Gas to Dynegy, while the larger issues affecting its future are resolved.
The company has concluded that with this settlement, Enron should be able to resolve the issue more quickly, as well as avoid the legal cost burden and distractions to the business from protracted litigation in state court. For the Northern Natural Gas employees, I believe this decision should allow them to steer clear of the dispute and focus on the day-to-day satisfaction of running a valuable, successful business.
Beginning immediately we will be working to achieve a smooth transition and to align the appropriate resources to assure continued safe, reliable and efficient operation of Northern Natural Gas. 
Over many years we have run high quality, cost conscious and profitable businesses in ETS. Keep up the good work!
Stan

But I can feel your profound sobs resonating in my heart, and my conscience stings me... Everyone was grieving for you, yet no one took action; I can envision you lying on your bed in your dilapidated cottage, your hair unkempt, your lips parched with dread, your eyes wide and filled with terror, reflecting the nightmares you’ve faced. I can imagine all the pain you’ve endured: your children sobbing as they tugged at your tattered skirt, their small hands pulling at your garment, their lips trembling with fear; your eyes filled with dread, blue with anxiety; your face marked by fear; the hardships of life etched on your features, your children nursing from your withered breasts; the pitiful, starving little ones, who haven’t had a proper meal in ages. Oh, poor little ones; you hear their cries; you awaken; you drift back to sleep, but you’re so weary. Oh, mother, I mourn for you. Let my tears blend with the blood of Euphretis and Tigris, cry out louder, cry out until someone listens to me.

Rewritten:
But I can hear your deep sobs echoed in my heart, and my conscience pricks me... Everyone was mourning you, but no one raised a hand; I can see you stretched out on your bed in your tumbledown cottage, your hair unbound, your lips dry with fear, your eyes frightened, round with fear, the nightmares you’ve endured. I can picture all you’ve suffered: your children weeping as they dragged your skirt, your torn skirt, their little hands dragging your skirt, their lips covered with fear; your eyes wide with fear, blue with fear; your face spattered with fear; the suffering of life written on your face, your children suck from your dried breasts; the pitiful, hungry creatures, who haven’t had a good meal for such a long time. Oh, poor little ones; you hear them crying; you wake up; you go back to sleep, but you’re exhausted. Oh, mother, I weep for you. Let my tears mingle with the blood of Euphretis and Tigris, cry out louder, cry out until someone hears me.

Quasi-trees extend the concept of trees by allowing the unique "path" between two nodes to be infinite and possess any countable order type. They serve to establish the rank-width of a countable graph, which is defined as the least upper-bound of the rank-widths of its finite induced subgraphs. Join-trees represent the directed counterparts of these structures. They play a significant role in defining the modular decomposition of a countable graph. Additionally, we examine ordered join-trees, which expand upon rooted trees by incorporating a linear order on the set of children for each node. We introduce algebras with a finite number of operations that can generate these generalized trees through infinite terms. We demonstrate that the related regular objects (those defined by regular terms) are precisely those that serve as the unique models of monadic second-order sentences. These findings build upon and extend a similar result by W. Thomas concerning countable linear orders.

Rewritten:
Quasi-trees generalize trees in that the unique "path" between two nodes may
be infinite and have any countable order type. They are used to define the
rank-width of a countable graph in such a way that it is equal to the least
upper-bound of the rank-widths of its finite induced subgraphs. Join-trees are
the corresponding directed trees. They are useful to define the modular
decomposition of a countable graph. We also consider ordered join-trees, that
generalize rooted trees equipped with a linear order on the set of sons of each
node. We define algebras with finitely many operations that generate (via
infinite terms) these generalized trees. We prove that the associated regular
objects (those defined by regular terms) are exactly the ones that are the
unique models of monadic second-order sentences. These results use and
generalize a similar result by W. Thomas for countable linear orders.
... Indeed, I uphold my initial assertion.

Rewritten:
So yes, I stand by my original statement.

It is clear that this data can offer precise and high-resolution ground truth for various tasks, but it remains uncertain whether it sufficiently resembles real-world images to enhance the practical effectiveness of visual recognition models. We outline experiments in which the performance of visual recognition models was assessed using images generated from a game. We created over 61,000 images that closely resemble those found in the real-world datasets CamVid and CityScapes. We conducted several experiments demonstrating that game-derived images can enhance the performance of neural networks in tasks like object segmentation and 3D depth estimation. The findings indicate that convolutional networks trained on simulated images achieve a test error comparable to that of networks trained on real-world images. A straightforward domain adaptation can further boost the model's performance. This could facilitate a meaningful expansion of the available image datasets for computer vision applications.

Rewritten:
It is certain that this data is capable of providing accurate and high-resolution ground truth for diverse tasks, but it is not yet known whether it has enough similarity to real-world images to improve the practical performance of visual recognition models. We describe experiments in which the accuracy of visual recognition models was evaluated on images derived from a game. We generated over 61,000 images that are similar in appearance to those in the real-world data sets CamVid and CityScapes. We perform a number of experiments that show that images derived from a game can improve the performance of neural nets on tasks such as object segmentation and 3D depth estimation. The results show that convolutional networks trained on simulated images yield a test error similar to that of a network trained on real-world images. A simple domain adaptation can improve the performance of the model. This could lead to an expansion of the usable image data sets in a useful way for computer vision.

To make a delicious sweet potato dish, start by peeling and quartering 5 large sweet potatoes. In a large pot, combine 1 tablespoon of vegetable oil, 1 large onion that's been diced, 1 pound of bulk sweet Italian sausage, 2 cloves of minced garlic, 8 ounces of mushrooms that have been sliced, 1 tablespoon of Italian seasoning, and 1 quarter of a half-and-half (or as needed). Add salt and ground black pepper to taste, and 1/4 cup of grated Parmesan cheese.

Place the sweet potatoes in the large pot and cover them with cold water. Bring the water to a boil, then reduce the heat to medium-low, cover, and simmer for 6 to 8 minutes. Drain the water and allow the potatoes to steam dry for a minute or two. Puree the potatoes in a food processor or blender in batches until smooth. Return the pureed potatoes to the large pot.

Heat the oil in a large skillet over medium heat. Cook the onion in the hot oil until it's translucent, about 4 minutes. Add the sausage to the skillet and cook until it's completely browned, breaking it apart with the back of a wooden spoon as it cooks. Stir in the garlic, mushrooms, and Italian seasoning, and continue cooking until the mushrooms are tender, another 4 to 5 minutes. Season with salt and pepper, then transfer the sausage mixture to the pot with the potatoes.

Pour the half-and-half over the mixture, stirring to mix. Allow the soup to slowly heat until hot and to your desired consistency. Garnish with Parmesan cheese to serve.

a) We have utilized language (for instance, Catequil Partners, LP) where the MAC prioritizes the S&P rating, and if there is no S&P rating, then Moody's, and if Enron lacks ratings from both agencies. Please apply the same language here. I anticipate this will become the norm for the hedge funds.  
b) Let's aim for Events of Default. If they object, I am fine with categorizing them as Termination events.  
c) Indeed, my perspective on the deal shifted when I recognized that we would be retaining cash instead of LCs. Therefore, there will be two-way margining.  
Yes, we require the monthly statement language, along with the engineering/reserve reports.  
All of the above also pertains to CD Holdings.

Subject: Turbine Market Insights - CERA Conference Call Playback

Supply Tsunami - CERA Conference Call Playback
Title: Turbine Market Trends in the Face of a Supply Tsunami
URL(s):
http://www20.cera.com/eprofile?u=35&m=2778;

On November 8, 2001, Steve Taub and Chris Seiple led a CERA Conference Call and Web Presentation, discussing key issues in the 60 hertz turbine market. They explored the current supply and demand fundamentals, the future direction of turbine prices, and the strategic actions that developers might take to address overcommitments for turbines. Additionally, they examined the potential for selling turbine orders outside of North America and the impact of turbine markets on electricity markets.

cc:  
Subject: Rice Team Meeting  
Hello, Rice Recruiting Team!  
You have all been selected to represent Enron in our Fall 2000 recruitment efforts at the Rice/Jones School. As part of this team, you will be tasked with identifying the top candidates from Rice to join our Associate Program.  
Our initial campus event will be a tailgate gathering for the Rice/University of Houston game on Saturday, September 2nd. Everyone is welcome to join us in the parking lot of Rice Stadium. We will provide tickets to the game, along with beer and sandwiches. A general presentation is scheduled for Wednesday, September 6th, and interviews will take place on campus on Thursday, October 5th, and Friday, October 6th. There are several campus events planned, and I hope you can all take part.  
We will hold a short team meeting on Tuesday, August 29th, from 9:00 to 10:00 am in 42C1 (the Gas Control Presentation Room) to go over the Associate Program and the fall recruiting schedule.  
I look forward to seeing all of you soon.  
Best regards,  
Celeste Roberts  
Director of Associate & Analyst Campus Recruiting

Rewritten:
So it seems about a week wait if you are after one.

For a fleeting instant, his gaze locked onto a spot below her waist, his nostrils widening as he detected an unfamiliar fragrance. He then shifted his attention to her foot, gently nuzzling it with affection before placing a tender kiss on the top. The sensation of her skin on his lips was unlike anything he could put into words, but he found it undeniably appealing.

Rewritten:
His eyes went right between her legs a moment, his nostrils flaring at that surprising scent...before he leaned his head over to nuzzle her foot affectionately before he kissed the top of it. Her skin tasted...he didn't know the word, but he liked it...
